fields.headline: Fake money costs Met £250,000
fields.trailText: A couple who say they were framed when detectives stole £26,080 from their home and then substituted the missing money with counterfeit bank notes, have been paid almost £250,000 compensation.
fields.body:
A couple who say they were framed when detectives stole £26,080 from their home and then substituted the missing money with counterfeit bank notes, have been paid almost £250,000 compensation.

Stanley Goodman and Lynn Gaffney sued the Metropolitan police for malicious prosecution after they were arrested and charged with possessing counterfeit currency.

A subsequent high court case brought by police was thrown out by a judge after it emerged that bank notes produced by police in court were not the same as those originally taken from the couple's home in east London in 1995.

A Scotland Yard spokesman said: "The civil action was settled out of court and without an admission of liability by the commissioner."

webTitle: No passport, no way out of Freetown

fields.headline: No passport, no way out of Freetown
fields.standfirst:
UNMASIL - UN mission
Sierra Leone Web
Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: The young black man with a Sierra Leone accent insisted that he was indeed William Edward Floode. It said so on his Welsh birth certificate: born October 1975 in South Glamorgan.
fields.body:
The young black man with a Sierra Leone accent insisted that he was indeed William Edward Floode. It said so on his Welsh birth certificate: born October 1975 in South Glamorgan.

Mr Floode, if that is who he is, pleaded that he has a brother in London and an aunt working for the probation service. Here were their phone numbers.

But the British official behind the gate of the hotel turned military camp and evacuation centre would have none of it. Where was his British passport? Mr Floode said he had been on his mother's passport as a child, when his family returned to Sierra Leone; since then, he had had no need of one. Until now. It wasn't good enough, and he was left to stand disconsolate in the sun.

"I cannot understand it. I really have to get out of this place. It's dreadful, always worrying about whether someone is going to chop your head. The British don't want to take me because I'm black but I'm British like them. Let them go to Cardiff and see. I'm sure there are lots of black people there," he said.

He was not alone. Many others tried to get through the hotel gates but without the right kind of passport they were turned back. The British military did evacuate more than 300 other people from Freetown yesterday, mostly with EU passports. But many other foreigners were reassured by the growing British army contingent in Sierra Leone's capital and decided just to register their names and return to their homes.

They may yet regret it. Freetown was quieter, but overnight shootings left at least 19 dead and more than 50 wounded as scores were settled after Revolutionary United Front rebels gunned down unarmed protesters on Monday.

The commander of the swelling British military force in Sierra Leone, Brigadier David Richards, said that with several thousand militiamen and demobilised soldiers in Freetown - some rebels, some from the government side - he was as concerned about the risk of factional fighting on the streets as he was of a rebel attack from outside the city.

"There are a lot of ex-combatants here who are taking the law into their own hands. We have to keep a watch on them. There's always the risk of a coup. It's a recipe for anarchy," he said.

It may not yet be anarchy, but the lack of central control was only too evident as lorries crammed with government soldiers wormed their way through the narrow streets. Occasional gunshots sent people scurrying.

Members of the Kamajor pro-government militia waved down cars and searched pedestrians. It was, they said, a security operation but Sierra Leoneans whispered that the hunt was on for supporters of the rebel leader, Foday Sankoh.

The search was also underway for Mr Sankoh himself. He disappeared from his house about the time his men opened fire on the protesters at his gates on Monday. His whereabouts could determine whether the country faces another extended bout of bloodletting and atrocities.

The most popular rumour had it that the UN was holding the RUF leader as a kind of bargaining chip for the nearly 500 peacekeepers being held hostage by the rebels. The UN heatedly deny this.

"We are anxious to contact him for reasons that are clear," said spokesman David Windhurst.

Then word spread that the Sierra Leonean army had snatched Mr Sankoh and was holding him at one of its bases. The government denied that.

Brigadier Richards believes that the rebel leader has fled the capital - and that this does not bode well: "He's out and about somewhere planning to have another go because he is testing the will of the United Nations," he said.

Wherever Mr Sankoh may be, if he returns to Freetown it won't be to his old home. The dead were still scattered outside a day after they fell victim to his rebels' impatience with the dissent exhibited by the protesters who surrounded the house. The body of a young woman, her arm pulled across her face and her chest soaked in blood, lay close to a cardboard placard with "UN toothless bulldog" written by a careful hand.

A couple of large lorries pulled up. Some thought they had come to collect the corpses, but it transpired that they were from the American embassy. US technicians had come to rip out a generator lent by the Americans to the Nigerian intervention force which preceded the UN peacekeeping operation here. The Nigerians turned it over to the rebel leader.

Last night, looters descended on the house, tearing from the walls portraits of Mr Sankoh and his cohorts and carting off their clothes and furniture. Thousands of syringes lay scattered on the floor, a testament to the wide use of drugs among the rebels.

Members of the British military contingent - with 800 soldiers already on the ground and many more on their way by ship - have rapidly taken on the role of the defenders of Freetown. The capital's residents are counting on it.

The British have taken over the international airport and the western part of the city from which the helicopters fly. Brig Richards said that freed up UN troops to defend the rest of the city - but he conceded that the UN mission (Unamsil) was not in the best position to do so, so the British were helping with that, too.

The army said it would remain for as long as evacuation might be necessary. That included the possibility of airlifting out diplomats including the British high commissioner, Alan Jones. But Mr Jones said he was not going anywhere.

"From a military perspective, it could go on for some time," Brig Richards said.

webTitle: Send in the mercenaries if our troops won't fight

fields.headline: Send in the mercenaries if our troops won't fight
fields.standfirst:
William Shawcross seeks to think the unthinkable in Sierra Leone

Sierra Leone: special report
Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: The catastrophe in Sierra Leone could have been avoided - but only if that fickle creature "the international community" or West African states had had both the will and the ability to defend the democratically elected government against the country's odious rebel movement.
fields.body:
The catastrophe in Sierra Leone could have been avoided - but only if that fickle creature "the international community" or West African states had had both the will and the ability to defend the democratically elected government against the country's odious rebel movement.

They did not. Instead in 1998 we actually forced the government into alliance with the rebels, whose speciality is cutting off the arms and legs of children and their parents.

If the Blair government is to have any claim to an "ethical" foreign policy, it must now give robust support to the democratically elected politicians against the rebels who have killed and captured lightly armed UN peacekeepers.

The rebel movement is under the control of Foday Sankoh, a former corporal, who has charisma among his followers, often child soldiers. But he is little more than a criminal psychopath, intent on personal power at all costs and enjoying the support of President Gaddafi of Libya and Charles Taylor of Liberia. So long as he is part of the government, or probably even in Sierra Leone, there will not be peace.

The politics of Sierra Leone are bitterly sad and infernally complicated. Today the basic problem is this: a civilian government was properly elected in 1996 after years of military and rebel mayhem and despite rebel atrocities. In the countryside in early 1996 I met refugees whose limbs had been cut off by the rebels as punishment for voting in the election.

The ordinary people who fared best - who did not lose their limbs - were in those areas of the country where a South African group of mercenaries called Executive Outcomes (EO) were in control.

EO had been brought in by the military regime which was attempting at last to make the transition to democracy. They drove the rebels away from Freetown, the capital, and then out of the areas around the diamond fields, which have been both the curse of Sierra Leone and the principal source of its potential wealth. The mercenaries were expensive but the people who lived under EO protection did not have to fear mutilation or death at rebel hands, as did almost everyone else in the country. The mercenaries were very popular.

Despite the rebels' attempts to ruin the elections, they went rather well and Ahmed Tejan Kabbah was elected president. He saw that Executive Outcomes was vital to the government and said he would retain them. He began peace talks with Foday Sankoh, who insisted he would not make peace so long as EO remained.

Rebel atrocities continued. Eventually, under pressure from both West Africa and the rest of the world to make peace, Kabbah had to ask EO to leave. Sierra Leone began to fall apart again. In 1997 Kabbah was overthrown in a coup backed by Sankoh, and went into exile in Guinea. There he engaged the services of another British mercenary group, Sandline, to try and secure his return. Some members of the British Foreign Office appear to have encouraged this, and I believe they were right given the circumstances. But there was an almighty hypocritical stink in London when it was revealed.

In 1998 Kabbah was restored to office by a Nigerian-led force assisted by Sandline. Sankoh had been arrested by the Nigerians and in October 1998 was sentenced to death, but not executed. His rebel movement, the RUF, continued to commit atrocities and by the end of 1998 they invaded Freetown. As Kosovo imploded Sierra Leone dissolved again into bloodshed worse than anything in the Balkans. The rebels abducted about 4,000 children to serve in their army.

We went to war for the Kosovan Albanians but there was never any question of doing so for Sierra Leone. The reasons are both sad and obvious and do not require repetition, but they give the lie to the claim that there now exists a "progressive" or "humanitarian" foreign policy agenda, in London or anywhere else.

Nigeria, now a democracy, wanted to leave, and unable to find other military assistance for President Kabbah, the international community insisted that he release Sankoh from jail and bring him into government. Sankoh demanded he be given control of the diamond fields. A blanket amnesty was extended. Under international duress Kabbah signed the peace agreement, accompanied by a little girl with an amputated arm.

Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, visited Sierra Leone in summer 1999 and was appalled by what he saw. The rebels' conduct, he said, "make all our fine speeches about peace and humanity seem inadequate, even futile". He said that "no one can feel happy about a peace agreement obtained on such terms" - but what was the alternative? Sierra Leone would never get the international support that Kosovo now enjoyed.

This deal with the devil never worked. Sankoh and his friends reaped the spoils of office while their soldiers continued to kill and mutilate in the bush. When the first UN peacekeepers arrived last year Sankoh denounced them and said they were living on "blood money". The present crisis has been gathering ever since.

In the middle of last week when Annan heard of the RUF attack on the peacekeepers, he was nearing the end of an African tour. He immediately tried to get Sankoh's supporters abroad to compel him to release the peacekeepers. Sankoh would not. Annan called for the peacekeepers to be reinforced.

Britain has now responded to this challenge, but it is not clear what the paratroopers and marines now being sent to Freetown will do. Are they merely to extricate British nationals? Or are they to support the peacekeepers with appropriate force? Only the latter can really help Sierra Leone.

Remember that the war in Bosnia was only ended in 1995 after the British and French sent a heavily-armed rapid reaction force to support the lightly-armed peacekeepers in order to suppress Serbian guns. That is what is needed in Sierra Leone; if the security council will not agree it, there is little hope for peace.

The RUF must be shown that it cannot continue forever to enjoy the impunity that it has been given for far too long. And Sankoh himself can no longer be any part of the process. In 1999, rather than being executed, he was given another chance. He did not deserve that chance then and he certainly does not deserve any more accommodations now. He is nothing less than a lunatic murderer.

He must be removed not only from government but also from Sierra Leone. Sending him next door into Liberia would be pointless; his bloodstained patron Charles Taylor would allow him to continue the war from there. If he cannot be brought before a properly constituted court to be tried for his crimes, he must be sent into distant exile where perhaps finally his hold over his child soldiers and their thuggish "officers" will diminish. Libya seems one possibility. So long as he remains in Sierra Leone, peace is impossible. If the international community, led by Britain, will not remove him, and defeat his forces, the outlook for Sierra Leone is appalling.

The rebels can be defeated. They are not vast in numbers, they have no ideology and without Sankoh they would have no real leadership. But the gruesome story of the past four years shows that President Kabbah cannot defeat them without outside assistance.

It is perhaps not surprising that traditional peacekeeping troop contributor countries - from both the first and the third world - are more and more reluctant to expose their soldiers to the dangers that peacekeeping involves.

This surely means that we should start considering the unthinkable. The recent history of Sierra Leone shows that mercenaries or private security forces, properly supervised and controlled, may be the best answer to this and some other crises.

Private security firms could not do all jobs. They could not undertake the immensely difficult peacekeeping mission proposed for the Congo and now threatened by events in Sierra Leone. Nor the expansion of peacekeeping forces n Lebanon. But in some places where governments fear to have their soldiers tread, they could play an important role. Mercenaries do not have to be "dogs of war". Executive Outcomes' troops were loved where they were deployed In Sierra Leone. If Kabbah had not been compelled to get rid of them in 1997, Sankoh's RUF might have been contained and the horrors of the last two years avoided. Hundreds of children would still have their arms.

William Shawcross's book Deliver Us From Evil - Warlords, Peacekeepers and a World of Endless Conflict, is published by Bloomsbury

fields.headline: BSkyB grabs soccer site
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: BSkyB will today tighten its grip over British football by announcing a 850p-per-share agreed takeover of soccer website firm Sports Internet.
fields.body:
BSkyB will today tighten its grip over British football by announcing a 850p-per-share agreed takeover of soccer website firm Sports Internet.

Confirmation of the £290m deal coincides with the broadcaster's interim results and is part of chief executive Tony Ball's plan to turn skysports.com into the leading online sports destination.

Sports Internet operates official websites for clubs including Leeds United, Newcastle United, Liverpool and Aston Villa, as well as the planetfootball.com general football news site.

BSkyB already has exclusive broadcasting rights to Premier League football and minority stakes in five leading clubs including Manchester United, Leeds, Chelsea, Sunderland and Manchester City.

The new deal will put BSkyB in pole position to win the internet rights available when the Premiership broadcasting contract is put out to tender this summer. BSkyB is already favourite to retain the television rights.

Though Sports Internet is thought to have attracted the attention of a number of companies, including cable operator NTL, BSkyB has always been favourite to clinch a deal. Talks are understood to have been underway for several weeks.

Last night Sports Internet shares closed up 7.5p at 775p, still some way below their best this year but well ahead of the 632.5p price at which they were trading before speculation about a bid surfaced.

Under the terms of the deal to be announced today, Peter Wilkinson, Sports Internet's largest shareholder, is likely to see his stake valued at about £127m.

 British Telecom has signed up FootballNews.co.uk to provide a broad range of soccer information for its internet portal.

FootballNews will be supplying information on British clubs from the Premiership to county leagues as well as all the leading continental European leagues - a total of more than 4,500 clubs in 700 leagues.

FootballNews.com, which was launched at the beginning of the season and which claims to reach fans in 300 countries, will take a percentage of call costs in exchange for its service to BT.

webTitle: Stop bleating about euro, boards told

fields.headline: Stop bleating about euro, boards told
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Legal & General is calling for tough action and less whingeing from directors of big established corporations who have watched their share prices dive to the benefit of the trendy dot.coms.
fields.body:
Legal & General is calling for tough action and less whingeing from directors of big established corporations who have watched their share prices dive to the benefit of the trendy dot.coms.

While investors' love affair with e-commerce stocks is waning, David Rough, director of investments at L&G, is warning boardrooms that it will not be enough to sit back and wait for investors to start ploughing their money back into their companies.

Mr Rough, never one to mince his words, says in L&G's monthly economic commentary: "So-called undervalued companies should be looking to share buy-backs and most importantly to enhanced corporate activity - buying and selling parts of their business to focus on core activities, refining and restructuring their organisations and looking to add value at every twist and turn."

The cry for corporate activity has echoes of the agitation Phillips & Drew inflicted on directors of some of its struggling investments at the nadir of its performance 18 months ago.

L&G's call for action comes as it too is having a difficult period, reflected in the recent Caps performance tables which show its £500m flagship pension fund fell to 60th place out of 67 in the first quarter of the year. Three years ago L&G, one of the country's biggest "index tracking groups", was a more comfortable 40th.

He sets his comments in the context of almost helpless fretting by companies about the strength of the pound versus the ailing euro which is hampering the competitiveness of their exports. At the same time, the pound is weakening against the yen and dollar which means they are not able to achieve any currency benefit when paying for their raw materials in dollars.

Mr Rough contends that the euro problem will lessen during the year and insists that "companies which echo the bleating of the sound pound by just going on about the share prices will suffer a continuing downward spiral".

That is why Mr Rough is calling for a more "positive and aggressive" attitude from the directors of the so-called undervalued companies, essentially ranging from the traditional manufacturers to the banks, to try to win fresh investment from investors distracted by the dot.com frenzy.

Mr Rough's parting shot is that "it's time now for managements to earn the salary rises of recent years and prove themselves men and women of true grit".

fields.headline: Labour moves to Livingstone deal
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour party last night seemed ready to agree a compromise deal with Ken Livingstone, the newly elected mayor of London, on terms for accepting jobs in his administration after earlier refusing to participate unless Mr Livingstone "stepped back" from confrontation with the government over the tube.
fields.body:
The Labour party last night seemed ready to agree a compromise deal with Ken Livingstone, the newly elected mayor of London, on terms for accepting jobs in his administration after earlier refusing to participate unless Mr Livingstone "stepped back" from confrontation with the government over the tube.

After days of haggling, the party's Greater London assembly members are now expected to accept Mr Livingstone's offer to appoint Nicky Gavron as his deputy for a year and nominate Lord Harris as chair of the Metropolitan police committee in exchange for an independent investigation of tube funding.

The journalist and rail expert Simon Jenkins, who is a critic of the government's part-privatisation plans for the London Underground, was last night in talks with the mayor about becoming chairman of an independent panel of experts to examine both the government's scheme and Mr Livingstone's bond financing plan.

Labour's decision will be taken at a meeting of its Greater London assembly members today, but last night Mr Livingstone - who joined David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, at a government skills and training launch - said he was "absolutely confident" that Ms Gavron would accept the offer to become deputy mayor of London.

The party's Millbank headquarters claimed that Mr Livingstone had "conceded" its demands - including for Labour appointees to have the right to pursue their own policy agenda and dissociate themselves from any mayoral political grandstanding - and had "shifted his position on the tube".

That was denied by Mr Livingstone's spokesman, who insisted: "Ken hasn't changed his position, but he thinks it's right for the mayor to have an independent panel to look at all the options, particularly in the light of the fact that the government's own assessment is biased in favour of the private sector."

Labour was also pointing to the fact that Frank Dobson, its unsuccessful mayoral candidate, had committed himself to appointing an independent panel to consider new schemes for tube modernisation - rather than the government's existing plans - and that Mr Livingstone had yesterday agreed to use Mr Dobson's principles for assessing the alternatives.

The prospect of a power-sharing agreement came after 24 hours of intense argument within the nine-strong GLA Labour group, London party and Labour hierarchy about whether and how far to cooperate with Mr Livingstone, who yesterday chatted aimiably with the Queen at the opening of London's new millennium bridge over the Thames at Southwark.

On Monday night, the London Labour board split down the middle about whether Ms Gavron and Lord Harris should accept the independent mayor's offers and left it to yesterday's group meeting to decide.

While Ms Gavron has been keen to take up the post of deputy mayor, Mr Dobson's former running mate Trevor Phillips, who is less likely to get the coveted job of assembly chairman if Labour accepts Mr Livingstone's proposals, is understood to have urged caution.

"We are not going to find ourselves essentially being part of an administration which spends all its time attacking the policies on which we were elected," Mr Phillips said yesterday.

"The issue here is not about personalities, it is about policies."

Mr Livingstone's manifesto committed him to "fight to retain a unified underground system in the public sector" and "argue that we should finance the investment needed to modernise the tube by the cheapest possible method, which the evidence indicates is raising bonds backed by a combination of fares and government grant".

But a Labour spokesman insisted yesterday that the party's 1997 election mandate overrode Mr Livingstone's and added that in any case Londoners had voted for him for a variety of reasons, rather than simply his stand on the tube.

The government is currently committed to locking in its part-privatisation scheme before handing over responsibility for London Transport to Mr Livingstone.

webTitle: Saved for the nation - Stephen Byers

fields.headline: Saved for the nation - Stephen Byers
fields.standfirst:
Rover in crisis: special report
Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers has had an awful last few weeks, much of it his own fault. But you would need to be a miserable curmudgeon not to feel a twinge of pleasure on his behalf when he rose yesterday to say that Rover, or at least some of it, had been saved. Perhaps. For the time being.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers has had an awful last few weeks, much of it his own fault. But you would need to be a miserable curmudgeon not to feel a twinge of pleasure on his behalf when he rose yesterday to say that Rover, or at least some of it, had been saved. Perhaps. For the time being.

Mr Byers is the ultimate Blairite. He lives in relation to the prime minister as Baldrick does to Blackadder - he doesn't merely need his support, but without Mr Blair he would not exist.

Even he, however, could not praise the prime minister for personally saving Rover. Instead, he paid tribute to the third way, which is the political equivalent of scientology - also a meaningless jumble of gobbledygook - and a crafty means of allotting the credit to our great leader, L Ron Blair.

"The corporate state has been tried and it simply did not work. But neither did a naive reliance on laissez-faire, which led to a crippling obsession with what government should not do," he said.

"We cannot rely on heads. Equally, we cannot sit back and hope for tails.

"We will never order chips. On the other hand, we know it is right to reject mash. We cannot approve of Ronnie, but at the same time we say 'no' to Reggie. Instead, we shall opt for the third Kray..."

Well, of course he didn't say the last bits, but when ministers launch in on these self-admiring platitudes, you expect similar drivel to issue forth at any moment.

Angela Browning, the Tory industry spokeswoman, made a graceless little speech in which she did not even express pleasure at the planned rescue. Mr Hague must be feeling a bit like the management of BMW: he made a big investment in Mrs Browning, he rescued her from the backbenches, saving her and all her suppliers - researchers, secretaries etc - from destitution, only to see the credibility of his core business draining away. But I don't think a consortium will rescue Mrs Browning from the fate that awaits her. The bankers won't allow it.

Mr Byers was able to claim that Rover workers would judge the Tories by their party political response. They looked almost embarrassed at this until the minister blew it: "While those of us who were getting our sleeves rolled up ..." he said, and they collapsed in laughter. Phoney laughter, to be sure, but it cheered them up after Mrs B.

She was not the only Tory woman who suffered for the cause yesterday. For some time this column has had a kindly eye open for Anne McIntosh, MP for the Vale of York, not least because she carpet-bombs our office in the Commons with faxed press releases about every little event which happens in her life.

It hasn't yet got to the stage of "Anne McIntosh takes cue from Nick Soames; flosses teeth regularly," but that can't be far off.

"Stop Press!" reads a recent despatch from the front, "MP welcomes further inquiry into pylon line."

Later, "MP stands up for the countryside. Venue and time change for photo op!"

In March, she thrillingly visited a chocolate factory: "MP samples sweet success." Days earlier, she cheerfully announced that constituents were welcome to meet her while she ate a hamburger. "Little Mac to meet Big Mac for Millennium Mac."

But there is something engagingly naive about Miss McIntosh. Yesterday she addressed John Prescott as "Mr Deputy Speaker," then went on to confuse the new deal for the unemployed with the new deal for communities. Mr Prescott corrected her courteously enough, though we haven't yet had the press release: "MP screws up badly in environment questions. Was my face red! Photo-op and cringing interviews available."

fields.headline: Tory peers in ethics row
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Tories yesterday accused Labour of trying to set a political agenda for the ethics watchdog Lord Neill's forthcoming inquiry into peers' business interests.
fields.body:
Tories yesterday accused Labour of trying to set a political agenda for the ethics watchdog Lord Neill's forthcoming inquiry into peers' business interests.

The attack, led by Tory opposition leader Lord Strathclyde, comes as Conservative peer Lord Rees Mogg will try today to pre-empt an inquiry by the committee of standards into public life by pressing for a rival inquiry run by the peers themselves.

Lord Neill has cancelled an appearance before the Commons public administration committee so he can explain to peers how he intends to have a wide ranging impartial inquiry into the need for high standards of probity in the upper house. Lord Strathclyde claimed yesterday that "it is becoming increasingly obvious that this whole process has been politicised."

He claimed that central to the inquiry was a proposal that opposition spokesman should divest themselves of their business interests, and that this idea had been put to the committee by Fraser Kemp, MP for Houghton and Washington East. Mr Kemp is one of Labour's election co-ordinators.

Last night the Tory attack was criticised by Lord Neill's committee, who said the idea was neither central to the investigation, nor had it originated from the government.

It is likely that the committee, which includes prominent Conservatives such as former cabinet minister John Macgregor as well as Labour stalwarts like Lord Shore, will examine the issue alongside a much wider examination of House of Lords procedures.

The committee will also be examining whether the Lords register of interests should be tightened, making it compulsory to declare all interests and whether to introduce an "advocacy rule" which bans peers promoting private bills and sponsoring motions where they have business interests. This was introduced in the Commons.

Lord Neill is said to have been influenced by Tory peer Lord Wakeham's observation that the Lords was now more a target for lobbyists than the Commons.

fields.headline: Lords consider daytime-only sittings
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Labour peers will today launch an attempt to introduce family friendly working hours to the House of Lords, amid revelations that the upper house sits longer than any other legislative chamber in the world.
fields.body:
Labour peers will today launch an attempt to introduce family friendly working hours to the House of Lords, amid revelations that the upper house sits longer than any other legislative chamber in the world.

In a rare debate on working practices in the second chamber, peers will propose reforms including ending evening sittings and turning the Lords into a daytime-only chamber.

Ministers are ready to establish a new committee to examine ways to adjust sitting hours for the first time in over six centuries. The move for a full-scale shake-up of the hours of the upper house reflects similar attempts in the Commons, which have so far stalled. Ministers, including the leader of the Lords, Lady Jay, argue there will be no hope of attracting a new breed of peers, including more women, if sitting hours are not changed.

Lords hours are usually longer than those of the Commons, and according to former Lords clerk Michael Wheeler-Booth, are the longest of any legislative chamber. However, Tories argue that talk of family-friendliness is a smoke screen for government attempts to tighten its grip on business in the upper house. One source said: "They want a government-friendly way of managing the House of Lords, and part of being government-friendly is actually making it easier to get their people here at the time they want to have votes."

Lady Jay, pointing to the fact that the Lords went ahead of the Commons in introducing TV coverage, is expected to say that the upper chamber again has the chance to lead in bringing Parliament "more obviously into line with contemporary life".

webTitle: Extremists on both sides still meting out their savage 'justice'

fields.headline: Extremists on both sides still meting out their savage 'justice'
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Amid religious icons in her north Belfast home, Angela Cairns yesterday unfolded the shredded Levi 501s. They were crusted with thick gobs of blood, and wide gashes marked where his IRA assailants plunged iron spikes into the legs of her son, Liam, 19.
fields.body:
Amid religious icons in her north Belfast home, Angela Cairns yesterday unfolded the shredded Levi 501s. They were crusted with thick gobs of blood, and wide gashes marked where his IRA assailants plunged iron spikes into the legs of her son, Liam, 19.

His cream Adidas top, stained deep pink, was pockmarked with nail holes, where he was thumped with studded baseball bats. The weapons had been dragged, enlarging the gashes.

His attackers broke both his legs, his right arm, and a bone in his neck. He was also left with a collapsed lung.

The Ardoyne IRA at first judged that punishment enough for stealing and burning out a local IRA man's car. But it thought again, returning to mete out what is seen locally as its trademark attack.

Its members ripped off his white trainers, and forced his feet through a nearby security fence, with tiny gaps between sharp-edge bars. Then, they went around the other side, and pulled hard.

His lower legs were skinned, virtually to the bone. Surgeons at the Royal Victoria hospital in Belfast are unsure if he will have enough of his own skin to carry out the necessary grafts.

All this happened early on Sunday, as the IRA's unprecedented statement to put its arms beyond use was winning widespread praise. But peace, as ever in Northern Ireland, is relative.

Security forces are pointing to a reduced threat of political violence because of the IRA's move, and are beginning a programme of rapid demilitarisation. But, no matter their intentions regarding their opponents, terrorists on both sides are carrying out more and increasingly vicious attacks on members of their own communities.

Liam, a known joyrider, was baby-sitting with his girlfriend, Anne-Marie Daly, 18, when nine masked men burst into the house. They bundled Anne-Maire upstairs, and wrestled Liam into a waiting car.

They hit and warned Anne-Marie to tell no one. They pinned down Liam's brother, Anthony, wrapping a coat round his head.

Liam was found an hour later by a girl aged 17. He was nearby, in a deserted lane, groaning.

His body was covered in debris, indicating his attackers intended him to die. Punishment squads often telephone ambulances for their victims, sometimes a few minutes before carrying out an attack.

Liam spent eight hours in the operating theatre. He was unable to talk yesterday because of the broken bone, close to his spine. Heavily sedated, he was drifting in and out of consciousness.

Mrs Cairns, 45, a mother of 10, with five grandchil dren, has had four relatives, including her sister, murdered in the troubles. But she said the attack on her son was the worst incident.

"Liam was no angel, like 99% of the kids here. He took a few cars and he was a joyrider. But he never hurt anyone, and no one deserves what he had to suffer.

"These people are great at talking about human rights when it suits them. But where were my son's rights when the IRA did this to him? It was inhuman and cowardly."

The IRA stopped all punishment shootings after the successful review of the Good Friday agreement by the former US senator, George Mitchell, last November. It carried out its first such attack in five months in March, a month after Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, suspended the power-sharing executive.

But IRA punishment shootings have since been running at the rate of two a week, with the latest six days ago in south Armagh when a man aged 24 was shot five times.

He too was left for dead, and was rescued by a passing motorist.

In the year to May 7, republicans were responsible for 19 shootings and 16 beatings. Loyalists shot 29 and assaulted 26.

In the previous 12 months, republicans shot 14 and assaulted 16. Loyalists were behind 15 shootings and 44 assaults.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: It was a painful day for London, with the FTSE 100 losing 92.5 points to 6123.8.
fields.body:
It was a painful day for London, with the FTSE 100 losing 92.5 points to 6123.8.

A few of the leaders, some with "old economy" status but with heavy consumer exposure, were in demand, such as drinks group Diageo (up 40p at 583.5p) and retailer Kingfisher (25p firmer at 542p). Even Bass put in a strong rally, ending the session 36p higher at 782p.

But heavy fails among the technology heavyweights ruined the atmosphere. The fall in Vodafone, down almost 6% on the day, accounted for 43 points off the Footsie.

There was also some heavy selling of BP Amoco - blamed on old fashioned profit-taking. The shares closed down 19.5p at 577.5p after a strong set of first quarter figures.

The slump in technology stocks gathered pace in the afternoon as thin trading and profit-taking took the shine off decent results from the TMT sector.

In the US, the Nasdaq's downward spiral continued ahead of the Fed's decision on interest rates, due next week, adding to the general gloom.

Dealers said institutions seemed to be paralysed, waiting for news on borrowing costs and unwilling to take short term market positions, leading to extremely thick trading conditions.

At the close, the Techmark 100 had fallen 99.04 points to 3,634.87.

Early features lost their lustre as the day wore on, as solid interim figures comfortably ahead of expectations for Baltimore and Sage failed to save either from the general rout.

By the close, Baltimore was down 333p to £66.36, reversing an earlier 381p gain in exceptionally thin volumes. Sage, whose first-half results were also well above consensus estimates, held in positive territory, but ended the day just 4p higher at 671p after a 73p jump in the morning.

Elsewhere only a few of the larger TMT stocks managed to make headway. Fibernet, recovering after heavy falls last week, closed up 25p to 302.5p, while Easynet, coming back from a precipitate drop over the last few months, managed a further rally of 45p to 887.5p.

Long-term support from analysts for many telecoms stocks could not stem short-term weakness, with Telewest losing 28.5p to 342.5p, Kingston Communications dropping 47p to 700p and Colt Telecom easing 149p to £26.40. BT was also a faller, down 43p to 957p at the close, as was Redstone Telecom, slipping 40p to 410p.

Motion Media, despite announcing a surveillance deal with CCTV specialists Norbain, lost 18p to 113p.

webTitle: Expats say evacuation is an occupational hazard

fields.headline: Expats say evacuation is an occupational hazard
fields.standfirst:
UNMASIL - UN mission
Sierra Leone Web
Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: Four Irish nuns from the Holy Rosary Sisters were among the 215 British nationals, European Union passport holders and Commonwealth citizens evacuated out of Sierra Leone by British and UN troops.
fields.body:
Four Irish nuns from the Holy Rosary Sisters were among the 215 British nationals, European Union passport holders and Commonwealth citizens evacuated out of Sierra Leone by British and UN troops.

Wearing her wimple and with a crucifix around her neck, Sister Celia Doyle, from Co Wexford, said yesterday she had lived in Sierra Leone since 1968 and evacuation had happened so often it was regarded as an occupational hazard.

"I suppose you get used to it in a way so I have taken my year's leave now and will not be coming back until my two months' break is over.

"I never get frightened here, but things have got rather tense in the last few days."

The nuns are part of an expatriate community in the West African nation largely made up of aid agency workers, missionaries, businessmen and diplomats.

The Foreign Office said that of the estimated 500 Britons living in Sierra Leone there were also some who had retired there or who had family links with the country.

The Xaverian Fathers, a Catholic missionary group with offices in London, has two Britons among its 15 Sierra Leone-based staff. Joseph Berton, a Scottish priest who has been there for 25 years and works with the rehabilitation of child soldiers, was last night still in the capital, Freetown.

Businesses have tended to leave the country because of its instability, especially since the civil war began in 1991, but some companies do still have branches there. Standard Charter bank has an office that employs 20 local people and one Briton, who happened to be on leave when the trouble started last week.

There are also expatriate entrepreneurs in businesses from mobile phones to breweries. There is a large community of Lebanese.

The larger aid agencies have a presence in Sierra Leone. Monique Nagelkerke, the country's programme director for Save the Children, says it is a very pleasant place to work.

Speaking from the Ivory Coast, where she was flown at the weekend, she said: "The evacuations are very much déjà vu. You just pack your bags and leave once a year."

She added that despite the troubles many foreigners decide to stay there.

"Freetown is a rundown town, but a beautiful town. It has the most beautiful beaches in all of Africa. I'm definitely going back."

Land of hope enslaved by war

1787 Freed slaves arrive in Sierra Leone from England to form a settlement. They are later joined by US slaves who had escaped to Canada

1808 Britain takes over the settlement to make it a naval base, later used by British frigates fighting the slave trade

1961 Sierra Leone becomes independent from Britain

1982 The west African country provides staging post for British forces en route to Falklands conflict

1985 General Joseph Momoh, who had served with British forces, becomes president after election in which he is sole candidate

1991 The first bands of Revolutionary United Front rebels covertly enter Sierra Leone from neighbouring countries, setting the stage for a civil war that will last through the 1990s

1992 Army morale collapses, prompting a coup by Captain Valentine Strasser, 26

1996 Another coup sees Strasser overthrown. Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, the current president, is elected

1997 Kabbah ousted in coup. Britain's high commissioner, Peter Penfold, acts as link between Kabbah and Sandline International, the British-based mercenary company trying to help him regain power, backed by Nigerian forces. Role of Foreign Office turns into embarrassment for Robin Cook

1998 Kabbah resumes power

January 1999 RUF rebels temporarily take over Freetown, the capital, before being pushed out, leaving many people mutilated and 6,000 dead, mainly civilians. But RUF retains control of much of the countryside

July 1999 Peace pact is reached between Kabbah government and RUF. Rebel leader Foday Sankoh gets cabinet place and control of diamond-producing areas. UN sends forces to police deal

fields.headline: Eurotunnel inquiry
fields.standfirst: Officials investigated after claims of irregularities
fields.trailText: Several senior figures at Eurotunnel, including its former chairman Sir Alastair Morton, are at the centre of a French investigation into alleged financial irregularities going back to 1994, the Anglo-French company confirmed last night.
fields.body:
Several senior figures at Eurotunnel, including its former chairman Sir Alastair Morton, are at the centre of a French investigation into alleged financial irregularities going back to 1994, the Anglo-French company confirmed last night.

Others involved in the inquiry by a French magistrate are its current chairman, Patrick Ponsolle, and Alain Bertrand, another senior executive. Under the French judicial system, a formal inquiry into alleged irregularities can be made by a lawyer, usually a magistrate, who has the authority to decide whether charges can be laid.

Sir Alastair, currently chairman of the Strategic Rail Authority (SRA), was regarded as the driving force behind the project, which had debts of £9bn on its completion. He gave up all his shares in Eurotunnel when he was appointed chairman of the SRA.

The period under investigation predates the issuing of shares. The inquiry is looking into a complaint that misleading financial information was given when the prospectus was drawn up.

A spokesman for Mr Ponsolle said: "He has received no letter informing him of this matter. He would certainly not resign if he did receive one."

Sarah Kendall, Eurotunnel's head of communications, confirmed that a French inquiry was in progress and that the matter had reached the examination stage. She said: "All these complaints were made six years ago, and involve a rights issue of Eurotunnel shares."

She said that at the time of the allegations, Mr Ponsolle was a director of Eurotunnel, but not its chairman.

It is understood that Mr Ponsolle and a number of his co-directors will soon be ordered to give evidence to the investigating magistrate about the allegations.

A report on the inquiry appeared yesterday in the French weekly Le Canard Enchainé. The results of the investigation are expected later this year.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Dresdner departures
fields.body:
Dresdner departures

Dresdner Bank's investment arm, Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, has lost its top corporate finance specialist Rudolf Vossen and 10 of the Frankfurt department's 24-member staff to JP Morgan, according to a German newspaper. Dresdner has suffered several high-profile losses in London and Frankfurt this year, during which time it has seen a merger with rival Deutsche Bank fall apart.

German jobless rate falls

Germany's April unadjusted unemployment rate - at 9.8% - dipped below the 10% mark for the first time since June 1996 and is a signal that the economy is improving, analysts said.

The number of jobless in Germany was down by 8,000 in April from March in seasonally adjusted terms, compared with an adjusted rise of 10,000 in March, the federal labour office said.

Rio Tinto is put under pressure

Large institutional investors in mining group Rio Tinto will support two union-backed shareholder resolutions calling for the board of directors to be more accountable to shareholders at its annual meeting today, the TUC said.

41% pay rise for Next chief

Next chief executive David Jones saw his pay jump 41% last year following the fashion retailer's 17% rise in pre-tax profits, according to the firm's annual report. Mr Jones received £855,000 in pay, bonuses and benefits compared with £501,000 the year before. Next pre-tax profits rose from £166.9m to £195.6m.

Post Office buys in France

The Post Office further extended its European parcel operations with the £71m purchase yesterday of Extand, the third biggest parcel company in France. Extand, based in Toulouse, has more than 800 employees and delivers more than 30m parcels a year. It specialises in business-to-business deliveries of small parcels. Since January last year the PO has bought distribution businesses in Germany, Ireland, Denmark, France, Austria, the Netherlands and the US.

Nedlloyd chief quits

Tim Harris, chief executive of P&O Nedlloyd Container Line, resigned from the board yesterday, following disagreements with fellow board members over the future of the 50:50 joint venture between P&O and Nedlloyd. P&O Nedlloyd appointed Haddo Meijer, deputy chairman of Nedlloyd and chief financial officer of P&O Nedlloyd, as chairman of the joint venture's executive committee, and Robert Woods as group managing director.

Invesco buys in Canada

Amvescap, the fund management group known as Invesco in Britain, yesterday said it agreed to pay £1.16bn in cash and shares for Canadian financial services group Trimark Financial.

The bid follows speculation that Amvescap is talking to UK fund manager Perpetual with a view to a £1.15bn takeover.

fields.headline: Shipyard hopes rise
fields.standfirst: Workers vote for pay freeze
fields.trailText: Belfast's troubled Harland and Wolff shipyard was last night chasing new orders after workers voted to accept a three-year wage freeze that could help secure the future of shipbuilding in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Belfast's troubled Harland and Wolff shipyard was last night chasing new orders after workers voted to accept a three-year wage freeze that could help secure the future of shipbuilding in Northern Ireland.

There was anger among the workers, many of whom believed a gun was being held to their head by management who said they would not sign any contract without the agreement with workers in place.

It is understood the yard is close to clinching a £400m contract to build four ferries for a Norwegian line that was dependent on the workers agreeing to the pay and conditions package.

The shipyard management welcomed the vote and said it would "aggressively pursue new orders." A spokesman refused to say whether the Norwegian order was imminent.

At a 90-minute meeting, held behind closed doors in central Belfast, the shipyard workers narrowly voted 424 to 389 to accept the deal, which will guarantee skilled workers a minimum of £310 a week. It is expected the workforce will be cut from 1,300 to 1,000. Bobby Carson, president of the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions, said workers had been angry but if the yard signed the ferry order it would provide three years work and a platform for continued shipbuilding. Press Association

fields.headline: Focus
fields.standfirst: Vodafone Airtouch
fields.trailText: Investors might have become blasé about big numbers over the past couple of years. But it still seems astonishing that one British company, Vodafone Airtouch, has seen some £80bn of its stock market value disappear over the past couple of months.
fields.body:
Investors might have become blasé about big numbers over the past couple of years. But it still seems astonishing that one British company, Vodafone Airtouch, has seen some £80bn of its stock market value disappear over the past couple of months.

At yesterday's close, with the shares slipping again from 267p to 252p, the company is still worth £160bn. But the speed with which the rating attached to Britain's biggest company has been eroded has perplexed pundits.

Sure, there has been the across-the-board sell-off of the TMT sector (technology, media and telecoms). There have been worries over the valuations previously attached to Orange, which Vodafone has to hive off. There has also been discussion over the price paid by Japanese telecoms outfit NTT this week for a 15% stake in the Dutch phone group KPN Mobile, which in turn is said to have cooled expectations on how much Vodafone might get for Orange.

Then there is the matter of Britain's mobile phone auction, raising more than £4bn for each of the five new third-generation licences. With the winners busy paying over the cash, the government has had to set up special bank accounts at high street lenders, rather than having the winners pay direct to the Bank of England - so as to avoid suddenly sucking £22bn out of the financial systems.

But this seems a short-sighted excuse for wiping out a third of Vodafone's market capitalisation. Yesterday the shares were trading at levels not seen for seven months. If they drop further, investors should look to topping up their holdings.

webTitle: British troops in stay or leave dilemma

fields.headline: British troops in stay or leave dilemma
fields.standfirst:
Cook wary of wider role as UN seeks help in keeping peace

UNMASIL - UN mission
Sierra Leone Web
Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: The British forces in Sierra Leone, with their evacuation operation well under way, were yesterday facing up to the risk of being sucked into this dangerous West African civil war.
fields.body:
The British forces in Sierra Leone, with their evacuation operation well under way, were yesterday facing up to the risk of being sucked into this dangerous West African civil war.

The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, led calls yesterday for Britain to play a wider role by supporting the struggling UN peace-keeping force.

Having gone in, the British government will find it harder to leave. As a permanent member of the UN security council, it will be difficult just to load up British troops and sail away. It will also be open to accusations that having looked after British citizens - black as well as white, as the Foreign Office pointed out - it turned its back on a potential bloodbath.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, was adamant yesterday that British forces would not become directly involved in the civil war: "These are not going to become combat troops as part of the UN force." He has said that the force should be made up of soldiers from African and other third world nations.

Safe passage

But already the British mission is developing into one that goes well beyond evacuation. After talking on the phone to Mr Annan yesterday afternoon, Mr Cook said: "If by remaining there and securing [Lungi] airport for a period of time, we can help the UN to build up, then that is a situation we will weigh."

Mr Cook and the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, who are in constant telephone contact, have now agreed to secure the airport to provide a safe passage for promised UN reinforcements. About 3,000 soldiers from India, Bangladesh and Jordan are to join the 8,000-strong contingent already there. The UN reinforcements are expected within about 10 to 14 days.

But British ministers have made statements in the past that involvement in foreign conflicts would be limited, only to be drawn in, most notably in the Balkans.

The situation in Sierra Leone remains volatile. The capital was relatively quiet yesterday but the rebel force, the Revolutionary United Front, was involved in clashes 35 miles away.

About 300 British, European Union and Commonwealth citizens were evacuated yesterday and the Foreign Office expected the operation to continue for a few more days. A French helicopter was helping evacuate 30 people in an outlying area.

The biggest problem is the fate of the UN hostages. The 300 UN troops, including a British army major, an unarmed UN adviser, are being detained by RUF forces in the south-east and 200 Zambian troops are missing in the north-east.

The British position in Sierra Leone is in danger of what the Americans call "mission creep". The paras' original mandate was restricted to hold the airport and protect what the ministry of defence called a "non-combatant evacuation operation". Now it includes protecting the airport for UN reinforcements.

Mr Cook also conceded yesterday that they could provide extra logistic support for the UN. This would involve helping with transport and radio communication.

Is it possible that British forces will become involved in trying to secure the release of the UN hostages? Asked yesterday whether British troops could play a role in helping to relieve the detained UN troops, a Whitehall source said it would depend on the advice of Brigadier David Richards, leader of a 15-strong technical assistance team sent in last week. "A negotiated release would be better but action has not been ruled out."

If the rebel forces were close to taking Freetown, would British forces stand by? The Foreign Office said yesterday that the role of the UN force was to police the peace, not enforce it. But Mr Cook and Mr Hoon could easily change the mandate for British forces.

The paras are armed with small mortars and heavy machine guns. Official sources conceded that they could remain in Sierra Leone for a long time. The 700 paras could easily be resupplied by air from the naval task force led by the helicopter carrier, HMS Ocean, with 600 marines and an artillery battery on board.

That force is expected to arrive by the end of the week and will be joined by the aircraft carrier, HMS Illustrious.

Such a show of force, the biggest unilateral action by Britain since the Falklands war, would make it even more difficult for ministers to order British troops and ships to return home immediately after its stated limited purpose had been achieved.

Having been drawn into the conflict, an honourable way out could be provided by the Nigerians. They have stepped in before to prop up the Sierra Leone government and in 1998 ousted coup leaders to restore the legitimate government. A spokesman for the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanju, said Nigeria would consider a UN request if the world body undertook to foot the bill.

The Conservatives called yesterday on Mr Cook to be more specific about the British mission.

Vice Admiral Sir Ian Garnett, who has operational command of British forces in Sierra Leone, said: "There is no intention at the moment, as has been said earlier, to have the paras form part of the UN force." That phrase "at the moment" could yet turn out to be significant.

About 3,000 soldiers from India, Bangladesh and Jordan are to join the 8,000-strong contingent already there. The UN reinforcements are expected within about 10 to 14 days. But British ministers have made statements in the past that involvement in foreign conflicts would be limited, only to be drawn in, most notably in the Balkans. The situation in Sierra Leone remains volatile. The capital was relatively quiet yesterday but the rebel force, the Revolutionary United Front, was involved in clashes 35 miles away. About 300 British, European Union and Commonwealth citizens were evacuated yesterday and the Foreign Office expected the operation to continue for a few more days. A French helicopter was helping evacuate 30 people in an outlying area. The biggest problem is the fate of the UN hostages. The 300 UN troops, including a British army major, an unarmed UN adviser, are being detained by RUF forces in the south-east and 200 Zambian troops are missing in the north-east. The British position in Sierra Leone is in danger of what the Americans call "mission creep". The paras' original mandate was restricted to hold the airport and protect what the ministry of defence called a "non-combatant evacuation operation". Now it includes protecting the airport for UN reinforcements. Mr Cook also conceded yesterday that they could provide extra logistic support for the UN. This would involve helping with transport and radio communication. Is it possible that British forces will become involved in trying to secure the release of the UN hostages? Asked yesterday whether British troops could play a role in helping to relieve the detained UN troops, a Whitehall source said it would depend on the advice of Brigadier David Richards, leader of a 15-strong technical assistance team sent in last week. "A negotiated release would be better but action has not been ruled out." If the rebel forces were close to taking Freetown, would British forces stand by? The Foreign Office said yesterday that the role of the UN force was to police the peace, not enforce it. But Mr Cook and Mr Hoon could easily change the mandate for British forces. The paras are armed with small mortars and heavy machine guns. Official sources conceded that they could remain in Sierra Leone for a long time. The 700 paras could easily be resupplied by air from the naval task force led by the helicopter carrier, HMS Ocean, with 600 marines and an artillery battery on board. That force is expected to arrive by the end of the week and will be joined by the aircraft carrier, HMS Illustrious. Such a show of force, the biggest unilateral action by Britain since the Falklands war, would make it even more difficult for ministers to order British troops and ships to return home immediately after its stated limited purpose had been achieved. Having been drawn into the conflict, an honourable way out could be provided by the Nigerians. They have stepped in before to prop up the Sierra Leone government and in 1998 ousted coup leaders to restore the legitimate government. A spokesman for the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanju, said Nigeria would consider a UN request if the world body undertook to foot the bill. The Conservatives called yesterday on Mr Cook to be more specific about the British mission. Vice Admiral Sir Ian Garnett, who has operational command of British forces in Sierra Leone, said: "There is no intention at the moment, as has been said earlier, to have the paras form part of the UN force." That phrase "at the moment" could yet turn out to be significant.

webTitle: Bitterness as Rover rescue left to the locals

fields.headline: Bitterness as Rover rescue left to the locals
fields.standfirst: Phoenix anger at political meddling
fields.trailText: W ell, fancy that. Despite all the alarmist nonsense about the burning of taxpayers money and allegedly un-buckable economic realities, a deal has finally been done. Britain's car manufacturing industry will not now go to the wall at the end of the month. Not all of it, in any case.
fields.body:
W ell, fancy that. Despite all the alarmist nonsense about the burning of taxpayers money and allegedly un-buckable economic realities, a deal has finally been done. Britain's car manufacturing industry will not now go to the wall at the end of the month. Not all of it, in any case.

Yet there was a hint of bitterness within the Phoenix camp yesterday. Former Rover chief executive John Towers has been given the chance to rescue the firm he used to run, but the man en couraging everyone to fly up out of the ashes clearly landed his deal in spite of the efforts of the government and with precious little help from the City of London.

This was a local rescue -- Midlands dealers, Midlands based managers, even a Midlands-based investment bank, Albert E Sharpe.

And as everyone was busy pointing out yesterday, this local, under-capitalised solution looks flimsy in the globalised world of car manufacturing, marketing and sales. Everyone other than those who were going to lose their jobs, that is.

Phoenix insiders say that, at times, the Labour government seemed to be actively working against this local proposal.

The allegations of political meddling and the complete inability to think laterally are not just being levelled at the Department of Trade and Industry and the beleaguered Stephen Byers. As for Britain's high street banks, they might want to be big, but they clearly don't want to have hefty exposure to the country's industrial heartlands.

The challenge for Mr Towers now is to leverage the goodwill of the Longbridge workforce and cut losses. He needs to stabilise market share, build credibility and then get on and forge an alliance with one of the industry majors.

Phoenix needs a partner that can help build the next generation of cars. In this, the new company stands a better chance than BMW, since the suspicion is that anyone the German car firm spoke to on the subject in the past always wanted a piece of BMW in return.

Having burnt around £4bn over the past six years, BMW has got off the hook in a much cleaner manner than it might have hoped.

Big four targeted

Of course, Britain's largest clearing banks have got other things on their corporate minds just now - such as the fact that the big four (Lloyds TSB, Barclays, HSBC and NatWest) are now under fire from the former building societies, who want a real piece of the majors' fabulous current account business.

Instead of the war of words inflicted on them by Don Cruickshank, the treasury's banking competition tsar, the clearers now have to contend with Abbey National and Halifax taking matters into their own hands, making pledges and launching products with the aim of luring all those lazy customers which it was presumed were more likely to divorce than move their money.

Given Mr Cruickshank's point that the big four have a grip on 80% of the current account market, Abbey and Halifax even sound virtuous. Both claim to make it as easy as possible for customers to move accounts, as they promise to do all the boring transfers of direct debits and standing orders for any customer who wants to move accounts, precisely one of the areas which caused Cruickshank so much angst.

Halifax also argues that it is countering another criticism hurled at the big banks who make money at each customer's expense - by taking their deposits and paying lowish rates of interest and then lending it back to them at higher rates. Its new Intelligent Finance service, Halifax claims, allows customers to make choices about whether to allow that to happen. But all these rigorous commercial declarations are not yet showing through in the mortgage banks' share prices. The City seems nonplussed.

One of the reason for this might be that it is far from clear what impact Halifax's new If bank will have on its existing customer base. The same is true of Abbey, which in addition to its new internet venture is promising to unveil a new branded bank (called cahoot) in the coming weeks.

Another is that the clearing banks themselves are unlikely to take such threats lying down. Lloyds TSB, criticised for being too slow to take to the internet, will today outline further details of its plans, while Barclays was yesterday declared as the world's fifth largest internet bank in one e-survey.

And there is also the problem of hype, causing investors to sell just as the news arrives. This clearly happened to Halifax yesterday, with its stock taking a pummelling on the day of a sleek presentation. Perhaps the market was looking for something more exciting than the five-product "money management system" unveiled.

fields.headline: Matalan's mixed fortunes
fields.standfirst: Good figures but placing hits shares
fields.trailText: Matalan, the one-time cash and carry warehouse turned high-powered discount retailer, clocked up another year of profit growth in 1999.
fields.body:
Matalan, the one-time cash and carry warehouse turned high-powered discount retailer, clocked up another year of profit growth in 1999.

The company also said yesterday that the first 10 weeks of the financial year have seen fatter margins and a sales surge fuelled by bargain-hunters, such as those pictured above in the St Helens store on Merseyside.

But investors set aside the positive trading figures and sent the shares spinning 40p lower to 505p after news that the firm's majority shareholders are to place 12% of combined holdings on the market.

More than 60% of shares are held by founder and chairman John Hargreaves, his family and boardroom colleagues, who have been criticised for their failure to make more shares available.

Matalan turned in pre-tax profits of £54.1m, a 138% rise on the same period in 1998-1999, with sales up 56% to £433.8m. It said gross margins had improved in March, April and early May with sales in that time rising 31.2% on a like-for-like basis.

The out-of-town, fashion and homeware chain has more than 4.5m people, one in 10 adults , in its membership scheme. The 99-strong chain hopes to double by 2005. Matalan's success in hooking its members, who pay £1 to register with the group, with own-brand products and discounted designer names has taken a bite from sales of rivals Bhs and Marks & Spencer.

It forecast substantial sales growth in the current year. Over Easter sales grew by 35.2% on a like-for-like basis. Earnings per share were up 151% to 9.8p from 3.9p. The company is to pay a final dividend of 2.4p against 1.1p last time, a total dividend for the period of 3.4p, against 1.1p. Matalan is to launch a credit card later this year, in partnership with Yorkshire Bank.

The placing will involve the sale of shares by non-executive director Charles Thompson and possible sales of parts of the stakes of chief executive Angus Monro and group finance director Ian Smith. Even after the placing, the Hargreaves family will still be left with 52% of Matalan.

fields.headline: Unilever stirs Bestfoods pot
fields.trailText: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer group, is to put further pressure on the management of Bestfoods to agree to a meeting today after the US food company is understood to have discussed potential cost savings from a merger with analysts.
fields.body:
Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer group, is to put further pressure on the management of Bestfoods to agree to a meeting today after the US food company is understood to have discussed potential cost savings from a merger with analysts.

When he talks to shareholders about Unilever's first-quarter results today, Niall Fitzgerald, its chief executive, is expected to highlight research published yesterday by Credit Suisse First Boston, the investment bank. In the report, David Nelson, a CSFB analyst, suggests that Bestfoods believes some $1bn cost savings will result from a merger of the two companies, more than double that estimated by Unilever.

Bestfoods has refused to meet Unilever to discuss a takeover proposal based on $66 a share, which would value the group at $18.4bn. CSFB concluded yesterday that an offer of close to $75 could work.

This analysis found support from one institutional shareholder in both Unilever and Bestfoods yesterday.

Richard Newboult, chief executive of Sherpa Asset Management, a London-based fund specialising in global consumer companies, said he believed fair value for Bestfoods was "between $75 and $80. It has been "absurdly undervalued", he added.

If Unilever is to win its target, however, it must convince far larger institutional shareholders such as Fidelity, Capital and Amvescap that its cash offer is adequate.

fields.headline: White farms invaded in Kenya
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: A white Kenyan government minister said yesterday that two farms on the Kenyan coast - one of which he owns - had been invaded by landless families in apparent copycat occupations to those in Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
A white Kenyan government minister said yesterday that two farms on the Kenyan coast - one of which he owns - had been invaded by landless families in apparent copycat occupations to those in Zimbabwe.

Basil Criticos, an assistant minister in the public works department, said that hundreds of people had invaded one of his farms, beaten up his security staff and burnt thousands of acres of his sisal crop.

Mr Criticos believed they had been incited by calls last month from maverick politician Stephen Ndichu for landless Kenyans to occupy and seize white-owned farms.

In a reference to Zimbabwe, where hundreds of white-owned farms have been invaded, Mr Criticos said: "Since the debate on this sensitive subject began my farm has been invaded by over 300 families."

He did not give the date of the invasion, but said the squatters had already started dividing up the land. Some had been arrested, he said, but most had since been released.

While confirming "a land dispute involving Mr Criticos's farm", the Kenyan government yesterday said there was "no connection whatsoever between events in Kenya and Zimbabwe".

Its statement, released from the office of the cabinet secretary, Richard Leakey - the only other white member of the government - said it was misleading to suggest that there was a racial element to the land problem in Kenya.

Like Zimbabwe, Kenya is a former British colony but most white farmers in Kenya gave up their land voluntarily after independence in 1963. However, the few farms which are still white-owned are some of the biggest farms in a country where land is a divisive issue.

webTitle: Sage places its bets on software to rent

fields.headline: Sage places its bets on software to rent
fields.trailText: Strong organic growth and expansion in the US helped business accounting software group Sage beat analysts' forecasts by some £3m yesterday to bring in a first-half profit of £54m before tax.
fields.body:
Strong organic growth and expansion in the US helped business accounting software group Sage beat analysts' forecasts by some £3m yesterday to bring in a first-half profit of £54m before tax.

The company, which has 2.3m customers, said the profit for the six months to the end of March was 52% higher than a year earlier, on turnover up a similar amount to 202.5m.

Organic growth was credited with generating most income growth rather than the string of companies Sage bought during the period as it expanded aggressively, chief among them US-based Best Software which it bought for $445m.

Best will bring 50,000 new customers to Sage, and the company expects it to boost its earnings within the full year. Its shares opened 7% up at 715p, compared with a year high of 995p and low of 538.5p, but finished down at 668p after a fall in the Techmark index.

"The board remains confident about prospects for the full year," said the chairman, Michael Jackson. He said the company was positioning itself for the expected take-off of the market for application service providers or companies which rent out software for use on the internet rather than for use with a copy loaded on to individual computers.

But Mr Jackson said most customers were still cautious towards processing data by internet for security reasons.

fields.headline: Buoyant Capital set to expand
fields.trailText: Fresh from its successful takeover of Border Television, Capital Radio said yesterday that strong advertising revenues had boosted profits and put the company in a strong position for further expansion.
fields.body:
Fresh from its successful takeover of Border Television, Capital Radio said yesterday that strong advertising revenues had boosted profits and put the company in a strong position for further expansion.

A better-than-expected first half result saw pre-tax profits rise to £21.7m, 21% up on last year's £17.9m. The company added that trading from April to June had been buoyant and the group expected a strong performance for the full year.

Chief executive David Mansfield said: "Our strategy of developing a national presence has been strengthened by our forthcoming acquisition of Border's radio stations." Last month the company won the battle for Border Television, which owns the Century brand of radio stations, with a £151m bid.

Mr Mansfield said the company has a commanding position in digital radio, but conceded that mass consumer take-up is unlikely for some time. He also said that Capital Interactive's new music sites will appear on line during the next few weeks. Work on further new elements for the sites is well advanced and more changes will appear online over the coming weeks. Group turnover was up 14% at £59.5m and the underlying radio margin was up to 40.3% from 38.5%. The dividend has been raised 17% to 6p from 5.15p.

Radio revenues increased by 14% to £58.9m with advertising revenues up 15% compared to an industry increase of 13.5%. Dot.com revenues were up an underlying 9%, the group said.

fields.headline: Victory for nostalgia
fields.standfirst:
Putin hails Soviet glory days as Russia marks defeat of Nazis

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Fifty-five years after the Red Army planted the Hammer and Sickle on the Reichstag in Berlin to seal the Soviet Union's greatest victory, President Vladimir Putin yesterday presided over his first Red Square military march-past and conjured up the glory days of a former superpower.
fields.body:
Fifty-five years after the Red Army planted the Hammer and Sickle on the Reichstag in Berlin to seal the Soviet Union's greatest victory, President Vladimir Putin yesterday presided over his first Red Square military march-past and conjured up the glory days of a former superpower.

On Victory Day, which marks the defeat of Nazi Germany, more than 5,000 elderly veterans and young servicemen went on parade.

At 47, Mr Putin is the first Russian leader with no experience of the second world war, though his infant brother died in the Nazi siege of Leningrad. His father was a guerrilla fighter in the Baltic region.

"It was hard, but we survived," said Pavel Todorchuk, 81, a veteran of the campaigns for Kiev, Warsaw, and Berlin in 1945 "We didn't respect Yeltsin, but we respect Putin," he said. "We'll see how he does, what his team is like, and then we'll make up our minds about him."

In what has become the pattern of the five-month Putin presidency - a triumph of form over content - the new leader concentrated on the feelgood factor, waxing nostalgic for the Soviet Union while avoiding even the slightest of policy statements.

He addressed the troops as "comrades", spoke of the "great Soviet motherland" before young veterans of the current Chechen war, in the khaki capes and helmets of the 1940s, marched past his podium to stirring martial music.

Despite defeat in Afghanistan, the 1994-96 Chechen war and the cold war, Russia, Mr Putin asserted, was making a habit of the victory secured in 1945.

A Putin supporter, Nikita Mikhalkov, the film director, used the anniversary to call for Volgograd, the city where decisive battle was joined, to revert to its Soviet name, Stalingrad.

fields.headline: Transco hits telecoms trail
fields.trailText: Transco, the domestic arm of about-to-demerge British Gas, yesterday built on earlier plans to break into the telecoms business with proposals to spend £235m building a fibre optic network to connect 12 major cities, including London. The system will be based mainly on Transco's pipeline routes.
fields.body:
Transco, the domestic arm of about-to-demerge British Gas, yesterday built on earlier plans to break into the telecoms business with proposals to spend £235m building a fibre optic network to connect 12 major cities, including London. The system will be based mainly on Transco's pipeline routes.

Last month Transco - which is to be split in the autumn from BG International, the group's gas production and supply arm - said it intended to set up the infrastructure needed to support third-generation mobile telephones. Yesterday's blueprint takes Transco further down the road of becoming a "multi-utility", with partners in telecoms, water and other areas.
