fields.headline: Phone link
fields.standfirst: Japanese and Dutch operators join up
fields.trailText: Dutch telecoms company KPN yesterday clinched a 5bn euro (£3bn) deal with Japanese cellphone operator NTT Docomo, but shares tumbled as investors questioned whether the two could take on Europe's heavyweights.
fields.body:
Dutch telecoms company KPN yesterday clinched a 5bn euro (£3bn) deal with Japanese cellphone operator NTT Docomo, but shares tumbled as investors questioned whether the two could take on Europe's heavyweights.

In its first European investment, NTT Docomo is taking a 15% stake in the mobile phone business of KPN Telecom, KPN Mobile, just four days after the Dutch group abandoned parallel merger talks with Telefonica of Spain.

The deal was announced in Amsterdam by an NTT Docomo senior executive vice-president, Norioki Morinaga.

Although NTT Docomo is Japan's most valuable company and has a reputation for innovation with hi-tech mobile internet phones, shares in KPN became one of the biggest blue-chip casualties in Europe. They ended 6.86% lower at 111.30 euros.

"It's not the deal the market had expected, yielding cost savings or strengthening KPN's European expansion, bringing together their networks, as Telefonica would," said one analyst.

In collaboration with US partner BellSouth, KPN Mobile hopes the deal will boost its chances of winning an expected auction battle for British cellphone group Orange, which Vodafone AirTouch will be forced to sell or float as a separate business later this year.

"We have stated our interest in Orange and this is shared by Docomo and BellSouth ... and we have now become much more attractive to Orange," said KPN spokesman Joop Drechsel.

Clinching a big partner should also boost KPN Mobile's chances of winning costly third generation mobile phone licences, which are being put up for grabs across Europe.

KPN and NTT Docomo are betting on opportunities in Europe's mobile and internet markets.

fields.headline: Baltimore races towards break-even
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Baltimore Technologies, the loss-making Irish internet security firm that has invested heavily to turn itself into a global market leader, looks likely to break even earlier than expected.
fields.body:
Baltimore Technologies, the loss-making Irish internet security firm that has invested heavily to turn itself into a global market leader, looks likely to break even earlier than expected.

The Dublin-based company, which was recently promoted to the FTSE 100 index, yesterday reported first quarter figures that beat most analyst forecasts and said the company was growing faster than anticipated.

In the three months to March 31 revenues doubled to £9.5m compared with the same period the previous year, although pre-tax losses rose slightly from £6.9m to £7.25m.

Analysts had forecast revenues of around £8.5m and a pre-tax loss of £10.5m, with break-even at the end of next year. Last night analysts were examining whether to change their forecasts and bring the date forward.

Coleen Kaiser, analyst at Merrill Lynch, said: "The outlook is more positive and the momentum is building faster than expected."

Fran Rooney, chief executive of Baltimore, said the revenue increase was due to strong organic growth and that the true effect of two recent acquisitions in the US and Japan would not be seen until the half-year figures.

"We could have been profitable by now but last year we took the decision to invest and grow our global footprint," he said. "We are starting to see the fruition of that investment. These figures show we did the right thing."

Revenue growth was buoyed by strong sales of software licences - up 800% year on year - and a healthy contribution from the US business.

The majority of Baltimore's sales come from Europe but Mr Rooney believes that the US, which accounted for 18% of sales, will become just as important. "I think we'll eventually see a 40-40 split between Europe and the US with Asia Pacific making up the remainder," he said.

Baltimore's share price was one of the market's best performers last year, rising 600%. Today it is one of the most volatile. Yesterday it swung more than 5% either way before settling to close down 333p at £66.30.

The company develops software that facilitates the secure transfer of payments and data over the internet. In the last quarter it added PricewaterhouseCoopers and a number of US banks to a customer base heavily skewed towards the financial services sector.

Mr Rooney believes healthcare, government and mobile e-commerce will be the next big growth markets. "Governments around the world want to offer secure ways to file things like tax returns online. Health services are increasingly making payments over the web and moving towards the virtual fulfilment of paperless prescriptions. We are starting to win a lot of business in these areas."

Acquisitions will continue to form a key part of Baltimore's growth strategy. Its two most recent buys - the $150m (£98m) purchase of CyberTrust in the US and £2.5m takeover of Japan's NSJ Corporation - both show healthy gains in valuation terms and new opportunities are continually being evaluated, Mr Rooney said.

Referring to the recent computer bug that struck global networks, Mr Rooney said: "The Love Bug has highlighted security and the need for people to be aware of the danger of viruses. The technology is in place to stop viruses like the Love Bug and other viruses becoming a problem."

"We were not affected by the Love Bug because our early warning systems were in place, though we saw other companies in our own building being affected."

fields.headline: Europe day
fields.standfirst: Bruno beats Brussels to the punch
fields.trailText: EC staff in Brussels took the day off and Frank Bruno in London unveiled a special Euro-punch as Europe yesterday paid homage to Robert Schuman, the Frenchman whose declaration launched the continent's integration half a century ago.
fields.body:
EC staff in Brussels took the day off and Frank Bruno in London unveiled a special Euro-punch as Europe yesterday paid homage to Robert Schuman, the Frenchman whose declaration launched the continent's integration half a century ago.

Schuman unveiled his proposal for pooling French and German coal and steel production, to make another conflict not only inconceivable but also impossible by pooling the raw materials needed to go to war, on May 9 1950. It gave birth to the European Coal and Steel Community, the first of Europe's 'supranational' authorities.

Speaking at the European parliament in Brussels, Romano Prodi, president of the European commission - flanked by Jacques Delors, a former commission president, and Valery Giscard d'Estaing, a former French president - described Schuman's plan as "an idea of genuis that changed the history of Europe". Mr Giscard, more downbeat, expressed concern about the continuing decline of the single currency. "We wanted the euro to be independent," he said, "but we didn't want it to be an orphan."

On a gloriously sunny day in Brussels, commission staff took Europe Day off while the Foreign Office in London held an open day featuring celebrities including Frank Bruno, Blackadder actor Tony Robinson,and quiz show host William G Stewart.

Keith Vaz, minister for Europe, praised the cultural diversity of the continent, illustrated by the Euro-punch which he quaffed with Frank Bruno. Its ingredients, from each of the member countries, included Red Bull (Austria), blackberries (Finland), water melons (Ireland), and strawberries (UK).

Francis Maude, shadow foreign secretary, agreed there was "much to celebrate" on the Schuman anniversary. But he said stability for the next century "can still be threatened if European nations make the wrong choices".

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Amanda Saxon, 32, told how Labour's New Deal helped her to lose 14 stone before landing her first job. She met employment minister Tessa Jowell outside the House of Commons a year after a £100 New Deal grant allowed her to enrol on a slimming course. Ms Saxon said she had been un employed for 10 years and weighed 28 stone before a Slimming World course helped her lose half her body weight.

Bad day

The BBC News chiefs admitted the Six 0'clock News should not have run a report featuring an alternative therapist who claimed to be involved in Cherie Blair's pregnancy. In a reply to an angry Downing Street BBC head of news Roger Mosey agreed the report should not have been run in the form it was.

Scramble of day

More than 200 Tories have applied for former prime minister John Major's ultra-safe Huntingdon seat, it was confirmed.

webTitle: Corporate killers to be brought to book

fields.headline: Corporate killers to be brought to book
fields.standfirst:
More about transport
Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: A new offence of corporate killing is to be announced by the government later this month in the wake of growing public unease about the background to the Paddington and Southall rail disasters, official sources confirmed last night.
fields.body:
A new offence of corporate killing is to be announced by the government later this month in the wake of growing public unease about the background to the Paddington and Southall rail disasters, official sources confirmed last night.

The Home Office is to reveal the decision, which will be followed by a consultation document in the summer with legislation in the next parliamentary session.

The move was foreshadowed yesterday, on the eve of the public inquiry into the Paddington rail crash, by David Calvert-Smith, director of public prosecutions. He called for a new offence of "corporate killing", saying the law was "insufficient to deal with what is culpable conduct".

The news came on the day that the crown prosecution service revealed there was "insufficient evidence" to provide a realistic prospect of conviction of an individual or company over the Paddington rail crash last October, in which 31 people died and hundreds were injured. That decision dismayed relatives who accused the CPS of acting too hastily.

But the health and safety executive made clear last night it was still carrying out inquiries, and it was still open for it to pursue criminal charges against a company.

Mr Calvert-Smith told the Commons home affairs select committee yesterday: "I am entirely in favour of an offence, properly drafted, of corporate killing, which will enable the criminal courts to bear down on negligent treatment of employees in the workforce."

Present laws for dealing with such cases had "reached the buffers". This was demonstrated during the Southall rail crash trial when the crown prosecution service failed to persuade the courts that the common law offence of manslaughter could be applied to corporations, in this case Great Western Trains.

Mr Calvert-Smith added: "At the moment, the law is, in our view, insufficient to deal with what is culpable conduct. I would hope that the recommendations of the law commission on the offence of corporate killing would be enacted."

Under present law, prosecutions for corporate manslaughter are doomed to failure, except for one-man or very small companies. The present law requires proof that a director or other "senior controlling" officer was grossly negligent. The new offence would allow companies to be convicted if their conduct fell short of what could reasonably be expected of them.

The HSE said last night that criminal charges against a company could be taken under health and safety legislation for which unlimited fines are also in place. It said it would conclude its investigations by July and would publish them. A decision to prosecute would not affect the Paddington rail crash inquiry, which is still likely to be sitting by then.

The two drivers involved in the crash are dead, and the inquiry chaired by Lord Cullen will be taking evidence from several corporate bodies and companies at the heart of the Paddington crash, among them Railtrack, Thames Trains, First Great Western, and the railway inspectorate.

The role of the inspectorate has been called into question by Jenny Bacon, the HSE's director general, in the first published evidence submitted to Cullen. In it, she effectively blamed the HSE for not pressing the railway inspectorate hard enough on reported problems on signal 109, which was at the centre of the crash.

She said more could have been done by the HSE to enforce health and safety legislation on the railway, and that consideration of signals passed at danger was based on "incomplete data".

Relatives and survivors reacted angrily to the CPS decision not to prosecute. Tony Jasper, of the Paddington Survivors' Group, accused the CPS of not considering every legal avenue. Louise Christian, of the Ladbroke Grove supporters' group, said the decision had been taken too soon. Her clients felt "upset and betrayed".

After opening statements, the inquiry will start hearing evidence on Monday. The first part is expected to end in July, to be followed in September by a joint inquiry into the Paddington and Southall crashes. Lord Cullen will chair a third inquiry in November into all matters of rail safety.

fields.headline: London link
fields.standfirst: Queen opens Millennium Bridge
fields.trailText: London's first new bridge across the Thames in a century was opened yesterday - but since the only way of crossing the water was a 370 metre tightrope walk along the suspension cables, the Queen contented herself with a formal launch.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
London's first new bridge across the Thames in a century was opened yesterday - but since the only way of crossing the water was a 370 metre tightrope walk along the suspension cables, the Queen contented herself with a formal launch.

The Millennium Footbridge links St Paul's and the Tate Modern on Bankside. The project - jointly designed by sculptor Sir Anthony Caro, architect Sir Norman Foster, and the engineering firm Ove Arup, with steel, bronze and aluminium parts prefabricated in Britain, Finland and Poland - has seen schedules slip, and costs rise from £10m to an estimated £18m.

After a service at St Paul's, also attended by London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, the Queen dedicated the bridge to the people of Southwark and the world.

The bridge should have been ready to coincide with Tate Modern's opening. It is now due to open on June 8.

The Queen awarded Sir Anthony the Order of Merit, an honour which is within her personal gift.

fields.headline: Reluctant McCain endorses Bush
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: George W Bush squeezed a tepid endorsement yesterday from his defeated presidential rival, John McCain, but the two Republicans made it clear they remained far apart on the issues of campaign finance reform and taxation.
fields.body:
George W Bush squeezed a tepid endorsement yesterday from his defeated presidential rival, John McCain, but the two Republicans made it clear they remained far apart on the issues of campaign finance reform and taxation.

Two months after Mr McCain dropped out of a bitter Republican primary contest, he finally agreed to meet Mr Bush in Pittsburgh and, after an 80-minute encounter behind closed doors, offered to campaign "enthusiastically" for the Texas governor against Vice-President Al Gore, the Democratic contender.

However, the senator from Arizona betrayed little outward enthusiasm at a joint press conference at which body language was scrutinised in forensic detail for signs of healing of the Republican wounds left by the primaries.

Mr McCain had the delicate task of reassuring Republicans that he can be a team player while maintaining his identity as a reformer on campaign finance and an independent thinker on taxation, with the aim of leaving open the possibility of a presidential run in 2004 if Mr Bush fails this year.

The Vietnam war hero had been withholding a full endorsement, demanding that Mr Bush embrace greater regulation of corporate funding of political candidates and to reduce his proposed $460bn tax cut to leave more funds to bolster the social security system.

The Bush camp, however, pointed out that Mr McCain had won the support of only a tenth of the delegates to the Republican convention, and was not in a powerful bargaining position.

Reconciliation clearly did not come easily to the senator, who did not mouth the key word "endorse" until prompted by the press. Then he made a joke of it. "I endorse Governor Bush," he repeated six times in different tones of voice.

Mr Bush appeared ill-at-ease. "I spoke my mind and he spoke his, and that's good. That's the way I like my relationships," he said.

He supported his former rival's right to speak at the party convention in July - a key concession the McCain camp had been demanding, so that it could keep the reform flag flying.

However, the meeting represented a success for Mr Bush. He won the endorsement without granting any significant policy concessions. He stood to gain backing from McCain supporters in the north east, in swing states like Ohio and Pennsylvania.

Mr McCain has retained his political star quality. In a Gallup poll yesterday, he emerged as one of the most popular politicians in the US with a favourable rating from 72% of those questioned, better than both Mr Bush and Mr Gore.

The two men discussed Mr Bush's other possible running mates, including Elizabeth Dole, the Pennsylvania governor, Tom Ridge, Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee, and the Wisconsin governor, Tommy Thompson.

webTitle: I hate your guts - in a subtle way

fields.headline: I hate your guts - in a subtle way
fields.trailText: It is a feeling estate agents, lawyers, traffic wardens, and even in-laws experience with regularity: the suspicion that people dislike them - but they cannot quite pinpoint why.
fields.body:
It is a feeling estate agents, lawyers, traffic wardens, and even in-laws experience with regularity: the suspicion that people dislike them - but they cannot quite pinpoint why.

Until now, that is. New research has revealed 36 telltale signs which reveal whether someone really hates you. We may believe we are being subtle, but when we dislike someone it seems we cannot help but show it, the study reveals.

The evidence of our inability to mask our true feelings was unearthed by Jon Hess, of the University of Missouri-Columbia, when he analysed how we manage to maintain relationships with people we really do not like.

After questioning nearly 350 students on how they dealt with tricky, but unavoidable, family or work relationships, he found they used a variety of different ways to distance themselves.

At their most extreme, these involved putting people down or failing to acknowledge their presence, and, at their most subtle, avoiding eye contact or jokes and banter.

Professor Hess, assistant professor of communication at the university, said that, on average, each person disliked three others at any one time - but used between five and 10 ways of hiding this by distancing themselves.

The most common means of doing so were: being reserved by avoiding all intimate topics of conversation; not asking questions, so as to speed up any interaction; treating the other person as a stranger; physically avoiding them; not paying attention to them; and showing excessive politeness.

At work, people avoided face-to-face contact, and if possible used the telephone or sent memos and emails.

Prof Hess said it was perfectly possible for the person who was disliked to be unaware of provoking such antipathy.

People tried to maintain a facade of civility if they were forced into regular contact with those they disliked, but the stress of this led to distancing strategies.

Telltale signs of hostility

They avoid asking questions - to speed up communication

They lie - to avoid intimacy

They humour you, merely tolerating your behaviour

They give you the cold shoulder

Conversations are polite - but meaningless

Conversations are excessively polite - as though you are a stranger

They exclude you from conversations

They avoid joking with you

They speed up business - to get away quickly

They fail to pay you much attention

They avoid eye contact

They leave the room when you arrive

webTitle: Girl killed to act as drug mule in Gulf

fields.headline: Girl killed to act as drug mule in Gulf
fields.trailText: Drug smugglers abducted and killed a small girl, then stuffed her body with drugs in order to take them into a Gulf state, a senior police officer was reported as saying yesterday.
fields.body:
Drug smugglers abducted and killed a small girl, then stuffed her body with drugs in order to take them into a Gulf state, a senior police officer was reported as saying yesterday.

Officials at the unnamed airport saw a woman cradling the child in her arms, apparently asleep. As the woman passed through immigration control an officer teased the child, but there was no response. Then he realised she was dead.

Sympathy quickly turned to horror when officials discovered that the girl's body was packed with drugs. They concluded that she had been killed for the specific purpose of smuggling narcotics.

Major Abdul Rahman Naser al-Fardan, head of the drugs squad in Sharjah, one of the seven states in the oil-rich United Arab Emirates, was describing how smugglers are resorting to increasingly desperate and cruel measures to conceal their wares.

They have been known to pack drugs inside the Koran or in the frames of Islamic art. In one case a blind man had a white stick full of drugs.

The Gulf has long been recognised as a staging post for drugs on the route from Pakistan and Afghanistan to Europe. It is also believed by some to be a money-laundering centre for the proceeds.

In states where alcohol is prohibited and drugs offend social and religious sensibilities, the problem is officially portrayed as a foreign one. Asians are blamed for 80% of drug dealing and the authorities become coy at suggestions that part of the trade may be aimed at a local market.

The Emirates does, however, have several drug rehabilitation centres.

Although Major Fardan does not admit to a drug abuse problem in the Emirates, his remarks, in a talk to Zayed University students reported by Gulf News yesterday, highlighted concern that the rich - and often bored - Emirates youngsters could be at risk.

He warned that parents should not allow their children to travel alone to countries where drugs are sold openly, or which are known to have "addiction dens".

Drug abuse among wealthy Arabs tends to be hushed up, with offenders sent by their families for medical treatment. Smuggling and dealing, on the other hand, attract severe penalties. Executions are common in Saudi Arabia, and there have been several in Kuwait and the Emirates - though there the penalty depends on the type of drug and the amount involved.

Eman Abdullah, who reports on crime in Dubai, said the most common drug in the region is hashish. In Kuwait, opium is said to be popular.

The drug stuffed inside the child's body at the airport was codeine, a synthetic opium-related painkiller used medicinally in the west but not freely available in the Gulf. A spokeswoman for Release, the drug advice organisation, said: "It's quite a powerful painkiller and people can become dependent on it. In Britain there's a small black market. It might be used by addicts as a substitute for heroin."

Kuwait is the only Gulf state which publicly acknowledges that it has a drug problem. According to local press reports there are more than 29,000 drug addicts, in a population of 1.7m. Almost half of the 2,000 prisoners in the central jail are there for drugs offences.

fields.headline: Groping fashion chief gets £600,000 payoff
fields.standfirst: New Look chairman rejects claim of hidden agenda for executive's dismissal
fields.trailText: The chief executive of a high street fashion chain has been sacked with a £600,000 pay-off after he admitted touching a woman's bottom at a disco.
fields.body:
The chief executive of a high street fashion chain has been sacked with a £600,000 pay-off after he admitted touching a woman's bottom at a disco.

Jim Hodkinson, 56, left the New Look company this week with full benefits - a year's salary, bonus and a pension. But last night he said he had been harshly treated and should have been "rapped over the knuckles" and been told not to let anything similar happen again.

He also alleged that the board had had a hidden agenda and had used the incident as an excuse to oust him from a job he had held for two years.

"I was prepared to apologise but this is ridiculous," said Mr Hodkinson. "I have never had any disciplinary hearing against me and no allegation has ever been brought against me."

Mr Hodkinson arrived at New Look, which has more than 8,000 women employees working in its 500 stores, two years ago from B&Q and is reported to have earned £1m in his first year with the company, including a £300,000 joining payment.

He said he respected women and added: "I have been working with women through all my career. I regret the whole incident. I haven't tried to hide anything. I think they were hoping I would go away because I wouldn't want anyone to hear about this."

The incident happened on March 6 at an awards dinner held by Retail Week magazine. Mr Hodkinson, married for more than 30 years and a grandfather, said that he went up to the disco after the meal. While standing at the bar, he touched and commented on the bottom of one of his own employees and made another comment about a woman supplier.

"While I was chatting, I touched the girl on the bum and said 'Nice bum'. That was that. I made a comment to the other girl on the dance floor when we were all enjoying ourselves dancing away - I think it was to Abba.

"I don't know how many people there were on the dance floor but it was pretty packed. And that was it."

He claimed that one of the women was "worse for wear". "There was no slapping of the face to make me feel [my action] was not wanted," he added.

On April 25, Howard Dyer, New Look's chairman, confronted Mr Hodkinson with statements from the two women. The board, whose members include one woman, entered into lengthy deliberations about his future. At first they decided to dismiss Mr Hodkinson without compensation but eventually agreed to honour the terms of his contract.

"Following criticism of his conduct when representing the company at a social event in March, the board has formally reviewed the position of its chief executive, Jim Hodkinson," the company said in a statement.

"As a result Mr Hodkinson's employment has been terminated and he is leaving the board with immediate effect."

Mr Dyer described the loss of the chief executive as "a great shame". Mr Hodkinson's wife Jan dismissed the affair as "pathetic".

Mr Hodkinson's lawyers responded to the board's initial charges with a 23-page letter claiming their action was draconian and unlawful. "Late on Monday I heard that the board felt it was the end of the line and that I should go but I would be fully compensated.

"If I did what I was supposed to have done and it was so bad, why did they pay me compensation? ... I found it extraordinary that Mr Dyer had apologised to these two people without getting my side of the story ... He presumed I was guilty."

Yesterday Mr Dyer rejected Mr Hodkinson's claims of a hidden agenda and said the sacking decision had not been made because of a boardroom spat or disagreement.

"We do not welcome this and coming three weeks before our results come out, the timing for us is appalling. The last thing we wanted to do was change chief executive. The reality is that Jim wanted to stay with us."

Mr Dyer said he had no regrets about appointing Mr Hodkinson.

"He was absolutely the right chief executive. I am very surprised we have found ourselves in this situation. Jim is a very strong character, but I am surprised at these specific incidents."

fields.headline: Stabbed boy 'had been stalked'
fields.trailText: The boy aged 10 who was stabbed to death in central London was escorted to and from school to protect him from an alleged stalker, his headmaster said yesterday.
fields.body:
The boy aged 10 who was stabbed to death in central London was escorted to and from school to protect him from an alleged stalker, his headmaster said yesterday.

Diego Pineiro-Zillar died in hospital from multiple wounds after he and his half-brother, 15, were attacked in Earlham Street, Covent Garden, on Sunday evening.

A knife was found at the scene and a man aged 52 is being questioned by police in connection with the attack.

Yesterday Epegmenzio Rodriguez, headteacher of Canada Blanch, the independent Spanish school Diego attended on the Portobello Road in west London, said the school had tightened security after graffiti, written in white correcting fluid and declaring love for Diego, appeared at the school's entrance.

Speaking in the chapel of the Spanish-government-funded 400-pupil school, Mr Rodriguez said: "At the end of October we detected that Diego was having problems outside of school because someone was harassing him. As soon as we were aware of this we called the police and we contacted the family.

"Both the police and the family told us a person was being investigated because something had been going on.

"They told us there were adults or officials to make sure there was always a companion with Diego both to the school and from the school.

"A few weeks later we saw some graffiti at the school's entrance.

"We reported it to the police again because we knew this man had written this graffiti, and the police took some photos and gave us permission to delete it because they had the proof already.

"When this happened the police told us they had arrested a man and they had adopted some measures to prevent this man from coming near the school or near where Diego lived."

The last contact the school had with the police was at the end of December when more graffiti were found at the entrance.

But after that "nothing strange" had occurred near school premises.

Mr Rodriguez could not say when police measures were stopped.

But he said that he was "disappointed and sad" that the police had not informed him that the man was no longer under surveillance.

Diego's murder had devastated the school.

Classmates and friends yesterday gathered in the playground to sign a large Spanish flag with tributes to Diego.

One of the largest read: "From your pals at school. We will all miss you. Sleep with the angels."

The flag will be taken to the murder scene.

The headteacher added: "As all of you can imagine we are leading a very sad day because of the tremendous tragedy two days ago. Above all our first responsibility is helping our pupils to come to terms with this."

Today has been declared a day of mourning at Canada Blanch. No lessons will be held in the school and a religious service will take place.

Diego's half-brother, Roberto, a former pupil at the school, is still undergoing treatment in hospital.

webTitle: Easter disappearance that heralded three decades of heartache

fields.headline: Easter disappearance that heralded three decades of heartache
fields.trailText: For weeks after Susan Blatchford and her schoolfriend Gary Hanlon disappeared, a chocolate Easter egg decorated with tiny pink and yellow roses stood on the sideboard in her home awaiting her return.
fields.body:
For weeks after Susan Blatchford and her schoolfriend Gary Hanlon disappeared, a chocolate Easter egg decorated with tiny pink and yellow roses stood on the sideboard in her home awaiting her return.

The youngsters had gone missing just two days after Easter in 1970 and Susan's mother Muriel insisted that her daughter would walk in at any moment.

But as the weeks turned into months and no sign of the pair was found, the families' hopes began to fade of seeing the children alive again.

Even when their bodies were discovered on June 17, after a nationwide search involving hundreds of officers, led by Detective Chief Inspector Leonard "Nipper" Read, the celebrated officer who had brought the Kray twins to justice, the waiting was still not over.

The badly decomposed bodies could offer no evidence as to how they had died and the coroner, Dr Charles Clark, was forced to record an open verdict.

Now, just over 30 years later, the families have finally learned the details of their children's final hours and the identity of the man responsible for their deaths.

Ronald Jebson had kept his terrible secret for almost three decades.

As a paedophile with a string of offences living in the area where the children disappeared, he had been one of the 15,000 people questioned by police but he was able to give a full account of his movements on March 31. That account, he finally confessed from his prison cell in 1998, had been a pack of lies.

On the last day of her short life, Susan - a well-built girl with long brown hair who appeared much older than her 11 years - had been teaching her niece and nephew how to fly a kite in a nearby park.

At 4.30pm, she returned to her home in Riley Road in Enfield, north London, before calling at Gary's house in Marrilyne Avenue where he asked his mother if he could join her for a walk.

Susan, an outgoing tomboy, often played with her fellow pupil at Albany comprehensive school, in Enfield Highway. Gary, 12, was told to be back for his dinner in an hour's time and the pair were last seen walking down the road laughing hand in hand as Gary clutched his football under his arm.

Their parents contacted police at 8pm that night but were told simply to wait at home.

The police mounted a full scale search of Epping Forest, with more than 600 officers, including the special patrol group, frogmen, helicopters and sniffer dogs.

The bodies were eventually discovered 11 weeks later by Leonard Cook, then 20, whose labrador dog, Tessa, found the bodies huddled together in a den close to the pathway running across a small, densely wooded copse on the outskirts of Epping Forest - just a 30 minute walk from the youngsters' homes.

DCI Read broke the news to the families in person and within days the press tagged the deaths the "Babes in the Wood" case.

A heatwave had hastened decomposition of the bodies which had to be identified by their clothing. Gary's clothes - a brown cardigan, jumper and blue jeans - appeared to be undisturbed, except for his black plimsolls, which were found nearby.

But while Susan was still wearing her green raincoat with red stitched pockets, a floral patterned blouse and green corduroy trousers, her bra, knickers, stockings, socks and shoes had all been removed.

The discovery of the bodies was embarrassing for the police who had twice searched the copse with sniffer dogs but failed to find the bodies hidden in the deep undergrowth.

Jebson, born in August 1938 to an unmarried mother, had been adopted by John and Muriel Jebson when he was only a few months old.

Always a loner, he joined the army in 1958 but was discharged on medical grounds. In 1960 he enlisted again, but within months went absent without leave.

He claimed to have been rejected by his adoptive parents, and for many years reverted to his birth name of Harper.

Although he also claimed to have married and had a daughter now aged in her teens, no marriage or birth certificates have ever been found.

An alcoholic who abused amphetamines and other drugs, Jebson spent much of his adult life in an out of prison for a string of crimes, including three sex offences against children, and once told a prison psychologist that he was "afraid of himself" and that he had done "evil" over the years.

In December 1968, he was jailed for two years for indecently assaulting a six-year-old girl while she slept in her bedroom. After his release on March 2, 1970 he went to live with Robert Papper, an old school friend, and his young family in Hatfield.

Just 29 days after Jebson's release from prison in 1970, Gary and Susan disappeared.

Weeks later, in April, Jebson enticed a young boy from Retford, in Nottinghamshire, into his car, took him into the woods and sexually assaulted him, a crime for which he was jailed for five years in May that year.

When Jebson was released from prison in August 1973, he again returned to stay at the Pappers' home but, after being asked to leave the following year, he raped their eight-year-old daughter Rosemary, and strangled her with baling twine.

Susan, an outgoing tomboy, often played with her fellow pupil at Albany comprehensive school, in Enfield Highway. Gary, 12, was told to be back for his dinner in an hour's time and the pair were last seen walking down the road laughing hand in hand as Gary clutched his football under his arm. Their parents contacted police at 8pm that night but were told simply to wait at home. The police mounted a full scale search of Epping Forest, with more than 600 officers, including the special patrol group, frogmen, helicopters and sniffer dogs. The bodies were eventually discovered 11 weeks later by Leonard Cook, then 20, whose labrador dog, Tessa, found the bodies huddled together in a den close to the pathway running across a small, densely wooded copse on the outskirts of Epping Forest - just a 30 minute walk from the youngsters' homes. DCI Read broke the news to the families in person and within days the press tagged the deaths the "Babes in the Wood" case. A heatwave had hastened decomposition of the bodies which had to be identified by their clothing. Gary's clothes - a brown cardigan, jumper and blue jeans - appeared to be undisturbed, except for his black plimsolls, which were found nearby. But while Susan was still wearing her green raincoat with red stitched pockets, a floral patterned blouse and green corduroy trousers, her bra, knickers, stockings, socks and shoes had all been removed. The discovery of the bodies was embarrassing for the police who had twice searched the copse with sniffer dogs but failed to find the bodies hidden in the deep undergrowth. Jebson, born in August 1938 to an unmarried mother, had been adopted by John and Muriel Jebson when he was only a few months old. Always a loner, he joined the army in 1958 but was discharged on medical grounds. In 1960 he enlisted again, but within months went absent without leave. He claimed to have been rejected by his adoptive parents, and for many years reverted to his birth name of Harper. Although he also claimed to have married and had a daughter now aged in her teens, no marriage or birth certificates have ever been found. An alcoholic who abused amphetamines and other drugs, Jebson spent much of his adult life in an out of prison for a string of crimes, including three sex offences against children, and once told a prison psychologist that he was "afraid of himself" and that he had done "evil" over the years. In December 1968, he was jailed for two years for indecently assaulting a six-year-old girl while she slept in her bedroom. After his release on March 2, 1970 he went to live with Robert Papper, an old school friend, and his young family in Hatfield. Just 29 days after Jebson's release from prison in 1970, Gary and Susan disappeared. Weeks later, in April, Jebson enticed a young boy from Retford, in Nottinghamshire, into his car, took him into the woods and sexually assaulted him, a crime for which he was jailed for five years in May that year. When Jebson was released from prison in August 1973, he again returned to stay at the Pappers' home but, after being asked to leave the following year, he raped their eight-year-old daughter Rosemary, and strangled her with baling twine.

webTitle: Top universities in inner city drive

fields.headline: Top universities in inner city drive
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Elite universities will be "twinned" with inner city schools in a drive to increase their intake of students from poorer families, David Blunkett, the education secretary, will announce today.
fields.body:
Elite universities will be "twinned" with inner city schools in a drive to increase their intake of students from poorer families, David Blunkett, the education secretary, will announce today.

Bright students from less affluent areas often do not apply for or take up places at the top universities, even when their A-level grades and academic records warrant it, research shows.

Mr Blunkett will announce a drive to encourage poorer pupils to apply for places among the top layer of academic institutions. Teachers and parents also need to be engaged to help persuade students to apply, he believes.

Under the plan, backed by the institutions, university tutors will build up "twinning" relationships with teachers in inner city schools.

Mr Blunkett is expected to offer more money for bursaries for 16- and 17-year olds from poor backgrounds to attend summer schools at leading universities.

According to the Higher Education Funding Council, only 3,500 students from low income families get into Oxford, Cambridge, York, Bristol, Warwick, Nottingham, St Andrews, Edinburgh, Birmingham, Durham and, in London, Imperial and University Colleges and the London School of Economics. But by entry qualifications and subject mix, 4,600 should.

The Sutton Trust, a charity campaigning to reduce social inequality in education, says that someone from a private school is nearly 30 times more likely to get into a top 13 university than from a disadvantaged background.

The trust's summer school scheme is likely to be rewarded in the initiative, to be announced by Mr Blunkett at the Association of University Teachers' council meeting in Eastbourne.

"The access challenge is one that government and universities must face together," Mr Blunkett is expected to say.

"The key issue is that we need to address access in radically new ways if we are to improve take-up for those students who are able to benefit across all universities in line with their A-level achievements.

"The future of children should not be determined by where they live or where they went to school or college."

Tony Blair and Mr Blunkett announced last year that 5,000 16- and 17-year-olds from inner city areas would be offered the chance of a taste of university or college at 70 higher education institutions.

Bright students are being nominated by student co-ordinators appointed by local authorities in the £4m scheme.

Ministers deny that tuition fees and student loans discourage poorer students from applying to university.

But they believe there is a gap in expectation. Students who could win places at Oxbridge or other high ranking universities sometimes did not because they, their teachers or parents believed they were beyond their reach, the ministers said.

fields.headline: Monolingual workers 'cost Britain dear'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ministers will be urged today to introduce modern language teaching in all primary schools following the publication of a report criticising Britain's "deplorable monolingualism".
fields.body:
Ministers will be urged today to introduce modern language teaching in all primary schools following the publication of a report criticising Britain's "deplorable monolingualism".

A two year inquiry, headed by Sir Trevor MacDonald, the ITN newscaster, will call for an overhaul of language policy across all government departments, headed by a languages "tsar".

The education system is singled out as the root cause of the problem, where provision is "fragmented" and achievement "poorly measured". Languages should be considered a key skill alongside literacy, numeracy, and information and communications technology, the report, Languages: the next generation, will recommend.

The inquiry, funded by the Nuffield Foundation and co-chaired by Sir John Boyd, of Churchill College, Cambridge, will contrast the growing public awareness of the importance of languages with the chronic shortage in the UK workforce of people with useful language skills.

It will claim this is putting Britain at an economic disadvantage.

The report will call for measures such as an early start in language learning for all primary pupils, a boost in provision in secondary schools, the restoration of a languages requirement for entry to higher education, and a sustained promotional campaign by the government and by employers to give the next generation a clearer message about the value of languages.

It will urge the government to declare a long term commitment to early language learning by declaring a 10 year target to allow all pupils to learn a new language from the age of seven.

Funding should be provided for at least 100 "international primary schools" for parents who would like their child educated from the age of five through the medium of a new language - not just French.

The schools minister, Jacqui Smith, welcomed the findings. Specialist language colleges had doubled since 1997, while a quarter of all primary schools already offered languages.

From September, the qualifications and curriculum authority would provide schemes to assist teachers of eight to 11-year-olds who wanted to offer taster classes in languages. John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "Boosting provision at secondary level would be very difficult given the current shortage of specialist teachers. And there are few people at primary level who are qualified to teach languages."

The report will also criticise the tourism industry. Two thirds of the 25m tourists who visit the UK each year come from countries whose first language is not English, and yet the British travel and tourism industry still depends largely on customers taking the trouble to learn English, in what was described as "a scandalous picture".

And in new technology, the report will claim that while the number of English speaking internet users is expected to rise by 60%, the number of non-English-speaking users will mushroom by 150%.

webTitle: 'Babes in Wood' murderer gets two life terms

fields.headline: 'Babes in Wood' murderer gets two life terms
fields.standfirst: Thirty year police hunt for the killer of two schoolfriends ends after paedophile's confession
fields.trailText: A paedophile was branded "wicked and perverted" by an Old Bailey judge yesterday after he pleaded guilty to the "Babes in the Wood" murders of two young children 30 years ago.
fields.body:
A paedophile was branded "wicked and perverted" by an Old Bailey judge yesterday after he pleaded guilty to the "Babes in the Wood" murders of two young children 30 years ago.

Ronald Jebson, 61, was given two life sentences for the murders of Susan Blatchford, 11, and her schoolfriend Gary Hanlon, 12, in March 1970.

His confession brings to an end a 30-year police investigation involving more than 600 officers who interviewed 14,272 people and searched 4,356 houses and 5,000 acres of woodland.

Jebson, who is already serving a life sentence for raping and strangling to death an eight-year-old girl in 1974, claimed he did not want to die with the two murders on his conscience.

But Detective Chief Inspector Declan Donnelly, who headed the recently reopened murder investigation, described Jebson as a "highly dangerous, fixated, sadistic paedophile" who would kill again if released. He said that Jebson may also have been involved in other unsolved crimes.

The widowed mothers of both children, Beryl Hanlon, 66, and Muriel Blatchford, 79, wept as they heard about their children's last hours, during which they were plied with alcohol, raped and sexually assualted before being strangled.

Despite a nationwide police search for the children, their decomposed bodies were not discovered for 11 weeks in a small copse on the fringes of Epping Forest.

The causes of death could not be established and the coroner recorded an open verdict. The case was not reopened until 1996 when Jebson first admitted involvement.

He eventually made a full confession in August 1998, leading to the exhumation of Susan's body for a second postmortem examination.

Sentencing Jebson, Judge David Stokes told him: "Thirty years ago you abducted, sexually assaulted and brutally murdered two young children.

"What they went through before they died does not bear thinking about. The only point on your behalf is that you finally owned up to what you did which caused a small degree of comfort to their close relatives who are here to see justice done.

"You are a truly wicked and perverted man."

Now white-haired with a pony-tail and beard, Jebson showed no emotion as he was led back to the cells, flanked by three guards.

The families of the two children described Jebson as a "monster" and pleaded with the home secretary, Jack Straw, to leave him to die in prison so no more children would be at risk from him.

Jebson, who has 11 previous convictions including three for sexual offences against youngsters, admitted to prison psychologists that he was "evil" and was especially dangerous to children, saying: "If I get a few drinks and poppers, nothing would stop me."

webTitle: Steering the company towards a better future

fields.headline: Steering the company towards a better future
fields.standfirst:
Men in the driving seat

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: John Towers will now become known as the man who saved Rover. Yet in 1995, he resigned as chief executive over disagreements with the German owners, BMW.
fields.body:
John Towers will now become known as the man who saved Rover. Yet in 1995, he resigned as chief executive over disagreements with the German owners, BMW.

With a degree in mechanical engineering, Mr Towers, 52, joined Rover in the late 1980s and became product development director and engineering director. With Mr Towers at the helm, Rover's balance sheet went from a £49m loss to profits of £92m.

After quitting Rover, Mr Towers took over as chief executive of Concentric, an engineering business based at Sutton Coldfield in the West Midlands. The company made a pre-tax profit of £10.72m in 1996 but posted losses in the three years after that. - Press Association

Tony Woodley has proved over Rover that he is a formidable campaigner. The T&G transport union's automotive secretary lobbied ministers, harangued BMW, encouraged Phoenix and kept the workforce united. Longbridge is the second car plant Mr Woodley has helped to save, after the rescue of the threatened Ford Halewood plant three years ago. He is tipped as a potential successor to Bill Morris.

Geoffrey Robinson, 61, was the government's Mr Fixit until he resigned as paymaster general shortly before Christmas 1998 over his £373,000 home loan to Peter Mandelson, who also quit.

A former chief executive of Jaguar cars, the MP for Coventry North West knows the motor industry inside out.

He also made and lost a £30m fortune by building up the engineering firm TransTec only to see it crash last year.

He has remained close to Gordon Brown, the chancellor, and is still on good terms with Tony Blair.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: In the aftermath of elections, all too often it's a case of "what if?" What, for example, if Jim Callaghan had called an election in October, 1978 - would he have won and spared us Mrs Thatcher? But not only the big boys are plagued by these intangibles.
fields.body:
In the aftermath of elections, all too often it's a case of "what if?" What, for example, if Jim Callaghan had called an election in October, 1978 - would he have won and spared us Mrs Thatcher? But not only the big boys are plagued by these intangibles. Spare a thought for Alick Smithers, father of our education correspondent Rebecca, who is asking himself this: what if I'd known before the vote that I was the Lib Dem candidate for the Hartshill and Penkhull ward in Stoke-on-Trent? After letting his name be used as a place-holder on election nominations until a proper candidate was found, Alick was amazed on reaching the polling booth to see he was running for office. In spite of his no-profile campaign, he came third with an impressive 560 votes (26%), and thinks it might have been better if the local Lib Dems had rung and let him in on the secret in advance. "But I'm tolerant of human error," he says. And what if he'd won? "I'm ashamed to say," says Alick, "that I might well have had a go".

Perhaps there's a lesson in Alick's novel campaigning technique for Oliver de Peyer. Using conventional methods Oliver stood for Labour in Winchester's Sparsholt ward in 1998, and was edged into third place scoring seven votes. Last week Oliver stood again in the Shedfield ward, and picked up seven votes again (enough this time, alas, only for fourth). "No, I'm not disappointed at all," says Oliver. "I do feel that there are seven people who were enfranchised by my standing." Well said. Any Labour group in London (where Oliver now lives) that prizes consistency above all may contact him via the Diary.

And so to the matter I was too shocked for yesterday. A letter has arrived from the Metropolitan police, starkly headed "notice of intended prosecution", referring to a recent speeding offence ("supported by photographic evidence") in the BMW 328i I was kind enough to borrow, in the dark days long before Phoenix came along when the Hun needed all the good publicity he could get. And now that same BMW has grassed me up to the Old Bill. I was planning to report my colleague Richard Adams's dramatic conversation with BMW press office Jo Slater, but frankly I'm still too upset, and will have to return to the matter tomorrow.

I am surprised to read that, following a complaint from Alastair Campbell, BBC news chief Roger Mosey has apologised for an item about the alternative health therapist who's been helping Cherie during her pregnancy. Since Bharti Vyas and her dealings with Cherie have featured in various newspapers without a word from Downing Street, you must assume this is less a matter of "privacy" than of trying to soften up the notoriously nervous BBC in the run up to an election. It's a very old, tiresome game, and while Mr Mosey is free to apologise if he chooses, he might find that telling Alastair to sod off and stop wasting his time makes him look less of a drongo.

At the Express, my old friend Rizla Rosie Boycott is on cracking form. "First and foremost, newspapers have a duty to their readers," reads a pompous leader on page 10. "They must never dupe them or treat them like fools." How true. On the facing page, page 11, the banner headline reads: "Is there really any need for women to wear knickers?" Either something a little less gutsy in the pipe, Rosie, I'm begging you, or more tobacco with it.

Meanwhile, a vacancy is advertised in Hounslow council's latest Job Search newsletter. "Incontinent Laundry Driver required," it reads, to work a 36 hour week at £5.74 per hour. "You will have excellent customer facing skills, and ability to organise yourself and be able to prioritise workload on a daily basis." A clean licence is required. Ah yes, a clean licence, I remember that...

webTitle: Five Ulster bases to close in army wind-down

fields.headline: Five Ulster bases to close in army wind-down
fields.standfirst:
Demilitarisation will be rapid if IRA keeps pledge on arms

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the RUC chief constable, last night announced that five military installations in Northern Ireland were to soon to close, signalling the first steps in a rapid demilitarisation provided the IRA sticks to its pledge to place its weapons in sealed arms dumps.
fields.body:
Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the RUC chief constable, last night announced that five military installations in Northern Ireland were to soon to close, signalling the first steps in a rapid demilitarisation provided the IRA sticks to its pledge to place its weapons in sealed arms dumps.

Army bases at Cookstown, Co Tyrone, and at Fort George in Londonderry are expected to be demolished, and soldiers are to pull out of two Belfast lookout posts, both in republican areas.

A partially operational border checkpoint at Cloghogue, near Newry, is also to go.

But Sir Ronnie confounded earlier reports when he indicated a lookout post in Crossmaglen, in the heart of republican South Armagh, would be retained for at least three months.

It would then be demolished if he was convinced the security threat was decreasing.

The anti-agreement Democratic Unionist Party was furious. It claims Sir Ronnie is being forced to act as a stooge of the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, to keep the IRA on board

The DUP leader, Ian Paisley, who accused the government of betrayal, is expected to meet Tony Blair in Downing Street today.

He was turned away when he arrived at Hillsborough Castle on Friday.

Troop levels, standing at about 14,000 in Northern Ireland, the lowest in almost 30 years, will be unaffected in the move. But a further planned review in August is expected to lead to substantial cuts.

The shutting of Fort George, the target of a recent failed dissident republican attack, means that for the first time since the troubles began, the city's nationalist west bank will be without a military base. Republicans welcomed the moves last night.

They are the latest of the choreographed steps which Mr Mandelson hopes will lead to the restoration of devolution on May 22. They may include a minor concession to Ulster Unionists on the RUC's name.

David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, is still taking a cautious approach to the IRA's statement.

But he is expected to come out strongly in favour of the deal before his ruling party council meets a week on Saturday to decide on a return to government.

Mr Mandelson said: "I have always said that the security of the public will continue to be my highest priority and that essential security interests will not be traded for political progress.

"The further review of normalisation to be conducted in three months time will take account of the threat and conditions on the ground at that time."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Suicide Kings
fields.body:
Suicide Kings

(Peter O'Fallon, 1997)

10pm, Sky MovieMax

A group of rich college boys decide on a not very wise plan: the sister of one of their gang has been kidnapped and the ransom has been set at $2 million, so they kidnap New York crime boss Christopher Walken, chop his finger off, and demand that he raise the ransom. Needless to say, it doesn't take long for Walken to outwit these amateurs, and all hell breaks loose. The film doesn't start out promisingly at all but through a series of twists and turns it takes on a character of its own.

The Last Supper

(Stacy Title, 1995)

10.30pm, FilmFour

Sharp little indie comedy about a group of PC housemates who start knocking off objectionable dinner guests and burying them in the garden. Cameron Diaz and Annabeth Gish are among the five who, having debated whether they would have assassinated Hitler in 1919, start the cull, beginning with redneck Bill Paxton, in a memorable cameo. Nora Dunn is the cop who grows suspicious of all the digging out back.

Exterminating Angel

(Luis Buñuel, 1962)

12.10am, FilmFour

More mealtime mayhem. The bourgeoisie gather for a dinner party and are having a lovely time, until they realise that some strange force is preventing them going home. That force is, of course, the surrealist Buñuel, who having rudely interrupted the party, presides over the collapse of civilisation, as all etiquette flies out the dining room window. Brilliantly black comedy.

The Wings Of The Dove

(Iain Softley, 1997)

2.10am, Sky Premier

Softley and scriptwriter Hossein Amini create a modern romantic drama out of the Henry James novel. Set in Edwardian London and Venice, it has Helena Bonham Carter remaking her Merchant-Ivory image: as well-to-do Kate, she is involved in an affair with lowly Merton (Linus Roache), and is prepared to act disgracefully to keep both him and her position in society. Alison Elliott plays her unfortunate friend; Elizabeth McGovern, Charlotte Rampling and Michael Gambon are high-class support.

fields.headline: 'Yes, I adored him'
fields.trailText: It was, maybe, mere happenstance that Vronsky, the dashing cavalry officer for whom Anna Karenina abandoned her dry stick of a husband, her son and her social position, had a distinct look of James Hewitt. Not that I am a great believer in happenstance. Underneath Anna's words, you seemed to hear the subterranean ripple of "Yes, I adored him! Yes, I was in love with him! But I was very let down."
fields.body:
It was, maybe, mere happenstance that Vronsky, the dashing cavalry officer for whom Anna Karenina abandoned her dry stick of a husband, her son and her social position, had a distinct look of James Hewitt. Not that I am a great believer in happenstance. Underneath Anna's words, you seemed to hear the subterranean ripple of "Yes, I adored him! Yes, I was in love with him! But I was very let down."

This version of Anna Karenina (Channel 4), like most recent classic serials, was highly spiced with sex. Even the opening titles rolled over some naked panting, which turned out to be merely Levin doing his morning push-ups. Anna and Vronsky's lovemaking, all flying clothes and whirling, dismembered limbs, was like a head-on train crash, or like their first, fatal waltz, accelerated to destruction.

The very name of Anna Karenina has a galloping rhythm, dactyls being commonly used for hoofbeats. Not only is Vronsky (Kevin McKidd) dashing, Anna (Helen McCrory) is headlong too. Like the steeplechase where Vronsky breaks his mare's back with reckless riding, you can only wait for the pistol shot.

The role has attracted great beauties. First Garbo, then Vivien Leigh, who had the looks but, as Gielgud once said of her Cleopatra, hadn't quite got the guns for it. Helen McCrory has a vivid little face, verging on perkiness, but there is no sound of gunfire yet. Curiously, it is secondary characters like Levin (Douglas Henshall) with his frank, open-fire face and the corpse-like Karenin (Stephen Dillane) who catch your attention. Karenin's smile was amiable to the point of idiocy until Anna blurted out "I love him. I'm his mistress. I hate you. I can't bear you", and then all smiling stopped.

And now, before you go, can you explain how Anna and Vronsky managed to take a bath together in an unplumbed tub? In my view, the arrival of a batman with a bucket of water is often inimical to romance.

Anna Karenina is, however, much more beautiful and watchable than anything else on offer at the same time. Fish (BBC1), for instance, seems actually insane. Last night's case about a transexual suing for sexual discrimination was redeemed only by Jemma Redgrave, long-legged like all the Redgraves, pointing out her collection of videos with her bare foot. It reminded me of Mrs Patrick Campbell who, according to Shaw, could thread a needle with her toes.

My Secret Life (C4) was scheduled, like a railway timetable, to connect with the passengers disembarking from Anna Karenina, both touching on the underbelly of Victorian propriety. It was about the engrossing diaries of an educated Victorian gentleman, who (as the Duchess of Beaufort said of Edward VII) was by no stretch of the imagination a gentleman. He called himself Walter and why, you wonder, would any sane man do that? He evidently suffered some form of satyriasis, compulsively buying and enjoying sex with prostitutes, domestic servants, agricultural labourers, children and recording it all. Walter flourished at much the same time as Jack the Ripper and his identity is just as conjectural. This dramatised documentary suggested that he may have been Henry Ashby, a silk merchant and Europe's foremost collector of erotica.

An unexpected gust of fresh air in this steaminess was Ashby's granddaughter, Felicity, brisk, mittened and in her 80s. It was as though someone had opened a window. She looks after Ashby's papers and read the livelier bits with gusto ("Isn't that extraordinary!") She said "I've often wondered what brought his wife to actually leaving him, because it was so very unusual. She walked out of the family home with the two unmarried daughters. Could it be that she had suddenly discovered all this pornographic interest?" She herself was superlatively unfazed by her grandfather's interests ("Who is one to judge?") At which point, of course, we cut to a judge, who thought otherwise.

My own great grandfather, a Victorian mill-owner naturally, was followed to his grave by a carriage full of whores. "And", as my grandmother said, never varying the story by a syllable, "no man raised his hat as they passed."

The phasing out of hats, I often think, has deprived us of several useful gestures.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What church-goers are watching on television
fields.trailText: Keith Bernard: "I'm not such an avid TV watcher as a TV listener. I like to have it on in the background when I'm pottering about the house. My son used to go to school with Martin Clunes, you know. I've seen Men Behaving Badly before, and I think it's rubbish. It's not my sort of humour, I'm more of a caveperson when it comes to that. I like Morecambe And Wise."
fields.body:
Keith Bernard: "I'm not such an avid TV watcher as a TV listener. I like to have it on in the background when I'm pottering about the house. My son used to go to school with Martin Clunes, you know. I've seen Men Behaving Badly before, and I think it's rubbish. It's not my sort of humour, I'm more of a caveperson when it comes to that. I like Morecambe And Wise."

Sheila Bernard: "If I have one TV hero then it has to be Jane McDonald. I think that's a lovely success story, don't you? I always watched The Boat. I have a lot of cats, and I always wonder whether they watch TV or not, because a friend of mine has a Persian who is entranced by TV. I also like watching Friends and I do pop in to my daughter's to see ER, because we both rather like George Clooney."

Rhys L Williams: "No, I don't really watch the Sunday morning programmes a lot, the religious ones, they're not really my type of thing. I will go to church on Sunday, but I'm more likely listening to the radio. I sometimes go round to my sister's because she's now got Digital TV and she has that on all the time. I always joke with her, if God had wanted us to have all this television he wouldn't have invented legs with which I can walk to the pub."

Audrey Ross: "It seems to me that television has lost its golden age. I remember the first broadcasts and sitting round a set that the neighbours in our street had, goggle-eyed at the sight of this amazing thing. My mum would bake a cake and we'd munch away. They've changed it now, it's not a public service anymore, even the BBC. Too much advertising and sponsorship. Last thing I watched? That Shakespeare TV drama - on at Easter. Neil Morrissey was in it. He played a coach driver having problems with his marriage. I can't say I liked him, no. It would have, hih!, been better if I'd had some of that old cake to eat while watching it."

Sin Pattenden spoke to people around Tewkesbury Abbey, Gloucestershire.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The belief that the industrialised world will be overwhelmed by millions of old people is dismissed as nonsense by Phil Mullan, a guest of Laurie Taylor in Thinking Allowed (4.0pm, Radio 4). Phil Mullan argues that the "problem" is being viewed wrongly. People are certainly living longer, but the balance in the generations has shifted because there is also a drop in the birth rate. Economically, he maintains, it just means shifting resources from those not being born to those gamely battling on with life.
fields.body:
The belief that the industrialised world will be overwhelmed by millions of old people is dismissed as nonsense by Phil Mullan, a guest of Laurie Taylor in Thinking Allowed (4.0pm, Radio 4). Phil Mullan argues that the "problem" is being viewed wrongly. People are certainly living longer, but the balance in the generations has shifted because there is also a drop in the birth rate. Economically, he maintains, it just means shifting resources from those not being born to those gamely battling on with life.

There's an almost instant riposte from the final presenter of The Reith Lectures 2000 (8.0pm, Radio 4). Dr Vandana Shiva argues that globalisation can't possibly generate the necessary transferable assets for the Third World. Rather it will convert poor people's natural resources into corporate property. Their survival as primary producers will be further threatened by free trade treaties which allow entry of artificially cheap and unnecessary Western commodities.

fields.headline: The oldest singer in town
fields.standfirst: Otello is one of the hardest roles in the opera repertoire. How would the great 75-year-old tenor Carlo Bergonzi fare, singing it for the first time?  Martin Kettle reports
fields.trailText: Otello is one of the hardest roles in the opera repertoire. How would the great 75-year-old tenor Carlo Bergonzi fare, singing it for the first time?
fields.body:
When the Three Tenors all attend a concert, but only as part of the audience, then you know that something special is going on. And indeed, ever since the word got out that the revered tenor Carlo Bergonzi planned to sing his first and only performance of Verdi's Otello in New York at the age of 75 this month, seats for the Carnegie Hall event have been opera's hottest ticket of the year.

It seemed incredible that a singer who quit the operatic stage more than a decade ago and who is at an age where even the most carefully preserved voice is a shadow of its former glory could still have the drive and the resources to undertake one of the most demanding roles in the operatic repertoire for the first time. Yet Bergonzi never did anything lightly. Throughout a career that began nearly 50 years ago, he was always disciplined, preserving an unequalled vocal technique by not straying beyond his range, which was mainly Verdi. If anyone could do a first Otello at 75, then perhaps he could.

A few months ago, the word from Milan was that the incredible was happening. Bergonzi was deep in study of the score. He had even gone back to Verdi's villa near Parma to study the composer's own manuscript. Tentative enquiries from New York as to whether the great singer would prefer to sing the role transposed down - as even Placido Domingo now does - were met with a disdainful reply that Bergonzi intended to do the role "tutto in tona".

Reports from the dress rehearsal increased the expectations. "Bergonzi is thrilling," the conductor Eve Queler reported to the press. "To think that this man could accomplish this at 75 is indeed a miracle," said New York opera buff Ed Rosen.

That afternoon, straight after the rehearsal, I spoke to Bergonzi in his hotel overlooking Central Park. He oozed charm, discoursing authoritatively on Verdi and the tenor voice, breaking into song, in that long-remembered voice, to make a point.

"I accepted the challenge voluntarily, with happiness and joy," he said of Otello. "After the rehearsal, many of the orchestra players said to me, 'Today we heard the Otello of Verdi for the first time.' That is all I want. All that I want is to do the best that I can and leave this as a last memory of a great career."

Not surprisingly, the atmosphere at Carnegie Hall on the night of the concert was electric. Ticketless opera fans milled around on 57th Street hoping for returns. The hall was packed. The great ones were there for the occasion. Pavarotti, Domingo and Carreras sat together in a box, drawing all eyes. James Levine arrived just as the doors were closing.

As Queler launched her Opera Orchestra of New York into Otello's stormy opening, expectations could not have been higher. The side door opened and, to a smattering of excited applause, the familiar portly figure entered, marched to the front of the stage and delivered the Esultate, perhaps the most famous opening lines in the tenor repertoire.

It was immediately apparent that there was something wrong. A grainy tone in the voice inhibited everything. Bergonzi strained audibly in an unsuccessful attempt to reach the high A that caps the triumphant entry phrase. As he walked off the stage again, one wondered what he must be saying under his breath.

This underlying tension - so different from the glory days - lasted throughout act one. Bergonzi seemed in permanent danger of singing slightly flat, and would cup his left hand to his ear to help him stabilise any projected or exposed tone. The love duet, even with Kallen Esperian at her best, was strangely subdued. You could feel the audience willing him on, but maybe the expectations had made him too nervous.

In retrospect, people said at the evening's end, maybe Bergonzi should have called it a day at that point, should have made his own announcement that he had tried, should have acknowledged that it was not working, and craved the audience's understanding for a situation they would have been only too willing to understand, however great their disappointment.

But Bergonzi pressed on. Perhaps he felt that he owed it to himself, perhaps to the public. Perhaps he felt that he could sing his way through his difficulties and reclaim the old authority as the opera developed.

If so, it was not to be. There was, though, one truly wonderful moment, where technique and musicianship came together in a passage of great vocal art. In the Ora e per sempre addio ("now and forever farewell), Otello begins to understand that his glories are behind him. Normally, in defiance of the score, Otellos tend to go stentorian here. Not Bergonzi. As he told me beforehand, this passage is reflective. Verdi wrote it to be sung mostly softly, with a covered tone, rather than the big open sound that most tenors adopt.

As the emotional temperature rose through act two, with Alberto Gazale an increasingly imposing Iago, Bergonzi seemed to struggle more and more. He was using his great art to try to conceal his difficulties, not illuminate his insights. Anything exposed was a high-wire act, and too often he slipped from the wire. By the end of act two, he looked an old man.

When an official came on to the platform at the start of act three, we all knew what she was about to say. "Mr Bergonzi is indisposed and will not continue his performance." Antonio Barasorda stood in, and did a good job in difficult circumstances.

And so Carlo Bergonzi's great operatic career came to a sad, humbled end. The Bergonzi Otello was a grand dream, but it was not to be. The miracle of the ageless tenor did not happen. Only those who were at the dress rehearsal know how he sang Dio mi potevi, or the death scene. But at least, and perhaps appropriately, some of us also have the memory of his singing of Ora e per sempre addio.
