In retrospect, people said at the evening's end, maybe Bergonzi should have called it a day at that point, should have made his own announcement that he had tried, should have acknowledged that it was not working, and craved the audience's understanding for a situation they would have been only too willing to understand, however great their disappointment. But Bergonzi pressed on. Perhaps he felt that he owed it to himself, perhaps to the public. Perhaps he felt that he could sing his way through his difficulties and reclaim the old authority as the opera developed. If so, it was not to be. There was, though, one truly wonderful moment, where technique and musicianship came together in a passage of great vocal art. In the Ora e per sempre addio ("now and forever farewell), Otello begins to understand that his glories are behind him. Normally, in defiance of the score, Otellos tend to go stentorian here. Not Bergonzi. As he told me beforehand, this passage is reflective. Verdi wrote it to be sung mostly softly, with a covered tone, rather than the big open sound that most tenors adopt. As the emotional temperature rose through act two, with Alberto Gazale an increasingly imposing Iago, Bergonzi seemed to struggle more and more. He was using his great art to try to conceal his difficulties, not illuminate his insights. Anything exposed was a high-wire act, and too often he slipped from the wire. By the end of act two, he looked an old man. When an official came on to the platform at the start of act three, we all knew what she was about to say. "Mr Bergonzi is indisposed and will not continue his performance." Antonio Barasorda stood in, and did a good job in difficult circumstances. And so Carlo Bergonzi's great operatic career came to a sad, humbled end. The Bergonzi Otello was a grand dream, but it was not to be. The miracle of the ageless tenor did not happen. Only those who were at the dress rehearsal know how he sang Dio mi potevi, or the death scene. But at least, and perhaps appropriately, some of us also have the memory of his singing of Ora e per sempre addio.

fields.headline: Sound of silence
fields.trailText: Has Beethoven's exuberant Ninth Symphony ever been greeted by an audience with complete silence before? Surely not, and probably it never will be so again. But then Sunday's performance from the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra under Sir Simon Rattle, in the quarry of the Mauthausen death camp, was unlike any other.
fields.body:
Has Beethoven's exuberant Ninth Symphony ever been greeted by an audience with complete silence before? Surely not, and probably it never will be so again. But then Sunday's performance from the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra under Sir Simon Rattle, in the quarry of the Mauthausen death camp, was unlike any other.

Sunday was the 55th anniversary of the liberation of Mauthausen, the deep quarry in Upper Austria where 100,000 victims of the Nazis perished, and this was a unique performance in which the layers of meaning and significance were almost infinite. As the Austrian president Thomas Klestil, speaking before the symphony, put it, the nation is still wrestling with the need for "remembrance, acceptance and watchfulness".

Before the Beethoven, a Viennese cantor sang the Kaddish prayer of mourning. Two hours later, as the last echoes of Beethoven's setting of Schiller's Ode to Joy faded, Rattle and an audience of more than 20,000 people rose quietly and lit candles, before standing in silence for what felt like minutes on end. Then the orchestra, the chorus, and the audience - which included survivors, liberators and their families - shuffled wordlessly out of the quarry. Many spontaneously placed their candles on the rock ledges of the quarry. Others constructed little clusters of remembrance in the dusty ground.

"No concert in the history of the Vienna Philharmonic has been discussed as intensively," the violinist Clemens Hellsberg told the audience. The debate about whether this concert should go ahead in Austria's new political situation, has absorbed Vienna for weeks, and was still at full tilt in Austria's weekend newspapers. Televised live around the country, the Mauthausen memorial was not so much a concert, more a journey of the Austrian soul.

Judged in strictly musical terms, which clearly it should not be, Rattle and the Vienna Philharmonic's performance at Mauthausen at first fell a little short of the exceptional standards they had set for themselves on Sunday morning in a performance in Vienna's Musikverein. Not until the adagio, played with a hymn-like cantabile that was utterly appropriate to the place and moment, did the Philharmonic master the inevitably difficult acoustics of playing in a rock-walled quarry, to say nothing of the emotions of the occasion.

The earlier performance, in the orchestra's familiar acoustic, was as dramatically and emotionally powerful as any that one could expect to hear in the modern era. It seemed to say everything that needed to be said, not just about the propriety of pitting Beethoven against the Holocaust, but about the necessity of it. It made one proud of the role that Rattle has played in the events of the past weekend: he got it right, politically as well as musically.

But this was one of those occasions where it makes no sense to separate the purely musical from the wider humanistic affirmation. The presence among the soloists of the severely physically disabled bass Thomas Quasthoff and the black American tenor Vinson Cole was eloquent even before they began to sing. Under the Nazis, both of these men would have been victims too.

Inescapably, this was a self-conscious performance on all sides. To perform in Mauthausen raises difficult questions which the orchestra members were still debating on the bus back to Vienna. "A painful experience," Hellsberg called it in his speech, but it was one that the Philharmonic, which itself had a guilty past during the Nazi years, was right to confront.

Those who feared, or perhaps even hoped, that the Mauthausen event would stumble under the weight that it has come to bear in recent weeks, will in the end have been disappointed. There were no disruptions, no false notes of any kind, and there were none of the potential embarrassments which even the organisers were clearly fearing when they and Rattle faced a difficult press conference in Vienna the previous morning.

In the event, the unrepeatable Mauthausen concert justified the determination of the two principal organisers, Hellsberg and the Viennese Jewish community leader Leon Zelman, that it should go ahead in spite of all the controversy. There can be little doubt that the final verdict on the Mauthausen Memorial event is that the decent people have done some good. In Austria, as elsewhere, that is surely its own vindication.

webTitle: 'I love dancing, I love music. I go to a lot of parties'

fields.headline: 'I love dancing, I love music. I go to a lot of parties'
fields.standfirst: Simon Hattenstone  meets Richard Wilson - TV star, director and raver
fields.trailText: Richard Wilson is pacing up and down a north London ballroom, eyes to the floor. He seems to have flicked into interview mode - intense, self-conscious. He's dreading the photo session. He tells me of the time he saw a photo of a desiccated old man who looked at least 100 on the front of a magazine and thought, who the hell is that? Then he realised it was him.
fields.body:
Richard Wilson is pacing up and down a north London ballroom, eyes to the floor. He seems to have flicked into interview mode - intense, self-conscious. He's dreading the photo session. He tells me of the time he saw a photo of a desiccated old man who looked at least 100 on the front of a magazine and thought, who the hell is that? Then he realised it was him. No, he didn't think it was funny. He looks out of the window and points to a distant building hidden by trees. "That's my flat," he says. "This is the nearest a journalist ever gets to my flat."

Wilson is best known as the grumpy old git from the long-running BBC comedy One Foot in the Grave. While the marketeers and strategic planners were telling telly executives the public wanted young, firm flesh starring in ever-so-cool projects, the unlikely Victor Meldrew drew bigger and bigger crowds until he was the biggest thing on telly. He hated change, hated getting old, and for some strange reason young people loved him. But there's a lesser-known Wilson: the avant-garde theatre director who only takes on embryonic works and nurtures them into existence.

Today he's at the Aslef ballroom in Hampstead to rehearse a new play for the Royal Court. Mr Kolpert, written by David Gieselmann, has never been performed before and reads like a jamming session between Pinter, Beckett and Quentin Tarantino.

We wander off through the streets, looking for coffee and bagels. A woman in a shop throws him a wide, knowing smile, which he returns. Must be an old friend. Who is she? "I don't know. I pass the shop quite a lot. I wave back if people wave to me."

He talks about the years before he was a professional actor when he worked as a laboratory technician, first in Scotland then in London. "I used to have to take blood samples so a lot of people thought I was a doctor. I used to explain I wasn't, then it took so much time I didn't bother. Hello! Very well, thank you." Another attractive young woman, another familiar smile. He says he's never seen her in his life.

When people see celebrities in the street they tend to nudge each other, or stare, or shout after they've passed. With Wilson, they simply say hello. Strangers accept him as an everyday part of life - old miseryguts who sits in the corner of the room with the telly. "The extraordinary thing about One Foot in the Grave is that it's young people, children, who write to me." Do they tell him he's a horrible old man? "No, they don't. By and large, they think Victor is very funny. I think what they like about him is that he says the things that kids want to say. He speaks out. Helloooo! "

Wilson, 63, has an ambivalent relationship with Meldrew. He detested the fact that he had been asked to play a pensioner when he was in his early 50s. He had never liked his appearance and this was the last straw. On the other hand, he says the writing is wonderful and it has made his fortune.

I tell him my mum wants to know if he's as conservative as his voice and manner suggest. He looks at me, appalled, and repeats the word, sucking hard on the syllables then spitting them out. " Con-ser-va-tive ? I'm really upset that she thinks I'm conservative. I think your mother's been listening to the wrong rumours."

Politically, Wilson has in fact been a Labour party member for decades, and old Labour at that. He supported Ken Livingstone as mayor of London until he realised it would cost him his party membership.

I tell him I've heard that when he escapes Victor he's a right little raver, dancing and drugging the nights away. This seems to cheer him up. "I'm not going to tell you what kind of raver I am. He-he-he." He laughs like a slow-motion sneeze. "When I get to a party I dance, provided I've got enough alcohol in me. I love dancing, I love music. Tell your mother I like parties. I go to a lot of parties."

Wilson advocates the legalisation of cannabis, which he says is a great relaxant for rehearsals. But he says alcohol has been the most liberating factor in his life, that as a teenager and a young man he was rigid with Presbyterian inhibitions. "There's no doubt about it: if it wasn't for alcohol I'd still be a lab tech in Greenock." He has three dry days a week. "I used to drink every day and one day I thought, when did I last not have a drink? I couldn't remember. I used to drink a lot of spirits and I think I damaged my liver."

Wilson takes acting and directing very seriously. He refers to the great Japanese director Ozu and his film Tokyo Story for inspiration - acting that isn't acting, just being. "It was such a revelation to see a film talking about the mores of family life that a British film hadn't even smelt, not even got close to. The nuances of family relationships. It rang so true." Ozu's films focus on the gentle, irrevocable disillusionments of older age. "I keep using this word in my directing - strangely enough, seeing I had this awful catchphrase - the word 'believability'. The actors must obey the text but in a real way, and the Japanese do that selflessly. The subtext of that world was so clearly worked out that if someone lifts a bagel it becomes a big moment, never mind a car chase."

Why does he call Victor Meldrew's "I don't believe it" catchphrase awful? He looks embarrassed. "I suppose you caught me out. I suppose only because I was talking of Ozu. The two seem so apart that it seems dreadful to talk about them in the same terms."

Wilson is a Manchester United fan. We talk about football and for the first time he forgets this is an interview. He says the "beautiful game" is not that different from acting. "To me good acting is about ensemble. There are no individual actors who interest me. Good acting to me is someone who'll work in a team. When a football team plays ensemble, that freedom of expression is wonderful. I'm very jealous of it."

Despite his credentials as a raver there is something old-fashioned about Wilson. He has often been described as a "confirmed bachelor", a peculiarly archaic expression. "I don't believe the word bachelor exists," he says. "I realise my lifestyle is very strange to lots of people..." Why? "I just said I don't talk about my private life and you've just started talking about it again." Suddenly, he's accusing me of ulterior motives. "You just chose the moment when we were getting very friendly and relaxed, talking about football...I don't find my life strange, but I realise I don't see myself as a 63-year-old Scottish actor "

What does that mean? Is "confirmed bachelor" a euphemism for being gay? "You can make as many conjectures as you like, but I suppose my life is strange inasmuch as I'm a 63-year-old whose friends' age range is huge. I don't mix in older circles, by and large." Is that so strange? "Well, a lot of older people want to be with older people all the time. I'm very happy to be with younger people. That keeps you fresh. It's good to have new ideas coming at you all the time. That's why I only do new writing."

We're walking back to the ballroom and seem to be friends again. Why is he so protective of his private life? "Because that is all I've got left. Helloooo. Hi, darling! How are you? All right! Mmmm! " He plants a smacker on the face of Amanda, an actress from the play, who passes us in the street. "Private life is what the public don't own."

Wilson is such a funny mix - so open, so shut. An introverted extrovert or an extroverted introvert? The oldest swinger in town or the prude's prude? Yes, funny mix, fair enough," he says. "I realise there is in some ways an enigma about me."

Richard Wilson: the life and works

Born July 9, 1936 in Greenock. After National Service with the army medical corps, works as lab technician while acting in am dram. Starts at Rada aged 27.

Theatre (acting) : Normal Service (1979), Operation Bad Apple (1982), An Honourable Trade (1984), May Days (1990), The Weekend (1994), Waiting for Godot (1999)

Theatre (directing) : Heaven and Hell (1981), Other Worlds (1983), An Inspector Calls (1986), A Wholly Healthy Glasgow (1987-88), Prin (1989), Imagine Drowning (1991), The Lodger (1994), Simply Disconnected (1996),Tom and Clem (1997), Toast (1999)

TV : Tutti Frutti (1987), Only When I Laugh (1979-82), Crown Court (1973-84), One Foot in the Grave (pictured below; five series, starting 1989), Under the Hammer (1994), Life Support (1999)

Awards : Top TV Comedy Actor at British Comedy Awards (1991), Bafta Light Entertainment Award (1991, 1993), OBE (1994)

Mr Kolpert is at the Royal Court, London SW1 (020-7565 5001), till May 20. Michael Billington's review will appear tomorrow.

webTitle: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Much grinding of corporate teeth and gleeful rubbing of tabloid palms in Hollywood this week, as Steven Spielberg found himself - not for the first time - on the receiving end of accusations from an unknown would-be player claiming plagiarism by the bearded auteur and his minions.
fields.body:
Much grinding of corporate teeth and gleeful rubbing of tabloid palms in Hollywood this week, as Steven Spielberg found himself - not for the first time - on the receiving end of accusations from an unknown would-be player claiming plagiarism by the bearded auteur and his minions.

The gory details, as revealed in a lawsuit filed last Thursday at LA District Court by obscure film-maker Gregory Grant, specify that Spielberg and his cohorts at Dreamworks pinched their idea for 1998's animated message-flick Small Soldiers from his 1991 short Ode To GI Joe. According to Grant's version of events, Dreamworks and parent company Universal had, for some time, been considering expanding the aforementioned Ode - which did the rounds of the festival circuit during the early 90s - into a feature proper, before dropping the idea on the grounds they "weren't interested in making a movie about toy dolls".

So imagine Grant's surprise when, a fortnight later, Spielberg personally announced the production of an animated movie about toy action figures who come to life and wreak havoc on a small American town, to be directed by the masterful Joe Dante. And then picture his face when, as alleged in the suit, several scenes from Ode were "directly lifted" for the subsequent Dreamworks project.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, considering the bad publicity which surrounded their handling of similar cases involving both Twister and Amistad, Dreamworks made no comment, although Grant's attorney Ira Reiner had enough for both parties. "This is not the stereotypical case of the producer getting a script left in a taxicab", he told reporters. "Grant graduated from film school, won several awards, and was asked to write a treatment and submit videos." Unsurprisingly, the plaintiff is now seeking unspecified monetary damages: watch this out-of-court settlement-sized space.

fields.headline: $350m lottery prize sparks goldrush
fields.trailText: Petrol stations were mobbed, hour-long queues formed outside corner groceries and interstate roads were jammed with frenzied punters hoping to win a $350m (£210m) lottery prize last night, the biggest jackpot in US history.
fields.body:
Petrol stations were mobbed, hour-long queues formed outside corner groceries and interstate roads were jammed with frenzied punters hoping to win a $350m (£210m) lottery prize last night, the biggest jackpot in US history.

The fact that the chances against winning were 76 million to one did not seem to deter a multitude of optimistic gamblers. Nor did the fact that the lottery, aptly called "the big game", was being played in only seven states: Georgia, Illinois, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Jersey and Virginia.

The crowds of would-be multi-millionaires simply climbed into their cars and drove across the country to buy a tiny scrap of hope, clogging roads and petrol station forecourts along state borders. In Virginia, lottery organisers appealed to the state police to help handle the traffic jams.

Most punters bought less than $10 worth of tickets, but there were reports of purchases costing more than $3,000. Joanna Franklin, a gambling counsellor in Baltimore, Maryland, said some people had taken out second mortgages to maximise their chances of winning.

"Its worth a shot," said George West as he bought a single ticket in Camden, New Jersey, marvelling at the resilience of the American dream.

"Where in the world can you win $350m for a dollar? And you've got just as much chance as anyone else who walks in the door."

If there is a single winner when the draw takes place at 4am BST, it will be the largest single lottery payout in the world. The record for an overall jackpot was set last year at $1.2bn by Spain's El gordo, the fat one, but that was spread out among thousands of winners. The previous US record was $296m, which was won by a group of 13 Ohio factory workers two years ago.

In a futile attempt to contain the mania, statisticians have illustrated the staggering odds involved with a variety of real-life examples. Winning with a single $1 ticket, for example, is about as likely as tossing a coin 26 times and getting heads every time; or sticking a pin in a telephone book containing the entire US population and finding a former president.

John Allen Paulos, a mathematics professor at Temple University, Philadelphia, put the odds in a more macabre light.

"A man is hundreds of times more likely to suffer a heart attack between the time he buys the ticket and the drawing than he is to win the jackpot," he said.

fields.headline: Nuts and bolts
fields.standfirst:
£575m package, 50,000 unsold cars and a shares offer for workers

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The tenner Phoenix paid BMW for Rover will be repaid many times over because the car company comes with a £575m package.
fields.body:
The tenner Phoenix paid BMW for Rover will be repaid many times over because the car company comes with a £575m package.

So desperate is the German firm to escape the West Midlands that it is funding the consortium to take "the English patient" off its hands.

BMW maintained it was a loan but terms are favourable and a Phoenix adviser predicted most, if not all, will not have to be repaid.

Sources close to BMW said it would stump up £275m on completion with another £150m on the first and second anniversaries of the deal. The funds are intended to keep Longbridge going while Phoenix finds its feet.

Under the deal Phoenix is to get the Longbridge complex making the Rover 25, 45, old Mini and MGF sports model. BMW will transfer an assembly line making Rover 75 executive motors from Cowley to Longbridge, moving equipment to make a new Mini the other way.

A stock of more than 50,000 unsold cars will be signed over to Phoenix, which plans to sell them on for £200m to the US bank First Union.

Up to 1,750 redundancies at Longbridge are feared though Phoenix hopes initially to keep the total under 1,000.

The consortium is confident it can sell 200,000 cars a year, hitting 280,000 if it does well in the US market. Longbridge's new owners reckon they could sell 20,000 more Rover 75s a year by introducing an estate version.

Workers and dealers are to be offered up to three-fifths of the shares in the new venture to raise funds and seal their commitment. Phoenix's success rests on slashing overheads by about two-thirds, and it will buy in more components.

BMW will continue to own the Rover brand but will license the name to Phoenix.

webTitle: Blow for BNFL as US energy department pulls out of 'outrageously expensive' deal

fields.headline: Blow for BNFL as US energy department pulls out of 'outrageously expensive' deal
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: The US government yesterday pulled the plug on a £4.5bn contract with British Nuclear Fuels while it was still reviewing procedures for other clean-up operations involving the crisis-torn company.
fields.body:
The US government yesterday pulled the plug on a £4.5bn contract with British Nuclear Fuels while it was still reviewing procedures for other clean-up operations involving the crisis-torn company.

Its Department of Energy said it had serious concerns about the management approach taken by BNFL as it pulled out of a deal to turn radioactive waste into glass logs because of an "outrageously expensive" estimate to complete the operation.

The company said last night it was "disappointed" by the announcement but would retender for the vitrification work which it now thought would cost nearly £10bn , more than double the price two years ago.

The contract for cleaning up waste kept in underground tanks at the Hanford weapons complex in Washington state was the most lucrative of a package arranged between the US department and BNFL Inc, a subsidiary, involving also plants in Colorado, Idaho, South Carolina and Tennessee.

Bill Richardson, the US energy secretary, last week sent inspectors to BNFL's Sellafield complex to examine its safety record in the wake of rows with Japan and Germany and critical reports from Britain's nuclear installations inspec torate which helped provoke sweeping changes in the management of the company. The US inspectors report has not been completed.

BNFL had agreed to design , build and operate, at Hanford, a hi-tech plant that would turn 54mn gallons of waste into glass that could then be buried safely at a government disposal site. But the sudden price rise clearly annoyed the US government and T.J. Glauthier, deputy energy secretary, hinted that BNFL's chances of winning a new bid for the contract were slim. "Why should we believe in their bid when we have just had this experience? We have been pretty unhappy with their performance..We are very disappointed to have to take this action and to have to change directions now."

BNFL would continue with design work for several months but then the rest of the work would be turned over to companies selected from new tenders. Payment for the work so far would probably be up to $300mn(£196m). It was not clear whether the government would have to pay a penalty for termination.

BNFL, which blamed increased costs on ways of financing the project, said it was pleased the US authorities had found the design and technical solution for Hanford was sound. It would ensure a smooth transition could take place and hoped to continue to work with the energy department in delivering the important clean-up project.

fields.headline:
No: 1632
 Dorothy Rodham
fields.trailText: Occupation: Catering to Bill Clinton's every whim.
fields.body:
Occupation: Catering to Bill Clinton's every whim.

God, not another one! No, no. She might tuck him into bed at night but it won't go any further than that. She's the mother-in-law.

Hillary's mum, you mean? Yes, and when Bill gets evicted from the White House, he's going to live in her condo in Little Rock, Arkansas.

So he's not too keen on cohabiting with the missus? Well, Hillary's busy during the week trying to win a Senate seat in New York, and he's got to be down south keeping an eye on the progress of the $125m Clinton library, his monument to himself.

Old Dot must be a pretty tolerant type, putting up with a 53-year-old saxophonist in her spare room. Not too tolerant: as a stern Methodist, she obviously disapproved of his messing about with Monica and the others.

How stern is she? Stern enough. When the first lady was just a slip of a thing and being teased by a group of older girls, her mum told the four-year-old: "Hillary, you can stay inside here with me for ever, or you can go out there and face those kids yourself." She hid behind a bush and watched as her lassie beat her persecutors black and blue.

Mrs Rodham must be proud of her daughter. Indeed, even if things didn't quite work out as she had hoped. Dorothy, now 81, and her husband Hugh were Republicans who always wanted Hillary to become the first woman member of the US Supreme Court.

Is she doing anything to help Hillary get elected? Dorothy showed her face on the day her daughter confirmed she was in the running, but confined herself to staring into space. She believes her little girl is much misunderstood: "Some people seem to resent that she has it all."

Such as who? Such as the one third of New Yorkers who say they would not vote for her because they see her as an opportunist from an alien planet - ie, anywhere outside New York.

Most likely to say: "Ovaltine or Horlicks?"

Least likely to say: "Why don't y'all go out and party some?"

fields.headline: The fight starts here
fields.standfirst:
Rover's reprieve must be put to good use

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The workers of Longbridge - last to know but destined to be first out - are not home and dry yet. Their new masters are the assetless Phoenix, endowed with £500m from BMW and various credit lines, but not yet a convincing plan for turning Rover around as a volume car maker.
fields.body:
The workers of Longbridge - last to know but destined to be first out - are not home and dry yet. Their new masters are the assetless Phoenix, endowed with £500m from BMW and various credit lines, but not yet a convincing plan for turning Rover around as a volume car maker.

What is needed more than investment in the plant is saleable product. While John Towers and colleagues have proved themselves as negotiators, they have yet to seduce a public which has never let noisy injunctions to buy British override its market instincts. In a week when a Hyundai-DaimlerChrysler-Mitsubishi union was promoted, albeit abortively, the prospects for a small national car producer are slim, even before the baleful effects of sterling's strength relative to the euro are factored in.

Still, another year's work is better than unemployment, even though the government is prepared to be generous with training and regeneration grants. And Phoenix, however temporarily, merits the thanks of those politicians whose chestnuts have been pulled from the fire - not just Labour, for the Tories are as incoherent on the rescue of "lame ducks" as when that phrase was coined during Ted Heath's tenure at Number 10. None the less, it was trade secretary Stephen Byers who looked most relieved yesterday. Despite his clean bill of health from the Commons' industry committee, the German professoriate ran rings round him; Cabinet omertà stopped him admitting that half Rover's problems are due to the exchange rate.

So when yesterday Tony Blair hailed Mr Byers's role in Rover's future as a "classic example of the new role for ministers in a changing world", he left us with a puzzle. Mr Byers wrung his hands; he put moral and political pressure on BMW, but gave few other clues whether there is indeed a "third way" policy for industry. Would you drive a car designed by a trade secretary? The European Union now rules out even the sweetener that BMW was to have got and John Towers yesterday earned his knighthood by asserting he will make Rover a going concern without subvention; except, of course, the state aid needed to pick up the pieces in Birmingham and in Oxford, which will finally lose all connection with what was created by that great Oxonian, William Morris, Lord Nuffield.

Mr Byers's travails are far from over - though his are a lot less painful than the disruption and hardship inflicted on the shopfloor victims of industrial reorganisation and trade shifts. Ford are supposed to decide later this month on the future of car production at Dagenham. (London's new mayor is right to concern himself with its fate, especially since, as Ken Livingstone says, the plant had been backed with large slugs of social capital, in the form of public housing for Dagenham's workers.) Positive policies for manufacturing are not just a matter of electoral calculations of the mood in the "heartlands". Trade secretaries worth their salt have to watch the external balance and the shape of an economy which cannot live by services alone. The Blairite response is: we must go with the flow of market forces by, for example, sharpening competition in the supply of capital, facilitating the transition between old and new economies and helping small and medium enterprise to flourish. That makes sense as far as it goes. But entire communities continue to depend upon large-scale factory-based manufacturing. For their sake, the government cannot simply stand idly by and watch international boardrooms carve up their production schedules to suit their interpretation of shareholders' interests.

fields.headline: Cowley pins hopes on Mini
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The future of 3,500 workers at the Cowley plant will hinge on a new version of one of Britain's favourite cars - the Mini.
fields.body:
The future of 3,500 workers at the Cowley plant will hinge on a new version of one of Britain's favourite cars - the Mini.

BMW's deal with the Phoenix consortium means that production of the Rover 75 will be switched from the Oxfordshire plant to Longbridge over the coming months, while production of the new Mini, originally intended for Longbridge, will move to Cowley.

A model of the new Mini was put on display at the Frankfurt motor show two years ago and it is expected to be larger and more upmarket than the traditional model. Production is expected to begin next summer which would mean a hole in the Cowley plant's schedule as Rover 75 production moves out. According to BMW the company plans to produce 80,000-100,000 cars a year.

A BMW spokesman said there would not be any redundancies at Cowley and that any slack in production would be absorbed through changes in shift patterns which would mean fewer hours when production requirements were low but more as demand picked up.

BMW will also retain the power train business, which is split between the Longbridge site and the new Hams Hall engine plant, and which makes engines for Rover and Land-Rover. It will also keep the pressing plant at Swindon, which provides body panels for Rover. However, Phoenix has options to buy the Swindon plant and the power train operation and is expected to take a decision within months.

One other outstanding question for BMW is the siting of the new plant to build Rolls-Royce cars. A task force is understood to have identified a number of potential sites in the UK but no decision has yet been reached.

The BMW spokesman said there was no link between the situation at Rover and the decision about the new Rolls-Royce.

fields.headline: Euphoric workers uncork the bubbly
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: John Bull, resplendent in his patriotic costume and mutton-chop whiskers, was cock-a-hoop. After standing outside Birmingham's Longbridge car plant almost every day for two months, he declared yesterday: "Obviously somebody up there cares about us."
fields.body:
John Bull, resplendent in his patriotic costume and mutton-chop whiskers, was cock-a-hoop. After standing outside Birmingham's Longbridge car plant almost every day for two months, he declared yesterday: "Obviously somebody up there cares about us."

Mr Bull (alias retired bobby Ray Egan, 62) was holding high his banner reading, "The word closure is not in our vocabulary", after thousands of auto workers got the result they wanted when BMW agreed to sell the Rover car group to Britain's Phoenix consortium.

The workforce had feared that the rival Alchemy bid would have slashed production and turned the business into a niche sports car maker.

The man behind Phoenix, Rover's former chief executive John Towers, arrived to a hero's welcome, cheered by hundreds of workers shouting: "Welcome to Longbridge."

They banged on the roof of his lime green Rover 75 and leaned in to offer him champagne.

All morning after news broke around 9am there was a carnival atmosphere in the blazing sunshine outside gate Q, the main entrance to the sprawling complex, as delighted men hugged each other and waved their fists in victory salutes for the cameras.

Dave Reynolds, 30, an engineer who got married three weeks ago, said: "It was all Rover people at the wedding, and we were in a sombre mood. We went on honeymoon to Tunisia not knowing if I had a job to come back to.

"I saw this [sale deal] on the internet at 9am and just thought, thank God we've got something to start from."

Workers are confident that shifting the production of the Rover 75 from the Cowley plant at Oxford to Longbridge will help secure their future. "It's a superb product," said one.

The optimism was more measured from the Phoenix consortium under questioning at a press conference, but John Towers' tanned face kept creasing into a smile.

Mr Towers was restrained in his comments about the outgoing owner, BMW, but workers vented their anger.

Ian Robinson, shop steward for the Transport and General Workers Union, recalled a Rover 25 advert in which the car drove around a roulette wheel before settling in 25.

"What sort of advertisement is that?" he asked. "It is saying you're gambling if you buy this car."

fields.headline: Churchill protester is jailed
fields.standfirst: May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: A former soldier was yesterday sentenced to 30 days' imprisonment for defacing the statue of Sir Winston Churchill during May day demonstrations in London.
fields.body:
A former soldier was yesterday sentenced to 30 days' imprisonment for defacing the statue of Sir Winston Churchill during May day demonstrations in London.

Student James Matthews, 25, was also ordered to pay £250 to compensate for the damage. He pleaded guilty at Horseferry Road magistrates' court in central London to intentionally or recklessly damaging the statue in Parliament Square.

Alun Milford, prosecuting, said Matthews was photographed spraying the statue with red paint and his picture appeared in national newspapers. He presented himself at a police station in Cambridge on Sunday.

Matthews, who defended himself, read a statement to the court in which he described Churchill as "a reactionary politician who was imperialist and anti-semitic".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Homes plan shelved
fields.body:
Homes plan shelved

Plans to build more than 2,000 homes on open ground belonging to the Althorp estate of Earl Spencer, brother of Diana, Princess of Wales, have been shelved, Northampton councillors said yesterday.

The planning committee said new guidelines and the discovery of more brownfield sites in the town had allowed the council to rethink its planning strategy. Press Association

Hospital error costs £925,000

A south Wales man has won £925,000 in compensation after a medical blunder left him confined to a wheelchair and unable to look after himself, his solicitor said yesterday.

Doctors failed to diagnose Terence Phelan, 62, from Rhondda, was suffering from lithium poisoning when he was treated at the East Glamorgan hospital. He had been taking lithium to combat depression.

False teeth clue to pub raider

A gunman threatened staff with an air pistol at the Old Ship pub in Southport, Merseyside, before fleeing on Sunday, leaving behind his false teeth.

Exposure threat to dirty dogs

Wardens at St John the Baptist church at Hatherleigh, near Okehampton, Devon, are so fed up with dog mess in their churchyard that they are planning to use the parish magazine to name and shame the owners of dirty dogs.

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Phoenix, the car company many in the motor industry feared would never succeed, emerged from the ashes of BMW's failure after two days and two nights of non-stop negotiations. It was a tired, baggy-eyed John Towers who signed his name on the dotted line yesterday at 8.30am to pay a symbolic £10 for Rover's Longbridge plant.
fields.body:
Phoenix, the car company many in the motor industry feared would never succeed, emerged from the ashes of BMW's failure after two days and two nights of non-stop negotiations. It was a tired, baggy-eyed John Towers who signed his name on the dotted line yesterday at 8.30am to pay a symbolic £10 for Rover's Longbridge plant.

His team had been locked in detailed negotiations with BMW's law firm since Saturday morning.

When Mr Towers put pen to paper, the jobs of thousands of West Midlands car workers were saved and a major British-owned mass car maker was born.

The remarkable agreement hammered out at the offices of lawyers' Norton Rose in London's Bishopsgate was clinched after Tony Blair told BMW it had his blessing. The prime minister, distracted during recent days by Ulster and elections in London and hundreds of local councils, summoned Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, to a No 10 summit with key advisers on Monday evening.

The group went through the Phoenix figures and agreed that, as one Downing Street source put it, the car plan was "a runner" and could work.

Mr Blair offered to ring BMW's Munich HQ but the call was made by Mr Byers, relieved that saving Longbridge jobs would also save his cabinet post after criticism of his performance.

BMW, looking to reverse out of a company losing it £2m a day, gave Norton Rose the green light to tie up loose ends, including giving Rover the right to sell spare parts.

Downing Street is also believed to have been advised to back Phoenix by an unlikely source: Geoffrey Robinson. The former paymaster-general, forced to quit the government over his home loan to Peter Mandelson, was sucked into the discussions about 10 days ago.

The former Jaguar chief executive, one of the few Labour MPs able to understand a balance sheet, is an old acquaintance of Tony Woodley, the T&G transport union official who championed the Phoenix bid.

Union sources said Mr Woodley rang Mr Robinson at his Surrey home and asked him to speak to Mr Towers and lobby ministers. Phoenix sources confirmed Mr Towers discussed the bid with Mr Robinson about half a dozen times.

And Mr Robinson is also understood to have reassured Gordon Brown, the chancellor, that Longbridge would not collapse if BMW handed the plant over.

"We needed someone we could rely on to make sure we were heard in Downing Street and the Treasury," said the union source. "So Tony [Woodley] rang Robinson and got him to call Towers. It seems to have paid off."

BMW had to be arm-twisted by the government at the end of April to sit down properly with Phoenix, a consortium of West Midlands businessmen put together just two months ago.

Sceptical

When the rival Alchemy takeover plan sensationally collapsed at the end of April, BMW was rubbishing the Phoenix proposals and even ministers were privately sceptical.

Mr Towers believed until very late that, despite the pressure put on BMW by Mr Byers and public pronouncements of support, that the DTI was secretly against him. A meeting with Mr Byers ended in acrimony last Friday. Mr Towers and Mr Woodley were left fuming - the latter admitted he rang Mr Robinson to accuse the government of still backing Alchemy.

A close confidante of Mr Towers disclosed: "John left thinking the government was deliberately putting obstacles in our way. It did not look good."

But prospects improved during the weekend as agreement was reached on the £575m BMW dowry for Phoenix and the consortium convinced BMW that it had the rest of the finance in place.

Yet even yesterday there was confusion. Phoenix and the government believed the £575m did not have to be repaid - and BMW spokesman Hubert Bergmann insisted in Munich: "It is seen as a credit - a credit that will be paid back."

Mr Towers and Mr Byers yesterday paid each other warm compliments.

The former Rover boss who quit in 1995 after a disagreement with BMW said: "I congratulate all involved and I hope people will recognise the important contribution of Steve Byers who, despite all the attacks on him, rolled up his sleeves, got to work and, behind the scenes, ensured the government did what it could to bring this about."

Mr Byers, often caught on the hop by developments that threatened his political career, said: "I am pleased that an agreement has been struck and I would like to personally congratulate Mr Towers, who despite considerable criticism has stuck to his task and has now delivered a project that will be good news for Longbridge"

Within eight minutes of Mr Towers signing the crucial documents yesterday, the news was announced to an unsuspecting world.

Rover workers at Longbridge, who celebrated last month when Jon Moulton's Alchemy lost its bid to buy Longbridge, celebrated this time because John Towers' Phoenix had won.

Shop steward Peter Logan said: "We believed that we were sunk under Alchemy and Jon Moulton but now we feel like we have raised the Titanic."

Rover workers at Cowley, who fear redundancies when the Rover 75 model is switched to the West Midlands, did not share the joy of their colleagues.

One of the Cowley workers, Roy Morris, who heard the news on the radio, said: "What are we going to do about our factory? There's no future."

Alchemy, which had been waiting in the wings in case the Phoenix bid collapsed, issued a brief statement which read: "Alchemy Partners wish the Phoenix consortium and its employees good luck for the future. Alchemy Partners looks forward to fresh transactions."

The phoenix of Greek legend was a magnificient bird that, after a certain number of years, burned itself to ashes before rising forth to new life.

The creature was once adopted as a sign over chemists' shops through the association of the bird with, ironically, alchemy.

After the Alchemy bid failed to turn to gold, Rover workers hope that Phoenix stays in the air.

fields.headline: Anti-GM claims 'misleading'
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Advertising watchdogs yesterday fired a warning shot at supermarkets for making exaggerated claims in the battle to win customers to organic or non-genetically modified food.
fields.body:
Advertising watchdogs yesterday fired a warning shot at supermarkets for making exaggerated claims in the battle to win customers to organic or non-genetically modified food.

Iceland, the first chain to promote own brand products for having non-GM ingredients, was rebuked for making misleading and "unacceptable" appeals to some people's fears over the new technology, including an allegation that mistakes had caused 37 deaths in the US.

Tesco was criticised for claiming that prices for organic food were "only a little higher" than conventional produce and that it tasted better.

The Advertising Standards Authority upheld six out of nine complaints made against an Iceland leaflet and all three complaints made against a Tesco brochure.

A spokesman for the ASA said the companies "are both trying to stake out new ground in foods being healthier or better for you for whatever reason, but are taking the science too far."

Last year the authority criticised GM giant Monsanto for inaccuracies in its advertising on behalf of the technology.

Iceland said it would contest yesterday's adjudication, and claimed the authority's procedures were flawed. Russell Ford, managing director, said: "We can't understand why the ASA feels it has the expertise within its own ranks to judge scientific statements."

The company believed the leaflet was not an advertisement, and therefore fell outside the authority's powers.

Tesco said it had withdrawn the criticised brochure months ago because it was out of date.

fields.headline: 'Unfair' care cost for old
fields.trailText: Elderly and disabled people on income support are being pushed further into poverty because councils charge them for providing essential help to get up, get dressed, bathe and prepare food, according to an audit commission report published yesterday.
fields.body:
Elderly and disabled people on income support are being pushed further into poverty because councils charge them for providing essential help to get up, get dressed, bathe and prepare food, according to an audit commission report published yesterday.

It reveals that 30% of councils levy charges for help and care in the home on people who receive income support, leaving them less money to live on than they are assessed as needing.

The report also found some "unacceptable" variations in the amount that councils charge for the essential help that can allow an elderly person to stay in their home instead of having to go into residential care.

Pensioners on income support of £78.75 a week may lose £10 out of a sum intended for basic living costs such as food and heating to pay for three hours' help.

The report reveals that some councils take up to 90% of a disabled person's attendance allowance.

Gail Elkington, policy officer of Help the Aged, welcomed the report. "It is high time the lid was lifted on the appalling discrepancies in charging for home care across the country," she said.

The report said that 94% of councils charge for home care services, which can vary according to need, from cleaning and shopping to the "personal" services such as help with getting dressed.

But, says the audit commission, they have little guidance from the government as to what can be charged for or how to assess what people should pay. The government has said it is waiting for the audit commission's report before announcing its response to the royal commission on long-term care, which recommended that personal care should be free.

fields.headline: José Luis López de Lacalle
fields.standfirst: Outspoken trade unionist and newspaper columnist murdered for his criticism of Basque separatist violence
fields.trailText: José Luis López de Lacalle, who has been assassinated aged 62, had "never had the chance to live in a free country," he said last February, after his home was firebombed by the groups of pro-independence youths who, these days, roam the streets of Basque towns at night, attacking shops, banks and the homes of individuals deemed negative to the separatist cause. "First, it was the Franco dictatorship," López de Lacalle recalled, "and later it was the ETA dictatorship."
fields.body:
José Luis López de Lacalle, who has been assassinated aged 62, had "never had the chance to live in a free country," he said last February, after his home was firebombed by the groups of pro-independence youths who, these days, roam the streets of Basque towns at night, attacking shops, banks and the homes of individuals deemed negative to the separatist cause. "First, it was the Franco dictatorship," López de Lacalle recalled, "and later it was the ETA dictatorship."

ETA (the acronym for Basque homeland and liberty) was believed to be responsible for the murder this week of the much-threatened López de Lacalle. The nationalist group has been blamed for almost 800 deaths in its struggle for Basque independence over the past 32 years. The veteran trade union organiser and political columnist was shot four times in front of his home in a San Sebastián suburb after going out to buy newspapers.

Born during the Spanish civil war, near Tolosa, in the isolated, Basque-speaking Goi Herri region that was to become a hotbed of ETA activism, López de Lacalle had little formal education, and started working in the paper industry as a teenager. Yet from an early age, he was often in the company of Basque intellectuals, who helped him to become a voracious reader, from classic Basque novelists, such as Pío Baroja, to modern social writings.

By the late 1950s, he was a member of the Spanish Communist party, having been introduced by his friend Enrique Múgica, later to become justice minister in one of Felipe González's socialist cabinets. "It sounds a bit incongruous by now," López de Lacalle would later recall, "but back then the only real opposition to Francoism was there." He became an early promoter of the communist-inspired trade union movement, the then-illegal workers' commissions, which had a decisive social influence in the waning years of the Franco era. He was jailed for more than five years for "illegal association".

During the early years of Spanish democracy, López de Lacalle worked as the efficient general manager of the Ugarola industrial co-operative, leaving two years ago after steering it through the deep industrial crisis of the pulp and paper sector and transforming it into an appliance manufacturer. For a long time before that, he was a leading negotiator for the workers' commissions, although he had left the Communist party and become close to the Socialist party. He once ran unsuccessfully for the Spanish senate as an independent on a socialist ticket.

López de Lacalle chose early retirement to devote his full energies to writing, particularly his political columns for the El Mundo newspaper, as well as essays on the Basque problem. He had become increasingly critical of the political paralysis in the region as the mainstream, non-violent BasqueNationalist party (PNV) inched closer to the independence demands of ETA and its political fronts. The Basque country has enjoyed a large degree of autonomy since the late 1970s, with its own parliament, police and education system.

The El Mundo columns have made López de Lacalle a well-known Basque figure over the past six years. He became a founder of the Ermua Forum, a non-partisan, non-violent institution created after the 1997 kidnap and murder of Miguel Angel Blanco, a young Popular party (conservative) council member. Despite threats and violence by ETA and its backers, he continued to live in his apartment in Andoain, refusing police protection. A man of simple habits, who loved long hikes, he could be constantly seen walking around his town.

After ETA broke its truce last year and murdered an army officer, a Socialist politician and his police escort, López de Lacalle was vocal in his criticism of the PNV-led Basque government, demanding new regional elections.

"A change in the political leadership of the Basque country is now necessary," he wrote in his last column, published five days before his death. "This is perfectly normal in a democracy, but it draws the ire of those installed in power. Various people maintain that the PNV is indispensable. They fear that it would take its radicalism to extremes if it were to lose power. But PNV is tied in by many interests. Its aim is to be a travel companion of ETA - but in the sleeping car."

López de Lacalle leaves his wife and two grown-up children.

José Luis López de Lacalle, labour activist and writer, born August 23 1937; died May 7 2000

fields.headline: 'Blast signs' on Pan Am suitcase
fields.standfirst: Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: Charred suitcase fragments showing possible blast damage were found in debris from Pan Am flight 103, the trial of two Libyans accused of causing the Lockerbie disaster was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Charred suitcase fragments showing possible blast damage were found in debris from Pan Am flight 103, the trial of two Libyans accused of causing the Lockerbie disaster was told yesterday.

In the months following the outrage, which claimed 270 lives, pieces of a brown suitcase were discovered at Newcastleton forest and the Borders forest park in the Scottish Borders.

Detective Constable Duncan McInnes, of Strathclyde police, told the court at Camp Zeist in Holland that he found parts of a brown suitcase with "possible blast damage", heavily fragmented pieces of charred material and copper-coloured rubber trim which he had noted as being "possibly from the bomb case".

He worked at a warehouse in a military base near Longtown, Cumbria, where wreckage from the aircraft was brought.

Some debris was marked with labels which had been torn or damaged because of bad weather and which were often illegible.

It was therefore impossible to ascertain exactly where, when and by whom such articles were discovered.

Abdelbaset Ali Al Megrahi, 48, and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, 44, have both denied alternative charges of conspiracy to murder, murder and a breach of the 1982 Aviation Security Act.

Detective Constable Duncan McInnes, of Strathclyde police, told the court at Camp Zeist in Holland that he found parts of a brown suitcase with "possible blast damage", heavily fragmented pieces of charred material and copper-coloured rubber trim which he had noted as being "possibly from the bomb case". He worked at a warehouse in a military base near Longtown, Cumbria, where wreckage from the aircraft was brought. Some debris was marked with labels which had been torn or damaged because of bad weather and which were often illegible. It was therefore impossible to ascertain exactly where, when and by whom such articles were discovered. Abdelbaset Ali Al Megrahi, 48, and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, 44, have both denied alternative charges of conspiracy to murder, murder and a breach of the 1982 Aviation Security Act. fields.headline: In for the duration
fields.standfirst:
There can be no quick fix in Sierra Leone

UNMASIL - UN mission
Sierra Leone Web
Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: In Sierra Leone, Britain is suddenly engaged in its biggest, unilateral overseas military deployment since the Falklands. The government is to be congratulated for moving decisively and swiftly to prevent the hapless UN mission being driven into the sea. But there must be no pretence that this can be a short-term commitment, limited to facilitating an evacuation of foreign nationals.
fields.body:
In Sierra Leone, Britain is suddenly engaged in its biggest, unilateral overseas military deployment since the Falklands. The government is to be congratulated for moving decisively and swiftly to prevent the hapless UN mission being driven into the sea. But there must be no pretence that this can be a short-term commitment, limited to facilitating an evacuation of foreign nationals.

Now the troops have gone in, in such impressive numbers and with such formidable naval and air back-up, international pressure on Britain to keep them there and to expand their role will intensify. Kofi Annan, the UN secretary-general, who knows that the future of peacekeeping in Africa is at stake, is already leaning hard on the government. The Clinton-Gore administration has predictably decided not to risk military involvement in a US election year. In terms of the western alliance, Britain is out on its own; and it is Britain which is expected to deliver a result. In American parlance, and to answer an objection raised by the Liberal Democrat spokesman Menzies Campbell, mission creep is unavoidable, for there is no fast, honourable exit strategy.

This need not be all bad. In dispatching what amounts to a rapid reaction force, the government has put into practice an intervention policy for international crises long advocated in theory by Robin Cook and by the armed forces. The arrival of the highly professional British forces has already boosted the UN's less well-trained and equipped national contingents. Britain's stabilising action has also brought hope to the people of Sierra Leone. As each day passes, the Tories' idea that Britain can somehow quickly pull out, condemning the local population to renewed terror from rebels and rival militias, will grow less tenable. Despite the financial costs and the worsening problem of UK global military "over-stretch", an open-ended operation looms.

To maximise their effectiveness, British forces must remain independent of UN command and avoid being drawn into factional fighting. Help is at hand from Nigeria, which is promising a substantial new force, and from UN reinforcements. Restoring even a semblance of order and the UN mission's credibility will take time and resolve - and it may well be that, ultimately, Sierra Leone is beyond help. But it is right to attempt it. And there must be no illusions that Britain, having stormed ashore, can easily sail away with the job incomplete.

fields.headline: John Fforde
fields.standfirst: Making monetary history at the Bank of England
fields.trailText: As official historian of the Bank Of England, its chief cashier from 1966 to 1970, and its executive director (home finance) from 1970 to 1982, John Fforde, who has died aged 78, played a leading part in British monetary affairs for more than three decades.
fields.body:
As official historian of the Bank Of England, its chief cashier from 1966 to 1970, and its executive director (home finance) from 1970 to 1982, John Fforde, who has died aged 78, played a leading part in British monetary affairs for more than three decades.

Born in Dorset, the son of a civil engineer, he was brought up at the family home in County Armagh and educated at Rossall school. His studies were interrupted by wartime enlistment in the Royal Air Force; by 1942, he was a pilot-instructor, based in Canada, and three years later he was flying bombers in Burma, after which his RAF career concluded with a spell in Transport Command.

After the war, Fforde spent five years at Oxford University. He graduated with first-class honours in politics, philosophy and economics from Christ Church, and, at Nuffield College, chose central banking as the subject of his doctoral thesis, focusing on the United States federal reserve system. He joined the prime minister's statistical branch after the 1951 Conservative election victory, but maintained his links with academic economics, becoming a fellow of Nuffield College in 1953.

In 1957, the Bank of England faced the task of preparing its submissions to the Radcliffe committee, set up to review the working of the monetary and financial system. Fforde was persuaded to join the bank, working alongside Maurice Allen, until then its only professional economist, but also having a close involvement on the Radcliffe work with Leslie O'Brien, the chief cashier.

Among the recommendations of the report, published in 1959, was the proposal that the Bank of England should enhance its capacity for economic research and analysis, and do more to explain publicly its assessment of the state of the economy and the reasons for policy actions. Both tasks were entrusted to Fforde; he was made responsible for building up a small section of professional economists and for launching the bank's quarterly bulletin, of which he became editor-in-chief.

Once these ventures were up and running, Fforde became available to play a wider role within the bank. In 1963, he went to the discount office, the bank's eyes and ears in the City, though still observ ing the top-hat rituals of the traditional money market. This move was something of a culture shock to all concerned, but Fforde's equability and dry humour, allied to his quickness of understanding, soon earned him the respect of his new audience.

In 1966, O'Brien became governor of the bank, leaving the position of chief cashier open to his chosen successor, Fforde. The job had much wider-ranging responsibilities then than it does today, including all aspects of the implementation of monetary policy. For the next 16 years - from 1970 to 1982 as an executive director of the bank - the practical operation of monetary policy was Fforde's chief concern.

To that task, he brought some clear guiding principles, but no ideological attachments. The period in the mid- to late-1960s - of heavy reliance on direct control over bank lending - convinced him that it should have no long-term place in the official armoury; its institutional consequences were too damaging, and its monetary effectiveness increasingly questionable.

Fforde strongly supported the collection of good monetary data and its careful assessment and monitoring, but equally strongly opposed any idea that monetary relationships could be relied upon to provide simple rules for the conduct of policy. The erratic behaviour of broad money following the adoption in 1971 of competition and credit control, the reform which embodied the abandoning of lending controls in which he had been the prime mover, confirmed him in that view.

Fforde supported the adoption of a target for broad money in the difficult years of the mid-1970s, though he was conscious that direct controls on banking balance sheets, then restored in a somewhat different form from the lending ceilings of the 1960s, could have a distorting effect on the target variable.

He was much less happy with the approach of the incoming Conservative government in 1979, which made the delivery of a predetermined path for the growth of broad money the centrepiece of its economic policy. Direct control of banking balance sheets could no longer be effective following the removal of foreign exchange control at the end of 1979.

Broad money grew massively and unpredictably, and the bank stood accused of a lack of resolve in pursuing monetary objectives - even though the evidence from the real economy was of unprecedented and undesired tightness. Fforde was probably relieved to be able, in 1982, to exchange operational responsibility for monetary policy for the role of policy adviser.

On retiring in 1984, Fforde agreed to write the next volume of the bank's official history, covering its involvement in public policy issues from 1941 to 1958. This was a task for which he was well-equipped, bringing to it the qualities he had displayed during his service in the bank: perceptive analysis, great skill in drafting (albeit at the cost of much arduous labour), meticulousness, courage in reaching conclusions, and cogency of argument in presenting them. The Bank Of England And Public Policy (1941-1958) was published in 1992.

In retirement, Fforde held directorships of Alexanders Discount, and its successor companies, and the Halifax Building Society.

He is survived by his wife, Marya, and by their three sons and one daughter.

John Standish Fforde, economist, born November 16 1921; died April 10 2000

fields.headline: Jonah Jones
fields.trailText: Jonah Jones, who has died in New York aged 90, was one of the great swing trumpeters, and gained new success long after the heyday of the style with a formula he called "muted jazz". It brought him engagements, a recording contract and financial security.
fields.body:
Jonah Jones, who has died in New York aged 90, was one of the great swing trumpeters, and gained new success long after the heyday of the style with a formula he called "muted jazz". It brought him engagements, a recording contract and financial security.

Born in Louisville, Kentucky, he enlisted in a Sunday school music group when he was 11. He wanted to play trombone, but was assigned the alto horn; he was nicknamed "Jonah" after a music instructor stuttered over his surname.

Within a couple of years, Jones had progressed to trumpet, and fallen under the spell of Louis Armstrong. He took local danceband jobs while still at school, but his first professional engagement was playing moonlight excursions on the Ohio river. In 1928, he joined the trumpet section of Horace Henderson's band.

Moves from band to band led Jones to Buffalo, New York, where he linked up with Jimmie Lunceford's orchestra. He later joined the manic jazz violinist Hezekiah "Stuff" Smith, beginning an association which lasted until 1940, with occasional other engagements when Smith's combo was without a job. One was with pianist Lil Armstrong, who featured Jones as "Louis Armstrong II", and had him play her former husband's specialities. After Smith found a spot at the Harlem Grill in Buffalo, Jones rejoined, staying on to play at the Onyx Club on New York's 52nd Street.

Smith's group specialised in extended improvisations - one extemporisation lasted for an hour. He played hard, and expected his men to live hard, too, fuelled by copious quantities of whisky and cannabis. When a doctor gave Jones a year to live unless he changed his ways, he moved on to work briefly with Benny Carter and Fletcher Henderson, also appearing on many freelance recordings, where his full tone and solo command helped build a solid reputation.

Jones joined Cab Calloway's orchestra in 1941, displacing the band's existing soloist, the young Dizzy Gillespie. Calloway was so pleased to sign Jones that he recorded an original composition, Jonah Joins The Cab. Jones participated in the notorious "spitball" incident, when he flicked a soggy ball of paper at the band's drummer. Gillespie was falsely accused, a fight ensued, a knife was pulled, Calloway was cut, and Gillespie hurriedly quit the band. Jones stayed mute.

Despite his orchestra's considerable success, Calloway eventually reduced it to a sextet, finally disbanding in 1952. After a stint in pianist Joe Bushkin's quartet, and a good summer in Europe in 1954, which saw Jones teamed on record and holding his own with the fiery soprano sax virtuoso Sidney Bechet, he returned to New York facing a shaky future. A chance encounter with agent Sam Berg led him to form a quartet which won a five-year contract at the Embers Club.

Recordings with Capitol followed, his first album - with the hit song On The Street Where You Live - selling a million copies and setting a pattern which endured for the remainder of Jones's playing career. Many more albums were made, hotels and clubs vying for Jones's services, the quartet later touring Europe, (though not Britain), Australia and the Far East. Formulaic, perhaps, the concept of "muted jazz" - with Jones using a variety of mutes and presenting familiar melodies in swinging fashion, often over a shuffle-beat - brought him fame and fortune and, in his view, introduced many people to jazz.

Jones was an outstanding instrumentalist, whose power and attack made every solo a joy. Staying true to the inspiration of Louis Armstrong to the end, he said: "Louis could do no wrong." Nor, in the views of many jazz fans, could he. He is survived by a daughter, two sons and two grandchildren.

Robert Elliott 'Jonah' Jones, trumpeter and bandleader, born December 31 1909; died April 29 2000

fields.headline: Now the hard part begins
fields.standfirst:
Rover's future: losses and vehicle development pose urgent problems

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The challenges now facing the Phoenix team are daunting. Even getting BMW to the negotiating table represented a triumph of determination over scepticism - that it had a workable business plan and the money to put it into effect.
fields.body:
The challenges now facing the Phoenix team are daunting. Even getting BMW to the negotiating table represented a triumph of determination over scepticism - that it had a workable business plan and the money to put it into effect.

Now the Towers team has to stem the losses at Rover, get it back into the black and, having done so, exploit the existing model range for all it is worth before embarking on the potentially hugely expensive task of developing a new model range.

The team has no other options if it is to stick to the core of its business plan - which set it apart from rival bidder Alchemy - of maintaining volume car production at Longbridge.

A glance at last month's car sales figures for the UK might suggest the first bit would be plain sailing. The company took more than 13% of the market - more than double the total for the previous month - with the Rover 25 claiming top slot and the Rover 75 in fifth place.

But though Rover's sudden sales success last month may have owed something to a sympathy vote, it owed rather more to hefty price cutting. That may help the cash flow but is hardly good news for profits.

Now the figures for April, not March, will have to become the norm for Phoenix if it is to hit its target of producing between 150,000 and 200,000 cars a year and raise Rover from the ashes.

Phoenix will also have to tackle the problem of cutting costs. Up to 1,000 jobs are expected to go at Longbridge and there are plans to source more components from outside the UK to help offset the strength of the pound which is hitting the whole of the UK car industry.

But even if Phoenix bolsters its market share while coping with the disruption of switching production of the Rover 75 from Cowley to Longbridge, it will still have to show it has the capacity to move the model range forward.

It is retaining some 600 engineers from Rover's research and development centre at Gaydon, near Warwick. They will work on the design of new vehicles with outside partners such as body panel makers Mayflower and racing car specialists Lola.

The Phoenix plan includes elements of the aborted Alchemy project such as giving a sportier look to the Rover models and launching new models under the MG marque.

Edmond Warner, chief executive of Albert E Sharp Securities which helped put together the financing for the deal, said the Phoenix operation was not a "sentimental" response to the crisis at Longbridge but a "hard headed" proposition. "The business plan includes a solid lump (of finance) for necessary investment going forward."

The key will be Phoenix's ability to negotiate alliances. That could be at the corporate level, involving another car maker taking a stake in the British group. Or it could be at the operating level with Phoenix sharing development costs with another volume manufacturer or (more likely) using another manufacturer's platform - the bulk of the car you don't see - on which to build its own distinctive Rover body.

Yesterday Mr Towers made it plain that he was open to cooperative agreements and one name already being mentioned is Honda. Mr Towers himself had close links with the Japanese car maker during its previous partnership with Rover - before the sale of the British company to BMW in 1994.

Honda lost face when Rover was sold to BMW and may be reluctant to risk another engagement with the British group.

But Mr Towers and Phoenix colleague Nick Stephenson have already had new talks with Honda which they described as "friendly and positive". Mr Stephenson said: "They indicated they were keen to talk once we had secured the company."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Land invasions spread to Kenya
fields.body:
Land invasions spread to Kenya

In a move that mirrored the invasions of farms in Zimbabwe, some 500 families moved on to two white-owned farms in Kenya yesterday, one of which belongs to Basil Criticos, a government minister.

The apparent copycat Kenyan invasions in Taveta, about 100 miles north-west of Mombasa on the Tanzanian border, came after calls by two radical parliamentarians for the occupation of under-utilised white-owned farms. Security workers at the farms were assaulted and more than 810 hectares of crops were burned, the minister said. Reuters, Nairobi

Troops admit executions

Claiming to be following the orders of their superiors, 13 Indonesian soldiers gave unprecedented testimony at a tribunal yesterday that they had executed civilians in the troubled Aceh province last July.

They told the military-civilian court in Aceh that they had been forced to take 26 students, injured in a military assault on their Islamic boarding school,to a nearby field and shoot them dead. AP, Banda Aceh, Indonesia

Singapore vets public speakers

Authorities will record the names of those who vent their opinions at Singapore's Speakers' Corner, and investigate those who go too far, the government said yesterday.

The government of tightly controlled Singapore recently promised to set up an area where Singaporeans can, for the first time, speak publicly without having to get a licence first. But they must show identification and register their names with police before speaking. The names will be kept on record for five years. AP, Singapore

US accused of routine torture

Certain forms of torture are becoming institutionalised in the United States, especially within the justice system, the human rights group Amnesty International claims in a report to be given to the UN Committee Against Torture today in Geneva.

The organisation said the country's rising prison population contributed to widespread ill-treatment of men, women and children in custody, while police brutality is particularly directed at racial and ethnic minorities. AP, Geneva

webTitle: Sri Lanka on the defensive as Tigers push for Jaffna

fields.headline: Sri Lanka on the defensive as Tigers push for Jaffna
fields.standfirst: Tamil Eelam
fields.trailText: Tamil Tiger rebels began an offensive aimed at capturing the town of Jaffna yesterday, hours after their offer of a temporary ceasefire was rejected by the Sri Lankan government.
fields.body:
Tamil Tiger rebels began an offensive aimed at capturing the town of Jaffna yesterday, hours after their offer of a temporary ceasefire was rejected by the Sri Lankan government.

After a four-day lull in fighting, the rebels made a fresh push to try to seize the village of Kodikamam, which - if it fell - would allow the Tigers to shell the runway of Jaffna's only airport at Palali.

"They are advancing, but at a much slower pace than before," one source said.

The Sri Lankan government insisted the fighting was taking place several miles away from Kodikaman, at Pallai, a military base the Tigers overran 10 days ago. Troops were consolidating their defences and putting up heavy resistance to the rebel attack, an information officer said.

The resumption of fighting yesterday follows an address to the nation on Monday night by the president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, in which she ruled out any evacuation of the 40,000 troops marooned in Jaffna by the rebel advance. "We will not allow the half million people of Jaffna to fall into the hands and the fascist rule of the LTTE [Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam]," she said.

She admitted government forces had suffered "setbacks", but said they were "temporary".

"It was in the full knowledge of the seriousness of the situation that we decided to place the country on a war footing."

The deputy defence minister, Anuruddha Ratwatte, told parliament that 358 government soldiers had been killed in the last three weeks, with 349 missing and 2,368 wounded.

If the runway at Palali is destroyed the only supply route to Jaffna would be cut off, making evacuation the only option. Analysts believe the Tigers will mount an all-out push for the town, before new weaponry and fighter jets arrive at the frontline.

fields.headline: Mother's anger over rail incident
fields.trailText: An investigation has been launched into how a toddler was left dangling above a railway line after his mother was trapped in train doors.
fields.body:
An investigation has been launched into how a toddler was left dangling above a railway line after his mother was trapped in train doors.

Three-year-old Jayke Manning was allegedly left in the gap between train and platform, gripping his mother Janine's hand. When the doors were released, Mrs Manning jerked forward and nearly lost hold of her son.

Mrs Manning, of South Norwood, south London, said yesterday that Jayke had been left traumatised.

The incident happened a week ago as they got off a Connex train at Streatham Hill station in south-west London.

Mrs Manning has complained to the rail company.

A spokesman for Connex Trains said yesterday: "We are carrying out an investigation to establish what happened."
