webTitle: Rebels keep Philippines hostages on move

fields.headline: Rebels keep Philippines hostages on move
fields.standfirst:
Sabah Ministry of Tourism Development
Institute for Counter-Terrorism: Abu Sayyaf
fields.trailText: Muslim rebels holding 21 hostages in the Philippines are moving groups of captives around to confuse government forces and complicate efforts to secure their freedom, officials claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Muslim rebels holding 21 hostages in the Philippines are moving groups of captives around to confuse government forces and complicate efforts to secure their freedom, officials claimed yesterday.

But they said hopes were high that a German woman who is ill could soon be freed, perhaps as early as today.

Nur Misuari, a former rebel chief chosen by the government to be the chief negotiator, said that on Monday 12 hostages were moved a few miles from the thickly forested area on Jolo island where they have been kept since they were abducted from a Malaysian diving resort on April 23.

Candido Casimoro, the police chief on Jolo, said the Abu Sayyaf rebels, who are fighting for a separate Islamic state, later regrouped the hostages. "It was just a move to confuse the military," he said.

Mr Misuari, who was due to go to Jolo, 600 miles south of Manila, early today, said he did not know where the other nine hostages were being held.

The hostages - nine Malaysians, three Germans, two French, two South Africans, two Finns, two Filipinos and one Lebanese - have been kept in an Abu Sayyaf stronghold in Jolo's hilly interior.

The area has been ringed by hundreds of troops and militia loyal to Mr Misuari while authorities make preliminary contact with the captors.

As European and Libyan envoys joined Philippine efforts to end the crisis, there were signs that the German woman, Renate Wallert, could soon be freed.

"So far it's good," said President Joseph Estrada's envoy, Robert Aventajado, when asked about the prospects for the release of Ms Wallert, who has high blood pressure and has weakened in the jungle heat since being abducted. "We have a jet on standby."

Abdusakur Tan, the governor of Sulu province, said the emissaries hoped to send a doctor to retrieve Ms Wallert. "Not necessarily today, maybe tomorrow, maybe the day after tomorrow," he said. "We are optimistic about the outcome of the negotiations."

After meeting Mr Estrada in Manila, the European Union's foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, said he hoped for a breakthrough in the hostage crisis "in the coming hours, in the coming days".

Mr Aventajado was joined on Jolo by a Libyan envoy, Rajab Azzarouq, who has experience of negotiating with rebels fighting to carve out a separate Islamic homeland in the southern Philippines.

Government troops and local militia have sought to seal off the section of remote jungle where the rebels have been hiding with their captives, occasionally skirmishing with the government's forces.

Mr Estrada's executive secretary, Ronaldo Zamora, said the troops did not intend to launch a rescue raid.

"We don't want to risk the lives that are at stake there," he said. "We will not move. If we do that, it is like condemning them to death."

In a letter to family members obtained by a cameraman who visited the hostages, the two South African hostages said they hoped that their government was pushing for their release.

"We are still OK, not eating healthy and under a lot of emotional stress, but we are praying (and preaching sometimes)," Carel and Monique Strydom wrote. "We will be back soon." Reuters

webTitle: Love bug suspect freed as hunt for hackers goes on

fields.headline: Love bug suspect freed as hunt for hackers goes on
fields.standfirst:
FBI - NIPC Advice & Warning
Sophos virus information Virus myths
fields.trailText: Prosecutors in the Philippines said yesterday that they did not have enough evidence to hold a man suspected of being one of the creators of the crippling love bug computer virus and ordered that he be freed from jail.
fields.body:
Prosecutors in the Philippines said yesterday that they did not have enough evidence to hold a man suspected of being one of the creators of the crippling love bug computer virus and ordered that he be freed from jail.

Reonel Ramones, a 27-year-old bank employee, was arrested by the Philippine National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) on Monday and charged with violating the Access Devices Regulation Act, which primarily deals with passwords for credit cards. Computer hacking is not a crime under Filipino law.

The charge was based on a complaint by an internet services provider that the virus, which penetrated millions of computers last week, originated in the flat where Mr Ramones lived with his girlfriend, Irene de Guzman.

Damage from the love bug virus and variants on it has already reached about $5bn (£3.3bn) and could amount to $10bn, the US firm Computer Economics said.

The original virus, tagged "ILOVEYOU", works by enticing e-mail recipients to open an attached letter; the virus launched then cripples their email systems.

"The evidence is incomplete," Severino Gana, a senior prosecutor, told reporters after an inquest on the NBI's findings, the prelude to the launching of a criminal case. "There are still diskettes which they need to evaluate."

He said Mr Ramones had been freed pending the collection of more evidence but would have to appear before authorities on May 19 to answer the preliminary charges.

Mr Ramones told the inquest that he was a victim of "mistaken identity," but did not elaborate.

NBI detectives searched his flat on Monday and arrested Mr Ramones but Ms de Guzman, 23, was not at home. She later told the NBI that she would turn herself in, but has not done so.

"Definitely she has nothing to do with it," Rolando Quimbo, Ms de Guzman's lawyer, said yesterday.

The chief state prosecutor, Jovencito Zunio, said the NBI would probably mount a separate investigation to determine whether Ms de Guzman was involved.

The couple both attended courses at the AMA Computer College (AMACC) in Manila and a senior NBI officer, Elfren Meneses, said eight other people with links to the college could be involved in the spread of the love bug. He told reporters that 10 coded names were found embedded in the virus.

"There were reports from the FBI that the names are somewhat from an organisation called AMACC," he said, adding that the college promised to help any investigation.

AMACC said in a press statement on Monday it was aware of reports that some people with links to it were accused of creating the love bug, and it did not condone hacking. Reuters

webTitle: How tourists could save Europe's natural born killers

fields.headline: How tourists could save Europe's natural born killers
fields.trailText: Conservationists yesterday called for a big increase in "carnivore tourism" to save Europe's last great predators from extinction.
fields.body:
Conservationists yesterday called for a big increase in "carnivore tourism" to save Europe's last great predators from extinction.

Well-managed tours could protect the continent's few remaining examples wolves and lynx, as well as the similarly threatened brown bear, by providing the funds to save their habitats, as well as boosting local jobs, according to a WWF-UK report.

The organisation said that a reduction in suitable habitat and encroachment and persecution by humans had all threatened the animals' survival. "These animals are Europe's pandas, tigers and rhinos," said the WWF-UK chief executive, Robert Napier.

The report highlighted the Carpathian mountains in Romania as an example of how responsible tourism can help to conserve carnivores and other large mammals. The mountains are home to the largest population of bears, wolves and lynx in any European country outside Russia.

"This is the last place where high numbers and large predators co-exist. Bears are nightly visitors to the city of Brasov and wolves scavenge for food within the city boundaries," said WWF-UK, while conceding that local farmers who are worried about livestock needed to be won over.

WWF-UK's report said national parks also suitable for nature tourism included Bialowieza in eastern Poland, where wolf-tracking is popular, and the Abruzzo in Italy where about 80 brown bears are thought to survive.

The report also looked at the Donana national park in Spain, important for conserv ing the Iberian lynx, and the Mercantour park, north of France's Cte D'Azur, where a "wolf centre" has been opened.

Small-scale nature tourism already under way not only brought in money, but also helped preserve local traditions including story-telling and shepherding.

WWF-UK is working with the Large Carnivore Initiative for Europe, comprising organisations from 17 countries.

webTitle: Japanese police stamp on foot fetish cult

fields.headline: Japanese police stamp on foot fetish cult
fields.standfirst: A guru who made millions from 'reading' victims' feet is arrested
fields.trailText: Japanese police yesterday swooped on a cult guru accused of a bizarre foot-reading swindle that has netted its practitioners £500m.
fields.body:
Japanese police yesterday swooped on a cult guru accused of a bizarre foot-reading swindle that has netted its practitioners £500m.

Hogen Fukunaga, the self-proclaimed reincarnation of Buddha and Christ, was arrested with 11 acolytes and charged with defrauding five women of 25m yen (£150,000).

His detention marks the climax of a four-year investigation into the Ho-no-Hana Sanpogyo cult, which attracts followers by offering to diagnose their spiritual and mental health through an examination of their soles and toes.

The followers paid 100,000 yen (£600 ) to have their feet stroked and scrutinised by Mr Fukunaga and other senior acolytes who claimed their powers were granted by a voice from heaven.

Based on the colour of the skin and marks on the toes, the foot readers predicted that the victims would suffer such fates as dying from Aids or falling into debt, or that their children would commit suicide.

A blemish on the big toe was said to indicate that the problem derived from the parents, on the second toe it was the grandparents and this pattern ran down to the little toe, where a mark indicated that today's problems could be traced to the follower's great-great-great grandparents.

Almost every diagnosis pin pointed anguish and suffering, which was hardly surprising as the followers had to write down their problems before each consultation with the sole-readers.

According to police, the sole-readers also followed a manual instructing them to make apocalyptic predictions that could only be averted by enrolling on three-day lecture sessions costing £15,000 or by purchasing expensive religious scrolls or a pinch of Buddha's ashes for £120,000.

"I was told that if I did nothing I would die of cancer, but if I followed the voice of heaven, then I would be cured," one victim told police.

Mr Fukunaga and his acolytes are believed to have taken in more than 22,000 people with the scam, netting themselves about 87bn yen (£512m) since the group was founded in 1987.

The arrest appears to mark the end for the 55-year-old Mr Fukunaga, a former electrical engineer who liked to mix with the rich and famous.

Ho-no-Hana's publications show the guru shaking hands with the Pope, Mother Teresa and Margaret Thatcher.

Mr Fukunaga denied fraud, saying he was no longer responsible because he had given up his position as head of the cult in January.

"I was just obeying the voices of heaven, but now I cannot remember what they told me," he said.

However, the arrest should not concern him too much - he has predicted that human beings will disappear from the Earth next January.

Groups that prey on members

Thanks to liberal religious beliefs and generous tax incentives, Japan is home to more than 20,000 new religions, several of which have recently been exposed as dangerous frauds or expensive gambles

Life Space has 150 members. It came into the spotlight in November when members were found trying to heal a decaying corpse that had been left in a hotel room for months. The cult's leader, accountant-turned-guru Koji Takahashi, who was paid to carry out the "treatment", said that the changing colour of the corpse was proof that the man was still alive

Kaedajuku has under 50 members. The group is led by management consultant Ju nichiro Higashi, who was found in January with two mummified children. He told police he was trying to revive the corpses with his energy, having charged the parents about 1m yen for the treatment

Myokaku-ji Leaders of this buddhist group swindled followers out of 19.8bn yen (£115m) in 1996. One of the group's tactics was to demand fees to exorcise the spirits of aborted foetuses from women who were guilt-stricken

fields.headline: Abacha's stolen millions 'in British banks'
fields.trailText: Hundreds of millions of pounds stolen by the late Nigerian dictator General Sani Abacha and his entourage is stashed in bank accounts in London and Jersey, lawyers working for the Nigerian government claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Hundreds of millions of pounds stolen by the late Nigerian dictator General Sani Abacha and his entourage is stashed in bank accounts in London and Jersey, lawyers working for the Nigerian government claimed yesterday.

The money is allegedly in accounts belonging to some of Abacha's close family and friends and some former members of his military government. It is thought to be part of an estimated £2bn systematically looted from Nigeria's central bank during the dictator's five-year rule.

Britain is not the only place where the money is stored - banks in Singapore, Hong Kong, Dubai, the US, Liechtenstein, Switzerland and Luxembourg are also involved.

Authorities in Switzerland froze £430m-worth of assets belonging to the Abacha entourage at the end of last year, and yesterday prosecutors in Luxembourg sequestered around £420m in eight separate bank accounts.

A Swiss lawyer acting on behalf of the Nigerian government has contacted the Home Office with a view to freezing British bank accounts containing money linked to Abacha.

The Nigerian government wants this money, estimated at more than £300m, returned along with any evidence which can be used in a case against Abacha's entourage. More than a dozen UK-based banks, some international and some British, are affected.

The Home Office yesterday said that it would neither confirm nor deny that UK banks are holding Abacha money or whether an investigation into the matter is under way. However, Peter Hain, the Foreign Office minister with responsibility for Africa, has already pledged British support in recovering the money.

Abacha took power in a military coup in 1993 after the newly elected Moshood Abiola had been deposed by a rival general. He then dissolved political parties, banned demonstrations and introduced strict media censorship.

A period of fierce repression followed and in 1995 Abacha ordered the execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa, the political activist who dared defy him, and seven others. Nigeria was then suspended from the Commonwealth. The general died of a heart attack in 1998.

"More than two and a half billion dollars was simply stolen as if from a cash register through a mixture of fraud, false contracts and commissions," Enrico Monfrini, the lawyer acting on behalf of the Nigerian government, told the Guardian yesterday. "We are aware that there is more money out there than we'll ever find.

"The longer we carry on the more we'll find. It's not just about money, it's symbolic. The current government wants to show Nigerians and the world that Nigeria exists and is fighting corruption with all its might."

There are, according to Mr Monfrini, only two ways the Nigerian authorities can now proceed: Abacha's entourage can either agree to the confiscation of all monies identified or the investigations will go on. Nigeria has already reclaimed some £530m-worth of assets taken during Abacha's rule and is anxious to get more.

In a bizarre twist to the case Johnnie Cochran, the lawyer who defended OJ Simpson, has been brought in by the Abacha entourage to help them retain the disputed funds.

Authorities in Switzerland froze £430m-worth of assets belonging to the Abacha entourage at the end of last year, and yesterday prosecutors in Luxembourg sequestered around £420m in eight separate bank accounts. A Swiss lawyer acting on behalf of the Nigerian government has contacted the Home Office with a view to freezing British bank accounts containing money linked to Abacha. The Nigerian government wants this money, estimated at more than £300m, returned along with any evidence which can be used in a case against Abacha's entourage. More than a dozen UK-based banks, some international and some British, are affected. The Home Office yesterday said that it would neither confirm nor deny that UK banks are holding Abacha money or whether an investigation into the matter is under way. However, Peter Hain, the Foreign Office minister with responsibility for Africa, has already pledged British support in recovering the money. Abacha took power in a military coup in 1993 after the newly elected Moshood Abiola had been deposed by a rival general. He then dissolved political parties, banned demonstrations and introduced strict media censorship. A period of fierce repression followed and in 1995 Abacha ordered the execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa, the political activist who dared defy him, and seven others. Nigeria was then suspended from the Commonwealth. The general died of a heart attack in 1998. "More than two and a half billion dollars was simply stolen as if from a cash register through a mixture of fraud, false contracts and commissions," Enrico Monfrini, the lawyer acting on behalf of the Nigerian government, told the Guardian yesterday. "We are aware that there is more money out there than we'll ever find. "The longer we carry on the more we'll find. It's not just about money, it's symbolic. The current government wants to show Nigerians and the world that Nigeria exists and is fighting corruption with all its might." There are, according to Mr Monfrini, only two ways the Nigerian authorities can now proceed: Abacha's entourage can either agree to the confiscation of all monies identified or the investigations will go on. Nigeria has already reclaimed some £530m-worth of assets taken during Abacha's rule and is anxious to get more. In a bizarre twist to the case Johnnie Cochran, the lawyer who defended OJ Simpson, has been brought in by the Abacha entourage to help them retain the disputed funds.

fields.headline: 'Cover-up' claim by freed man
fields.trailText: A man who spent 19 years in jail for a murder he did not commit yesterday accused the appeal court of a cover-up despite its ruling quashing his conviction.
fields.body:
A man who spent 19 years in jail for a murder he did not commit yesterday accused the appeal court of a cover-up despite its ruling quashing his conviction.

John Kamara, now 44, was wrongly convicted of the murder of a betting shop manager in Liverpool in 1981. His conviction was quashed in March this year after a lengthy legal battle.

Yesterday the three appeal court judges gave their reasons. They criticised the office of the director of public prosecutions for failing to disclose 201 witness statements taken by Merseyside police to the defence lawyers at the original trial.

They said: "On the material available before us, it appears that the fault lies within the office of the DPP.

"We have come to the firm conclusion that the verdicts of guilty of murder and robbery can no longer be considered safe."

Mr Kamara said yesterday that he was disappointed with the ruling. "It doesn't go far enough - it's a complete cover up," he said. "They have just blamed the DPP, when they should have looked at the way Merseyside police dealt with the investigation."

He plans to continue his legal battle to prove that the police knew about the statements which were not disclosed to the defence.

In 1981, Mr Kamara, from Liverpool, and Raymond Gilbert were sentenced to life in prison for the murder of John Suffield, stabbed during a bungled burglary at his betting shop. They were also convicted of robbery.

During the trial, Gilbert changed his plea to guilty. Even though Mr Kamara continued to profess his innocence, the trial was allowed to continue.

fields.body:
Nick Raynsford, the minister for planning and housing, has asked us to point out, in connection with our report, £120m stadium to be built next to incinerator, April 25, page one, that he is no longer minister for London. He has not had anything to do with any application for an extension of incinerator facilities in Edmonton.

In our leader, Death of a journalist, page 19, yesterday, we described Mr Lopez de la Calle, aged 62, as a "communist jailed by Franco's forces during the civil war ..." We meant to say during General Franco's dictatorship. The Spanish civil war started in 1936, before Mr Lopez de la Calle was born. General Franco, on the other hand, remained in power until his death in 1975.

In our report, Scientists race to beat DNA patents, page 9, yesterday, we gave the impression that DNA was made up of four acids. We should have said four bases.

The annual conference of the Association of University Teachers, page 9, Education, yesterday, is at Eastbourne, not Bournemouth.

Homophone corner, from a caption to the picture with our obituary of Gino Bartali, page 20, yesterday, "He was often urged on by children singing canticles as he peddled past."

fields.headline: An ethnical foreign policy
fields.trailText:
How much more TV news footage do we need of white boys off to Sierra Leone? All they lack is pith helmets. For goodness sake, one's even a girl. If we can see the Paras cleaning up their act on sex, where's the good news on race? Why do we go on showing Africa that to be white is to have the money, the guns and the best escape route when Freetown, yet again, lies open to the vengeance and butchery of the RUF? We could undo some of the damage we ourselves perpetuate by being prepared to defend everyone who lives there. But only with fighters who are a lot less black than the rest of us. We seem much more likely to fly in some black chaps from another ex-colony instead. It is high time Robin Cook, not least with some help from Geoff Hoon, scrapped this shamefully ethnical foreign policy.
Tom Snow
London

 You are right (Leader, May 8), the near total lack of international support for the Nigerian-led Ecomog peace enforcement efforts in Sierra Leone was simply criminal. The UN peacekeeping mission was a disaster waiting to happen. Not only are the light-armed peacekeepers from east Africa, Jordan, India and Pakistan out of their depth in the unfamiliar terrain, but also there is hardly any real peace for them to keep.

On a fact-finding mission to Sierra Leone last month, it was obvious that no weapons had been surrendered by either side. While Freetown appeared calm, clashes between combatants of the opposing camps continued in areas close to the capital. Further north, close to the border with Liberia, hardly any ceasefire could be observed. Former combatants waiting to be disarmed in demilitarisation camps have been starved of food rations and other support.

Proper risk assessment would have, for instance, led experts to question the level of control of Foday Sankoh and Johnny Koromah of the RUF over "their" combatants, particularly as some rebel field commanders are, for all intents and purposes, outside the peace process and under the protection of Charles Taylor in neighbouring Liberia. The abductions could well be the ex-combatants' way of posting statements about their neglect. It could also imply the existence of multiple centres of control over combatants. In all instances, the overriding desire to maintain control over mineral resources keeps the war going.

The only way to put the precarious peace process back on track is by deploying a credible peace enforcement contingent to counter the real threats on the ground, while "neutrals" carry out disarmament and reintegration. A revamped and adequately supported Ecomog can perform the former role, while the UN takes on the latter. UN peacekeeping must continue. Otherwise the only beneficiaries will be mercenaries and private military companies who are waiting in the wings as alternatives to multilateral peacekeeping.
J Kayode Fayemi Abdel-Fatau Musah
Centre for Democracy and Development
Cddorg@aol.com

 Before Britain takes all the credit for solving the UN's failure in Sierra Leone (Britain sets limits to show of force, May 9), we could perhaps think back to our reaction to the crisis last year. The frigate HMS Westminster was sent to restore confidence in Freetown following the expulsion of the rebels, but withdrawn the week that we began military action in Yugoslavia. Rather than contributing to any lasting peace, Britain told its former colony to make a deal with the rebels, while it got on with the serious business of war in Kosovo. Now we expect the UN to pick up the pieces. When are we going to accept responsibility for our actions and omissions?
Peter Moszynski
London
globewisecom@hotmail.com

webTitle: The best way to get rid of Mugabe

fields.headline: The best way to get rid of Mugabe
fields.trailText: Gary Younge's assessment of the options facing the MDC in Zimbabwe (Comment, May 8) overlooks two aspects of Zimbabwe's electoral history. Firstly, violence and intimidation have always accompanied elections in Zimbabwe, and the voters know this. (What is new in this election is the effectiveness of the opposition, and the violence affecting white voters too.) Nonetheless, the body politic has remained robust, and opposition alliances (such as ZUM and Forum) have grown in influence.
fields.body:
Gary Younge's assessment of the options facing the MDC in Zimbabwe (Comment, May 8) overlooks two aspects of Zimbabwe's electoral history. Firstly, violence and intimidation have always accompanied elections in Zimbabwe, and the voters know this. (What is new in this election is the effectiveness of the opposition, and the violence affecting white voters too.) Nonetheless, the body politic has remained robust, and opposition alliances (such as ZUM and Forum) have grown in influence.

Secondly, in 1980, when Zanu-PF was itself a movement for democratic change, the country's rulers believed that they had stitched up a deal which would, at best, produce a continuation of Muzorewa's acquiescent rule, and at worst produce an alliance with Joshua Nkomo. As with Mugabe's reserved seats in this election, the old white influence had reserved seats in 1980. And yet the voters exercised their right in a (broadly) secret ballot, regardless of what they were being told by the government, media or intimidators, and Zanu-PF won a massive majority.

The MDC is making a sensible choice in seeking the electoral route. What Zimbabwe needs now is not civil disobedience or cancelled elections, but an effective system of electoral monitoring. The international community has a clear role to play. Its role will have greater credibility if the UK keeps well out of it and stops acting as if it were still the responsible colonial power.
Dr Diana Jeater
University of the West of England
Diana.Jeater@uwe.ac.uk

 As a Zimbabwean, I feel Zimbabwe's opposition party is failing to make a difference. They could and should occupy the moral high ground of good governance and champion the most important of all human rights - the right to life. The opposition's response to President Mugabe and his supporters' campaign of intimidation and murder, telling its supporters to "put away their T-shirt for their safety" as Gary Younge put it, has only served to increase the thugs' arrogance. President Mugabe is confident no one will ask, "What land do the many innocent blacks beaten and murdered own?" Their double "crime" is that they dared long for freedom and they supported an opposition party that, like Zanu-PF, cares little about human life.
Name and address supplied

fields.headline: ... brought too close
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone matters and the fighting there needs to be fully reported. Despite that, I ask you not to publish images like the one on yesterday's front page, or at least confine them to an inner page where I can easily avoid them.
fields.body:
Sierra Leone matters and the fighting there needs to be fully reported. Despite that, I ask you not to publish images like the one on yesterday's front page, or at least confine them to an inner page where I can easily avoid them. As a clinical psychologist, I work closely with victims of violence and find my work emotionally draining. I control my exposure to violent imagery at home in order to avoid overload. I have no difficulty imagining what death and disaster look like and wish only that my exposure to them was less continuous.

Through pictures like that I become a secondary (though very minor) victim. It is possible that the majority of your readers value such explicit imagery, but this one would be grateful to have the choice.

I also wonder if images like this represent a form of institutional racism. Would you have printed a picture of a dead victim of a train crash in Britain in close-up on the front page? How does distance alone justify such explicitness?
Barbara Quin
Southsea, Hants
 My 17-year-old daughter returned from delivering newspapers this morning in some distress. The cause of this was the photograph of a recently killed man on the front page of your paper. She asked me if there were any guidelines as to what was appropriate or not for such prominent display. Perhaps you could enlighten us as to what your editorial policy is?

Of course we need to be informed about such atrocities but I agree with my daughter that putting such a picture where it is seen by people of all ages and sensitivities is gratuitously offensive.
John Hereward
London

fields.headline: Bilateral aid
fields.trailText: With news of drought in parts of western India (How one village beat the drought, May 1) and talk of organising international aid for the drought-stricken people of Rajasthan and Gujarat, it would be of interest to recall a similar tragedy faced by a small village in England nearly 150 years ago.
fields.body:
With news of drought in parts of western India (How one village beat the drought, May 1) and talk of organising international aid for the drought-stricken people of Rajasthan and Gujarat, it would be of interest to recall a similar tragedy faced by a small village in England nearly 150 years ago.

In the 19th century, the Maharajah of Benaras heard that the village of Stoke Row, near Henley in Oxfordshire, had no water supply. He was filled with sympathy for the poor peasants of Stoke Row and sent money for a well to be sunk so that the inhabitants could have water for the first time. The "Maharajah's Well" is still there and is an important and popular tourist attraction.
Daljit Sehbai
Kingston upon Thames

fields.headline: The left triumphed (or not)
fields.trailText: If Charlotte Raven (G2, May 9) had any experience in applied politics, she would know that the London Socialist Alliance's performances in assembly contests in London North East (7% of the vote) and Lambeth and Southwark (6.2%) were exceptional by any historic measure. Each of these assembly constituencies is the size of Sheffield. Is there a precedent for a previously unknown grassroots campaign, without a celebrity name on the ballot paper, without big business backing, denied an election broadcast or a free mailshot, saving its deposits and making substantial inroads on the vote? In many wards in Hackney, Islington and Lambeth, we scored 20%.
fields.body:
If Charlotte Raven (G2, May 9) had any experience in applied politics, she would know that the London Socialist Alliance's performances in assembly contests in London North East (7% of the vote) and Lambeth and Southwark (6.2%) were exceptional by any historic measure. Each of these assembly constituencies is the size of Sheffield. Is there a precedent for a previously unknown grassroots campaign, without a celebrity name on the ballot paper, without big business backing, denied an election broadcast or a free mailshot, saving its deposits and making substantial inroads on the vote? In many wards in Hackney, Islington and Lambeth, we scored 20%.

We ran an innovative and energetic campaign, harrying New Labour on the hustings and addressing a wide number of issues. These included not only the "economistic" issues (like affordable housing) which Raven finds "boring", but also democratic, social, cultural, environmental and personal issues - from police racism and the treatment of asylum seekers, to the legalisation of cannabis and the provision of cycle routes.

How sad to see the world through such tired stereotypes - "economistic left" v "anti-capitalist hippies". The LSA supported and took part in both demonstrations on May Day. "Inactivists" like Charlotte Raven are always several years behind the times.
Mike Marqusee
London Socialist Alliance

 Charlotte Raven is spot on. The left's failure to grasp the problem of "cultural ennui" among voters cost them dear. Step into a lift on practically any estate in London and the ennui, cultural or otherwise, is just overpowering.
Peter Keighron
London

fields.headline: Henry seals Wednesday's fate
fields.standfirst:
Peter Shreeves' side relegated after throwing away a two-goal lead
Bruce in pole position for Hillsborough role
fields.trailText: Arsenal 3 - 3 Sheff Wed
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday were finally relegated to the Nationwide First Division last night but not before an amazing fightback had seen them almost snatch a Premiership lifeline.

The noise emanating from Wednesday's travelling brass band belied the seriousness of the task of their team, who surprisingly saw their leading scorer Gilles De Bilde relegated to the bench and Andy Booth and the youngster Alan Quinn entrusted with the striking duties.

Arsenal - and their supporters - were in relaxed mood on a sultry evening, tensions eased by the certainty of second place and a Champions League berth. There was a rare, possibly sentimental, return for Nigel Winterburn at left-back as Wenger shuffled his defensive pack, resting Tony Adams and inserted Oleg Luzhny in central defence.

With Dennis Bergkamp starting on the bench Henry largely foraged alone up front, with Nwankwo Kanu in support. It was the prolific French striker who created an opening for himself after a desultory first half-hour.

There was little hint of danger to Wednesday's defence when Henry seized on a loose ball, sized up the opportunity and let fly from 25 yards with a low shot. Kevin Pressman was utterly beaten, but the ball rebounded from the near post.

Wednesday's sole response in the first half was a Booth header that David Seaman caught almost nonchalantly. It was a rare foray by a side whose shortage of goal power has plagued them all season.

Pressman was not seriously troubled, either, for most of the first half although he had to be alert to stop another sudden, low shot from the left, this time from Gilles Grimandi.

Arsenal's first-half goal, when it did come, arrived from an unlikely source. Henry closed to the left byline, swept in a quick, low cross that eluded two defenders and a stretching Pressman but Dixon managed to retrieve the ball close to the right byline and from a most unpromising position managed to squeeze it into the net.

Bergkamp replaced Parlour at half-time and the Dutch international began the second period by curling a free-kick straight at Pressman.

Finally the Owls made the necessary change, bringing on Gerald Sibon and Gilles De Bilde on 56 minutes for Haslam and Sonner.

It proved to be the most astute substitution of the season - and possibly Shreeves's career - as both players scored within four minutes of coming on.

Sibon scored with his first touch, climbing above Vieira to head home Wim Jonk's cross after 58 minutes.

And just two minutes later De Bilde stunned Highbury with an amazing second, playing a one-two with Booth, nutmegging Keown in the process, before slotting the ball past Seaman into the far corner.

The Wednesday management were up off the bench and De Bilde made his feelings about being dropped clear, gesturing wildly to the bench and punching the air furiously as his team-mates tried to congratulate him.

There was still more drama to come as Bergkamp flashed a shot just wide before Sibon wasted a glorious opportunity to make it 3-1. webTitle: Bruce in pole position for Hillsborough post

fields.headline: Bruce in pole position for Hillsborough post
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday, condemned to relegation last night, will attempt to entice the Huddersfield Town manager Steve Bruce to Hillsborough.
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday, condemned to relegation last night, will attempt to entice the Huddersfield Town manager Steve Bruce to Hillsborough.

Bruce has emerged as the leading contender to replace Wednesday's acting manager Peter Shreeves and the early indications are that the former Manchester United captain is willing to accept his third job in two years. Although Bruce is unwilling to go public with his grievances, he has become increasingly disillusioned at Huddersfield after suffering similar problems to those that prompted his defection from Sheffield United a year ago.

Money that was pledged by Huddersfield's owners has failed to materialise and their season subsequently finished on a disappointing note when they slipped out of the First Division play-off zone by losing 3-0 at Fulham on Sunday - the first time they had been out of the top six since the middle of September.

Nevertheless Bruce's record at both United and Huddersfield has been more than impressive considering their limited resources and Wednesday's debts of around £12m necessitate appointing some with a proven record of operating to a tight budget. The Wednesday hierarchy have spoken to Joe Kinnear although the former Wimbledon manager remains very much on their B list.

They are also monitoring Peter Taylor's situation at Gillingham but are less than optimistic about their chances of luring the former England under-21 manager away from the Second Division play-off contenders.

If Bruce opts to move across Yorkshire, and Huddersfield are certain to resist any advances, he can anticipate a busy summer of transfer activity.

Des Walker is likely to start the exodus with a move to either West Ham or Charlton and Celta Vigo want Wednesday's leading scorer Gilles de Bilde.

The chances of Niclas Alexandersson, Petter Rudi, Gerald Sibon, Wim Jonk, Lee Briscoe, Andy Hinchcliffe and Pavel Srnicek remaining at Hillsborough are almost non-existent and Danny Sonner, Ian Nolan and Peter Atherton, a target for Wigan Athletic, are all out of contract this summer.

On a brighter note, the promising Irish teenage midfielder Alan Quinn is close to signing a new four-year deal and the long- serving goalkeeper Kevin Pressman has indicated he wants to stay.

webTitle: Stuck in the middle with you

fields.headline: Stuck in the middle with you
fields.standfirst:
The average annual salary in Britain today is £21,000. Think that's good? Think it's bad? Think you could live on it? The four people here all do. Oliver Burkeman finds out what they think

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The average annual salary in Britain today is £21,000. Think that's good? Think it's bad? Think you could live on it? The four people here all do. Oliver Burkeman finds out what they think
fields.body:
Bill McFadyean, coastguard: Age 44, deputy district controller of the Marine Coastguard Agency in Aberdeen

It's a very varied life. This week, for instance, I was out of the office doing operational readiness checks and I found myself on an exercise on Loch Ness, at 9 o'clock on a Wednesday night with the wind blowing and heavy rain. But my worst experience has been the evacuation of a passenger vessel. This part of the world is the southern terminus for the UK's longest ferry journey, from Aberdeen to Lerwick, so you've got two ferries a night with potentially 600 people on each. We're always within 45 minutes of the operations centre, contactable on a pager and a mobile phone.

I'm responsible for the supervision, operation and administration of our district, stretching from Arbroath up the east coast to Helmsdale, near Wick. We have to ensure the operational readiness of teams up and down the coast in preparation for a search and rescue operation. You're looking at 800 incidents a year, ranging from children stuck on cliffs all the way up to oil-related accidents or a Piper Alpha-type situation.

I started as a coastguard up in Shetland 14 years ago. Initially I was a deck officer in the merchant navy but that was a single man's post and things change. When I decided to come ashore and start a family, I was looking to continue my career in a post in which my previous experience could be put to good use. Nowadays we have people from all sorts of backgrounds - straight from school or college or university.

I find the money extremely tight. I have three children, we take a short holiday each year and I drive an F-reg Sierra - 100,000 miles on the clock. But at the end of the week, I do feel as if it's been worthwhile. I feel I am making a difference as part of a team, sometimes saving lives, and I do get a buzz out of that.

Joel Hawkins, nurse: Age 31, clinical charge nurse at the Royal Maudsley Hospital's eating disorders unit

Getting people back into a healthier way of eating is one of the key parts of treatment at the unit, so if I get in at 7am, the first thing we do is have breakfast. Then there are snacks at 10 and dinner at 12. It's a busy day - meals, one-to-one therapy, teaching students - and it can be stressful: we treat people who have been ill for, on average, six years, and the nature of the conditions is that both patients and their relatives become incredibly distressed. Progress is measured in small amounts.

I don't come from a family of nurses - my interest probably stems from watching medical documentaries as a child. I thought the idea of someone choosing not to eat was endlessly fascinating - it's such a powerful thing, expressing such a level of distress, and is an area of psychology in which there are still many questions and not enough answers. It's a voyage of discovery, you and the patient learning together.

I'm married, with a child due in September, so I'm very conscious of my pay and of being able to provide. For what I do, with 17 patients, staff and relatives if they're on the ward - well, it's a lot of responsibility for 20-odd grand a year. It's never enough, but it's certainly not enough for my level of responsibility. I can't have holidays every year and I have to drive a fairly old car. That's one of the unfortunate things about nursing: you have to make compromises.

But I'm very committed to what I'm doing now. I could go and work in the private sector, but I have a very strong attachment to the health service: it's trained me and it's given me the most diverse experiences. And there's the age-old thing with nurses - you have a feeling of duty and that's what keeps you going.

Pippa Smith, trainee solicitor: Age 24, works at Beachcroft Wansbroughs Solicitors

I have wanted to be a lawyer for a long, long time, but I didn't always think I would want to be a solicitor. Until my first year in university, I wanted to be a barrister, but even then I could see that it's a very financially insecure occupation. As a solicitor, you are more stable because you're somebody's employee.

I work in employment law. I get in at about 9.15 in the morning, but there isn't really a typical pattern after that: I can never plan or structure my day because I work at the whim of the people in the department. But I do enjoy my job: it changes every day and there is a great deal of interaction with the rest of the team - which is another good reason not to be a barrister. When our work involves employees who are subject to disciplinary action because of their conduct, things can get quite high-profile, too.

As a trainee, you don't have complete control over specific cases and files. I have lots of responsibility, though - drafting letters, faxes and clauses, and amending contracts. There's a lot of attending meetings, too. As a trainee, you don't contribute all that much at these but you do take word-for-word attendance notes, which can be a bit boring and is a nightmare because you can never get everything down.

The money is enough to live on. I'm very lucky, mind you, because I live at home and so I don't have to pay rent. I have one major holiday a year and a few weekends away as well. I enjoy working in London - I think you get high-quality clients and I like the after-work socialising mentality, which I don't think exists everywhere - but I'm pretty sure it would be a struggle to afford to do the things I want to do if I had to pay for my own place here.

Thomas Burmester, web producer: Age 24, works on web production for BBC Online and lives in London

We get commissioned to produce websites for different parts of the BBC - there's a whole team involved, of designers, coders, sub-editors - and if it all goes like clockwork, then these elements are combined to make the site. The last one I did was for BBC Knowledge and it was full of interactive case studies, business theories and business gurus expanding on their particular subjects, from entrepreneurialism to change management to personnel.

I don't have any plans to become an internet entrepreneur. I've gone through phases where I thought maybe that would be an option, but right now I'm doing something useful, so I don't have the kind of crises you maybe get in other jobs where you think: "What have I been doing for the past six months?" It's in the nature of the job that at the end of each project, there's something there that wasn't there when you started and because they're all educational sites, there is obviously an educational value, too. Working in this particular industry is exciting at the moment - there's no such thing as a typical working day.

As for money, I got a raise recently, which has made things a lot easier, but even I'm having difficulty and I have no dependants or anything. I don't run a car and as for bar prices and things like that - well, I grew up in London, so I'm used to them.

What really bothers me is the cost of housing. I just rented a property yesterday and it's extortionate, it really is. I do sometimes wonder what would happen if I went and worked abroad, then wanted to return to London because it's my home - would I be able to afford to? If I don't buy a place now, am I ever going to be able to come back?

webTitle: Want to get ahead? See a head doctor

fields.headline: Want to get ahead? See a head doctor
fields.standfirst:
The way we work
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: You have been out of the office for a few days. On your return, do you tell senior colleagues:
fields.body:
You have been out of the office for a few days. On your return, do you tell senior colleagues:

a) you had an "intense" session with your therapist about your relationship with your mother and needed some time in your "own space"?

b) you have been on a "personal self-development" course which will transform the way you work and make the company more successful?

If you answered b) congratulations, you are on your way to the top of the corporate ladder. If you answered a) a big hand for your honesty and self-reflective nature. Sadly, they won't help you much in the dole queue for which you are headed. (But Mummy will probably look after you.)

Self-development courses for middle-ranking and senior executives are all the rage. Bombarded with messages about the need to be emotionally or even spiritually "intelligent" - which in the Good Old Days meant the ability to have a laugh at the office typist and consume vast amounts of booze at sales dinners - the average manager understandably feels in need of a little help. Enter the "guru", the person able to guide execs through this minefield and put their lives on a new and better path.

The Transformers, leaders in this field, promise nothing short of a better life, with a more successful company thrown in for good measure. One of the most striking aspects of these courses is their similarity to straightforward therapy. The Transformers encourage participants to think about their childhood and identify behavioural traits adopted at an early age to win love from the people around them. Then they are taught to apply these lessons to their current work and home life. So if the way you won love and respect was by being the toughest kid in the playground, maybe that explains your domineering approach to your spouse.

Given the content, it is not surprising that most of the people who attend these courses come away thinking about their personal lives, rather than how to handle the next marketing pitch. And on the face of it, there is nothing wrong with this stuff. But it isn't rocket science. For anyone who has been near a therapist - or even thought long and hard about themselves - this is a dot-to-dot exercise. The truth is that most people could get as much insight from an hour with a decent shrink, followed by a long walk in the park.

But remember the simple quiz. Therapy = P45. Self-development = promotion. Even in post-Diana Britain, most of us feel reluctance about going to a therapist, let alone telling colleagues about it. But it is equally clear that lots of us benefit from some deeper thinking about who we are and what patterns underlie our behaviour. What better solution than a course our companies actually pay for us to go on, ostensibly to make us more effective employees? Self-development is therapy in disguise. And for us uptight Brits, the disguise is all too necessary.

To the extent that people with more sorted heads make better workers, firms paying for therapy in disguise might seem a laudable development. But it's a bit more complicated than that. For a start, few Transformers are qualified in therapy and for people who are encouraged to bare all, the process can be dangerous because, unlike therapy, there is little follow-up.

There is another problem, too. It is not enough for firms to send their staff off to the head doctor (sorry, "business guru"), then just expect them to buckle down to it again because often difficulties are not in the heads of the staff but in the culture of the company. James Park from Antidote, a group that lobbies for greater emotional literacy in the workplace, says: "Employers tend to think they can just say 'Go and sort yourself out on a course'. But organisations must be as emotionally literate as individuals. They come back and all the old patterns are the same."

It may be that someone is a bully because they work in a bullying environment, rather than because their father never read fairy stories to them. But that would be a much tougher nut to crack. That would take real workplace transformation. So a few grand for a few days learning a few things in an overheated hotel seems like a bargain.

Rocking the boat

Wags in the consultancy business have reduced their beloved cycle of staff reduction programmes to a simple and easy-to-remember mantra: "First downsize, then rightsize, finally capsize."

Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

webTitle: Car insurer ordered to stop selling

fields.headline: Car insurer ordered to stop selling
fields.standfirst: Cut-throat pricing eats into Drake's margin of assets to liabilities
fields.trailText: A motor insurer with 200,000 clients and a £100m asset base has been ordered to cease writing new business because of the size of its liabilities. Drake Insurance of Brighton seems to have been a victim of cut-throat competition.
fields.body:
A motor insurer with 200,000 clients and a £100m asset base has been ordered to cease writing new business because of the size of its liabilities. Drake Insurance of Brighton seems to have been a victim of cut-throat competition.

The company "failed to maintain the required margin of assets over its liabilities and has failed to produce an adequate plan to remedy the situation," the financial services authority, the chief City regulator, said yesterday. Drake would need new funding to be allowed to recruit new policyholders, but the FSA said existing policies remain valid.

Among brokers through which the policies are sold is Direct Choice, a long-established telephone service operated by Taylor Price & Co, of Suffolk, which said it was seeking clarification from Drake.

The FSA said Drake "is taking steps urgently to contact all its intermediaries and agents to advise them of the situation".

Officially, Drake can take business up to today but it is thought all recruitment of policyholders has ceased.

In the event of the failure of any insurance company, the Policyholders' Protection Scheme will pay 100% compensation for insurance required by law - such as third-party motor cover - and, usually, 90% of other claims, such as fully comprehensive cover.

By law, insurers must maintain a healthy margin of assets over liabilities to ensure they can more than cover the "worst case" position on claims.

Drake advertises cover for "most types of private cars ranging from family saloons to high performance vehicles" and boasts an "elite repair service" under which collection of the damaged car and its repair are guaranteed, as is the free loan of a courtesy car while repairs are under way.

It has specialised in customers who are traditionally hard to insure. These are thought to include younger drivers and those who have made a number of previous claims.

Car insurance rates have been recovering after a highly competitive period in which profitability was sacrificed in the scramble for market share. Most rates, including Drake's, have been rising again, but it is understood actuaries were unable to vouch for Drake's ability to meet official standards on its ability to pay out likely future claims.

The FSA has been in contact with Drake for some time to see if there were an alternative to yesterday's action.

Nobody at the company was available for comment.

fields.headline: Anne-Sophie Mutter
fields.standfirst:
Anne-Sophie Mutter/ LSO/ Kurt Masur
***
Barbican Hall, London
fields.trailText:
Anne-Sophie Mutter/ LSO/ Kurt Masur
***
Barbican Hall, London
fields.body:
The final instalments of Anne-Sophie Mutter's survey of her own "subjective choice" of the 20th-century violin repertoire intensified the mixed feelings aroused by the series as a whole. The flaws in her playing that made the first three evenings variable - dodgy intonation, inconsistency in involvement and intensity - were mercifully less in evidence. But the self-congratulatory quality of the whole enterprise became increasingly apparent towards the end, particularly on the last night, which focused on two works she had inspired, Wolfgang Rihm's Time Chant and Penderecki's Second Concerto.

Subtitled Metamorphoses, the latter is an otiose piece, subjecting a single brief phrase, heard at the outset, to ceaseless transformations. Pulsating elegies alternate with a series of scherzos varying from the grotesque to the skittish, before seraphic calm finally descends. The demands it makes on Mutter are formidable - cadenzas full of triple-stopped trills, and the like - and one could only gawp at the stamina and athleticism with which she approached it, but the Concerto aims too high and goes on far too long.

Time Chant, however, is a canny, ambivalent masterpiece. Fascinated by what he describes as the "vocal" quality of Mutter's playing, Rihm turns her into a dominant siren, whose heady singing gradually coaxes an imitative, adulatory response from an accompanying chamber ensemble. Yet she is not allowed to be centre-stage all the time. At one point, the ensemble rebels with a series of resentful snarls, and she has to follow their lead until peace is restored.

It was the penultimate concert, however, which proved the best of the five. Clearly enjoying herself, she sailed through Bernstein's gorgeous Serenade with gleeful relish, pouring out a steady stream of warm lyrical tone. Lutoslawski's complex, austere Partita-Interlude-Chain II was invested with a thrilling ferocity which we hadn't heard since her performance of Bartok's Second Sonata on the opening night.

Throughout, Masur and the LSO have been outstanding - eloquent partners when Mutter has been on the platform, showstoppers when she is off it. Orchestral treats in the last two concerts included a hypnotic version of Ravel's La Valse, a sinuous Till Eulenspiegel and a performance of the Symphonic Picture from Gershwin's Porgy and Bess, for which the audience roared its approval, some standing to applaud. Throughout the entire series, Mutter never received quite such an enthusiastic ovation - and that, perhaps, is significant.

webTitle: Pensions to rise by up to £5 a week

fields.headline: Pensions to rise by up to £5 a week
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The government plans to raise basic state pensions by £4 or £5 a week next spring in an attempt to win back disaffected older voters before the general election.
fields.body:
The government plans to raise basic state pensions by £4 or £5 a week next spring in an attempt to win back disaffected older voters before the general election.

Though ministers are not prepared to restore the link between pensions and earnings, they are increasingly aware that last winter's 75p increase on a single person's pension backfired badly in last week's elections and accept that the £2 to £3 a week increase expected in next winter's inflation-linked increase will not be enough.

Gordon Brown and Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, are adamant that they will not sacrifice Labour's strategic goal of giving most extra cash to those pensioners in greatest need. But Mr Darling's officials are working on plans to increase the basic pension by more than inflation in April 2001.

The device now favoured at the Department of Social Security is one which would increase the winter fuel allowance still further above the £150 payment to all pensioner households which Mr Brown announced in his fourth budget last March.

Part of the increased allowance - perhaps to £200 or more - would then be consolidated into the basic pension. That would produce a £4 to £5 a week increase for single pensioners instead of the £2 to £3 which inflation trends currently indicate.

Treasury officials said last night that no final agreement on how best to tackle the pensions issue had yet been reached.

Although the pensions minister, Jeff Rooker, made a robust defence of the government's policy of targeting all extra money on the bottom one fifth of poorest pensioners - many of them over 75 - there are signals in Whitehall that the government is making hasty plans to increase the basic pension.

This contradicts Mr Brown's declared aim to focus extra funds where they are needed most, via his minimum income guarantee which has provided up to £20 a week extra for a million of the poorest pensioners.

"We are not going to be buffeted by short-term difficulties," one Brown adviser said last night.

But linking the minimum income guarantee to earnings not prices has caused other problems. It will continue to rise faster over the years, helping the poorest to catch up but that may create resentment among those pensioners with some savings or small occupational pensions. They will feel penalised for thrift without the adjustments - notably the new pension credit - which Mr Darling is devising.

The idea is that the government redistributes money between pensioners because their incomes have becomemore unequal than among the rest of the population. Pensioner groups, including Age Concern, have campaigned for the restoration of the link betweeen basic pension and earnings, which was broken 20 years ago by Margaret Thatcher.

But the chancellor this week said his total spending on increasing pensions has cost the state £800 more than if the government had re-established the earnings link.

Although the basic pension will rise above inflation next April under the Darling plan, the government will be able to claim it has not abandoned its policy.

Changes will be announced in November in the annual benefit uprating.

webTitle: Halifax seeks half a million new bank clients a year

fields.headline: Halifax seeks half a million new bank clients a year
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Halifax plans to assault the clearing banks' dominance of the market for current accounts by attracting 500,000 customers a year for the next four years to If, its new Intelligent Finance telephone and internet bank.
fields.body:
Halifax plans to assault the clearing banks' dominance of the market for current accounts by attracting 500,000 customers a year for the next four years to If, its new Intelligent Finance telephone and internet bank.

The second former building society in as many days to pledge to win customers from the four big clearing banks, which have an 80% stranglehold on current accounts, Halifax insisted that the proposition it unveiled yesterday heralded a revolution in banking.

Abbey National, another big former building society, earlier this week said it too wanted to boost the number customers using current accounts. Today, though, Lloyds TSB, one of the "big four", is expected to unveil its internet proposition, entitled ebank, as well as details of its internet bank in Europe. James Crosby, the chief executive of Halifax, said If was part of the bank's aim of becoming the "consumers' champion".

Unveiled to the tunes of Fatboy Slim, to which If has secured the rights for £500,000, If could save the typical consumer £60 to £70 a month, he said. Mr Crosby said banks made profits from borrowing money from customers in the form of current accounts and lending it back to the same individual through loans. If intended to avoid that.

Referring to Don Cruickshank's critical inquiry into banking competition, Mr Crosby said: "Cruickshank confirmed what we knew about UK banking".

He said If would allow Halifax, which also has its own-branded internet bank, to compete with the clearing banks in current accounts and credit cards. Halifax intends to roll the service out to small businesses, its first foray into the market. It is also looking for partnerships in Europe.

If consists of five products - current accounts, personal loans, credit cards, mortgages and savings - and will be connected together to allow customers to allow the rates of interest paid or charged on each of the products to counteract one another.

In some very few circumstances this would mean some customers enjoyed 0% mortgage rates, said Jim Spowart, chief executive of If, who also set up Standard Life bank.

Unlike other "start-up" banks, Mr Crosby said, If would be profitable in three years, produce a return on capital of 15% and have 500,000 customers in a year, and 2m by the end of 2004.

Mark Thomas, banking analyst at Fox Pitt Kelton said: "This type of product is not new although some of the technical delivery will be state of the art."

fields.headline: Microsoft wants mini-trial
fields.standfirst: The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft will today file court papers offering to change its behaviour in a move that could delay the final ruling in the anti-monopoly case brought against it by the US government.
fields.body:
Microsoft will today file court papers offering to change its behaviour in a move that could delay the final ruling in the anti-monopoly case brought against it by the US government.

It will also argue that the breakup of the company, as proposed by the Justice Department and 17 US states, goes far beyond the remit of the trial and that a new mini-trial is therefore warranted.

If the judge agrees, the final decision on Microsoft's fate could be pushed back several months.

Immediately after the government presented its break-up proposals two weeks ago, Microsoft lawyers said they would ask the judge for a mini-trial because of the scope of the proposals. A Microsoft spokesman said yesterday: "The government has essentially brought a whole new case under the guise of remedy proposals that should not be allowed to stand."

The company has rejected any attempt to split its Office applications software from its Windows operating system. One adviser said that "not a word" was said about Office or the server market during the two-year trial.

However, the Justice Department has argued that Microsoft attempted to use its stranglehold on the operating system market to force its way into other markets. In its submission to Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, the government said only drastic restructuring could end this behaviour.

Sources said yesterday that Microsoft's own proposals - such as promising not to discriminate between developers - would fall short of the government's suggestions and would be unlikely to satisfy the Justice Department.

In meetings held after Judge Jackson found Microsoft guilty of breaking anti-trust laws, the company's lawyers said they could not agree to a timetable for the trial until they knew the scope of the government's proposals.

Judge Jackson's comments that this was a "fair" demand led Microsoft to believe that he will agree to further hearings, although Judge Jackson has indicated a desire to rule on the case as quickly as possible.

Microsoft has already said that it will appeal his earlier ruling once he has made a final ruling.

fields.headline: Pru rushes to float Egg
fields.standfirst:
Hasty public offering of internet bank will bring in half what it once promised

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Prudential is to rush ahead with plans for the partial flotation of its Egg banking subsidiary even though it will fetch half the £4bn price tag the City first attached to the telephone-cum-internet bank.
fields.body:
Prudential is to rush ahead with plans for the partial flotation of its Egg banking subsidiary even though it will fetch half the £4bn price tag the City first attached to the telephone-cum-internet bank.

In a statement expected as soon as today, Pru will outline its intention to publish a prospectus towards the end of the month with a plan to sell shares to investors in the first or second week of June.

The insurance group is expected to admit that Egg's break-even targets - it cost Pru £150m last year - have been pushed even further past the "latter part of 2001" date.

Egg, which sent shock waves through the financial services industry when it was opened 18 months ago because of its high savings rates, is now expected to break even in 2002 and move into profit some time during that year.

It was not clear last night what proportion of Egg is to be sold to investors, but the City expects Pru to settle on selling a 20% stake in the bank, which now has £7.6bn of deposits and 250,000 credit card customers.

Pru, which refused to comment last night, has said that by selling off Egg it would be able to improve the return to its shareholders who have watched their shares fall from above £12 at the start of the year to under £9.40 last night.

Jonathan Bloomer, the new chief executive, has also admitted that the share sale would make it easier for Egg to make acquisitions and incentivise its staff to prevent them being lured by other dot.com companies.

Egg was beset by difficulties in its early months when it was swamped by demand from savers for its new products. City analysts initially valued it at between £1.5bn to £4bn. However, the City believes that the insurer is thought to have been told by its advisers that a more realistic price tag is between £1.5 and £2bn.

It has expanded from a high-rate of interest savings account to a "supermarket" for funds products.

The City had originally expected the Egg share sale to take place in July but the timing is thought to have been revised after the recent shake-out in dotcom stocks and to avoid any further diminishing in investors' appetite for such stocks during the traditional summer lull.

Pru has said that Egg's 800,000-or-so customer base will not receive any direct personal benefits as a result of the flotation but they will be able to subscribe for shares.

One leading analyst said yesterday that by floating off part of Egg, the insurance group would make it easier for the City to value its shares, including its so-called £8bn of "orphan assets".

By spinning off a minority of Egg, Pru will be retaining a controlling interest in the bank.

The insurer has not given an indication of how long it intends to retain a majority stake but can expect speculation that it will gradually reduce its holding after the move by Dixons earlier this week that it was considering selling its remaining 80% stake in Freeserve, the internet service provider.

The Egg share sale comes at a time when many of the traditional banking players are also setting up new banks. Halifax, which yesterday unveiled plans for its Intelligent Finance telephone and internet bank, said it did not have any plans to sell off any stake in the new venture.

webTitle: He liked Rover so much he bought it. For £10

fields.headline: He liked Rover so much he bought it. For £10
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Rover's giant Longbridge complex was dramatically rescued yesterday, reprieving thousands of car jobs in the West Midlands and defusing an industrial and political crisis.
fields.body:
Rover's giant Longbridge complex was dramatically rescued yesterday, reprieving thousands of car jobs in the West Midlands and defusing an industrial and political crisis.

Jubiliant workers at the Birmingham site celebrated after BMW agreed to sell its factory to the Phoenix consortium for a symbolic £10 and to fund £575m to cover running costs - though whether the money was a loan or a gift was being disputed last night.

But as Tony Blair and the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, welcomed the agreement, Ford was preparing to announce tomorrow night that car production is to end at its plant at Dagenham, east London, with the loss of 3,000 jobs.

The Ford decision underlines the shaky state of the British motor industry, which is being buffeted by the strong pound and massive international over-capacity.

And despite yesterday's relief in the West Midlands some experts remain sceptical about the long-term prospects for the Phoenix plan.

The sudden completion of the BMW-Phoenix deal was as dramatic as last month's collapse of talks with the venture capitalists Alchemy and the German company's original announcement two months ago. Closure of Longbridge could have led to the loss of 24,000 jobs in a region that contains a number of Labour constituencies.

The Phoenix plan envisages that redundancies at Longbridge would be below 1,000, with up to £25,000 offered to workers who lose their jobs.

Mr Towers made clear that Phoenix, which intends to build about 200,000 cars a year, is seeking a partner and confirmed that Honda of Japan has already been approached. He also signalled that state aid is likely in the future to retool Longbridge and design new models.

"What we're looking for from the government is strong support, but not support in terms of massive state aid," said Mr Towers. "That would be folly and is not the way we've put our plan together."

He said the aim was to make Phoenix profitable in two years.

The prime minister congratulated Mr Byers, who had to lobby BMW initially.

Up to 60% of the new company is to be owned by the workforce and dealers, with about a quarter of the shares likely to be offered to employees through a Treasury-backed scheme.

The workforce at Cowley fear they could pay a high price for Longbridge's survival. The Rover 75 executive model is to be transferred to the West Midlands, leaving the Oxfordshire plant without a car until the new Mini comes on stream next summer. BMW said yesterday there would be no redundancies and any production shortfall would be covered by flexible shift patterns which allow for shorter hours when work is slack and longer hours when demand picks up.

Professor Joachim Milberg, BMW's chairman, said: "After intense negotiations, we have managed to find a buyer for Rover whose aim is to continue to run Rover and who will therefore prevent the loss of thousands of jobs in the Rover plant in Birmingham, in the supplier industry and in the retail business."

A BMW spokesman said the £575m made available to Rover was a loan, but a British source close to the negotiations said it would not have to be repaid.

Tony Woodley, chief car negotiator for the T&G transport union, said: "We've worked extremely hard, thousands of hours of work with the Towers team, to be able to limit the damage after the industrial disaster that BMW left us with."

Graeme Maxton, an analyst at the consultants Autopolis, warned: "Phoenix is buying a marginal brand which lacks scale in a market which is consolidating. It is good for employment but I suspect this just prolongs the agony."

Ford is accused by the unions of going back on earlier undertakings to continue carmaking at Dagenham by ceasing to build Fiestas by November 2001, switching production to Cologne in Germany.

The 3,000 workers facing redundancy will be offered pay-offs of up to £55,000 or redeployment when vacancies arise. To sweeten the pill, Ford is to expand engine manufacturing at the site.

Angela Browning, Tory trade spokeswoman, reacted to the rescue by accusing Mr Byers of failing to spot BMW's decision to pull out of Longbridge.

Fewer than 1,000 redundancies at Longbridge

Company will sell as many as 200,000 cars next year

Rover will be profitable within two years

A new estate version of the Rover 75 executive model will prove popular

Using new suppliers will reduce the cost of developing new models

Another car manufacturer will be found to collaborate with the company

webTitle: Surrey must look to cup for cheer

fields.headline: Surrey must look to cup for cheer
fields.trailText: Surrey, the championship favourites and most richly talented side in the domestic game, will seek to reverse their disastrous start to the summer today in an eye-catching B&H Cup quarter-final against Yorkshire at Headingley.
fields.body:
Surrey, the championship favourites and most richly talented side in the domestic game, will seek to reverse their disastrous start to the summer today in an eye-catching B&H Cup quarter-final against Yorkshire at Headingley.

Their only doubtful starter is the opener Mark Butcher, who is expected to recover from a sore ear, while Yorkshire have been weakened considerably by injuries to the test newcomer Michael Vaughan and paceman Chris Silverwood.

Surrey will be keen to repair the damage inflicted by Durham, hardly the most fearsome of foes, in beating them inside three days in the championship last week. Though their recent one-day record has been poor - indeed they only snuck through to this stage of the tournament on run-rate - the likes of Alec Stewart, Graham Thorpe, Alex Tudor and the unfulfilled talents of the Hollioakes, Adam and Ben, suggest that on paper at least they are ideally suited to the shorter game.

Lancashire have brought in Chris Schofield to replace the off-spinner Gary Yates for their quarter-final against the summer's upstarts Durham at Old Trafford.

The rookie leg-spinner showed his all-round talents in the championship last week, complementing his four second-innings wickets with a career-best 66 not out. But the man to watch out for will be Andrew Flintoff, who has combined might with maturity this season and boasts a first-class average of 138.

Gloucestershire, the winners of last year's so-called B&H Super Cup, will continue their defence against Sussex at Hove. The home side will again look to their Australian batsman Michael Bevan, who has smashed one century and three fifties in four one-day innings this season, to give them the edge. The champions have added the seamer Jon Lewis to their squad.

Australians will also be prominent in the other quarter-final between Glamorgan and Hampshire at Cardiff, where the Victorian pair Matthew Elliott and Shane Warne will be enemies for only the second time.

"It was back in 1989 in a district cup match," said Elliott of the first occasion, "but I didn't even face him because I got myself run out before he came on to bowl."

Derek Kenway will again stand in for Hampshire's regular keeper Adrian Aymes. Glamorgan have named the all-rounder Alex Wharf and left-arm spinner Dean Cosker.
