webTitle: TV deal to fuel Premiership wage hike

fields.headline: TV deal to fuel Premiership wage hike
fields.standfirst:
Clubs prepared to gamble with high stakes risk financial ruin, says new report
Deloitte and Touche survey
fields.trailText: Football clubs continue to spend most of their revenue on players' wages, but may end up paying them even more because of increased income from the new television deal.
fields.body:
Football clubs continue to spend most of their revenue on players' wages, but may end up paying them even more because of increased income from the new television deal.

Though revenue for all 20 Premiership clubs increased by 18% during the 1998-99 season, their total wage bill shot up by 31% to just over £397m. Salary costs now account for more than 59% of the clubs' income, with Manchester United the highest payers.

According to the survey of Premiership finances by the accountants Deloitte and Touche, gate receipts still generate the bulk of club revenue but television money is catching up fast.

The survey found that 37% of club revenue was provided by gate receipts, 29% by television. Despite more football on television, Premiership attendances have increased on average by 56% since the 1980s.

The survey says clubs will benefit even more from the forthcoming renegotiated television deal, which begins next year and will lead to greater income from pay-per-view, internet rights and increased competition between broadcasters. According to some estimates the deal will be worth as much as £2bn and the bulk will go towards higher wages.

The report warns: "Any significant increase on the previous deal will mean a rise in income for the clubs and in demands from players and their agents. This will be a true test for chairmen and managers."

The report suggests that in financial terms there are three or four sub-divisions within the Premiership, with Manchester United leading the way, followed by Newcastle, Liverpool, Tottenham, Chelsea and Arsenal. The Old Trafford club pay the highest wages but are financially more secure than many of their rivals.

Robert Elstone, one of the report's authors, estimates that clubs spending more than 50% of their turnover on wages, which in 1999 was everyone except Manchester United, Aston Villa and Leeds, may face financial ruin if their gambles do not pay off.

Liverpool and Everton spent 80% of their turnover on wages and Blackburn Rovers, relegated in 1998-99, exceeded their turnover for that season by spending £26.8m. Southampton spent 84%.

Elstone said: "Paying high wages is a very dangerous strategy but some clubs see investment in the short term as a way to make the club stronger in the long term.

"But the money has to be borrowed and that increases debt, which must be paid back eventually. For someone like Southampton with a limited income it is a huge risk."

Controversially, the report suggests that clubs in some cities may have to merge to increase their fan base and unite resources.

The report found that though revenue from television is set to increase, fans are spending less on merchandising and the clubs' earnings from such revenues are falling each season.

Given the growing overseas popularity of the Premiership, clubs may have to search abroad for income. The report states: "Development of inter national revenues, where English clubs are hardly scratching the surface at the moment, could and should be the next big step for the top few clubs."

Transfer activity was also healthy in 1998-99, with a total of £268.8m spent by Premiership clubs, an increase of £55.6m on the previous season. Of that total, £136.2m was spent on players from English clubs and £132.6m from non-English clubs.

There was also good news for the Nationwide League, with £27.5m trickling down the divisions in transfer fees. During the 1997-98 season smaller clubs benefited by only £1.5m in transfer dealings with the Premiership clubs.

The report claims the Premier League is financially the strongest in Europe. Average gate receipts are twice those in Italy's Serie A, three times those in Germany and four times those in France.

However, Manchester United, Chelsea and other leading clubs receive about £10-12m each season from broadcast fees whereas leading clubs in Italy and Spain receive £30-50m.

fields.headline: Bayern Munich 2 - 1 Real Madrid
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Bayern Munich: Kahn, Babbel, Lizarazu, Kuffour, Andersson, Scholl, Elber, Effenberg, Sergio, Jeremies, Jancker. Subs: Wessels, Weisinger, Fink, Tarnat, Salihamidzic, Santa Cruz, Linke.

Real Madrid: Casillas, Carlos, Redondo, Raul, McManaman, Savio, Campo, Helguera, Anelka, Geremi, Julio Cesar. Subs: Bizzarri, Sanchis, Baljic, Karembeu, Ognjenovic, Sestelo, Meca Garcia.

Referee: G Poll (Tring)

Bayern will be hoping their 3-0 German Cup final win over Werder Bremen will help inspire them against a Real team hoping to reclaim the trophy the club won in 1998.

For the Germans, Zickler is out with a torn tendon, while Brazilian Savio replaces injured striker Morientes for Real.

1 FA Cup final referee Graham Poll gets the game underway and Jeremies cuts out an early advance by Savio for Real.
2 Scholl makes a good run to the edge of the Real penalty area but loses possession at the critical .
3 Bayern almost open the scoring. Babbel plays a one-two with Paulo Sergio on the right before crossing for Jancker in the six-yard box; 'keeper Casillas misses the ball and Helguera clears off the line.
5 Bayern so far doing a good job of keeping Real in their own half.
7 Scholl with a corner for Bayern on the right but Real clear. Babbel launches a long throw towards the box but it is cleared for a corner.
8 Scholl again takes but comes to nothing.
10 Babbel gets on the end of a Scholl cross to the far post but can only dircect his header wide of the post.
11 Real concede a free-kick after a Helguera challenge on Effenburg.
12 Goal: B Munich 1 - 0 Real Madrid Efenburg finds Jeremies on the left-hand corner of the Real penalty area; he crosses to Sergio on the far post and Jancker is on hand to head home.
15 Paulo Sergio and Jancker are all over the Real penalty area as Bayern sense they could recover the deficit in the first 45 minutes.
17 Paulo Sergio makes a surging run from midfield before being tackled on the edge of the area. Elber picks up and instantly shoots straight at Kahn.
19 Anelka and Raul looking somewhat lonely up front as Real keep men back to counter a rampant opening spell from Bayern. Bayern win a corner but it comes to nothing.
22 Real start pushing the ball out to Steve McManaman on the right but his passes are not finding the target.
23 Geremi attempts to find a way through the middle with a centre to Raul but the ball doesn't fall kindly.
25 Much more play in the Bayern half now as Real push up.
26 Bayern unlucky not get a second. Paulo Sergio attacks on the break and gets the better of McManaman deep on the left. He lays the ball back for Scholl to shoot from 20 yards but Casillas can only parry and when Elber pounces on the loose ball he is called offside.
29 Real come close when Kahn misjudges a Real corner and sees the ball fly just over the bar.
30 Elber, on the edge of the area, shoots through the legs of Campo but well wide of Casillas.
31 Goal: Bayern Munich 1 - 1 Real Madrid Savio and Redondo exchange passes deep on the left before Redondo crosses for Anelka to glance a header into the near corner. Bayern now need to score three more gaols to go through to the final.
34 Geremi picks up the rebound from a McManaman corner and shoots from 25 yards; Kahn saves easily.
36 Lizarazu finds Jancker on the edge of the penalty area and the big German holds off Geremi before centering for Scholl to shoot at Casillas. Great movement from Bayern.
39 McManaman picks up Geremi's centre to the edge of the Bayern area before passing to Raul. He loses possession but the ball comes out for Geremi to force an excellent save form 'keeper Kahn.
42 A scramble in the Real goalmouth allows Bayern a sniff of another goal, Scholl fails to get enough power behind his eventual shot and Real clear.
43 Bayern desperate now to get another goal before half-time.
44 Booking Elber for a challenge on Helguera.
45 Bayern win a corner, Scholl takes but Kuffour, steaming into the box, is unable to get on the end of it. Real attack on the break and Anelka fires in a right-foot shot from 15 yards for Kahn to claw clear at the near post. Half-time. After a blinding start, Bayern now have it all to do in the second half.

46 Bayern kick-off and will be hoping for a miracle if they are to prevent their hopes a final place disappearing into the Bavarian hinterland.
47 Real playing well back as Effenburg tries to make early inroads down the left.
49 Bayern win a corner, Effenburg takes, Real clear.
50 Geremi and Anelka try to work the ball down the right but Geremi's cross is poor.
52 A hopeful long ball finds Jancker outnumbered in the Real area.
54 Goal: Bayern Munich 2 - 1 Real Madrid Effenburg floats a free-kick into area and Elber glances a header into the far corner of the net to give the German side a glimmer of hope.
56 A lot of arguing after a foul on Jancker brings a free-kick for Bayern on the edge of the Real area. Effenburg takes, hits the wall and Real clear.
59 Real attack with Anelka and Raul through the middle before the ball is laid off for Geremi out on the right. Real win a corner but the ball runs out for a throw-in.
60 Substitutions Babbel on for Salihamidzic.
61 Lizarazu gets away from Geremi on the right and tries unsuccessfully to chip Casillas.
62 Good work by Bayern allows Savio a shot at goal; Scholl fails to make the most of the deflection. Corner to Bayern, taken by Scholl, with Jancker just failing to beat Casillas at the near post.
66 Salihamidzic spots Casillas out of position and attempts and audacious lob from distance that Casillas manages to tip over the bar.
67 Bayern appeal for a penalty after Geremi brings down Lizarazu just outside the Real penalty area. Referee Poll opts for the power of words rather than book Geremi.
69 As in the first half, an intense 20 minutes by Bayern is starting to give way to more attacking play from Real.
70 Bayern refuse to lie down and Paulo Sergio wins a corner deep on the left. Kuffour makes his way up to the penalty area but fails to make the crucial contact.
73 Real push up and knock the ball around in the Bayern half as if they are the only team on the pitch.
74 Anelka gets away from Kuffour in the Bayern area but his chip over Kahn goes for a goal-kick.
77 Redondo finds McManaman in midfield, he passes to Raul who then exchanges passes with Geremi before running into trouble deep on the right.
79 Booking Lizarazu. Substitution Santa Cruz on for Jancker.
81 Substitute Karembeu on for Savio.
82 Real Madrid now looking as if they are in firm control of the game and are fighting to regain possession each time Bayern attack.
83 Bayern win a free-kick 30 yards out but Effenburg fails to make it count.
84 Bayern win another free-kick out on the right but Scholl's effort is again poor and Real clear.
87 Bayern continue to play balls into the Real penalty but Real keep things tight.
88 A massive clearance by Kahn finds Effenburg running on to goal but his snatched shot flies over the bar.
89 Bayern see their hopes disappear when Effenburg fires wide after Casillas makes a hash of a high ball into the area.
90 Bayern continue to look for an opening but Real, defending deeply, muster well and play out time. Full-time. Bayern Munich 2 - 1 Real Madrid. Real go forward to make up the first half of an all-Spanish Champions League final in Paris.

Kuffour makes his way up to the penalty area but fails to make the crucial contact. 73 Real push up and knock the ball around in the Bayern half as if they are the only team on the pitch. 74 Anelka gets away from Kuffour in the Bayern area but his chip over Kahn goes for a goal-kick. 77 Redondo finds McManaman in midfield, he passes to Raul who then exchanges passes with Geremi before running into trouble deep on the right. 79 Booking Lizarazu. Substitution Santa Cruz on for Jancker. 81 Substitute Karembeu on for Savio. 82 Real Madrid now looking as if they are in firm control of the game and are fighting to regain possession each time Bayern attack. 83 Bayern win a free-kick 30 yards out but Effenburg fails to make it count. 84 Bayern win another free-kick out on the right but Scholl's effort is again poor and Real clear. 87 Bayern continue to play balls into the Real penalty but Real keep things tight. 88 A massive clearance by Kahn finds Effenburg running on to goal but his snatched shot flies over the bar. 89 Bayern see their hopes disappear when Effenburg fires wide after Casillas makes a hash of a high ball into the area. 90 Bayern continue to look for an opening but Real, defending deeply, muster well and play out time. Full-time. Bayern Munich 2 - 1 Real Madrid. Real go forward to make up the first half of an all-Spanish Champions League final in Paris.

webTitle: Promoted City in line for £35m cash boost

fields.headline: Promoted City in line for £35m cash boost
fields.trailText: Manchester City are on the verge of elevating themselves into a new financial league that would see them benefit from their return to the Premiership to the tune of £35m.
fields.body:
Manchester City are on the verge of elevating themselves into a new financial league that would see them benefit from their return to the Premiership to the tune of £35m.

The renewal of hostilities with Manchester United, as opposed to Macclesfield 18 months ago, has prompted an approach from undisclosed backers who are willing to swell City's finances by £20m.

Negotiations are at a preliminary stage but the Maine Road hierarchy are confident they can strike a deal that will ensure they will not be Premiership paupers next season.

"We have had an approach from a specific party and although we won't be rushing into anything we shall be looking at it very carefully," City's chairman David Bernstein confirmed last night.

"We have gone from a weak bargaining position to a very strong one and we shall be getting the deal that is best for this club. We're not in a boom-and-bust situation and it's vital we investigate all our options."

Even though United may still seem light years away, the proposed money injection will go a considerable way towards making Mancunian derbies a regular fixture in the sporting calendar once again. City stand to gain £15m from season-ticket sales, sponsorship deals and television rights.

"There will be substantial funds available for Joe [Royle] to spend on new players," said Bernstein. "My dream is for City to be at the best of British football, then European football, and Manchester can become the Milan of Britain with two great sides. We will not be found wanting when it comes to finance and Joe knows he has our full backing."

So much so, in fact, that City are offering the 51-year-old manager an extended contract to 2004. "The masterplan is to retire at 55. I want to go out while I've still got all my marbles and still got all my hair," said Royle, who has more than a year left on his present deal. "For the time being I will be looking at bringing in one or two players, although I don't foresee wholesale changes. The players who have taken us into the Premiership deserve the chance to prove it is their stage. It won't be a case of saying thank you and goodnight."

Across the city, meanwhile, Sir Alex Ferguson, 58, has disclosed he wants to remain on the United payroll as an international ambassador when he relinquishes team duties in two years' time.

"The last thing I want to do is continue in first-team management. What I have in mind would have nothing to do with that," he said. "The way United are growing it is becoming a very big organisation. We already have alliances in Cape Town, Belgium, Sweden, Ireland and many other places.

"I would like to travel and see certain places properly, like Australia, South America or China. In football we travel the world but we don't get a chance to see these places."

After 14 years at Old Trafford, however, it is clear that when Ferguson reaches the age of 60 he will want only a part-time role. "The thing about retirement is that if you wait too long you won't be able to do the things you've talked about over the years because you won't be fit to do them. Old age doesn't come alone.

"Retirement for me would be about remaining just active enough to spread out the week. For example, two or three days' work and three or four days off to pursue other interests such as my racehorses. Plus the odd fortnight here or there to allow me to visit the countries I've talked about."

 Charlton's manager Alan Curbishley has a £12m transfer budget to keep the club in the Premiership next season. He has been given £9m to add to the £3m still in the kitty from the £4m sale of Danny Mills to Leeds last summer.

webTitle: Le Saux promised England place if he proves fitness

fields.headline: Le Saux promised England place if he proves fitness
fields.trailText: Graeme le Saux, out for almost eight months, has been given an even greater incentive to return for Chelsea after Kevin Keegan virtually guaranteed the left-back a place in the England squad for Euro 2000 if he proves his fitness before the end of the season.
fields.body:
Graeme le Saux, out for almost eight months, has been given an even greater incentive to return for Chelsea after Kevin Keegan virtually guaranteed the left-back a place in the England squad for Euro 2000 if he proves his fitness before the end of the season.

An ankle injury has sidelined the 31-year-old Le Saux since October but he has an outside chance of featuring in Chelsea's final league game, against Derby on Sunday, six days before the FA Cup final against Aston Villa.

Keegan said yesterday: "I'll be absolutely delighted if he is considered fit enough to play in the Cup final, or in one league game and then the Cup final. If he was fit then, there's no doubt about it, he would be in the squad.

"The door is still open for Graeme. He's a left-sided player and we haven't got an abundance of them.

"I would say if he proves his fitness then I can make a judgment on that, just like I will with Robbie Fowler.

"We must remember England have three games as well before Euro 2000. Anybody only playing one game before the end of the season will actually have four games before the tournament."

The news will be heartening for Le Saux, who has started only 10 Chelsea matches this season and recently admitted it was "unlikely" he would have enough games to prove his fitness before Keegan names his squad on June 1.

England's first-choice left-back in France 98 has not played competitively since suffering ankle tendon trouble against Arsenal in October and has had two operations with as many comeback dates unfulfilled.

But he recently started running again and his availability would offer Keegan a valuable option in what has been a notorious problem position for England.

England have warm-up friendlies against Brazil and Ukraine at Wembley after the FA Cup final before Keegan names the 22-man squad who will travel to Belgium and the Netherlands for Euro 2000, which starts on June 10.

Before their first game, against Portugal on June 12, Keegan's men travel to Malta for a final friendly international.

Sol Campbell has ended speculation about his future by saying he will stay at Tottenham next season, according to Spurs' director of football David Pleat.

The England centre-back has been continually linked with a £15m move to Manchester United but Pleat said the captain plans to see out his contract, which expires after next season, and is in negotiations over a new deal.

David Ginola, angry at being dropped at Manchester United on Saturday, will be assured he has a future at Tottenham when he meets the manager George Graham this week.

"David has an important part to play for Tottenham next season," Graham said. "I want him to stay." But he will tell the Frenchman that he has to accept that he cannot start all matches.

Manchester United yesterday told Massimo Taibi, the goalkeeper bought from Venezia last August for £4.3m but who made only four first-team appearances, that his future lies in Italy. He is currently on loan with Reggina.

webTitle: Italy in uproar after Juve steal a march

fields.headline: Italy in uproar after Juve steal a march
fields.trailText: Suspicions of conspiracy and corruption chilled Italian football yesterday after a disallowed goal effectively handed the Serie A title to Juventus and prompted Lazio to threaten to quit domestic football in favour of a European super league in protest at the return of an old "poison".
fields.body:
Suspicions of conspiracy and corruption chilled Italian football yesterday after a disallowed goal effectively handed the Serie A title to Juventus and prompted Lazio to threaten to quit domestic football in favour of a European super league in protest at the return of an old "poison".

Juventus were leading 1-0 on Sunday when Parma's Fabio Cannavaro headed home a 90th-minute corner. But the referee Massimo De Santis ruled that there had been pushing in the penalty area and disallowed the goal, a decision unsupported by television replays.

Two seconds of stunned silence in the stadium have been followed by a national wave of protests. The victory kept Juventus two points ahead of their Roman rivals with one match to play.

"Our football has to be completely rebuilt," said Lazio's president Sergio Cragnotti. "Everybody, whether they are fans or not, saw what happened in Turin, and no one is able to explain why that goal wasn't allowed.

"Everything that led up to it was perfectly normal. If anything the Juventus players were committing the fouls. But the referee disallowed it. Why, I don't know."

Cragnotti continued: "Once again there's been a lack of sportsmanship and also a lack of professionalism by those who carry out certain duties."

He looked forward to a pan-European league with full-time professional referees.

"Lazio deserve the league title, both morally and for their football. We've shown that we're clearly superior in the head-to-head matches." Lazio beat Juventus last month.

Anger and suspicion at the decision convulsed the sport yesterday. "We're sorry, but it's a scandal," was the front-page headline of Corriere dello Sport. "The referee's decision was incredible," said the editor Mario Sconcerti. "I have seen a colossal injustice and something has to be done."

Southern Italian clubs have frequently accused referees of aiding Juventus in winning their 26 titles, including two in the past three years. There is a euphemism that the Fiat-owned club enjoy a "psychological advantage".

Juventus narrowly beat Internazionale to the 1998 title in "the season of poison", so-called because of a spate of dubious decisions.

 Roy Hodgson resigned as coach of Grasshoppers after only nine months when the team lost again on Sunday. "It was a mistake to come back to Switzerland," he said.

webTitle: Angry Atkins hits back at Chester chairman

fields.headline: Angry Atkins hits back at Chester chairman
fields.trailText: The Chester City manager Ian Atkins has accused the club's owner Terry Smith of conning the public and wanting to be "the great hero" as the Nationwide League's least successful outfit prepared for life outside football's mainstream.
fields.body:
The Chester City manager Ian Atkins has accused the club's owner Terry Smith of conning the public and wanting to be "the great hero" as the Nationwide League's least successful outfit prepared for life outside football's mainstream.

City's 69-year stay in the Football League ended in tears on Saturday when a 1-0 defeat by Peterborough United at the Deva stadium condemned them to relegation from the Third Division to the Conference.

In the immediate after math Chester's maverick American owner insisted that Atkins must shoulder much of the blame. But Atkins reacted angrily yesterday, pointing out that during his brief, uncontracted stay at Chester he had turned down the offer of two jobs.

"The fans have been conned. The reason the club now finds itself in the Conference is down to one man, and that is the owner," said Atkins. "The harsh truth is that he never liked the fact that the supporters took to me; he wanted to be the great hero."

Atkins joined Chester in January, picking up the managerial reins from Smith, who had installed himself as the first-team coach last August after the departure of Kevin Ratcliffe. Yesterday a Football League tribunal ordered Chester to pay Ratcliffe £200,000 in compensation.

Although the team Atkins fashioned on a shoestring collected 23 points from 21 games, it was not enough.

"We had three months in which to complete a real sporting miracle, and we very nearly did it," he said. "When I arrived the whole club was demoralised.

"Terry Smith should take a long, hard look at himself this morning. The words he came out with at the week end really hurt me; they cut deep. There was no need at all for him to say what he did and, more to the point, there was no substance at all to any of the allegations."

It is understood that Atkins would like to stay on, but only if Smith severs his ties with the club he bought from administrators for a knockdown price 10 months ago.

 The Swansea defender Steve Jones, who was punched in the face and kicked at the end of Saturday's 1-1 draw at Millmoor, plans to sue the Rotherham fans who assaulted him.

fields.headline: 10 festival films to watch
fields.trailText:
O Brother, Where Art Thou (Joel Coen)

An unlikely musical homage to Homer's The Odyssey, starring George Clooney and John Turturro as fugitives from a Deep South chain gang in search of riches
fields.body:
O Brother, Where Art Thou (Joel Coen)

An unlikely musical homage to Homer's The Odyssey, starring George Clooney and John Turturro as fugitives from a Deep South chain gang in search of riches

Bread and Roses (Ken Loach)

Festival favourite Loach makes his first foray into America with this political drama about the union drive among immigrant Los Angeles workers in the 80s.

The Yards (James Gray)

New York crime drama with a superb young cast: Mark Wahlberg, Joaquin Phoenix and Charlize Theron.

Dancer in the Dark (Lars von Trier) (pictured)

A musical starring Bjork as a Czech immigrant working in an American factory.

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (Ang Lee)

A swashbuckling period romance starring Chow Yun-Fat and Michele Yeoh.

Cecil B Demented (John Waters)

Melanie Griffith plays a fading star kidnapped by guerilla fighters

The Golden Bowl (James Ivory)

This Henry James adaptation is familiar Merchant-Ivory territory. An American art collector (Nick Nolte) and daughter (Kate Beckinsale) travel across Europe and get entangled in romantic intrigue.

Gohatto (Nagisa Oshima)

Japanese star Takeshi Kitano re-teams with Merry Christmas, Mr Lawrence director Oshima for Gohatto (Taboo), a gay-themed samurai epic set in 1865.

Nurse Betty (Neil LaBute)

A dark romantic comedy from normally misanthropic writer-director LaBute. Chased by hitmen, soap opera-obsessed nurse Renee Zellwegger takes to the road to meet her TV heartthrob.

In the Mood for Love (Won Kar-Wai)

The Hong Kong heavyweight has made an offbeat romantic comedy set in the 60s, which has been widely tipped for prizes.

The Cannes players

The actress: Bjork

Best known for her eclectic pop warblings and bizarre videos, the Icelandic singer looks certain to make a splash with Dancer in the Dark. Guaranteed to make a memorable entrance and divide the fashion critics.

The actor: Morgan Freeman

The avuncular figure of American cinema toys with his image, playing an embittered criminal in Nurse Betty alongside motormouth comedian Chris Rock. Also stars in serial killer thriller Under Suspicion, a taut two-header co-starring Gene Hackman.

The director: Wong Kar-Wai

A festival regular and former Best Director winner at Cannes, Kar-Wai's films attract critical acclaim and court cult status. Although he has never won the Palme d'Or, his rise continues, and if this isn't his year, Cannes recognition beckons in the future.

fields.headline: Standing up against the unspeakable
fields.standfirst: Once you wouldn't catch our politicians running for anything
fields.trailText: Once you wouldn't catch our politicians running for anything
fields.body:
The first casualty of the London mayoral election was doubtless, as ever, the truth. But there is something else lying badly injured: our political language. There were many features of this exercise that were unprecedented in British politics, and the terminology used was stolen wholly, without explanation, apology or thought, from the United States.

Traditionally, Americans have always run for office, while British politicians have stood . This was, I like to think, a sign of our seemliness and reticence; it is unBritish to rush after power too energetically. For anyone who grew up with the politics in the 1960s the distinction was obvious. When your leading politicians were as languid as Harold Macmillan, as effete as Sir Alec Douglas-Home, as podgy as Harold Wilson and as falling-down drunk as George Brown, the notion of them running for anything was unthinkable. Across the Atlantic, Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon were more vibrant. The mayoral contest changed everything. From the start, the question was: would Ken Run?

Alongside that came the new and equally unBritish concept of the running-mate - employed on a daily basis to explain the relationship between Trevor Phillips, Labour's candidate for deputy mayor, and Frank Dobson. Now, this is one of those phrases with which I have a peculiar personal problem. In my mind - even in the customary US context - it always conjures up an image of a couple of eight-year-old girls skipping hand-in-hand over the hills with daisy chains in their hair. This is bad enough when applied to, say, Clinton and Gore, but when Frank infiltrates the image, you will understand that it becomes truly terrifying. Admittedly, standing-mate would sound very strange, but even so...

Then there was the question of the ticket . Vote the straight Labour ticket, people were enjoined. This usage of straight is itself an Americanism. Ticket certainly is. I think its first regular appearance in Britain was in 1983 when Neil Kinnock and Roy Hattersley emerged as leader and deputy leader of the Labour party, a combination which (bizarrely enough) was described as the dream ticket .

After he had won, the mayor was asked whether he wanted to be called your honour, which gave him a chance to go into people's-Ken mode and say of course not. But our mayors are traditionally known as your worship (which sounds just a little less weird when you twig that the word is a corruption of worth + ship). Given the separation of powers in the new set-up, and the US-style balance that will exist between the mayor and the government, the assembly and the London boroughs, the process is probably not over yet. There will be log-rolling and the pork-barrel before we are done.

Now, of course, language must import or die, but the trading does seem to have become rather one-way of late. Even lobbyist is a newish word in Britain, though it goes back to the 1820s in the US, when special pleaders were barred from the New York state legislature, but allowed to hang around the lobby (like our own lobby correspondents). The Arami tribe of Ghana is a figment, and the stuff about them being poisoned by the potassium in bananas utter nonsense. webTitle: Win tickets to an exclusive screening of Gladiator

fields.headline: Win tickets to an exclusive screening of Gladiator
fields.trailText: We have 25 pairs of tickets to give away to one of this year's most eagerly anticipated movies
fields.body:
Played out in the kill-or-be-killed amphitheatres of ancient Rome, Ridley Scott's Gladiator (cert 15) is already being tipped as one of the year's hottest pictures, and went straight to the top of the US box-office on its release last Friday.

Directed by Ridley Scott (the man behind Bladerunner and Thelma and Louise), the film stars Oscar-nominated Russell Crowe as a usurped Roman general who battles his way back from slavery as a gladiator in the Collisseum. With its red-meat story-line, breathtaking computer-generated visuals, and abundance of action sequences, the film re-ignites the old-style toga epic and drags it into the 21st-century.

The screening will be in the theatre at the Computer Film Company (CFC), 19-23 Wells Street W1 at 6.00pm for 6.30pm (Running time is 2 hours 30 mins approx).

Gladiator (cert 15) opens in the UK on Friday 12 May. But Film Unlimited users can avoid fighting the opening night crowds by attending a special private showing at the Computer Film Company, 19-23 Wells Street, London W1. Courtesy of UIP/Universal, we are offering 25 pairs of tickets to an exclusive Film Unlimited screening on the evening of Monday 15 May, at 6pm for 6.30pm start.

How to enter
You can enter the draw for a pair of tickets by clicking here. The lucky winners will be notified by email by midday on Monday. Please note, the tickets are for this night and this venue only.

Exclusive online footage
We also have exclusive behind-the-scenes footage and interviews with the stars and director which you can watch now. The clips are in Quicktime format (you need to be using QT 3 or higher), which can be downloaded for free here.

webTitle: Cream and crumbs on the table

fields.headline: Cream and crumbs on the table
fields.standfirst: An elite group of universities still receive the lion's share of research grants
fields.trailText: An elite group of universities still receive the lion's share of research grants
fields.body:
The university elite have flourished since the introduction of the research assessment exercise, expanding staff numbers and securing an increasingly large share of research grants, according to a study for the Higher Education Funding Council for England. The UK's 20 large universities with medical schools - otherwise known as the Russell group - secure 75% of all research awards and contracts.

But the biggest changes over the last 14 years concern people: 70% of research students train in Russell group institutions; and 75% of research-only staff work in these universities, where they have trebled in number since 1980.

The increasing dominance of the top research universities has come despite a doubling of the number of universities competing for research grants over the last decade. The former polytechnics gained university status eight years ago, but only take 4.5% of all research funds, 3% of research council awards, and 9% of research students.

But the review, carried out by the higher education policy unit at Leeds University, suggests the exercise should not be killed off. It says the introduction of research ratings for university departments has greatly improved both the management and output of research in universities.

The assessment has been heavily criticised during the funding council's long-term research funding and policy review, with many academic heads arguing it has outlived its purpose. Last month, meanwhile, academic unions called for an equal opportunities audit of the assessment, after an industrial tribunal found that women academics are less likely to be selected for the exercise than male counterparts.

The Leeds academics concede that gauging the quality of research in universities is a complex problem, but argue there is "less wastage, more purpose, and more overt support for the most promising ideas". The study revealed that research papers published by academics have become shorter and sharper over the last 15 years, but this appears to be an international phenomenon, and not necessarily a consequence of the assessment exercise.

"The quality of the research base has changed," says the Leeds report. "As funds have become more concentrated, so the output of the most active universities has both increased and improved: they are delivering more, better research. The UK average has probably shifted less because of stiff international competition."

Yet the study dispels a central argument for skewing research grants to even fewer university departments. Preliminary international comparisons suggest block grant research funding in UK universities is not less concentrated than academic research budgets in the US, as is commonly thought.

The area where the funding council's resources are most likely to become more focused is the support of PhD students. A group considering the link between teaching and research as part of the long-term funding review has been given the go-ahead to investigate funding options to improve the support of postgraduates.

Improving research training and career development in the higher education sector has emerged as one of the central issues in the Hefce review, which is considering possible research funding schemes after the 2001 assessment exercise.

The group, led by Howard Newby, vice-chancellor of Southampton University and president of the Committee of vice-chancellors and principals, is assessing the merits of a new "hub and spoke" funding model for research students. Under the proposals, a selected number of university departments would offer general research training for first-year PhD students. A larger number of departments would continue to receive funding for the latter years of their training.

The research careers initiative group, set up two years ago to improve the career management of researchers on short-term contracts, meanwhile, is shortly to publish new guidance for assessment panels scrutinising university department submissions in the 2001 exercise. This is expected to urge referees to consider whether departments are providing adequate training and career development for young research staff.

webTitle: Rover 'back in profit in two years'

fields.headline: Rover 'back in profit in two years'
fields.trailText: BMW's sale of Rover to the Phoenix consortium will see the ailing British car producer back in profit within two years, Phoenix boss John Towers predicted today.
fields.body:
BMW's sale of Rover to the Phoenix consortium will see the ailing British car producer back in profit within two years, Phoenix boss John Towers predicted today.

The deal, welcomed by trade unions, will preserve Rover as a mass car producer and safeguard some 20,000 jobs, though 1,000 redundancies are still expected. A rival bid for Rover, by the venture capital firm Alchemy, would have entailed a shift to the niche production of luxury cars and mass layoffs.

Phoenix announced this morning that it had formally acquired Rover after several days of negotiations with the German parent company. Mr Towers, a former Rover executive, said this afternoon that his business plan for Rover was "robust".

Phoenix will now take responsibility for the development, production and distribution of Rover cars. Production of the Rover 75 and the MG brand will be shifted from Cowley, Oxford to Longbridge in Birmingham. Cowley will remain part of BMW, producing the new Mini which is due to be launched next year.

The Phoenix deal will be financed by a loan of £200m from the US bank First Union, with a £500m refundable "credit" from BMW to help the consortium get Rover off the ground. Phoenix itself has contributed a symbolic £10. BMW had previously disparaged the Phoenix bid, saying it lacked sufficient financial backing.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers welcomed the sell-off. In a statement to the Commons this afternoon he paid tribute to Mr Towers, who he said had been "determined and dogged in the face of hostility and criticism". Mr Byers said the deal would "preserve volume car manufacturing at Longbridge, safeguard the majority of jobs and minimise the knock-on effect in the supply change".

He acknowledged that there would still be a number of redundancies at Longbridge and said the government's priority would be to help those affected by providing training and attracting new jobs to the West Midlands. Mr Byers confirmed that the £129m already promised to the West Midlands task force would "remain available" for good quality projects in the region.

Earlier, he confirmed that Phoenix would not be receiving any state aid towards the purchase: "John Towers is very clear that he wants this to be a commercially viable business without government aid.

"The government has not played the old role of throwing money at a problem in the hope it will go away," he told the Commons. "But neither have we adopted the laissez-faire attitude of the last government - just standing to one side and doing nothing."

BMW chairman Joachim Milberg, whose own position as BMW chairman is being questioned by some analysts because of his handling of the Rover issue, said the deal would prevent the loss of thousands of jobs at Rover, while the jubilant Phoenix team said: "This is a good deal for everyone except Alchemy." Alchemy issued a brief statement wishing the Phoenix consortium and its employees "good luck for the future".

Mr Towers later confirmed that the shift from Cowley to Longbridge would mean the loss of nearly 1,000 jobs at the Oxfordshire plant. However, the completion of the new BMW engine plant at Hams Hall near Birmingham will proceed as planned.

"There has been a lot of inaccurate reporting about the financial position. I expect Rover to be in profit within two years," said Mr Towers. He added that this would probably mean collaborating with other firms. Mr Byers, he said, had been "extremely helpful" during the negotiations.

Tony Woodley, of the Transport and General Workers' Union, said the union had worked extremely hard to secure the deal "after the industrial disaster that BMW left us with. Our aim was to save as many jobs in the short term as is humanly possible and, just as importantly, to maintain the fabric of the plant to allow it to stay in car building."

fields.headline: The green machine
fields.trailText: Amazingly little attention has been paid to the Green's performance in last week's elections for the London assembly. Media commentators seem determined to overlook their strong performance as just another maverick element in a maverick contest. But in some areas, the Green vote was almost as big as that of the Liberal Democrats and, for the first time, people appeared to be voting for a "green slate". This deserves more consideration; it may mark a shift in political perceptions and priorities far more interesting than a story of protest votes and personalities in a crazy capital city.
fields.body:
Amazingly little attention has been paid to the Green's performance in last week's elections for the London assembly. Media commentators seem determined to overlook their strong performance as just another maverick element in a maverick contest. But in some areas, the Green vote was almost as big as that of the Liberal Democrats and, for the first time, people appeared to be voting for a "green slate". This deserves more consideration; it may mark a shift in political perceptions and priorities far more interesting than a story of protest votes and personalities in a crazy capital city.

I was astonished by how many of my acquaintances who have not previously bothered about environmental issues, suddenly voted Green. In my street two lifelong Labour supporters voted for them as did a friend, originally from Sierra Leone, living nearby. Both her neighbour and cousin did as well. On the same estate Jenny, an active Christian originally from Jamaica, also voted Green for the first time and persuaded her best friend to do the same. The list could go on; it even includes my mother. They were all part of the 14% of Londoners who put three Greens onto the London assembly.

Obviously some voters wanted to give Tony Blair a slap in the face without endorsing either of the other major parties. Juanita from Sierra Leone certainly blames Labour for reneging on promises but adds that the Green's leaflet appealed to her with promises to "do more about the environment and pledges of free fares for young people". Her cousin was attracted by their push to do more about waste and recycling, while Jenny supports traffic reduction and air quality improvement.

The Greens have gone through a psychological barrier where voting for them no longer feels like a wasted vote. Proportional representation has been crucial. In last year's European parliament elections, the Greens secured two candidates with a much lower vote (between 3 and 6%). Seeing votes count like this may be enough to change political perceptions. But the vote is higher now and it's clear that the Greens' uncompromising agenda - improving air quality, protecting open spaces, improving transport and campaigning to protect local places - has begun to feel like plausible and effective solutions to the quality of life issues at the heart of local elections.

The Green's campaign around Crystal Palace is a good example. They won respect by pledging opposition to the development of the old park in south London into a multi-million pound leisure complex. Yesterday Livingstone gave this policy his full endorsement. Other local parties have given similar commitments but the electorate is rightly sceptical. Who can trust Labour to oppose building and road developments when they actively placate big business and Mondeo Man? The as yet unproven Greens seem more likely to maintain their integrity on these issues than the major parties.

The one issue where political integrity will really be on trail is the issue at the heart of inner city support for the Greens, public transport. Londoners really do believe that cheap, efficient public transport could transform their lives: lowering the cost of living, reducing pollution, making the streets more child-friendly. This may be idealistic but before Livingstone rushes back to the Labour party, he would do well to remember the main reason for his support was his principled stance on the tube.

Most other aspects of the Ken package are either subsidiary or off-putting. Voters are ambivalent about his kneejerk radicalism and actively fear the reignition of rainbow alliance politics where anyone who shouts their oppression loudly will be heard (more than a faint possibility if the prime exponent of guilt and grievance politics, Peter Tatchell, finds a place in Ken's regime). Livingstone would not be exempt from a Blair-type trashing if he too disappoints these high expectations.

This is the context of the recent Green successes. If voters had merely been following Livingstone's instructions to vote Green in second preference, Darren Johnson would have performed better. In fact he was a rather lacklustre candidate and the final vote reflected that. The strong vote came in the London assembly and shows there is now real commitment to the Green agenda itself.

It remains to be seen how well the Greens can use their position in the new assembly. In spite of the good result, their London election performance was more amateurish than last year's European elections. But they still represent the best block against a drift back to the old political expediencies.

The one issue where political integrity will really be on trail is the issue at the heart of inner city support for the Greens, public transport. Londoners really do believe that cheap, efficient public transport could transform their lives: lowering the cost of living, reducing pollution, making the streets more child-friendly. This may be idealistic but before Livingstone rushes back to the Labour party, he would do well to remember the main reason for his support was his principled stance on the tube. Most other aspects of the Ken package are either subsidiary or off-putting. Voters are ambivalent about his kneejerk radicalism and actively fear the reignition of rainbow alliance politics where anyone who shouts their oppression loudly will be heard (more than a faint possibility if the prime exponent of guilt and grievance politics, Peter Tatchell, finds a place in Ken's regime). Livingstone would not be exempt from a Blair-type trashing if he too disappoints these high expectations. This is the context of the recent Green successes. If voters had merely been following Livingstone's instructions to vote Green in second preference, Darren Johnson would have performed better. In fact he was a rather lacklustre candidate and the final vote reflected that. The strong vote came in the London assembly and shows there is now real commitment to the Green agenda itself. It remains to be seen how well the Greens can use their position in the new assembly. In spite of the good result, their London election performance was more amateurish than last year's European elections. But they still represent the best block against a drift back to the old political expediencies. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Top job in the capital
fields.standfirst: Ken Livingstone has won the race to be London's mayor, but what will his responsibilities be?
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone has won the race to be London's mayor, but what will his responsibilities be?
fields.body:
Question: why does every school need a headteacher? Answer: to ensure things run properly, to keep an eye on what goes on and promote the school to the world outside. But for the last 14 years London has been without anyone to oversee it or speak up for it - that was until last Thursday's elections for a mayor. Now there could be big changes ahead for the capital.

Why does London need a mayor?

A city as large as London, with a population of over 7 million people, needs someone with an overview of how things are organised - most other capital cities do. Many London services such as education will go on being run by the borough councils, but there are over 32 of these. The mayor will need to ensure the councils work together and to battle for extra money for them from the government. He is also likely to be an ambassador for London, pushing for it to host events such as the Olympic Games.

Do Londoners want a mayor?

There was a big yes to this question in May 1998 and last week's election, in which 34% of Londoners voted, was a direct result of that vote.

Is this just a London thing?

No. Following the London election, Liverpool, Manchester and other cities are likely to argue for mayors.

What signs of change will there be with London's new mayor?

One of the mayor's largest responsibilities is the city's transport system, which most people agree is in a bad state. London's roads are becoming more crowded. Soon, some estimate, it will take longer to cross the capital by car than the Victorians took to cross it by horse and carriage. People may have to start paying a special congestion charge if they want to enter central London in a car.

A big effort will go into making buses and tubes more efficient. More conductors may appear on buses, and fares may be frozen or cut. The network of bicycle lanes will probably be increased. Other changes will include Trafalgar and Parliament Squares being made car-free and a giant glass building in the shape of an egg near London Bridge. This will be the mayor's headquarters and will house the London Assembly, also elected last week.

What will the mayor be able to do for the environment?

The mayor is expected to draw up a special biodiversity plan for London to be used to safeguard and encourage its animal and plantlife. Over 115 kinds of fish live in the Thames which may gain special protection. Proposals to develop marshland to the east of the city may be shelved and the mayor may push for the creation of some 10,000 environmental jobs by 2005 - the date of the election for the next London mayor.

On average each London household produces about a tonne of rubbish a year - an issue to be taken up by the mayor to boost our current recycling rate of 6 per cent. In some cities, such as Barcelona, over a quarter of household waste is recycled.

Homelessness is bad in London - will the mayor tackle this?

The mayor can ask the government to hand over more money to help build what is called "social housing" - flats and houses available at a reasonable rent. There may be as many as 100,000 empty homes in London which the mayor might help bring back into use.

What amount of money will the mayor have to spend?

The mayor has no powers to raise cash through taxes. Some people fear many promises of what will be done after the election rely on extra money from central government which may not be available. However, the mayor will be a powerful force to advance London's cause when money is being divided up.

He will have £3.6bn a year to hand out to several new groups such as the London Development Agency, the London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority and the Metropolitan Police Authority. But this is not "new" money since it has been diverted to the mayor from local councils that used to distribute it. If enough assembly members dislike the mayor's budget, they can change it.

But despite these controls, the mayor really does have the "biggest job in London". The capital is a complex place. Its huge population needs housing, jobs, education and entertainment. It must provide efficient transport and clean air, effective police forces and good hospitals. It must cope with rush hours and tourist seasons, demonstrations and celebrations. London is still seen as one of the world's most important cities, and with a mayor in place, could well remain so.

For further information, visit web pages on the election and the GLA

Other useful websites include:

www.detr.gov.uk
www.london-research.gov.uk
www.londonnet.co.uk contains a useful set of light-hearted articles on the history of mayoral elections.

See also A mayor for London special report.

fields.headline: Mysteries, Makeovers and Mannequins
fields.trailText: WHERE IN THE WORLD IS FAUSTINO ASPRILLA?
fields.body:
WHERE IN THE WORLD IS FAUSTINO ASPRILLA?

Colombia's Radionet radio has never heard anything like it. Carlos Valderrama and his crazy, crazy breakfast crew were chatting to the hilarious Senor Sniff-Sniff this morning, when who should appear on the phone but Luis Garcia - coach of the Colombian national team! Luis was in a chatty mood and before long conversation turned, as it often does, to Faustino Asprilla's career plans. "He is close to being transferred again to an English club," Luis said. "I believe this team is very interested in him." As you can imagine, the phone lines went a bit crazy after that.

Luis may not have actually spoken to Valderrama (his breakfast show finishes at 8am), but he's dead serious about former Newcastle star Tino. So the Fiver performed a quick survey of Premiership clubs to see if we could unearth the mystery buyer. The results were not overwhelmingly positive: five "we don't know"s, more than a few "we don't comment on transfer speculation"s, and one "if there's anything to say we give a press release to the Press Association" (thank you Chelsea's of Chelsea). At least Bradford told the Fiver they were "damn certain it's not us".

In fact, if Tino is to go anywhere, a return to the North-east seems the most likely option. Newcastle wisely decided not to pick up the phone when we rang. Middlesbrough seemed a trifle uncertain, their spokesman suggesting, "I've never heard Bryan Robson say he's a target." (But what about the secret targets he keeps to himself?) And then there's Newcastle's deadliest rivals Sunderland. "We haven't been given any information on that," the Fiver was told. So you're not interested in taking him on then? "That isn't what I said." Oh really.

 Are you a Mackem? Has Tino been standing in front of you in the queue at Do It All? Has a mysterious person with a Spanish accent tried to buy your home? Let the Fiver know at the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll share it with the world.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IT STARTS ON THE FIFTH OF JUNE, SO SIGN UP - IT'S COMING SOON!

The Euro, the Fiver's beautiful bouncing Euro 2000 baby, wants you to give it a cuddle. It's brought to you in association with breathe, and will arrive in your inbox each morning, keeping you up to date with everything that goes on in the lowlands this summer. To suckle it (ie: subscribe), send a mail to euro2000-request@footballunlimited.co.uk with 'subscribe' in the subject line.

Oh yeah, and if you get a incomprehensible mail back, it's our software's fault. As long as the word 'succeeded' appears on it, you're OK.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

AL-FAYED'S 15-YEAR PLAN

Visiting fans may chant foul-mouthed obscenities about how he'll "never be a Brit / and his football team is ****," but indefatigable rapster Mo "Al-Fayed!" Al-Fayed's blind devotion to his queen, his club and his country remains undiminished. Freestyle!

"I had to sacrifice him because England is more important than Fulham," Mo says patriotically of Kelvin Koogan, as the sounds of God Save the Queen stir heroically in the background. "If he was still here we would be in the Premiership, but it was my decision. It was possible I would not let him go, but you can't just have somebody. There is a matter of patriotism, England and glory." Mr Straw, are you listening?

Mo also took time out from dealing with Libya's state-owned oil company and talking about his little pinkie (and we don't mean his finger) to outline his vision for Fulham's future. "Harrods is the best department store in the world, it took me 15 years to bring it to its glory. The Paris Ritz is the number one hotel in the world. Fulham will also be the best, I hope. I am bringing back a great institution which has created so many heroes and I think we are there."

Well not quite, Mr Al-Fayed. But even if Fulham don't make it all the way, Mo will continue his pitch for that British passport. "The number one priority for me is British players. This is a British team and we must have British players first, that is very important." And there were we thinking he was Egyptian.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha" - Viking Stavanger manager Benny Lennartsson when asked if he'd be interested in loaning Paul Gascoigne for the summer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE FIVER'S WORST PLAYER OF THE SEASON 1999-2000

Who will take over John Hartson's fat mantle? Chris Sutton, Mickael Silvestre, Dagenham Davor Suker, Wim Jonk or Steffen Freund? Send your vote to the.boss@theguardian.com and wait for the result on Friday. If you're bored, why not send in several to distort the result?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IT'S HALL OVER NOW

It's the end of the road for the FA Premier League Hall of Fame. Unable to compete with other top London tourist attractions like Big Ben, Buckingham Palace and the gentleman's toilets just behind Kings Cross, it's being forced to close. Apparently, the ridiculously-optimistic 750,000 idiot (sorry, visitor) target for the first year wasn't met, and some probably-not-very-surprised staff at the museum are being laid off as the Fiver writes.

How could it all go so horribly, horribly wrong? How could a project which saw Jonathan Pearce and Gabby Yorath decide which footballers were worthy of the epithet "famer" go so awry? How could an establishment which tells you that Les Ferdinand "has always scored goals" fail to deliver? And why didn't more people flock to stare at a gormless wax Ian Rush?

The Fiver doesn't know, and is sorry to see the Hall of Fame close. We didn't actually go to it, of course, although we were sent a promotional CD-ROM which didn't run but made a useful coaster. Desperate not to miss out, the Fiver rang Gary Trowsdale, director of football at the Hall of Fame, to put in an offer for the wax Sir Les. But apparently Fifa want all the models for their own "internationally-themed football attraction" and Les was "absolutely not for sale". Not even for the £10 in ready cash we offered.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leeds are closing in on £7m Olivier Dacourt, with a deal for the midfielder set to be finalised within a couple of weeks. Busy Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale said: "Our interest in Olivier is well documented and we'll be doing everything we can to capture his signature. We will be announcing our new arrivals in the next week or two and they will all be major players."

According to the Yorkshire Evening Post, Middlesbrough and Tottenham are fighting it out for the signature of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink after his Atletico Madrid side were relegated from the Primera Liga.

Didier Deschamps has been linked with a move to French first-division side Lyon to become their player-coach.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Chelsea defender Graeme Le Saux has admitted he would be "very surprised" if he was fit for Euro 2000.

Manchester City will donate £25,000 to charity instead of holding a parade to celebrate their return to the Premiership. The club has decided against an open top tour of the city because it was too difficult to organise and that the achievement was "not of a scale to merit a parade." A spokesman for the club said the chosen charities would be named over the next few days.

Harry Kewell must wait until June at the earliest to discover whether he will miss the start of Leeds' next European campaign. A Uefa U-turn means Kewell could face suspension after all following his sending-off for stamping during Leeds' Euro-Vase semi-final with Galatasaray at Elland Road. Meanwhile, Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale is hoping to "tie up" the appointment of Brian Kidd as the club's youth development supervisor by the end of the week.

Derby manager Jim Smith has been charged with misconduct for comments made to referee Neale Barry during the Rams' draw with Tottenham last month.

The Welsh squad to play Brazil at the Millennium Stadium, Cardiff, on May 23 and Portugal at Chaves, near Oporto on June 3 is: Crossley, Ward, Freestone, Delaney, Barnard, Giggs, Blake, Page, Coleman, Pembridge, Melville, Saunders, Speed, J Robinson, C Robinson, Bellamy, Jones, Symons, Savage, Hartson, I.Roberts, Johnson, G Roberts, Oster. Stand-by players: N Roberts, Jenkins, Haworth, Coates, Ready. Former Scotland international Steve Archibald heads one of three consortiums who have offered to save under-threat Airdrie.

Newcastle goalkeeper Steve Harper has undergone surgery on a knee injury.

Manchester United will play Manchester City on Wednesday August 16 in a testimonial for Denis Irwin.

The nine yellow cards and three reds shown by Andy D'Urso in last night's 1-1 draw between Leeds and Everton at Elland Road set a new Premiership record. The tally beat the nine bookings and one dismissal dished out by Oxford referee Rob Harris in last October's game between Aston Villa and Liverpool at Villa Park.

Rangers officials have arrived in Sydney to finalise the purchase of Australian club Northern Spirit. David Murray announced his hopes to take a controlling interest in the Australian side 11 days ago.

Aston Villa chairman Doug Ellis has been appointed to Fifa's marketing and television advisory board.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (11.30pm)

Bayern Munich v Real Madrid. It's going to be Big Cup heartbreak for either Bayern Munich or Steve McManaman. Stop laughing, it's cruel.

The Big Match (2am)

Look, stop laughing!

Nationwide Football Extra (3.40am)

And what's so amusing about the plight of Chester?

Channel 4: Football Italia (1.35am)

So dubious decisions going in favour of Juventus are funny, are they?

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11.30pm)

Laugh all you like.

The Last Word (7.30pm)

Hill hell.

***'** ** *** ******! (10.45pm, 3.45am)

"Bon. Glad you heeded my advice and used Clover on your rear end. Nowt else would have worked, I'm telling you. SMB." McCaff can't believe it's not butter - spread a creamy message all over him by emailing the.boss@theguardian.com.

British Eurosport: Football (5pm)

Tune in to British Eurosport for football, brought to you by the football department of British Eurosport.

ONsport 1: Uefa Big Cup Magazine (7pm)

Magazine as in the group with Howard Devoto in it? What are you talking about?

Bayern Munich v Real Madrid - Live! (7.45pm, 9.55pm)

You're only live once, as Nancy Sinatra might have sung.

Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm)

Peter Purves sends John Noakes free down the left, but before he can send a cross onto the head of the unmarked Shep, Jenny Hanley from Magpie slides in with an outrageous chest-high tackle and dumps him into the stand.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

Do you want to "click on Alan Green"? We do. We want to "click on Alan Green". So that's why we went to www.voiceoffootball.com. Where we found him having a row.

talkSPORT: Football First Big Cup Live with Adrian Durham (7pm)

How many listeners does the tag "with Adrian Durham" add on, we wonder?

Alvin Martin's Big Cup Phone-In (10pm)

Not in any way a cheap way to fill the schedules.

webTitle: Eurotunnel pays out for race bias

fields.headline: Eurotunnel pays out for race bias
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A public relations manager sacked by Eurotunnel because she was not a "native English speaker" was a victim of race discrimination, an employment tribunal has ruled.
fields.body:
A public relations manager sacked by Eurotunnel because she was not a "native English speaker" was a victim of race discrimination, an employment tribunal has ruled.

Michele Fox, 53, who is French and a fluent English speaker and has lived in Kent since she married an Englishman 32 years ago, has been awarded an agreed payment of £200,000. She was dismissed from the Channel tunnel operator's press office after 12 years when her post was abolished and she had to apply for a new job. The tribunal chairman, Graham Davis, said the the job description asking for a native English speaker was comparable to having a "whites-only policy".

The tribunal heard that banter in Eurotunnel offices at Cheriton, in Kent, often criticised French colleagues, with one manager claiming: "The French could not organise a piss-up in a brewery." Mrs Fox earned £34,000 and had a company car when she was dismissed in 1998. Her solicitor, Tony Bertin, said last night she had started her own cross-Channel PR company, Entente Cordiale.

In her evidence to the tribunal, Mrs Fox said: "Bi-nationality does not work as well in practice as Eurotunnel would have you believe."

The tribunal found that her redundancy and dismissal were "an act of unlawful discrimination on the grounds of her race". It ruled that she was also unfairly dismissed.

Anne Leva, Eurotunnel spokeswoman, said the company would consider the findings. She said there were 26 nationalities among the staff.

webTitle: Key jobs: Profiles of mayor's race advisers

fields.headline: Key jobs: Profiles of mayor's race advisers
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone has already named two key advisers on race and the police - Lee Jasper, a radical black activist, and Kumar Mashid, a Tower Hamlets Labour councillor.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone has already named two key advisers on race and the police - Lee Jasper, a radical black activist, and Kumar Mashid, a Tower Hamlets Labour councillor.

As radicals go, Lee Jasper is very much in demand from the establishment. The home secretary, Jack Straw, picked him to be one of his advisers on race and appointed him to his race relations forum.

Mr Jasper, who grew up in Oldham, is secretary of the National Assembly Against Racism pressure group and has advised Scotland Yard on the use of informants and on its Operation Trident, aimed at cracking down on Yardie murders.

He was also a member of Scotland Yard's lay advisory group set up in the wake of the Stephen Lawrence report. In October last year he resigned after a row over allegations that members who counselled black and Asian victims at the Paddington rail crash were cold-shouldered by police officers.

For six years he earned up to £500 a day training the Met police in community issues.That came to end after the Brixton riots in 1995, when some police officers blamed him for a hardline speech that inflamed the crowd.

He was hired by Equality Associates, to give officers an insight into the way black people perceive the police. Jerome Mack, head of Equality Associates which still has contracts to train the Met, said Mr Jasper was in touch with Afro-Caribbean grass roots opinion. "Lee is very consistent and principled in the way he addresses the policing issue. He has never wavered and is forthright in his opinions."

Mr Mack said Mr Jasper was ahead of his time in his views on police reform, and in the early 1990s argued that the system for investigating complaints against officers should be independent of the police, a view now shared by some senior officers. Mr Jasper believes the police should be stripped of the roles of training new recruits and of regulating internal discipline.

In a speech to the National Assembly Against Racism (NAAR) group, Mr Jasper said: "Let's be clear about it, you can't ask the police, as they are currently constituted, to reform themselves. What has to happen ... is the break-up of the institution of the police. Because currently there are different departments, and sergeants and inspectors, superintendents, and commanders who are able to hide, shift, collude, bury and try to obscure the fight against racism in these institutions.

"What do I mean by this? Take police training away from the police. They cannot recognise racist officers in recruitment training, and sometimes I don't think they'd be able to recognise them if they turned up in Nazi SS uniform."

Ken Livingstone first became allied with Lee Jasper and Kumar Murshid, his new advisers on race and the police, six years ago in the bitter battle for control of the Anti Racist Alliance. They lost and then set up the NAAR.

Kumar Murshid earned his credentials in Tower Hamlets, east London. He was the head of a group helping victims of race attacks as the area was convulsed by racial violence in the late 1980s and early 1990s.

Mr Murshid, chairman of the NAAR, is a Labour councillor in Tower Hamlets. He was dismayed not to be chosen as a Labour candidate for the Greater London assembly elections.

His comments to the Sunday Telegraph that the Duke of Edinburgh is an "an unreconstructed racist" are not new.

After the duke's comments during a visit to an electronics company that an unsophisticated fusebox looked as if it had been "put in by an Indian", Mr Murshid wrote to the Guardian: "The duke is not exceptional in his racism, but this is no reason to ignore it when he manifests his stupidity in public. Such conduct should be unequivocally condemned."

webTitle: Privatising the airways: why Prescott's programme is in trouble

fields.headline: Privatising the airways: why Prescott's programme is in trouble
fields.standfirst: Political correspondent Nicholas Watt examines the chances of a government U-turn over air traffic control privatisation
fields.trailText: At least one member of the cabinet will be keeping a low profile tonight when Labour MPs mount a rebellion against the government's plans to part privatise Britain's national air traffic service.
fields.body:
At least one member of the cabinet will be keeping a low profile tonight when Labour MPs mount a rebellion against the government's plans to part privatise Britain's national air traffic service.

Andrew Smith, the chief secretary to the treasury, famously dismissed privatisation before the last election as "crazy", adding for good measure: "Our air is not for sale."

Labour quickly embarked on a U-turn and, since then, Tony Blair has swept aside opponents as he uses the privatisation of the national air traffic services (Nats) as a powerful symbol of his Third Way philosophy, which combines the private and public sectors.

The prime minister today reinforced his determination to face down the rebels when he said that the privatisation of Nats was the best way to improve air traffic control.

"If we make the investment in the old way, we will have to cut investment in core services like schools and hospitals," he said. "This is exactly the kind of tough, but unpopular at the time, reform that governments have to make to do the right thing for the long-term."

The Labour leadership believes that the rebels, who include the former transport minister Gavin Strang, have an outdated view of the private sector which belongs to the Labour party of the 1980s. John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, has said that the sell-off of a 51% stake would raised £500m, ensuring that a private sector company would inject a further £1bn which would modernise the system. But rebels, such as the Labour MP and former Heathrow shop steward, Martin Salter, believe that the government's plans are a "privatisation too far" which could jeopardise safety. Ominously for the government the likes of Mr Salter, who once begged Peter Mandelson for a job, do not come from the ranks of the "usual suspects" of left wing Labour backbenchers who regularly challenge the government.

Their opposition has been reinforced by a report by the independent accountants, Chantrey Vellacott, which accused the government of being disingenuous for claiming that part privatisation was the only way to raise investment. They said the public finances are so buoyant that the government could easily dip into its own resources.

Gordon Brown, who jealously guards his "war chest", will be unmoved by such claims. The government will therefore press ahead with its privatisation plans regardless of the size of tonight's rebellion.

webTitle: Sacked tipster alters story to accuse Mirror editor

fields.headline: Sacked tipster alters story to accuse Mirror editor
fields.trailText: One of the key figures in the share-dealing scandal surrounding Piers Morgan last night changed his story to allege that the editor of the Mirror had knowingly bought shares in a company his newspaper tipped the following day.
fields.body:
One of the key figures in the share-dealing scandal surrounding Piers Morgan last night changed his story to allege that the editor of the Mirror had knowingly bought shares in a company his newspaper tipped the following day.

Anil Bhoyrul, one half of the sacked City Slickers team which tipped shares for the Mirror, claimed in a signed affidavit that Mr Morgan had been fully aware of the story that was to run in the newspaper.

Mr Morgan has maintained since his share buying came to light that his purchase was coincidental to the tip.

Mr Bhoyrul's statement, made to the Daily Express, comes as the the press complaints commission prepares to issue its verdict on the frenzy of claim and counter- claim behind the Mirror share-dealing episode.

In his statement he claimed: "Piers Morgan has lied throughout and I initially went along with it. The truth is that he purchased the stock with the knowledge that our story would raise the share price."

The episode began when Mr Morgan admitted to buying £20,000 worth of shares in Viglen Technology, run by Sir Alan Sugar, the day before the Slickers column ran a very positive article about the company.

The editor was subsequently cleared in an inquiry held by the newspaper's parent group, Trinity Mirror, but has been the subject of further allegations about his stock portfolio.

As a result of the revelations of its journalists' stock market dealings, Trinity Mirror issued new rules on share owning. The PCC will meet tomorrow to finalise its ruling as to whether Mr Morgan's actions were in breach of its code of conduct.

Last night Mirror insiders shrugged off Mr Bhoyrul's claims. "This is his fourth version of events," said one. "He has no evidence for any of these things."

Mr Bhoyrul and his colleague James Hipwell were fired for gross misconduct in February; according to sources they had repeatedly bought shares the day before tipping them in the newspaper. They would then sell the shares at a profit.

Last week Mr Bhoyrul's appeal against his dismissal failed. He is understood to have also failed in his attempts to make a cash settlement with Trinity Mirror.
