webTitle: 'My face feels like it's being eaten by maggots'

fields.headline: 'My face feels like it's being eaten by maggots'
fields.standfirst: Eighteen-year-old  Ruth Williams describes a childhood cut short by chronic fatigue syndrome
fields.trailText: Eighteen-year-old Ruth Williams describes a childhood cut short by chronic fatigue syndrome
fields.body:
The first time I knew something was wrong was three years ago, when I almost got run over by a car. I was 15. I'd got off the bus from school. My mum was waiting for me down the lane and I walked across the road, straight in front of a car. It was like I wasn't there; I felt numb. The car screeched to a halt, and I carried on. It wasn't until my mum asked me what I was doing that I realised I could have died.

When we got home, I remember crying and shaking and screaming uncontrollably because I didn't know what was happening to my body. I was exhausted, my stomach hurt, I had a terrible headache. Which just wasn't like me. Before, I'd been really active and outgoing. I'd been into long-distance running. I was the typical teenager - going out, babysitting, doing all the teenage things.

Looking back, I'd say the illness had started a couple of weeks before that. I'd gone to hospital with bad tummy pains, which the doctors had initially thought was appendicitis. It wasn't, and I was discharged from hospital. To begin with, I seemed to get better; but when I went to school for the start of the summer term, I lasted about a week.

My sleep was really badly affected. It got to the point where I wouldn't be able to sleep until about 4am, and then I'd be unable to get up the next day. The mornings were such a physical effort - even to get dressed and washed felt almost impossible. I'd be able to rest a bit on the bus to school, and at school I'd struggle on and try and do the work with my muscles hurting so badly.

At the beginning, I managed to go into school a bit, but I was having to force myself. I'd put on a face and try to smile. My friends would be talking about boys and so on, but I couldn't care less what they were saying to me; I was in too much pain to be interested. I'd pretend, but I never let them know how I felt because I didn't want to upset them. I didn't want them to treat me as different. I worried that if I moaned too much about my illness, they wouldn't phone me.

Before too long, I wasn't strong enough to go to school. The teachers were sympathetic and, because they knew what I'd been like before, didn't think I was putting it on. It was different with the school counsellor, though. She just made everything worse. She talked about my family. She asked if I was enjoying school. She was trying to dig into other reasons, and this really hurt. I knew that it wasn't anything to do with my childhood. They were suggesting things and I had to fight to keep hold of my own beliefs. But it was tempting to want to believe what they were saying, simply because I wanted to be better.

Throughout this time I kept going to my GP. She took blood tests to see if I'd had glandular fever. She was sympathetic, and gave me painkillers, but these didn't do any good. At one point I was on six a day, and all they did was numb the pain a little.

My family have been great, though. I remember when my dad realised for the first time that I was in a bad way. I'd been on at him for weeks to make me a picture frame and one day we finally went down to the wood yard to do it. We were getting the tools out and I just broke down. I felt exhausted. I couldn't cope with doing even this simple task.

In December 1997, I was sent to a paediatrician. I described all my symptoms, and he said they didn't add up. The next day he called my mum at home. My dad and I were listening on the other phone and heard him say that there was nothing wrong with me - I should just get on with my life. Being treated this way left me with such a lot of anger, and I did a picture of how I felt. Since there seemed to be no way of describing to people how it felt to have rods of iron down my spine, I began drawing and painting how I felt instead. The pictures are not nice to look at - because the feelings weren't very nice either. Painting has really helped to let that anger out and show people a bit more what I feel. People can now look at them and see what I've been through.

I'm now doing my art full-time. I started at Hereford college of art and design last September and, although I've only been in for a total of one and a half days, they've been supportive. There's a tutor who lives in Hay who drops in to check on my work. It's given me something to aim towards. Plus it's something that I love doing. The upcoming exhibition is my first.

After the episode with the paediatrician, the school doctor came to see me at home. He was the first person who admitted that it might be ME, or chronic fatigue syndrome. That was a huge relief - I finally had a name for my illness. I knew that people might now believe me and not think that I was just making it up.

Then we got in touch with the ME Association and my mum read all their books. I didn't. I worried that if I read the books then I'd be accused even more of making up my symptoms. But reading the material helped my mother. She was able to understand why this once smiley, laughing daughter wasn't getting up in the morning, and was spending all her time in a chair, unable to walk, in constant pain, with insufficient concentration even to read a book.

It's only in the last year that it's started to get a bit better. I've been able to walk across a couple of fields without having awful after-effects. I'm still in pain, my muscles hurt pretty much constantly, my face feels like it's being eaten away by maggots. But it's made me a stronger person. I appreciate life more. My advice to anyone suffering from it would be: remember that you are going to get better; that it's the illness that's making you ill, not you. Rest as much as you can and don't overdo it because you'll pay for it in the end. Keep smiling and hope that you're going to get better. Who knows, one day there may be a magic pill.

fields.headline: Toxic debate
fields.standfirst: Are your old mercury fillings slowly poisoning you?  Oliver Burkeman  investigates the dire health warnings while, below,  Claire Wallerstein  visits one dentist convinced that the heavy metal in our mouths is making us ill
fields.trailText: Are your old mercury fillings slowly poisoning you? Oliver Burkeman investigates the dire health warnings while, below, Claire Wallerstein visits one dentist convinced that the heavy metal in our mouths is making us ill
fields.body:
Anthony Newbury is a dentist, but listening to him you'd be forgiven for thinking he was some kind of faith healer. "One chap came twice from Ireland, and he said: 'You'll never believe this, but the clinical depression I've suffered for 40 years disappeared after the first visit,'" Newbury recalls. "He told me that unfortunately it hadn't happened soon enough to save his first marriage - but still, that's a nice thing to be able to do for someone."

The wonder treatment in question is the removal of mercury amalgam fillings. Stoking a debate that has raged since the 70s, a small but growing band of dentists blame widespread mercury poisoning for a terrifying range of conditions, ranging from gum disease, migraine, headaches, depression, chronic fatigue, eczema and asthma to rheumatism, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, kidney disease and multiple sclerosis. Either they have exposed a cost-saving conspiracy between the dental establishment and the NHS that is costing people their good health and, in some cases, their lives - or they are lending credibility to a classic case of medical scaremongering that helps line the pockets of greedy dentists.

Their argument is intuitively convincing. Mercury is the second most toxic metal on the planet after plutonium, and all dentists now agree that it is not, as previously believed, safely "locked in" when mixed with other metals in amalgam. Instead, it constantly releases toxic vapours, particularly during chewing, and has been banned for use in dentistry in Sweden. The Department of Health's committee on toxicity, while ruling the dangers unproved, warns that pregnant women should avoid the placement or removal of mercury fillings. Says Newbury: "Everybody knows mercury is toxic, and if they brought it out now for use in fillings they'd be laughed out of the country."

Jack Levenson, founder of the British Society for Mercury-Free Dentistry and author of a book on the subject, says any other problem on the same scale would have been labelled an epidemic long ago. "The British Dental Association's figures say 3% of the population are particularly sensitive to mercury, and when you have an outbreak of flu, 0.4% counts as an epidemic," he argues. "There is nothing in medicine that compares to the health benefits of having mercury fillings removed."

In extreme cases, patients have spoken of serious symptoms vanishing within days of having their fillings removed. Levenson says the same thing happened to him when sweaty palms brought a halt to a potential professional career in tennis: having his fillings out appeared to eliminate the problem.

One leading antiamalgamist, who prefers not to be named, smells a conspiracy. "The new materials would increase the NHS dental bill sixfold. Then there's all the litigation from patients, and the pressure on health insurance companies. There's strong pressure to keep the lid on it."

Mercury amalgam has been used by dentists for 150 years, though the effects of mercury poisoning were well-known before that: the use of mercury chloride in the preparation of felt hats - apart from providing the inspiration for a character from Alice in Wonderland - was blamed for the widespread incidence of St Vitus's Dance among hatmakers. For those campaigning to end its use, amalgam's long history explains why it was able to avoid the safety tests it would face if introduced today. "We've been smoking for 300 years," says Anthony Newbury, by way of comparison, "but only recently have we been told of the dangers, and cigarettes still haven't been banned."

For more sceptical dentists, though, mercury's longevity makes exactly the opposite point. It has been used in billions of fillings - currently 15m a year - and the only evidence of harm is to be found in patients' anecdotal evidence or scientific studies whose methods have since been thrown into question.

"It's utter nonsense," says Professor Barry Eley of King's College, London. "These fillings release small quantities of mercury, but well below the levels associated with toxicity. There is absolutely no scientific evidence that mercury released from amalgam is associated with the dan gers claimed." The health department's warning to pregnant women is, he reckons, a case of "taking the maximum safety posture. Undoubtedly an awful lot of money is being made by dentists saying that you need all your mercury fillings replaced. Obviously, that can't be done on the health service, because there is no clinical justification."

Other evidence makes the antiamalgamists' case look even less solid. Mercury was banned in Sweden - according to public pronouncements, at least - for environmental reasons; the BDA's former claim that 3% of the population are sensitive to mercury refers to reactions to all mercury in the environment and does not imply that 3% of people will necessarily react badly to amalgam fillings. Many of the tests for mercury levels used in studies, which frequently date back to the 70s, have since been accused of skewing results, while doubts have been raised over the "electrodiagnostic" tests used by some dentists today to measure levels of mercury in patients' mouths. Recent research by scientists at the University of Heidelberg found that many who complain of side-effects from mercury fillings may be unwittingly using them as a scapegoat for other disorders.

The worst excesses of the anti- amalgam movement are exemplified by one Hal Huggins, an American dentist who published some of the earliest claims of the perils of amalgam. Huggins operated a lucrative consultation by mail and recommended a range of special dietary supplements - not unlike the charcoal tablets and vitamins recommended by antiamalgamists in Britain today - until his licence was revoked for malpractice in 1996. The presiding judge ruled that Huggins had diagnosed mercury toxicity in every patient who had visited him, including several who didn't even have mercury fillings.

The number of complaints made against British dentists for unscrupulously recommending amalgam replacement is, sadly, unknown: complaints made to the General Dental Council are confidential until they reach the level of the council's professional conduct committee. A spokesman could not recall any ever having done so. "The GDC are doing a very poor job of protecting the public on this matter," says one experienced dentist. "They catch the very severe cheats, but they don't bother with the day-to-day things."

Despite the entrenched nature of the debate, there is a surprising amount of agreement over whether you should automatically have all your mercury fillings replaced, and the answer is: don't. Antiamalgamists, though they would argue that unexplained health problems may well be due to mercury in your mouth, agree that removal of fillings exposes the body to an intense dose of toxins, even when properly carried out using specialised suction equipment and dental dams. Besides being more expensive, the composite material used instead has its own dangers too, since it releases peroxides and free radicals into the body. The decision remains a personal and financial one - but if your dentist doesn't at least inform of the existence of powerful evidence suggesting that the risk from mercury amalgam may be much smaller than some claim, find another dentist.

Sick to the back teeth
Like most other paid-up members of the 21st century, I suffer from a variety of niggling, non-life-threatening health problems, which I have always ascribed to stress, pesticides, traffic fumes, sick building syndrome, hangovers or too much junk food. One thing I never gave a second thought to was my 12 amalgam fillings, which I started to accumulate as a chocolate-loving 10-year-old, writes Claire Wallerstein.

An appointment with holistic dentist Dr Jack Levenson, however, has left me with the suspicion that there is a mini-toxic waste dump inside my head; that I, along with millions of others, could be suffering from long-term, low-level mercury poisoning.

Dr Levenson, president of the British Society for Mercury-Free Dentistry, has removed the fillings of more than 6,000 patients over the past 20 years, and claims that nearly all found their health improved. "I believe that many conditions fashionably attributed to viruses could in fact be caused by mercury toxicity," he says.

On my visit to his surgery, my first task is to fill in a questionnaire. I tick away at symptom after symptom, but even I, a professional hypochondriac, can see that many are fairly minor - nightmares, shyness, bad breath, bedwetting, dandruff - and could have many potential causes.

One point that interests Levenson is my allergy to costume jewellery - often made with other substances found in amalgam fillings, such as nickel. "If you're allergic to it on your skin, what's it going to be like inside your head?" he asks.

This had never occurred to me before. Nor had I ever realised the numbness and tingling I often feel in my limbs could be a classic symptom of mercury poisoning.

Next, Levenson measures the electric current in each of my fillings. The highest - in the one that makes me cringe most whenever I bite a Kit-Kat wrapper - reads 3.3 microamps. "A few microamps may not sound a lot, but remember that the electrical current of the brain is measured in nanoamps - thousandths of a micro-amp," he says. "The roof of the mouth is effectively the floor of the brain, and electrical interference may be implicated in problems such as migraine, epilepsy, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and motor neurone disease. In many patients there is a measurable change in brain waves after the removal of fillings."

Next, I am hooked up to a "vega meter" which measures the energy flowing through an acupressure point on my thumb when I am exposed to different materials. My energy levels plunge in reaction to the amalgam, but not white plastic.

By now I feel sure that having a head full of mercury probably isn't a good idea. But what horrifies me more is the cost - around £1,500 - of having my fillings removed. The problem is that you can't just get the fillings ripped out, as mercury vapour is released when they are ground up for removal.

Dr Levenson says extraction should be done in a well-ventilated surgery, and that the patient should have a rubber dam and extraction pump in their mouth to avoid inhalation of particles. They should also wear clothes covering as much of the skin as possible, and breathe air from a nasal tube.

During the operation, Levenson sometimes uses intravenous vitamin C as a detoxifying agent. He also prescribes a whole range of vitamins, homeopathic remedies, massages and saunas afterwards to help remove the reservoir of mercury that has built up in the body over the years.

So what can be done for people like me with a mouth lined with mercury, but not enough money to have it removed? Apparently the best thing is to limit your exposure by avoiding unnecessary chewing (which increases the production of mercury vapour), which means cutting out snacks between meals, and avoiding salty, sour and hot foods. Refined carbohydrates and sugars are also a no-no, as they help oral bacteria to produce lactic acid, which corrodes fillings.

It's also sensible to cut down on mercury intake from other sources, such as contact lens solutions, and to try to avoid your fillings when brushing your teeth. Supplements of vitamin C, sulphur, selenium, seaweed and charcoal may help to remove mercury from the body.

 The Brompton Dental Surgery, 221 Old Brompton Rd, London W1.

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: Alternative to HRT | Sore mouth
fields.body:
Alternative to HRT
Q: I am only 42 but my doctor has told me I am entering the menopause. She has provided me with lots of information about the pros and cons of HRT. It seems to have risks and benefits. What do you think about it? Are there any natural alternatives?

A: Firstly, 42 is young to be menopausal - the average age in the UK is 50. A blood test for the hormone FSH can confirm if you're in any doubt. HRT is great for hot flushes, sweats, vaginal dryness and is the best way of preventing bone thinning (osteoporosis). You can't take HRT if you've had a thrombosis and taking HRT slightly increases your risk of getting a thrombosis from one woman in 10,000 per year to three women in 10,000 per year. Among 50-year-old non-HRT users, 45 women in every 1,000 will get breast cancer by the time they get to 70 years old. If you use HRT for over five years, there will be an extra two cases of breast cancer in every 1,000 women. You can boost your oestrogen levels by eating phytoestrogens-plant derived oestrogens in soy and linseed. 1,000mgs per day of calcium, not smoking and regular exercise help keep bones strong and a bone density scan every year can check for osteoporosis. Natural progesterone skin cream (eg Progest) remains unproven but some women swear by it.

Sore mouth
Q: I am 72 years old and am plagued by splits at the sides of my mouth which become so sore that I have to take my dentures out. It is stoppping me from enjoying my food. Any advice?

A: This problem, known as angular cheilitis, is likely to be caused by your dentures. If you don't regularly wear both top and bottom sets, your upper lip may be over-riding your lower lip, causing deep grooves at the angles of the mouth. Saliva and sweat collect in the grooves causing infection. You may want to get your dentures checked, wear both sets all the time, and scrub them daily with soap and water. Vaseline and Canesten cream help.

Phlegmy throat
Q: I have recently been to see my doctor over a throat problem that just won't go away. It feels like I have a lot of mucus I am constantly swallowing. It is making me feel very sick. My doctor gave me some mouthwash but this is not working. I am at a stage in life that is very tiring as I have an eight-year-old Down's syndrome child with insulin-dependant diabetes and this feeling is making me feel like I can't cope.

A: You might be suffering from acid reflux. With all the worries you must have about your child, it wouldn't be suprising if your stomach is producing excess acid. If a good swig of an antacid such as gaviscon (10mls, three times day) gets rid of the sensation, you have your answer. If not, you may want to ask your GP to refer you to a gastroenterologist. If the Gaviscon works, you can try to prevent a recurrence by cutting out acid, spicy foods and alcohol, eating small, frequent meals, losing excess weight and sleeping with an extra pillow. Managing your stress levels must be a challenge and I wonder whether you are able to put some time aside for yourself to help you cope.

Pregnancy pain
Q: I'm six months pregnant and am in more pain than I could ever imagine. I get a shooting pain through the pubic bone, round my whole pelvis, in my inner thighs and an ache in my lower back. My GP and midwife have suggested paracetamol and hot baths. Can you help?

A Your condition has a name - diastasis symphysis pubis (DSP). There is no known cure, though it does improve once you've had the baby. It's common and frightening. A lady called Angie Lambert had such a bad time with this condition in her pregnancies that she helped set up a self-help group with an expert advisory team. Contact the British Symphysis Pubic Dysfunction (SPD) Support Group (01843 587 356 or at http://dsp.future.easyspace.com)

Wet nights
Q: My eight year old son still wets the bed. He's got a school trip next year and we really want to crack the problem. What do you suggest?

A: A star chart can work wonders. Award a star for a dry night, and a special star for a full week. If that doesn't work, ask your GP for referral to a clinic that can provide you with a bed-wetting alarm. It goes off when in contact with liquid. This wakes your child who then needs to change the sheets. There's useful advice from Eric (Enuresis Resource and Information Centre) on 0117 960 3060.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

fields.headline: Airlift of trapped Britons begins
fields.standfirst:
UNAMSIL - UN mission
Sierra Leone Web
Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: RAF Hercules aircraft will today evacuate the first British and other European citizens trapped in Sierra Leone as part of the biggest military operation since the Kosovo conflict.
fields.body:
RAF Hercules aircraft will today evacuate the first British and other European citizens trapped in Sierra Leone as part of the biggest military operation since the Kosovo conflict.

With the situation in the capital Freetown becoming increasingly chaotic and volatile, more than 1,000 British paratroopers, marines and special forces swiftly moved in and are expected to evacuate up to 850 people.

British citizens were last night told to gather at the Mammy Yoko hotel in the centre. Most are to be airlifted from Freetown but British Chinook helicopters were also preparing to fan out to pick up those in outlying areas.

The operation began when an advance party of 250 paratroopers landed at Lungi international airfield near the capital. Later, a further 450 were deployed either at the international airport or provincial ones.

The Foreign Office said there were 550 British nationals in Sierra Leone, 250 EU citizens and 50 Commonwealth citizens. The British consular staff are to stay in the capital.

fields.headline: Livingstone in car plant talks
fields.standfirst:
Byers breaks Labour's quarantine on London's new mayor to discuss crisis that threatens Ford car plant

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers yesterday became the first minister to break New Labour's political quarantine around Ken Livingstone when he met the newly-elected mayor to discuss the closure threat hanging over Ford's Dagenham car factory.
fields.body:
Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers yesterday became the first minister to break New Labour's political quarantine around Ken Livingstone when he met the newly-elected mayor to discuss the closure threat hanging over Ford's Dagenham car factory.

The two men agreed to work together to intensify pressure on the US-owned multinational to maintain manufacturing production at the Essex site - Ford is expected to announce the closure of the Fiesta assembly plant on Friday - and maximise investment in the area to offset the expected loss of more than 2,000 jobs.

Mr Livingstone, who was sworn in as mayor at the temporary Greater London assembly headquarters at Westminster yesterday, is also seeking an emergency meeting with senior Ford managers.

He will argue that Ford's reputation in Britain as a good "corporate citizen" will be seriously damaged if it goes ahead with plans to phase out car production in a country which now accounts for 28% of its European market.

Mr Livingstone has already met union and business leaders to discuss what can be done to save the plant, though responsibility for economic regeneration will remain with the trade and industry department until July.

Both Mr Byers and Mr Livingstone described their meeting as constructive.

The mayor also held talks yesterday with London assembly members he was hoping to draw into his coalition administration, amid signs of disagreement in the GLA Labour group and between Downing Street and Labour's Millbank headquarters about how far to co-operate.

The discussions were described by one member of Mr Livingstone's team as "extremely sensitive" and last night only one assembly member had accepted a job in his cabinet: Darren Johnson, the Green party's former mayoral candidate, who has taken the environment portfolio.

Mr Johnson immediately threw the mayoral administration's weight behind the campaign to stop the building of a controversial leisure complex in Crystal Palace park, south London.

But Liberal Democrat Lord Tope yesterday turned down an offer to become chairman of the fire and emergency planning authority, saying the job did not "accord with our priorities", which were equalities and social justice.

Labour GLA member Lord Harris, who Mr Livingstone wanted to chair the new Metropolitan police committee, complained that he first heard about the proposal through the media, and Tory Bob Neill said the offer of a "non-portfolio role" smacked of tokenism.

The Labour group was meeting last night to consider how far to co-operate with Mr Livingstone, who has offered the post of deputy to Labour's Nicky Gavron.

fields.headline: Ignoring the patient
fields.standfirst: Observer health editor Anthony Browne explains why the latest consultation exercise on the NHS won't make a blind bit of difference to users
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Observer health editor Anthony Browne explains why the consultation exercise on the NHS launched today won't make a blind bit of difference to users
fields.body:
At last: the sick can speak, and they shall be listened to! After decades of reform of the NHS imposed on the doctors and patients alike, the government has finally decided to consult the people who actually use it. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, today launched the "biggest ever" public consultation on the future of the NHS.

The old, the young, the chronically sick and their pressure groups will all have their say on what they want. It follows the announcement that ministers have called in British business tycoon Richard Branson to help make the NHS more "patient-friendly".

It all sounds good, and it's already attracted glowing headlines, but there is one small catch. It won't, in the long run, even make one hospital meal more palatable.

The public consultation is all part of the grandly titled "national plan" for the NHS, one of the biggest panic measures in history. Labour came to power promising to save the NHS, but has seen it reel from crisis to crisis. Public confidence in the NHS has been undermined, and support for its founding principles - universal healthcare free at the point of access - is being eroded.

Tony Blair, keen not to go down as the man who destroyed the NHS, recently announced huge piles of cash for the ailing service, and half a dozen "action teams" to draw up proposals to "modernise" it.

So why won't all this public consultation make a difference?

Patients have always been incredibly powerless in the NHS, as anyone who has tried to complain or get an appointment that is convenient or the doctor they want can tell you. The consultation may come up with better queuing systems, but they will just join the list of well-meant, but short-lived initiatives.

The patient is powerless in the NHS because they are costs, not sources of revenue. If a patient is disgusted with a treatment or service at one hospital and go somewhere else, they have just saved that bad hospital money. Why should doctors and hospitals bother keeping patients happy when there is no reward - and plenty of trouble and expenses - for doing so?

Patients will remain overlooked while the incentive structure is so perverse. What is needed is a system that actually rewards hospitals and doctors for treating patients well and keeping them happy.

There are such systems that are in use in Europe: for example, giving patients money for treatment so they decide where they are treated and by whom. But unfortunately for the British public, that is not one of the things they are being consulted on.

fields.headline: Keegan left in the lurch
fields.standfirst: Kevin Keegan is prepared to wait for Graeme Le Saux to fill England's left-back position. But the Chelsea man is unlikely to make it and, writes Sean Ingle, he hasn't left himself with many other options
fields.trailText: With Euro 2000 just five weeks away, Kevin Keegan's choice of left-back looks like boiling down to a barely-fit Graeme Le Saux or a barely-competent Phil Neville. Talk about being caught between a rock and a hard place.
fields.body:
With Euro 2000 just five weeks away, Kevin Keegan's choice of left-back looks like boiling down to a barely-fit Graeme Le Saux or a barely-competent Phil Neville. Talk about being caught between a rock and a hard place.

Yesterday Keegan all but guaranteed a place for Le Saux in his Euro 2000 squad - even though he hasn't played since damaging ankle ligaments in October. "I'll be absolutely delighted if he is considered fit enough to play in the Cup final or in one league game and then the Cup final," admitted Keegan. "If he was fit then, there's no doubt about it, he would be in the squad."

Unfortunately there's a slight flaw in this plan: Le Saux isn't nearly as fit as Keegan thinks he is. As Chelsea assistant manager Gwyn Williams told the Sun this morning: "Graeme is still three weeks away from fitness and will certainly not be involved at Wembley." And - if that proves to be the case, probably not involved in Euro 2000 as well.

That leaves just Phil Neville. That's Phil Neville, the Manchester United third-choice left back, who only gets a game when Denis Irwin and Mikael Silvestre are rested.

Is English football really in such a sorry state?

Some will blame our paucity of left-footed players on a freak of nature. Others will see it as a damning indictment on the state of English football. But whether the reason, the fact is that Keegan must take some of the blame as well.

He's regularly expressed a preference for a 4-4-2 formation, which is fair enough. But it's up to him as England manager to trawl through the Premiership scouting for players with the potential to fill the problem positions on the left - and then stick them in the squad so he can assess them close up.

Back in February, for instance - when Le Saux was already doubtful for Euro 2000 - Keegan had the perfect opportunity to do just that when England hosted Argentina.

But for some reason he decided that Chelsea's Jon Harley was too young, and Wimbledon's Ben Thatcher too violent (his flailing elbow in Nicky Summerbee's face was still fresh in the public's mind), so neither player made his squad.

Who did we get instead? Phil Neville again - who, try as he might, can't dispell the impression that he's a second-rate Alan Harper; someone who is a jack of all trades but master of none.

As a result of Keegan's short-termism, England will be in trouble if Le Saux does drop out, as there are only two friendlies - against Brazil and Ukraine - before he names the 22-man squad.

English football is hardly awash with budding young Kenny Sansoms, but surely Keegan could have looked a little harder. Harley, Thatcher, Kieron Dyer, Gareth Barry, even Nigel Winterburn - all may have proven themselves worthy of a squad place if they'd been given a chance. But they weren't, and it could be too late now.

webTitle: No combat role for British troops, says Cook

fields.headline: No combat role for British troops, says Cook
fields.trailText: Britain today ruled out a combat role for its paratroopers as they began evacuating British and other European nationals from Sierra Leone.
fields.body:
Britain today ruled out a combat role for its paratroopers as they began evacuating British and other European nationals from Sierra Leone.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, insisted that British forces would not be drawn into the bloody civil conflict despite pleas from the UN for Britain to inject some military muscle into the disorganised UN peacekeeping force, Unamsil.

"We are not going to commit British troops as combat troops as part of the UN force," Mr Cook said. "They were sent in to supervise the evacuation and make sure that British nationals can leave safely. By their very presence, they also do secure the airport and make a real contribution to the UN force which is still building up and now has a secure bridgehead to do so."

But Mr Cook said he and Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, would evaluate the troops' position on a "day-to-day" basis and had no fixed timetable for their presence in Sierra Leone.

Britain's refusal to play a more robust role came despite pleas from UN headquarters in New York for London to deploy its forces more aggressively. UN secretary-general Kofi Annan is pushing for a rapid reaction force to put the peacekeeping mission back on track, asking western countries and Russia to contribute.

"The secretary-general continues to stress that, in addition to UN efforts, a rapid reaction force may be needed in Sierra Leone as soon as possible to assist in restoring conditions conducive to the resumption of the peace process," his spokesman Fred Eckhard said.

Human Rights Watch, the human rights group based in New York, welcomed the idea of a rapid reaction force, but urged the UN to put protection of local civilians at the heart of its mission. "The people of Sierra Leone must not be abandoned," said Peter Takirambudde, executive director of the organisation's Africa division. "The UN should respond rapidly to their crisis, as well as its own."

UN forces have not acquitted themselves well so far. Three hundred peacekeepers have been rounded up by rebels from the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) led by Foday Sankoh and another 200 are missing. The rebels also took UN armoured personnel carriers.

The international organisation's poor performance has already led to comparisons to past debacles in Somalia, Rwanda and Angola, which has called into question a planned deployment in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

For his part, Mr Sankoh has been reportedly placed under the protection of the Sierra Leonean army after a rival faction attacked and took control of his home. The government wants to ensure his safety amid fears that the fragile peace accord between the government and the RUF in the former British colony would break down completely should anything happen to him.

Demonstrators marched on Mr Sankoh's home on Monday to demand that his forces release the UN hostages. His gunmen fired on the estimated crowd of 10,000, killing at least four people.

"For security reasons, Chairman Sankoh has been taken to military headquarters where he is now in the protection of the military," a military source said. Mr Sankoh was at the defence headquarters in the west of the capital, Freetown, and apparently not under arrest.

Mr Sankoh was brought into the government as vice-president under the controversial Lome peace deal. Signed in July 1999, the accord contained a blanket amnesty for atrocities committed mostly by RUF forces - summary executions, amputations, rapes, abductions and looting - committed during Sierra Leone's nine-year civil war.

Freetown was quiet overnight, with residents reporting no gunshots. The city was being patrolled by Sierra Leonean troops, paramilitary police and Kajamor militiamen, traditional hunters who supported President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah during the civil war against the RUF and its allies.

webTitle: 'Magic news' - but jobs will still be lost

fields.headline: 'Magic news' - but jobs will still be lost
fields.standfirst: Reactions to the Rover sale
fields.trailText:
"After intensive negotiations, we have managed to find a buyer for Rover whose aim is to continue running Rover and to therefore prevent the loss of thousands of jobs in the Rover plant in Birmingham, in the supply industry and in the retail business."
Joachim Milberg, BMW chairman
fields.body:
"After intensive negotiations, we have managed to find a buyer for Rover whose aim is to continue running Rover and to therefore prevent the loss of thousands of jobs in the Rover plant in Birmingham, in the supply industry and in the retail business."
Joachim Milberg, BMW chairman

"We are delighted that together with BMW we have secured a brighter future for Rover and its stakeholders. This is the first step in a series of changes which will fully justify the confidence and support which has kept this process going."
John Towers, head of the Phoenix consortium and former Rover chief executive

"The John Towers proposals will involve a number of jobs being lost, but it is a prospect which is far better than we were seeing two or three weeks ago."
Stephen Byers, secretary of state for trade and industry

"Mr Byers held out for the deal that would secure the maximum amount of employment. Phoenix had always promised more jobs than Alchemy. We will now have to see what can be done to ensure that the West Midlands economy is able to accommodate the workers who will lose their jobs as a result of this. That is the next test for the government."
Martin O'Neill MP, chairman of the House of Commons trade and industry select committee

"The fact that Phoenix has been able to present a viable bid to BMW is very much to be welcomed. I hope that if Stephen Byers is going to take credit now he will follow through and deliver."
Angela Browning, shadow trade and industry secretary

"Alchemy Partners wish the Phoenix consortium and its employees good luck for the future. Alchemy Partners looks forward to fresh transactions."
Alchemy Partners, original bidder for Rover

"This is excellent news. It is what many of us had been working very hard to achieve for some time. It will be a great relief for the workers at Rover and their families. It provides a basis for a secure future for Rover's brands and safeguards thousands of jobs, not just in Rover but in the supply chain. We have seen a real cooperative effort between different stakeholders coming in response to BMW's decision in March."
Richard Burden, MP for Birmingham Northfield

"At this stage we are happy about the principle but let's keep our feet on the floor - this still means job losses albeit not as many as if the Alchemy deal had gone through."
Duncan Simpson, national officer, Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union

"We are very, very relieved and very pleased. There will be 1,000 redundancies but hopefully that will be achieved by voluntary redundancies. This is a far, far better story than we had a month ago and I think there will be a great load lifted off people's shoulders in the West Midlands. This is a great opportunity and it is down to the people of Longbridge to make it happen."
Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary AEEU

"This is wonderful news. Our campaign and support for the Phoenix bid has saved jobs throughout the West Midlands and the rest of the country."
Roger Lyons, general secretary, Manufacturing, Science and Finance union

"I would have thought that maybe 800 [voluntary redundancies] was more realistic."
Tony Woodley, chief negotiator, Transport and General Workers Union

"It's magic news but I would have to say what is the long-term plan? It's brilliant. But it's going to take at least 12 months to turn it around."
Roger Voice, 44, Longbridge production worker

"The deal does not get over the initial problem of Longbridge needing a lot of development. It's a very, very old factory and it will need a lot of money spent on it. If Rover now just stands still in terms of investment and new products, then the Phoenix plan will merely be a stay of execution for Rover."
Mark Norman, CAP Motor Research company analyst

fields.headline: Mother-in-laws
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about a special relationship on the net
fields.trailText: As Bill Clinton moves in with his, everything you need to know about a special relationship on the net
fields.body:
1. The Clintons' marriage has taken an unusual turn with the president's announcement that he is moving in with his mother-in-law.

2. Contrary to what you may think, the most powerful man in the world is not signing up for some Arkansas ear-bashing in penance for those times he strayed from his marriage vows.

3. Instead Slick Willy wants somewhere to stay as he supervises the construction of a presidential library in Little Rock.

webTitle: Louis Bourgeois, Turbine Hall, Tate Modern, London

fields.headline: 'I feel like an ant in here...'
fields.trailText: You could park the space shuttle in Tate Modern's Turbine Hall, and probably have room for the moon too. Walking though it some weeks ago, I wondered how artists invited to show in this 155 metre long, 35 metre high space could survive the attempt.
fields.body:
You could park the space shuttle in Tate Modern's Turbine Hall, and probably have room for the moon too. Walking though it some weeks ago, I wondered how artists invited to show in this 155 metre long, 35 metre high space could survive the attempt. Lars Nittve, Tate Modern's director, has talked of it as "the street". But streets have convivial corners, breaks, a sense of human scale. I feel like an ant in here, and the bridge that cuts across the space about halfway along is a hard climb to reach. Once up there, I feel horribly aware of emptiness above and below. A giant, pregnant spider's up here with me. And it's worse down at ground level again, because then there is the prospect of climbing all three of Louise Bourgeois's rickety-looking towers, where, once aloft, one is truly suspended in the void.

Bourgeois herself, at 89, has never seen her towers except as maquettes. She once did a series of prints called He Disappeared into Complete Silence, which is exactly how you feel as you climb the wavering, rusted spiral stairs. The towers, called I Do, I Undo and I Redo, did and undid me. They nearly did for me, but it is worth it. Atop two of the towers are what look like arrangements of giant dental mirrors, and sturdy old wooden chairs. Sit down, and you find yourself distortedly reflected from every angle, your image looming over the void.

The towers, as all towers should, contain secrets. Carved marble hands sparkling out of the chipped stone. Forearms with a hand at either end - babies' and mothers' hands, palm up, palm down. There are other things to find as you climb through the dark, clanking interiors. A mother and child under a bell jar, like junk-shop voodoo, the baby floating on the umbilical cord that snakes from navel to navel. Other mothers and babies in bell jars, one in each tower, good mothers and bad mothers and mothers who aren't quite good enough. The bad mother spurts her milk on the ground. A fat, homely mother sewn from old pink corduroy nursing her fat pink babe. There's more, including big bubbles of red glass floating up through one tower's red-lit interior, which one views through a magnifying mirror, while sitting inside the tower's base. I realise that the chairs Bourgeois has provided make you sit like a child, a diminished, watched being with your knees together in a world that's too big.

The Turbine Hall is going to be daunting for any artist invited to work there. The choices, as far as I can see, are either to work, as it were, at street level, or to engage architecturally, as Bourgeois has. The success of her project is partly due to the way she has worked with the very big (the towers, the spider) and the very small (the mantlepiece curio in the bell jar, the life-size hand). And once inside the towers, of course, you are shut off, and could be anywhere.

Louise Bourgeois is extremely old, and excessively, calculatedly, at odds with the everyday world about her. This would be terrible, if it weren't also her strength. This isn't her greatest work, even if it is her largest, although it is incredibly successful in this most difficult of spaces, a space that could make an artist disappear into complete, irrevocable silence. Which, I guess, is also what much of the Tate's audience might feel on their first visit here.

webTitle: Laughing all the way to Bankside

fields.headline: Laughing all the way to Bankside
fields.standfirst: Tate Modern's temporary show, Between Cinema and a Hard Place, aims to include the viewer in the artwork.  Adrian Searle  gets involved
fields.trailText: Tate Modern's temporary show, Between Cinema and a Hard Place, aims to include the viewer in the artwork. Adrian Searle gets involved
fields.body:
Sandwiched between the two levels housing the Tate Modern's contentious display of its permanent collection is a floor devoted to a temporary exhibition, Between Cinema and a Hard Place. This exhibition includes 22 artists, each of whom has been given a gallery, and highlights a major strength of Tate Modern: one is, by and large, able to see individual or small groups of works in almost ideal conditions. The exhibition has an air of clarity and distinction - where, that is, the artists are capable of it. Many repay close individual attention, and I'll be returning to them.

There is no catalogue to this paying exhibition, which comprises both Tate-owned works and temporary loans. It would be easy, too, to see this floor as an extension of the suites above and below, so porous are the themes of the collection's display. In fact, certain works here fulfil the rubrics exactly. Ilya Kabakov's installation, Labyrinth: My Mother's Album, for example, might even be called History/Memory/Society, as he takes us down the narrow, gloomy corridors of a Moscow apartment. We brush the walls as we turn and turn again, ever inwards towards a distant room, where a man is singing to himself. The walls are decorated with the typed and handwritten memories of a fictitious tenant, who has lived through the deprivations of Russian life, while other texts promise the burgeoning utopia of the Soviet system. The corridor takes us to a vacant, abandoned room, a core of melancholy, futility and wasted human potential.

This melancholy, this weighty sense of yearning is continued in Rachel Whiteread's Ghost, her cast of a Victorian living room, and in Miroslaw Balka's Dawn, an installation of human-sized cylinders and small objects related to the body. It is a kind of symbolic, theatrical space for unknown actions, bounded by a horizon line of metal pipe, as though we were inside the diagram for a ritual.

The artists in Between Cinema and a Hard Place, we are told in a short introduction by Tate Modern curator Frances Morris, "have sought to include, as part of the work, the actual space in which it is installed". This means that we are included too, inside the metaphorical as well as physical space of the work. The cinema of the title can stand for the use of imagery and allusion in the work, even when there isn't a projector in sight. The "hard place", Morris writes, brings us back to the material world itself, either in the artists' deployment of actual materials, or in the world as it appears in cinema or video. A nice analogy, even though it is a sort of sleight of hand, and could apply to almost anything.

We cannot avoid narrating our way through exhibitions, even when the stories the artists themselves tell - like Matthew Barney's - are so opaque as to be entirely inscrutable to anyone else. In this context, the group of figures on tiered benches, by Juan Munoz, who laugh at whatever it is that they can see in the blank, empty space between themselves and the wall, invites us to speculate on what is withheld, and what we ourselves bring to the work.

Between Cinema and a Hard Place also includes Bill Viola's Nantes Triptych, a video installation depicting real birth, real death and a man plunging and resurfacing in water, as well as video works by Gary Hill, Douglas Gordon and Stan Douglas, and annoying rooms by Rebecca Horn and Mona Hatoum - both of whom are being over-promoted by the Tate. There is a room full of Horn's performance accoutrements upstairs and Hatoum, as well as showing in the permanent collection, also has a current exhibition over at Tate Britain. But this exhibition tells us that we no longer need to travel abroad all the time to catch up on many of these artists, and that their work isn't necessarily compromised in group shows.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Cruise and Kidman join up on stage, Babe director in new project, Jolie weds Thornton, Damon and Affleck fight for Harvard pay rise, and Jackie Chan makes it into Madame Tussaud's
fields.body:
 Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman are reportedly considering a visit to England to co-star on the London stage. According to the Daily Express, the husband-and-wife team have their sights set on a production of Tennessee Williams's fevered Deep South familial drama Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, which will be directed by Sam Mendes, winner of the Best Director Oscar for his film debut American Beauty. Cruise and Kidman have acted together on screen with mixed results in films like Days of Thunder, Far and Away and Stanley Kubrick's Eyes Wide Shut, though they have never taken to the stage together. Cruise has little stage pedigree, though Kidman won rave reviews for her appearance in the Donmar Warehouse's production of The Blue Room back in 1998 - a performance dubbed by one panting critic as "pure theatrical Viagra".

 Babe director Chris Noonan will break a self-imposed five-year lay-off when he adapts and directs Rule of Bone, based on the Russell Banks novel. Rule of Bone will recount the rites-of-passage story of a troubled New York teenager named Chappie who lights out for Jamaica in the company of a Rastafarian mystic. It will be the third Banks adaptation in four years, following on the heels of Atom Egoyan's The Sweet Hereafter and Paul Schrader's Affliction. After striking the mother lode with 1995's family favourite Babe, writer-director Noonan turned down a brace of high-profile offers, including the 1998 monster movie Godzilla. "I felt a great deal of pressure to say yes to things I didn't quite believe in," he says.

 Finally it's official: Angelina Jolie wed boyfriend Billy Bob Thornton at a low-key ceremony in Las Vegas over the weekend. The nuptials had been reported a tad prematurely by the American gossipmongers who claimed that they had actually married the weekend before. It's the second time up the aisle for Oscar-winning Jolie, 24, following her two-year marriage to Britain's Jonny Lee Miller. Thornton has amassed a far more impressive track record: his wedding to Jolie is a case of fifth time lucky for the 44-year-old.

 Matt Damon and Ben Affleck both appeared at a rally at Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, over the weekend to demand a pay increase for the college's custodial staff. The acting duo won an Oscar for their screenplay for the 1998 film Good Will Hunting, about a janitor at Harvard (played by Damon, himself a Harvard drop-out). Affleck's parents both worked as custodial staff at the university. The pair were appearing as speakers in support of Cambridge city council's Harvard Living Wage Campaign, which aims to bump custodial pay up to a more competitive $10.25 per hour.

 Martial arts star Jackie Chan is to be the first Chinese entertainer to be honoured at the new Madame Tussaud's museum in Hong Kong. Currently forging a career in Hollywood, Chan is revered by fans for his blend of rumpled charm and quick-silver martial arts skills. But the waxwork will be an altogether more sedate affair. Chan told a news conference that he wants to be depicted in "a normal, friendly pose Doing the drunken tiger or snake stance would be far too tiring to keep up for 200, 300 years," he said.

webTitle: Juninho's rise and fall from Boro's finest to nearly man

fields.headline: Juninho's rise and fall from Boro's finest to nearly man
fields.trailText: These days we are blase about top foreign players signing for English clubs. Meanwhile the man whose signature heralded the change waits to find out what the future holds.
fields.body:
In mid-afternoon the players' tunnel at the Riverside stadium in Middlesbrough is shaded by the west stand. Last Saturday Boro's Brazilian midfielder Juninho did what he always does before running on to the field. The 27-year-old dipped one knee, touched the turf by the touchline with his right hand and then crossed himself before passing from the shadow into the sunlight.

It may be the last time home fans see that characteristic gesture. Juninho's loan spell from Atletico Madrid, the club for whom he left Teesside in a £12m deal in 1997, comes to an end at Goodison Park on Sunday. No one, including the 1994 Brazilian footballer of the year, knows if Boro plan to make the move permanent.

In his last full season at Middlesbrough Juninho scored 15 times in 47 games and Opta rated him the Premiership's most effective player, way ahead of his nearest rivals Gianfranco Zola and Eric Cantona. He was named Premiership player of the year and finished second to his friend Zola in the football writers' version.

The response to what may turn out to have been his last game in this country was muted to say the least: a lap of honour in a half-empty stadium and hardly a headline in the national press.

Juninho plainly wants to stay in England. A cynic might say he has little to go back to. Atletico have been relegated for the first time in 60 years, government appointees now handle the financial administration of the club and there is a nasty fascist element in the crowd.

Despite the fact that Jesus Gil is facing charges of fraud, the former Marbella mayor is back at the club as president; a man who enjoys turbulence so much that he might have done better in white-water canoeing than football.

Gil announced his comeback in typical fashion: "My name is Jesus, not Jesus Christ, but I will try to perform a miracle." Past performance suggests this is less likely to involve loaves and fishes than the sacking of the odd manager or 12. No wonder the little man from Sao Paulo says he feels "comfortable" on Teesside.

The Boro supporters are more ambivalent than might be expected about the future of the player they voted the greatest in the club's history three years ago. The chant of "Sign On Juninho" - a phrase that seems less open to misinterpretation when shouted than it does in print - may have echoed round the Riverside on Saturday but a poll published in the club fanzine, Fly Me To The Moon, found 40% of respondents thought Boro should not pay the £5.9m asking price.

Many feel the Brazilian has not recovered from the destruction wrought on his ankle by the Celta Vigo defender Michel Salgado in 1998. Atletico appear to agree. When Juninho signed a five-year contract at the Estadio Vicente Calderon the Spaniards said anyone who wanted to lure him away would have to pay £36m. Now he is on offer for less than a sixth of that sum.

Since his return to Boro in September, Juninho has been used sparingly. Explaining why he had kept the Brazilian on the bench for much of March and April, Bryan Robson was adamant that the player simply was not creating enough to justify being given a free role.

Fans, forever programmed for conspiracy, have suspected more convoluted motives that rival Alfred Hitchcock. And why not? Down the years Middlesbrough have displayed an aptitude for upsetting their greatest stars, Wilf Mannion and Brian Clough among them.

Some feel that the ridicule heaped on the manager after he substituted Juninho against Wimbledon hardened his heart against the Brazilian; others that, in a tactic favoured in carpet bazaars across the Middle East, the club are trying to force down Atletico's asking price by feigning indifference to the product.

Times have changed, of course, and not only for the Brazilian. Juninho's arrival in 1995, to the accompaniment of a samba band from Stockton-on-Tees and the whirring of cameras from around the world, was more than just a triumph for Robson and Middlesbrough. It was a coup for the Premiership.

These days we are blase about top foreign players signing for English clubs. Back then it was regarded as an inexplicable phenomenon on a par with the Mary Celeste or Kenny Cunningham's hairstyle. Big names come and go. Rivaldo for Coventry City? Hey, why not? Meanwhile the man whose signature heralded the change waits to find out what the future holds.

fields.headline: Spielberg sued over Small Soldiers
fields.trailText: The saga of the Small Soldiers lawsuit against Steven Spielberg continues today (see Friday's report), as more details of the charges against the ET director emerge.
fields.body:
The saga of the Small Soldiers lawsuit against Steven Spielberg continues today (see Friday's report), as more details of the charges against the ET director emerge.

In a suit filed at a district court in LA, little known film-maker Gregory Grant charges Spielberg, DreamWorks and Universal Pictures with copyright infringement of his 1990 short film Ode to GI Joe for their 1998 feature Small Soldiers.

Both Ode to GI Joe and Small Soldiers centre on the adventures of a troop of toy servicemen who come to life. Grant claims that he met with representatives of Spielberg's production company Amblin Entertainment in 1991 to discuss expanding his short into a full-length production and that Spielberg personally requested a 16mm print of the original picture.

Grant says he was asked to write a script treatment, but Spielberg's company eventually passed on the project. The suit alleges that Small Soldiers (which was then titled Toy Soldiers) went into development less than a month after Grant was given the knock-back.

Directed by Joe Dante, Small Soldiers was released to mixed reviews and poor business in 1998. fields.headline: Prescott faces sell-off revolt
fields.trailText: The government is fighting to avert a rebellion by around 50 backbench MPs against its plans to part-privatise air traffic control. The revolt, led by the former transport secretary Gavin Strang, could be one of the most embarrassing since Labour came to power.
fields.body:
The government is fighting to avert a rebellion by around 50 backbench MPs against its plans to part-privatise air traffic control. The revolt, led by the former transport secretary Gavin Strang, could be one of the most embarrassing since Labour came to power.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is expected to go on the offensive to win over wavering MPs, but government sources admit they expect the revolt to be "serious".

The extent of the rebellion will emerge during today and tomorrow's Commons debate of the transport bill, which aims to sell off 51% of the National Air Traffic Service (NATS) to private investors. The government argues that air traffic is growing at more than 5 % a year, and that money raised by the public-private partnership will help to upgrade the service.

However, the backbench MPs are anxious that the culture of safety will be eroded by the drive to generate profits for shareholders. Mr Strang told the BBC's Good Morning Scotland programme: "The worry we have is that if it is privatised, a private company will want to get more return. Eventually that could erode the safety culture that is the best in the world."

A Commons select committee report recently warned that part-privatisation was the worst option for air traffic control services. Trade unions and many air traffic controllers themselves are also opposed.

The rebel MPs argue that NATS provides levels of safety above and beyond any statutory requirements, and that a part-privatised service would have no incentive to go beyond the legal minimum. Mr Strang said the rebels were also concerned about national security, and it was for this reason that no other European country had gone ahead with privatisation.

Mr Prescott, however, argues that safety would actually be improved by his proposals, because the same organisation would no longer be responsible for operating air-traffic control and overseeing safety. "I'm taking safety away from the operator," he said. "I've actually had the discussions with trade unions about these matters, listening to their concerns. But we've improved the safety so the hours are controlled, the skills are controlled, the inspectors. In all that way it is a gold-plated safety system."

webTitle: Arriva la tessera per i trapianti

fields.headline: Arriva la tessera per i trapianti
fields.standfirst: Soon all Italians will be required to keep a card stating whether they agree to donate their organs
fields.trailText: Soon all Italians will be required to keep a card stating whether they agree to donate their organs
fields.body:
Fra pochi giorni verrà recapitata agli italiani, insieme alla scheda elettorale per il referendum del 21 maggio, anche una busta contenente un tesserino che dovranno compilare e conservare. Servirà a dichiarare se vogliono o meno donare i propri organi dopo la morte.

È un primo passo verso l'attuazione della legge sui trapianti che prevede che tutti i cittadini esprimano la propria volontà. Coloro che non lo faranno, dopo un'adeguata informazione, verranno considerati consenzienti all'espianto dei propri organi. È la norma del cosidetto silenzio- assenso informato. Secondo un sondaggio pubblicato dal quotidiano "Repubblica", il 68,5% degli italiani si dichiara disposto a donare i propri organi, ma solo il 42% è favorevole a questa norma.

Il numero dei donatori di organi in Italia è oggi di 13,7 su ogni milione di abitanti. Malgrado sia in aumento, non basta a salvare le vite sospese di chi attende un trapianto. Il tesserino che piomberà nelle case, senza una seria campagna di informazione, potrà sensibilizzare i cittadini?

Abbiamo chiesto il parere di alcuni giovani che saranno chiamati ad esprimersi e del Presidente per la Regione Piemonte dell'Associazione Italiana Donatori di Organi.

Cosa pensate del problema della donazione degli organi?

Emanuele Perrone, studente - Se dovessi morire, gli organi non mi servirebbero più! Vorrei donarli a chi può continuare a vivere.

Ilaria Goffi, studentessa - Sono combattuta fra sensazioni diverse: la paura che l'espianto sia qualcosa di "brutto" e il desiderio di aiutare chi ne ha bisogno. Sono comunque favorevole alla donazione dei miei organi, ma non autorizzerei l'espianto da miei congiunti.

Roberta Ferrero, infermiera - I termini del problema mi sono stati spiegati a scuola, ma penso che gli infermieri debbano essere regolarmente aggiornati, cosa che non avviene. Sono favorevole alla donazione di organi miei o di miei congiunti. Lavorando in ospedale so che l'espianto non è un'azione brutale, come molti pensano.

Giorgio Elia, operaio - Sono assolutamente favorevole alla donazione. È una cosa giusta e anche estremamente bella.

Prof. Francesco Gorgerino, Presidente Regionale Aido - Aumentare la donazione degli organi significa salvare molte vite. Ricordo sempre, nel mio ospedale, una ragazza che aspettava il trapianto di un polmone che non è mai arrivato. Aveva 18 anni e molte speranze quando è morta... Bisogna orientare i cittadini a esprimere il parere in vita e registrarlo per non creare equivoci. Esistono però molti, delicati argomenti su cui fare chiarezza, come ad esempio il concetto della morte cerebrale, che è lo stato che rende possibile l'espianto. Le persone debbono poter capire e avere risposte.

Conosci la nuova legge sulla donazione degli organi?

Emanuele - No, non ne ho la minima idea.

Ilaria - Ho sentito che dovremo esprimerci su un foglio che riceveremo, ma non so altro.

Roberta - So che riceveremo, con la scheda del prossimo referendum, una specie di tesserino ma della nuova legge so poco o niente, benché infermiera. Quante persone butteranno via il tesserino, per distrazione o non sapendo cosa farne?

Giorgio - Ho sentito dire che riceverò un foglio da compilare. C'è molta disinformazione. La questione dell'espianto di organi spesso spaventa. Le istituzioni dovrebbero avviare una informazione capillare, mandando ad ogni cittadino un opuscolo chiaro e corretto sulla donazione di organi, che raccomandi anche di rivolgersi al medico di famiglia per eventuali dubbi.

Prof. Gorgerino - La nuova legge è, secondo le associazioni, difficile da applicare perché molto macchinosa. Prevede la realizzazione di strutture, come un centro informatico nazionale che attribuisca ad ogni cittadino una carta sanitaria. Ci vorranno, presumibilmente, da tre a cinque anni perché diventi operativa. Per adesso si procede come in passato: i parenti di una persona in stato di morte cerebrale vengono informati dell'utilità dell'espianto e danno l'autorizzazione, oppure si oppongono, a meno che il soggetto stesso non abbia preso una decisione in vita.

La nuova legge prevede invece che venga notificata a tutti i cittadini la richiesta di esprimersi, previa una buona informazione. Se, entro un certo limite di tempo dalla notifica, un cittadino non si esprimerà, si presumerà che sia consenziente.

Ma il documento che pare sarà inviato insieme al certificato elettorale non ha le caratteristiche della notifica prevista dalla legge. Per esserlo, dovrebbe essere consegnato personalmente e registrato. Inoltre non c'è stata alcuna seria informazione.

Come giudicate la norma del silenzio-assenso?

Emanuele - Non sono d'accordo. Il silenzio dimostra che non c'è una certezza su una materia sulla quale bisogna essere espliciti.

Ilaria - Non penso sia giusto. La scarsa informazione può provocare equivoci. Nessuno dovrebbe prendersi la briga di decidere per conto di altri.

Roberta - Sono d'accordo a patto che ci sia un'informazione corretta che attualmente non vedo. Tante cose non le so neppure io, che lavoro in campo ospedaliero.

Prof. Gorgerino - Molte nazioni hanno risolto questo problema abbastanza serenamente. Ma ripeto, è indispensabile una lunga campagna di informazione, capillare e corretta, che per il momento non esiste.

Glossario/Glossary

a patto che provided

il congiunto next of kin

la disinformazione lack of information

non avere la minima idea (coll.) not to have a clue

per adesso for the time being

piombare (fig.) to rush into

poco o niente (coll.) next to nothing

prendersi la briga (coll.) to dare/to dream of

previo subject to

il quotidiano daily newspaper

se vogliono o meno whether they want or not

il silenzio-assenso opt-out scheme

il tesserino card

una specie di (coll.) a sort of

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip marinated and put over a low heat to simmer
fields.trailText: Manchester United want Parma's Lilian Thuram. The Mirror reports that Old Trafford insiders have abandoned their attempts to sign Sol Campbell because the England man looks set to stay at Spurs. The versatile Thuram meanwhile could leave Parma this summer and United are expected to make a bid of £11m for his services.
fields.body:
Manchester United want Parma's Lilian Thuram. The Mirror reports that Old Trafford insiders have abandoned their attempts to sign Sol Campbell because the England man looks set to stay at Spurs. The versatile Thuram meanwhile could leave Parma this summer and United are expected to make a bid of £11m for his services.

The Daily Mail meanwhile suggests that Sir Alex Ferguson's eye is on another Serie A star, Italian international Christian Panucci. The United manager apparently watched Panucci in Internazionale's 4-0 home defeat by Fiorentina at the weekend and will spend £6m on the adaptable defender.

One player United won't be signing is Fiorentina goalkeeper Francesco Toldo. The Italian international has patched up the differences with his club Fiorentina. "I have spoken with President Cecchi Gori and together we've decided that I'm staying at Fiorentina," Toldo revealed. He is now expected to sign a new five year deal with the club.

England under-21 goalkeeper Richard Wright will leave Ipswich Town this summer if they are not promoted. The Sun report him as saying: "I will sit down with the club after the play-offs and discuss my future. I want Premiership football."

Newcastle are the latest club to develop an interest in £6m Trevor Sinclair. The Sun claims that the Hammers midfielder is admired by Bobby Robson, and that Harry Redknapp may have to sell the England international if he wants to complete Frederic Kanoute's move to Upton Park.

The Express believes that Chelsea are leading the race to sign £5m Eidur Gudjohnsen from Bolton. The 21-year-old Icelandic striker has been a long time target for Newcastle and Middlesbrough amongst others, and Bolton are resigned to losing him if they fail to gain Premiership status this summer.

Middlesbrough are set to make a £3m move for Chris Morgan according to the Daily Mail. The 22-year-old defender is the Tyke's player of the year.

Brentford midfielder Martin Rowlands is wanted by both Coventry and Charlton. Teamtalk suggest that the 21-year-old is likely to move for £3m this summer.

The Mirror reports that Leeds look like completing the £7m signing of former Everton midfielder Olivier Dacourt from Lens.

An unnamed English club is on the verge of signing Faustino Asprilla. Asprilla, currently playing for Palmeiras in Brazil, "is close to being transferred again to an English club", according to Colombian national coach Luis Garcia. "This team is very interested in him."

webTitle: Smithies bristles at being left out by England

fields.headline: Smithies bristles at being left out by England
fields.trailText: At last, a little light relief. No dollars, no Dalmiya, no declarations - just a good ordinary cricket dispute involving a wounded ex-captain with a sharp tongue and a good line in insults.
fields.body:
At last, a little light relief. No dollars, no Dalmiya, no declarations - just a good ordinary cricket dispute involving a wounded ex-captain with a sharp tongue and a good line in insults.

The row rages around the omission of Karen Smithies from the England squad for the first three one-day internationals against South Africa this summer.

Smithies, 31, has played 15 Tests and 69 one-dayers for England. She became captain in 1993, and was expected to lead England right through to the World Cup in December this year. However she resigned half-way through England's spectacularly disastrous tour of Australasia last winter, and was subsequently dropped from the team for the last three one-dayers of the tour. (It made no difference, England lost all of them too.)

Smithies held her tongue in New Zealand, despite feeling that she hadn't been fairly treated, but was incensed enough this time round to break an ECB embargo and fulminate to the press last Thursday, four days before the official announcement of the squad. She rounded on the team manager, Paul Farbrace, and the chairman of selectors, Eric Chapman. "Paul Farbrace said that [I had been dropped] because of a lack of ability to score runs quickly, but Eric Chapman said it was due to a lack of fitness. That is a load of bull," she fumed, echoing a sentiment expressed slightly more choicely by Chris Lewis when he was left out of the long list of 37 for the men's World Cup.

"I really don't understand the decision," Smithies later told wisden.com, "it is very hurtful. I hope it is not a sad end to my career.

"I don't think that the accusation that I score too slowly is fair. I am used to playing in the middle order but was promoted to stabilise the top order, which I did.

"The squad which has been chosen [including 16-year-old wunderkind Laura Harper, and 17-year-old allrounder Aaran Thompson] is a very young one, very very young and very inexperienced. Without me there are only two experienced players, Barbara Daniels and Clare Taylor. There are a few 23- and 24-year-olds who haven't produced the goods. Well, they are going to have to now."

There have been whispers about Smithies' batting for a while, but she still feels she has a lot to offer: "Only last July I got my maiden century against India. I was probably not in form in Australia and New Zealand, but neither were quite a few other people who are still in the squad."

Paul Farbrace denies that the decision to drop Smithies was personal. "Anyone who knows me knows that I don't operate in that way. I might be grumpy at times but I've never been vindictive. We as selectors are under pressure too, so we are not going to leave out people who we think will help us win the series.

"I like Karen, she is someone who tries very hard and the book isn't shut on her by any means. The squad will be reviewed before the last two games and if she can just improve her scoring rate, I want her back in the side."

But it could be hard for Smithies, who is desperate to play in what would be her fourth World Cup. England's recent run of results has been dismal and the selectors want and need to test some new blood before the winter - which means giving the younger women a fair run.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. Her Women's Page appears on wisden.com and CricketUnlimited every Tuesday.
