We as selectors are under pressure too, so we are not going to leave out people who we think will help us win the series. "I like Karen, she is someone who tries very hard and the book isn't shut on her by any means. The squad will be reviewed before the last two games and if she can just improve her scoring rate, I want her back in the side." But it could be hard for Smithies, who is desperate to play in what would be her fourth World Cup. England's recent run of results has been dismal and the selectors want and need to test some new blood before the winter - which means giving the younger women a fair run. Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. Her Women's Page appears on wisden.com and CricketUnlimited every Tuesday.

fields.headline: Rover in crisis
fields.standfirst: Phoenix, a consortium run by John Towers, a former Rover chief executive, has succeeded against the odds in buying the ailing car company from BMW, the German car maker. David Hearst and Mark Tran look at the background to the Rover crisis.
fields.trailText: Phoenix, a consortium run by John Towers, a former Rover executive, has succeeded against the odds in buying the ailing car company from BMW, the German car maker. David Hearst and Mark Tran look at the background to the Rover crisis.
fields.body:
Is this a happy ending for Rover?
The unions are certainly delighted that Rover is being bought by Phoenix rather than Alchemy, the venture capitalist which threatended to axe thousands of jobs at the Longbridge plant in Birmingham. But Longbridge is a very old plant that needs a lot of money. "If Rover now just stands still in terms of investment and new products, then the Phoenix plan will merely be a stay of execution for Rover," said Mark Norman of CAP Motor Research.

What is Phoenix paying BMW?
BMW is so glad to be getting rid of Rover, which was costing it £2m a day, it is lending Phoenix £500m to overhaul the company. Phoenix paid a symbolic amount of £10 for Rover, which says much about Rover's sad state.

What are Phoenix's plans?
Under the terms of the deal, Phoenix will continue to produce the Rover 25, 45 and MG sports car marques at Rover's Longbridge factory in Birmingham. Production of the Rover 75 car will be moved from Cowley, Oxford, to Longbridge.

What was Alchemy's plan for Rover?
It wanted to keep the profitable bits, such as the well known MG sports car brand, and sell off the less profitable parts. Alchemy planned to develop a new MG sports car by 2002 and relaunch the MG marque in America.

How long has Rover been making cars?
Since 1904. At one point the company was in the vanguard of technological breakthroughs, like the gas turbine car in 1950 and the four-wheel-drive T3 in 1956. In the prosperous postwar years, Britons bought as many cars as Rover could turn out. The brand became the hallmark of British motoring.

When did Rover's problems start?
In the 70s, when its plants were hit by waves of industrial unrest. Once the mainstay of UK corporate fleets, Rover lost many of its customers to cheaper and more reliable Japanese imports. Productivity at Longbridge lags far behind its rivals. A survey in 1998 showed that the plant produced 33 cars per worker, compared with 98 cars per worker at the Nissan factory in Sunderland.

How did BMW get involved?
The German manufacturer bought Rover in 1994, attracted by its Land Rover division of four-wheel-drive cars. It also thought Rover would fit into the bottom of its range. It pumped nearly £3bn into the group over the past five years, but the losses only mounted. BMW has estimated that Rover cost it £2.6bn in the six years since it acquired the business. This figure covers the purchase price, state subsidies, restructuring and investment costs and losses.

How did BMW try to turn things round?
Last year Rover shed 9,000 jobs in an attempt to close the productivity gap. It also hoped that new models, like the Rover 75 and updated versions of its 200 and 400 series, would be enough to turn the company round.

Did it work?
No, and the first casualty was BMW's chairman, Bernd Pischetsrieder, the man behind the Rover acquisition. He was replaced by Joachim Milberg, who imposed a two-year deadline for Rover to pull around. By threatening to transfer production to eastern Europe, BMW secured a £152m government aid package, in return for a £1.5bn investment, a controversial deal still subject to approval by the European commission. But even that level of subsidy was being eroded by the high pound, which knocked £230m off the company's revenue.

How many jobs are at stake if Longbridge closes?
Some 50,000 jobs are threatened, 16,000 of these in the Rover group, the rest in the car parts industry.

Who else makes cars in the UK?
Ford, Nissan and Jaguar, but only Ford is a volume manufacturer, with the rest consigned to the profitable but limited niche markets.

fields.headline: Témoin
fields.standfirst: Michel Arseneault describes this year's annual May Day demonstration in Paris
fields.trailText: Michel Arseneault describes this year's annual May Day demonstration in Paris.
fields.body:
Les manifestants avaient rendez-vous sur la place de la République. Selon les organisateurs, environ 30 mille personnes ont participé au défilé du Premier Mai. En France, c'est un jour férié qui commémore une grande manifestation qui a eu lieu à la fin du 19ème siècle à Chicago. C'est devenu une grande fête du mouvement ouvrier, mais aussi des anarchistes, des féministes, des comités de solidarité avec le tiers monde, et des gens qui défendent toutes sortes de causes.

Il y avait beaucoup de manifestants d'origine colombienne, irakienne, turque, sri-lankaise, etc. Le Premier Mai, on défend toutes sortes de causes. Parmi les Sri-Lankais par exemple, il y avait des supporters des Tigres Tamoul qui protestaient contre les ventes d'armes françaises au gouvernement de Colombo. En général en France, les manifs commençent toujours un peu en retard. Le rendez-vous était à 15 heures sur la place de la République. Et environ une heure plus tard, le cortège commençait à peine à marcher vers la place de la Bastille. Il y avait beaucoup de musique, entre autres africaine, mais peu de ballons. C'était un défilé très revendicateur, il y avait beaucoup de slogans, beaucoup d'affiches qui protestaient contre la mondialisation, le Fonds monétaire international et la Banque mondiale.

Il y avait plein de jeunes, même quelques enfants. Chez les Colombiens, il y avait plusieurs gamines qui tenaient le drapeau rouge de la guérilla colombienne. Mais c'est pas une fête où on voit papa, maman se balader avec le petit dernier sur les épaules de papa. C'était calme. Je n'ai pas vu beaucoup de policiers, mais je pense qu'il y en avait probablement pas mal en civil dans la foule.

le défilé march
le jour férié Bank holiday
une manif (coll.) demonstration
à peine only just
la gamine (coll.) kid (fem.)
se balader (coll.) take a stroll
le petit dernier (coll.) youngest child
être en civil to be in plain clothes

 Michel Arseneault was talking to Zo Eisenstein.

webTitle: Oldman signs up for Hannibal - at last

fields.headline: Oldman signs up for Hannibal - at last
fields.trailText: As reported on Friday and numerous other occasions, yes, it has been confirmed - he's done it, Gary Oldman has finally signed on the dotted line to play Anthony Hopkins's deranged nemesis in the much anticipated Hannibal.
fields.body:
As reported on Friday and numerous other occasions, yes, it has been confirmed - he's done it, Gary Oldman has finally signed on the dotted line to play Anthony Hopkins's deranged nemesis in the much anticipated Hannibal.

Oldman's entrance comes not a minute too soon - the Silence of the Lambs sequel begins filming this week in locations around Florence. The British-born actor will play Mason Verger, a millionaire pederast horribly disfigured in an earlier run-in with Hannibal "the Cannibal" Lecter (again played by Hopkins). To exact his revenge, Verger schemes to have Hannibal apprehended and fed feet first to a collection of carnivorous pigs he has imported from Sardinia.

The role will require extensive prosthetic make-up and an American accent. It will also require Oldman playing second fiddle to the film's leading lights Hopkins and Julianne Moore (who co-stars as FBI agent Clarice Starling). It is thought that wrangles over credits is what led to delays over Oldman committing to the project.

But he is not the only last-gasp cast member to arrive on the Hannibal set. American actor Ray Liotta has also announced his participation. The star of GoodFellas and Cop Land will take a supporting role as a corrupt FBI agent who undermines Starling.

Fortunately for director Ridley Scott, neither Oldman nor Liotta are needed during Hannibal's first five weeks of production in Sardinia and will only join up when the shoot moves across to America in June. For Scott, however, the work has already begun. Last week, Hannibal pressures forced the director to skip the LA premiere of his latest film, Gladiator.

fields.headline: Tony's good shirt day
fields.standfirst: These are hard times for the prime minister. But at least he seems to be getting one thing right - his working wardrobe.  Jess Cartner-Morley  reports
fields.trailText: These are hard times for the prime minister. But at least he seems to be getting one thing right - his working wardrobe. Jess Cartner-Morley reports
fields.body:
Things may be looking bad for Tony Blair, but Tony Blair is looking good. The pummelling he has taken over the last week seems to have left just the finest sprinkling of designer-casual creases on his linen shirt. The prime minister has been vilified in the past for letting the nation down in matters sartorial - the furore over Sandalgate in Tuscany roared like a forest fire through last August's news-starved papers - but yesterday's pictures suggested that he is finally getting the style message right.

In a polo-style shirt, deep blue with elbow-length sleeves and concealed buttons - crucially, worn loose rather than tucked in, which many middle aged men think makes them look slimmer when it does the opposite - the premier looked positively dashing, and nothing if not upbeat.

Perhaps he has learned what women's magazines have been preaching for years: in times of crisis, make sure you look fantastic. True, this crisis might be a little different from most but hey, rejection at the polls is just like any other kind. In the US, they have a name for a makeover following a break-up: a breakover.

The idea, in more masculine language, is to come back fighting - to score on the break, as it were. On polling day itself, knowing the importance of throwing the first punch, Blair already seemed to be making an extra effort, looking sleeker than usual in a dark blue single-breasted suit, and a pale biscuity tie with a light-blue shirt. (You don't have to be a colour expert to see that blue suits Blair better than red or even white. This is something the spinners will have to work on.)

Blair has always been a hard man to pin down, sartorially speaking. Not for him a hallmark, à la Michael Foot's duffel coat: eschewing look-at-me antics such as Ken's famous-scruffy-bloke overcoats and Margaret Thatcher's bossy handbags, he has taken the low road. His most noticeable feature, fashion-wise, has been his enthusiasm for the dress-down trend, generally expressed through the wearing of short-sleeved shirts.

This is significant, as attitudes to short-sleeved shirts are a litmus test of a man's ability to move with the times. Style experts over a certain age can be relied upon to get terrifically worked up about the wearing of short-sleeved shirts for activities other than gardening, declaring it vulgarity on a par with shell suits - thus, embracing short-sleeved shirts is Modern. But lest this be deemed rash, Blair compensates when dressing formally in a suit and proper shirt by always wearing double cuffs and cufflinks: a clever touch which is not only a nod to traditionalism but also says: "Leave it to me. I am so in control that I can even find my cufflinks before rushing off to attend to an international crisis."

It is the casual look that has sometimes backfired on Blair. The tomato-red polo shirt he sported at a Kosovan refugee camp in Albania in May last year showed clearly why the PM rarely wears red - it makes him look aggressive, the sort of man who might brazenly nab the last hedge-strimmer from under your nose in Homebase on a Saturday morning.

On European visits, he has shown a penchant for safe but stylish beige summer suits, but has slipped up badly in teaming a slightly-too-fitted shirt and chinos with sport sandals. But Blair is hardly alone in a certain clumsiness when it comes to mixing smart and casual garments. All over the country, you see outfits which look like the result of complex negotiations in front of the wardrobe: jeans and a T-shirt looks too scruffy so you try shirt and trousers but that looks too smart, so you end up wearing jeans with a shirt tucked in and belted. This often simply doesn't work, but men seem less able than women to grasp the idea that clothes have to work as outfits, that the favourite shoes don't necessarily go with the favourite jeans.

Blair's best look, as sported yesterday, owes as much to the US and its eastern seaboard Wasp resorts as to his favourite European holiday destinations - the hanging-loose-in-top-quality-linen look is extremely Hamptons-esque, and best accessorised with a boat and a large friendly dog. But, of course, it also works in Tuscany, and Islington, and Downing Street. And that is why it works on Blair: he looks at home in it.

Whether the Shirt is the beginning of a new sartorial era for Blair, it is too early to say. But with the ultimate fashion accessory on the way, in the form of a fourth child - Nicholas Coleridge of Condé Nast, the magazine publisher, declared last year that, among the smart set, four was the only number of children to have - Blair could soon be home and dry. Once he's got that Bill Amberg papoose on, there will be no stopping him.

webTitle: How precious resource has stoked the fires of conflict

fields.headline: How precious resource has stoked the fires of conflict
fields.trailText: The people of Sierra Leone seeking a peaceful life will today be regretting the discovery of the first diamond on its soil   in 1930. The fire that has fuelled the conflicts which have torn the country apart, and threatens to do so again, has been fed by that discovery.
fields.body:
The people of Sierra Leone seeking a peaceful life will today be regretting the discovery of the first diamond on its soil in 1930. The fire that has fuelled the conflicts which have torn the country apart, and threatens to do so again, has been fed by that discovery. The civil war that began in Sierra Leone in 1991 has seen tens of thousands of its citizens mutiliated or killed, with half a million in exile, and an economy, apart from diamonds, near collapse.

The diamond industry has proved to be a bloody one in Africa, responsible not only for the death and destruction in Sierra Leone but also paying for conflicts in Angola and the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

Human rights groups round the world and governments, including the British one, recognise the debilitating impact of the diamond trade and have been working to curb it. The British government recently asked the group Global Witness, which has been monitoring the diamond industry, to produce a detailed report on recommendations for controlling the industry. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, put the blame for the Sierra Leone crisis on both the rebel forces and the diamond industry.

He said: "This latest development does bring home the importance of the work that Britain has started through the G8 and through the United Nations to try and bring proper regulation to the diamond trade so that illicit diamonds being sold on the European markets do not fuel such civil strife within Africa."

The diamonds eventually end up in the Belgian port of Antwerp, the world centre of the trade. Few questions are asked about where they come from. Many are smuggled, with great pretence among traders that they have no knowledge of the country of origin.

Most of the diamond-producing areas in Sierra Leone are under the control of the rebel Revolutionary United Front. The UN forces sent in to try to police the peace agreement between the rebels and the government have moved into these areas to try to enforce decommissioning.

The UN has achieved some success in other parts of Sierra Leone but the diamond-producing areas were considered a step too far by the RUF. That is why some of the UN troops are dead and others held hostage.

Five years after discovery of the first diamond, serious production began. Sierra Leone quickly established a reputation for top-quality gems.

Until the 1980s, De Beers was directly involved in Sierra Leone but its involvement has since become indirect. It maintains a diamond trading company in Liberia and a buying office in Conakry, Guinea.

In a report The Heart of the Matter: Sierra Leone, Diamonds and Human Security, authors Ian Smillie, Lansana Gberie and Ralph Hazleton note that both countries produce very few diamonds themselves. Liberia is widely understood to be a transit country for smuggled diamonds. They say: "It is virtually inconceivable that [De Beers] is not in one way or another purchasing diamonds that have been smuggled out of Sierra Leone."

Liberia has established itself as a huge exporter of diamonds. The RUF, which controls the diamond-producing areas, receives in return for gems huge amounts of arms, mainly from the former Soviet bloc.

When De Beers ended direct trade, three companies moved in: Rex Diamond, AmCan Minerals, and DiamondWorks.

webTitle: Ruthless rebels who earned infamy for their terror tactics

fields.headline: Ruthless rebels who earned infamy for their terror tactics
fields.standfirst:
Guerrillas: Civilians suffer as the RUF rules through violence
UNMASIL - UN mission
Sierra Leone Web
Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: When the bands of guerrillas entered Sierra Leone in 1991 from Liberia and Burkina Faso, there were only a few hundred of them. Today, the Revolutionary United Front is a force of between 5,000 and 10,000, infamous for its terror tactics, which is now threatening the capital, Freetown.
fields.body:
When the bands of guerrillas entered Sierra Leone in 1991 from Liberia and Burkina Faso, there were only a few hundred of them. Today, the Revolutionary United Front is a force of between 5,000 and 10,000, infamous for its terror tactics, which is now threatening the capital, Freetown.

The RUF, one of several rebel groups, said it was fighting to destroy a corrupt system under which the government and foreigners monopolised the diamond trade.

The group created panic in Freetown early in its campaign by using mutilation; its trademark is the double mutilation - hacking off both hands.

The RUF is led by Foday Sankoh, a former professional photographer who never rose above the rank of corporal when serving in the military.

A western diplomat said yesterday: "Lots of people have questioned [Sankoh's] sanity. Some ask if he is in touch with his people in the field; others if he is in touch with reality."

"He's crazy," Alimamy Koroma, the general secretary of the Council of Churches in Sierra Leone, said in an interview last year. "It hurts all of us that someone of the low calibre of a Foday Sankoh could destabilise the entire Sierra Leone."

The Foreign Office questioned yesterday how much control Mr Sankoh had over his own commanders in the field: he claimed he had told his commanders to release the hostages. It said: "Either he is lying or he is not in control."

Mr Sankoh began his insurrection with a group said to have been trained in Libya. Initially, they concentrated on terrorising diamond-mining areas. This underlined the inability of the Freetown government to protect its citizens in the country's most important economic region.

Their effective control of the diamond areas gave them the money to buy high quality weapons. RUF ranks were swollen by boy soldiers, many press-ganged and allegedly plied with drugs.

Within a year, the RUF began to engage demoralised government troops in large numbers. Freetown and the mining companies responded by funding private security firms to take on the rebels.

In 1995, the RUF suffered reverses and retreated from the outskirts of Freetown. Under pressure, Mr Sankoh agreed to elections and a peace accord that gave the RUF four cabinet positions. To the horror of human rights groups round the world, Mr Sankoh was given responsibility for mining, enabling him to rebuild his army.

The UN forces have disarmed about half of the 45,000 rebels in Sierra Leone, but attempts to decommission Mr Sankoh's forces in the diamond-producing areas, have proved ineffective.

UN reports over the weekend created panic by suggesting that the RUF was on the outskirts of the capital. The statement was later revised but the damage was done.

At least RUF men were involved in shooting in the capital yesterday, but western diplomats said this was not a sign of a large-scale presence in Freetown.

Mr Sankoh himself remains in the capital, his home under attack from government supporters yesterday.

The evacuation of British and other EU nationals is an indication of lack of confidence in the ability of government's forces to prevent the RUF joining its leader in the capital.

webTitle: Britain sets limits to show of force

fields.headline: Britain sets limits to show of force
fields.standfirst:
Diplomacy: Evacuation effort shows how UN has failed
UNMASIL - UN mission
Sierra Leone Web
Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: The escalating crisis in Sierra Leone seemed a classic case for intervention by British mobile rapid reaction forces. At first sight, it appeared to give practical weight to the government's commitment to the UN last year to earmark troops for flashpoints across the world - and even to Tony Blair's call for a new "doctrine of international community".
fields.body:
The escalating crisis in Sierra Leone seemed a classic case for intervention by British mobile rapid reaction forces. At first sight, it appeared to give practical weight to the government's commitment to the UN last year to earmark troops for flashpoints across the world - and even to Tony Blair's call for a new "doctrine of international community".

Overnight, a battalion of paratroopers - 700 in all - had landed at Lungi airport, close to the capital, Freetown. Four RAF Chinook helicopters were preparing to airlift evacuees from outlying regions.

A Royal Navy taskforce consisting of the new helicopter carrier, HMS Ocean, HMS Chatham, a Type 23 destroyer, two landing ships and a supply ship, HMS Fort Austin, was preparing to sail for the west African country.

HMS Ocean was already in the Mediterranean, as were 600 marines from 42 Commando, who were carrying out exercises in southern France. The aircraft carrier HMS Illustrious was diverted from Nato exercises off Portugal.

Questioned about the strength of the fighting force sent to Sierra Leone, defence sources said last night: "It is inadvisable to have only one card to play." Offshore-based helicopters would provide an alternative escape route if Lungi were attacked by rebels.

Despite the scale of the mission, ministers insisted yesterday that the role of British troops was strictly limited to evacuating civilians.

They insisted that they will not be part of any "blue beret" force, although officials were careful not to rule out the possibility that they might help to keep Lungi airport safe for UN reinforcements.

The show of British force highlighted the UN's continuing failure to mount an effective multinational peacekeeping operation.

The problem, mentioned yesterday by Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, was identified by him a year ago when he said: "One of the problems with peacekeeping has been the speed of deployment. With each delay the problems get worse."

Yesterday independent analysts said they had already got worse. "There is an obvious need for a UN rapid reaction capability, a golden opportunity has gone begging," one said yesterday.

Nigel Vinson of the Royal United Services Institute said it would be a tall order for British troops to help evacuate UN forces from Sierra Leone in addition to civilians as the taskforce did not have the firepower or tactical mobility to get involved in fighting the rebel Revolutionary United Front.

Tim Spicer, director of Sand-line, the private military company at the centre of the arms-to-Africa affair two years ago, told the Guardian that the problem with the UN was that it had no standing military structure and its peacekeeping forces had no common training standards, equipment or communications systems.

He said the UN could sponsor private military firms that could put the RUF "right back into its box".

Mr Spicer also criticised the international community for allowing the RUF to join the Sierra Leone government and keep its weapons after the Lome peace accord.

Defence sources pointed out yesterday that the UN's mandate was merely to "stabilise" the situation. They admitted that the Lome peace accord had left a power vacuum in Sierra Leone. Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said the reason so many British troops had been deployed was to ensure that they could operate effectively in such a chaotic situation. "It is obviously important in such a confused and volatile situation that our own forces don't come under threat." The British action in Sierra Leone is impressive. But questions may be asked as to whether British troops, like those of the UN - or even the EU, which are absent from the present crisis - should have done more.

fields.headline: Launch pad
fields.standfirst: Learn.co.uk is the Guardian's latest website. It will help students, parents and teachers tackle the curriculum in an exciting way.
fields.trailText: Learn.co.uk is the Guardian's latest website. It will help students, parents and teachers tackle the curriculum in an exciting way.
fields.body:
The Guardian has long been more committed than any other national newspaper, not only to covering education, but to providing practical support to teachers, parents and students.

Last week that commitment entered a new phase: the educational values which are already deeply embedded in the newspaper are being massively expanded online.

We launched, last Wednesday, a new website called learn.co.uk. It aims to provide the most comprehensive, high-quality learning content anywhere on the web. Having looked at the future of the internet, it's clear to us (as it's no doubt clear to most parents and teachers, let alone their children) that one of the fields in which the web is most quickly going to transform our lives is education.

The net provides the opportunity to offer highly interactive learning materials to anyone who wants to access them, whenever they like. It could be in a classroom, it might be at home - it doesn't matter. The same materials will be open to all. And all our core content will be provided free.

Parents who use computers at home with their children (often in the form of "edutainment") know that interactivity can turn dry textbook learning into fun. Material that a child might yawn over on a page becomes a lively experience on screen.

On our site you can turn to a biology lesson, click on a diagram, and watch a plant being fertilised. In physics, you can call up a diagram of a planet going around a sun and, by altering its density, see how you can change the planet's orbit by changing gravitational pull. Or, instead of messing with a circuit board, you can connect to a lesson on Ohm's Law and alter resistances on the page, immediately seeing the effect of your actions.

And when a lesson is read, or an online experiment completed, you can ask the site to set a test to find out if you've taken in what you need to know. Unlike most other sites, though, you won't get the same test every time you come back: questions will be randomly generated, so the test will be subtly different every time. Within lessons, you will be asked to answer quite sophisticated questions. In English, for example, questions are not just multiple choice - sometimes a range of answers can be correct, and the site makes it clear what your options are.

For now, with exams just around the corner, the site has launched with the big four subjects at GCSE: English literature, English language, mathematics and double science. French (the next most popular GCSE subject after the "big four") will be uploaded to the site soon. We want to help students revise for those exams - but not in the conventional online way of simply offering up titbit Q and A exchanges. On learn.co.uk, students can recap whole topics online.

At this stage, each subject is covered for higher-tier candidates - for next year's exams we will cover every level, foundation, intermediate and higher, and start differentiating within lessons for a variety of ability levels.

Ultimately, we will cover every dot and comma of the national curriculum, from the age of five to 16, and all the main subjects at A level, too. We will upload more and more new subjects on to the site over the coming months. But again, unlike most other sites, we will never put up a subject until our coverage is comprehensive and complete. Everything in the curriculum for that subject, for that age group, will be on learn.co.uk. When you come to the site and see that we have, say, science for key stage 2, you will be able to find every component of the national curriculum covered for that age group.

The other basis for parents and teachers to feel confident about the site's educational content is that everything has been evaluated by classroom teachers at state comprehensive schools. In fact, we are looking for more partner schools to take part in that process, and are keen to hear from headteachers who want to play a part in developing what we believe will rapidly become one of the most powerful learning resources anywhere in the world.

In September, we will add the core subjects at key stages 2 and 3 and expand our coverage at key stage 4. Between now and then we will also be adding resources for teachers from the Guardian's vast archive, including all those up-to-date language materials and current affairs graphics that appear each week in this section.

For teachers we will be adding a job search section soon. For parents, there will be features offering information and advice on schools, as well as how to help your child learn on the web. For students we will be providing everything from online learning support to talk boards.

In researching what teachers, parents and students want from the web, we have discovered that they are most baffled by how and where to find the information they need. It seems like there's so much information out there, but it's a nightmare to find it. You can go to search engines, or you can take a tip from a friend - but then you find yourself spending what seems like hours trawling through page after web page, not quite arriving at the item you need.

One of the advantages we have as a newspaper is that we can build a relationship between printed words and pictures, and active online learning. In this recently redesigned section, we now have an area called Learning, with a regular web guide. Our web guides, in the paper and online, will make it vastly easier to find online learning resources. And each time we add a new feature or a new subject to the site, we will be able to keep you informed through the pages of this section.

The sample pages and images on these pages give you an idea what the site looks and feels like; they give you some impression of the seriousness and depth, but also the attractiveness of the material on offer. But the only way you can really judge is to go online and take a look for yourself. When you have, tell us what you think - either by emailing learn.co.uk, or by writing to the Education section. On the constantly evolving web, you might find your suggestion can be acted on more quickly than you believed possible.

fields.headline: Europe, our Europe
fields.standfirst: On Europe Day, David McKie imagines the heady cocktail of entertainments the Foreign Office has prepared to enthuse us with the European project.
fields.trailText: On Europe Day, David McKie imagines the heady cocktail of entertainments the Foreign Office has prepared to enthuse us with the European project.
fields.body:
Today is Europe Day. Which is why there is bunting everywhere, why the flags of all 15 EU member nations are flying in the streets, why bands of musicians and street entertainers from everywhere from Bergen to Barcelona are performing in all the principal squares of all our principal cities, why the Ode to Joy was played on early morning radio in the slots usually occupied by the national anthem when it is some royal person's birthday, and why it's a public holiday.

It isn't? None of that's happening? How very odd. We have been members of the European Union for nearly 30 years now, and of the European continent for even longer. Even those who resent the EU and set their faces like flint, as Enoch Powell used to say, against the euro often go out of their way to insist that they still love Europe. Given the unpopularity of their cause nowadays one might have expected the europhile lobby to fill the gap left by government inaction with colour and fun. Everyone knows there is plenty of colour and fun on the other side of the Channel, but in the context of the euro debate it frequently gets forgotten.

But even that isn't quite right. It is not wholly true that Tony Blair's government is guilty of inaction. It has ordered that the doors of the Foreign Office be flung open today and the public admitted. Two thousand schoolchildren have been given invitations so the place will be pretty busy. Visitors will be able freely to wander through the famous corridors, admiring the boastful architecture and the fairly expensive pictures. They may even, if they are lucky, catch a glimpse of Robin Cook, striding along on his way to some crisis meeting.

Within the walls of the FO there are all the attractions so conspicuously missing elsewhere. Every hour on the hour bulging supplies of food from members nations will be opened up to attenders. Still more exciting is the ceremonial mixing of a European cocktail, blending the drinks of the EU's member nations, under the kindly supervision of the boxer Frank Bruno. No doubt there have been trials for several months now, with Foreign Office minions judiciously sipping potential concoctions. The range is vast and enticing. A dash of Bordeaux, an equal measure of ouzo, a squirt of warm English beer; some schnapps from the Netherlands, a tinge of Martini, a slug of Scandinavian vodka, all shaken in a tumbler of Belgian trappist beer and Spanish porto fino - it should make for an experience which few who try it will ever forget.

There is also music: a Lithuanian saxophonist to open the day, Greek guitarists, Turkish folk dancers, a Polish jazz band and to finish the day in style, a Maltese pianist and tuba player. (Two people or one? The programme does not say).

For those who miss out today there is this consolation: the show does not end there. The Foreign Office promises that its minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, will be carrying the message on through the highways and byways of Britain through the rest of the year, as a kind of one-man-all-the-year-round Day of Europe. One hopes he will come equipped with a tanker of Euro-cocktail and hemmed about by such of the entertainers as can stay in his country once today's FO feast is over. If not, do not despair. They say that Vaz is a bit of a dab on the Maltese piano and tuba himself.

webTitle: All about Anna: Helen McCrory on Anna Karenina

fields.headline: All about Anna: Helen McCrory on Anna Karenina
fields.standfirst: Tonight, Tolstoy’s Anna Karenina hits our small screens. Helen McCrory, who plays Anna, asks why the 19th-century heroine still appeals to 21st-century women
fields.trailText: Tonight, Tolstoy’s Anna Karenina hits our small screens. Helen McCrory, who plays Anna, asks why the 19th-century heroine still appeals to 21st-century women
fields.body:
How should a woman live her life? Survive to the age of 70, fearfully, being as everyone else instructs her to be? Or play the heroine, passionately, in the knowledge that trying and failing need not equal defeat?

This is the timeless conundrum Tolstoy's vivid heroine, Anna Karenina, took on, long before it became fashionable to discuss the conflict of desire and expectation in women's lives. She was an original of her era, but what are the resonances of Anna's story for the modern woman?

Born into the wealthy, decadent upper class of 19th-century St Petersburg, Anna confronts the hypocrisy of the day when she breaks free of an empty marriage after falling in love with army officer Vronsky. She scandalises her contemporaries when she chooses to live with him as his mistress, after her husband refuses her a divorce. But her passion for her lover is tempered by the pain of leaving her son and the disapproval heaped on her by the Russian aristocracy. Spiralling into depression and opium addiction, she starts to doubt Vronsky. A bout of morbid jealousy tips her over the edge and she throws herself under a train.

When viewers first see Anna, they are aware of the elements of her existence - she is a society hostess, an obedient wife, a good mother - but they don't know who she is. Nor does anyone in the story because they don't bother to ask. But loneliness isn't dependent on the century: there are many women today who feel isolated. They don't feel they express themselves in the way they want to, they don't look the way they want to, they are not doing the job they should be doing. Anna is a woman who feels all those things and decides her passion to be loved is greater than her fear of being alone and afraid all her life.

Of course there is a great romanticism to her plight, but she is no feckless ingenue. She leaves her husband and son because it is her only chance of survival. For the first time in her life, Anna is pursued by a man who tells her that she is lovable, that she is beautiful, intelligent and sexual. Everyone understands that need to be loved. Tolstoy wrote that throughout life we experience such revelations and the skill of being alive is to acknowledge them and allow them to change you. Anna can never go back.

In the society in which she lived, it was the norm to be inspired by something higher than yourself: for a man to die for his tsar, his country or his God was considered noble. Women could live out their passions only within the constraints of the home, as Anna did during her nine-year marriage. But when she met Vronsky, her tremendous capacity to love was ignited. It is this passion that both excited Tolstoy and makes her such a compelling heroine. Her ability to live in the moment and her great honesty make her hugely satisfying to play. When she follows her heart, she feels those passions we all want to feel.

Today, passion is narrowly defined in a sexual way. And this in turn is externalised into the formulaic, cold, aesthetic beauty that is admired in our sex. Style has become a dress size, not an attitude, and passion is about a pair of kitten-heeled mules.

This is underlined by reactions to my being cast as Anna. Many people have compared me unfavourably with Greta Garbo, who played the part in 1935. But why shouldn't an actress be cast because of her passion for the role rather than because of her looks? When Tolstoy wrote the novel, he didn't describe Anna as beautiful - he gave her a low forehead and large features - but no reviewer then complained that he had failed to make her a goddess.

Anna's appeal lies in the visceral rather than the physical. It is worth remembering that in Tolstoy's Russia, the idea of beauty was far more personal, more localised. There was no media aesthetic and no sense of what people in other countries looked like. Today, women are constantly made aware of the physical impression they create; sexuality is defined by the male view of it and women's sexual role is seen as passive and usable. The images of women's bodies that appear in advertising and in the media signal vulnerability, needing to be saved and being sexually available at all times. At least Anna and her contemporaries escaped this.

Indeed, at that time, gender defined the roles ascribed to men and women, not the individuals' temperaments. Roles were created not to allow them to express individuality but, more pragmatically, to run a country. Nor was sexuality important in marriage: whether a woman was fulfilled didn't matter as long as she bred. Now we find ourselves at the other extreme. The pill has revolutionised women's lives - but the freedom it has brought can still be used against us.

In one sense, the Russian aristocracy were very honest about sex and love. Marriage was about blood and property, and affairs were acceptable. Anna's great betrayal is not of her husband but of society. She blows the roof off it when she falls in love and its hypocrisy and cruelty eventually destroy her. Today, the stigma of affairs is more personal but women are still contrained by social mores: Anna could now apply for visiting rights - but she may still be penalised for being a single mother.

Back then, emotional fulfilment was as likely to be discovered through one's relationship with God as with a lover. It is a very recent phenomenon to expect such totality from a partner. People then didn't marry thinking they were getting the complete package: best friend, lover, careers adviser. In a more realistic era, there was no sense of the holy grail of perfect union.

Just before she kills herself, Anna says to her lover: "I don't know who I am, Vronsky, I only know my appetites." She ultimately sacrifices herself for those appetites, but she has truly lived since Vronsky awakened her and I admire her so for that.

How should a woman live her life? By the end of the story, Anna's choice is to return to her husband, disgraced, and live a lie, or to say: "I did it, I've lived and that's enough." She jumps, not from something but to something. There is no defeat. It's wonderful to see a woman playing the heroine.

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
House Doctor
8.30pm, Channel 5
Interiors expert Ann Maurice is a scary woman. In this first of a new series, she's confronted with a cluttered Stepney flat and bluntly tells amiable owner Simon what needs changing if he's to shift the property. Ann just stops short of telling Simon to pull himself together - he's selling because his relationship broke up - but it still makes you wince when she finds some of Simon's ex's possessions and notes, "Maybe we don't really want to get rid of the old girlfriend."

Anna Karenina
9pm, Channel 4
It is, of course, de rigueur for cossie drama producers to promise a new slant on classics, but with busy camerawork that wouldn't look out of place in an episode of NYPD Blue, this at least avoids looking too much like other recent efforts. Having said that, how much you enjoy this four-part adaptation of Tolstoy's novel, scripted by Alan Cubitt (Prime Suspect II) and directed by David Blair (The Lakes), may depend on your tolerance for posh social gatherings where the subtext always means more than anything that actually gets said. Still, the performances, especially from Helen McCrory as Anna and Kevin McKidd as Anna's lover Vronsky, are fine, and the overwrought love affair at the heart of the story makes a change from yet another costume treatise on English manners.

Pleasure Island
10pm, ITV
Hedonism II in Jamaica is an "adult" resort. In short, it sells itself on the promise of copious sex and nudity. It's a simple brochure pitch, so it makes sense that this new series on the resort is simplistic TV.

Walter: The Secret Life Of A Victorian Pornographer
10.30pm, Channel 4
Who was Walter, the Victorian who wrote up his sexual adventures with 1,200 women in the 11 volumes of My Secret Life? We may never be sure, but this film examines how Walter's memoirs reveal a sadist who enjoyed exerting power over the women he slept with.

webTitle: Prosecutors seek death penalty for 'Angel of God'

fields.headline: Prosecutors seek death penalty for 'Angel of God'
fields.trailText: A Mexican drifter who saw himself as an "angel of God" and travelled around the US in empty carriages of freight trains, murdered nine people because he thought they "were evil and deserved to die", his lawyers said at the opening day of his trial yesterday.
fields.body:
A Mexican drifter who saw himself as an "angel of God" and travelled around the US in empty carriages of freight trains, murdered nine people because he thought they "were evil and deserved to die", his lawyers said at the opening day of his trial yesterday.

Angel Maturino Resendiz is so far charged with only one of the murders, but is suspected of killing six people in Texas, two in Illinois and one in Kentucky between 1997 and 1999 as he criss-crossed the US, hitching lifts in open freight wagons, leaving a trail of blood behind him and focusing attention on an itinerant sub-culture living on America's railway system.

Mr Resendiz's lawyers entered a plea of insanity yesterday after overcoming their client's objections, but a prosecutor in the Houston courtroom demanded the death penalty for what he said was "one of the most horrible events you will ever have the misfortune of hearing".

The FBI identified Mr Resendiz as a suspect after officers realised the killings all took place near railway tracks and began interviewing other drifters. He surrendered three weeks after being placed on the FBI's "ten most wanted" list last year.

The trial, which opened in Texas yesterday, focuses on the robbery, rape and murder of a doctor, Claudia Benton.

The prosecution said that fingerprints and DNA samples taken from the Ms Benton's home linked Mr Resendiz to the crime. The defendant's wife later handed in jewellery she suspected he had stolen from Benton.

"There is good, hard physical evidence that will be difficult to refute," a spokesman for the Texas police, said.

If Mr Resendiz is convicted of the Benton murder, prosecutors say they may bring up the other eight killings for consideration before sentencing.

"I don't want to overwhelm the jury with all these capital murders, but I still want to prove them beyond a reasonable doubt," Devon Anderson, one of the prosecutors, told journalists.

Speaking for the defence, Mr Resendiz's lawyer, Allen Tanner said: "The defendant has no remorse for any of his crimes. The defendant in his mind thinks these people were evil and deserved to die."

Mr Tanner read letters written by Mr Resendiz in which he talked about micro-organisms infecting the human body, travel on light-waves to other galaxies and being an angel of God "feared by all".

Mr Resendiz initially declared he did not want his lawyers to present an insanity defence but was later persuaded to change his mind. He also refused to talk to a court-appointed psychiatrist until the judge, Bill Harmon, warned him that his right to enter a plea of insanity would be limited if he refused to comply.

The judge rejected a last-minute defence motion for the trial to moved out of Houston on the grounds that Mr Resendiz had received too much adverse publicity to be assured of a fair hearing. In December, Mr Resendiz had asked for the trial to be moved to Waco, Texas, because he felt an affiliation with the Branch Davidians, an apocalyptic cult which clashed with federal agents in Waco five years ago. The judge told him he would have no say in the location of the trial.

Mr Resendiz has also complained that the threat of execution by lethal injection is a breach of a guarantee of humane treatment he was offered in exchange for handing himself in to the Texas Rangers at a remote border crossing at El Paso.

Mr Tanner said his client had handed himself in, after seeking refuge with relatives in Mexico, in the belief he would be treated as he would have been under Mexican law, which has no death penalty.

webTitle: Downing St attacks BBC report on Cherie Blair's pregnancy

fields.headline: Downing St attacks BBC report on Cherie Blair's pregnancy
fields.standfirst:
The future of the BBC: special report
Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: Downing Street last night launched a scathing attack on the BBC for featuring a therapist who claims to be involved in Cherie Blair's pregnancy.
fields.body:
Downing Street last night launched a scathing attack on the BBC for featuring a therapist who claims to be involved in Cherie Blair's pregnancy.

The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, accused the BBC of naive behaviour for claiming on last night's Six O'Clock News that the alternative health therapist Bharti Vyas was "understood" to be helping Mrs Blair.

In a letter to Roger Mosey, the BBC's head of news, Mr Campbell said: "I find it extraordinary that without any reference to Downing Street or to Mrs Blair's office, the BBC should run a package on someone they reported as being closely involved in preparations for the birth of the Blairs' fourth child.

"The only people involved in the preparations for the birth are the family themselves, their doctor, and the hospital."

Mr Campbell added: "As your reporter said, the prime minister and his wife are determined to protect the privacy of their children. It is a shame that as well as expressing that thought, the programme did not allow it to affect their editorial judgment.

"There are many people out there who will no doubt try to get publicity for themselves on the back of the birth and who will be on the lookout for naive parts of the media to help them.

"It is extraordinary that it should be the BBC that is fulfilling that role."

Ms Vyas, who was reported to have been treating Mrs Blair at her central London clinic, is said to have recommended that the prime minister should massage her back every day.

A BBC spokesman said last night: "We have received the letter and will reply in due course."

webTitle: One2One sues over licence payment terms

fields.headline: One2One sues over licence payment terms
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: One2One, the mobile phone operator, is to sue the government over the handling of payments for the third generation mobile phone licences which have recently been auctioned.
fields.body:
One2One, the mobile phone operator, is to sue the government over the handling of payments for the third generation mobile phone licences which have recently been auctioned.

It will serve a writ on Stephen Byers, the embattled trade and industry secretary, in an attempt to get a judicial review of the payment process.

German-owned One2One has to hand over the £4bn for its licence today but two other licence winners - Vodafone AirTouch and Orange - have been given up to 180 days in which to pay.

This is because the two operators cannot receive their licences until they have become separately owned companies.

Shortly before the auction for the five licences started, Vodafone acquired Mannesmann, the German company which owned Orange.

To get clearance for the Mannesmann deal from the European competition authorities, Vodafone agreed to sell Orange. But this could not be done by the time the auction for the new licences started.

Under the rules, no group was allowed to bid for more than one licence. But an exemption was made, allowing both Vodafone and Orange to bid separately.

One2One, which is now owned by Deutsche Telekom, believes that Vodafone and Orange will earn about £360m in interest by delaying their £10bn payment.

It wants compensation for the arrangement which, it claims, gives the other two companies an unfair financial advantage.

The government will collect a staggering £22bn for the four licences - but the DTI has turned down One2One's suggestion that its £4bn payment be held in an escrow account until Vodafone and Orange pay up.

During this time, One2One said, it should be paid the interest on the payment.

Robin Saphra, One2One's public policy director, said: "We have tried hard to reach agreement with the government over the discrepancy in payment terms between ourselves and Vodafone and Orange.

"We are disappointed that we have had to make the decision to take legal steps, in the interest of both our customers and shareholders, to ensure a fair and level playing field amongst UMTS licence winners."

When it comes into operation in 2002, the third generation universal mobile telecommunication system will offer mobile phone owners many more features including high-speed internet access and video pictures.

British Telecom, one of the other successful bidders, is also unhappy about the payment arrangements.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText:
• Piped

Oil industry specialists in the Gulf are to be trained online - from Edinburgh. Scottish Knowledge , which draws on expertise from universities in Aberdeen, Edinburgh and Dundee, as well as BP and Shell, has won the contract to establish the new Petroleum Institute in Abu Dhabi. Most training is expected to be online.

Scottish Knowledge , which draws on expertise from universities in Aberdeen, Edinburgh and Dundee, as well as BP and Shell, has won the contract to establish the new Petroleum Institute in Abu Dhabi. Most training is expected to be online.

 Out

Karl Chapman, founder of IT recruitment agency Spring , has made way for former Manpower financial director Jon Chait, part of an £11.7m move to kickstart international e-business operations.

 Wine

28,000 of the world's finest wines are to be traded on Uvine.com , the first internet wine exchange. Those with less than £600 per case to spend should stick to the off-licence.

webTitle: Banks join moves to return Holocaust cash

fields.headline: Banks join moves to return Holocaust cash
fields.standfirst:
www.restoreuk.org.uk
E-finance: special report
Rothschild
fields.trailText: Banks yesterday launched a scheme to re-unite Holocaust victims and their heirs with money frozen in UK accounts since the second world war.
fields.body:
Banks yesterday launched a scheme to re-unite Holocaust victims and their heirs with money frozen in UK accounts since the second world war.

The British Bankers' Association has published names of 10,800 dormant bank accounts holding £2.8m which were frozen during the war to prevent the cash reaching enemy hands.

The list of account names was today posted on the Internet (www.restoreuk.org.uk) by Restore UK, an agency set up and run by the association to return the accounts to their rightful owners.

Under the Trading with the Enemy Act of 1939, all accounts held by people living in enemy territory were frozen. Those from countries which had declared war on Britain were seized, while those held by people from countries invaded by Germany were also frozen so they could not be plundered by the Nazis.

While these accounts have long since been available to holders or their relatives, thousands have remained unused and possibly forgotten.

The BBA emphasised that most of the account holders or their relatives probably still lived abroad.

Tim Sweeney, director general of the BBA, said: "I hope that if any of these accounts do belong to Holocaust victims they can now be reunited with their rightful owners."

Where an account is found to belong to a Holocaust victim, the balance will be multi plied by 26 to bring it into line with today's values.

Original details of the frozen accounts were hand-written and deciphering some of the names has been a challenge. All likely variations on a name are listed, providing 13,000 names which could relate to the 10,800 accounts.

The Restore UK project includes accounts at all Britain's big high street banks as well as the leading investment banks such as Barings and NM Rothschild & Sons.

webTitle: Blinded by science, but investors still see the light

fields.headline: Blinded by science, but investors still see the light
fields.standfirst:
www.bookham.com
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: For Bookham Technology, the fibre optics group which joined the market a month ago, the official silence of the investment banking community is truly golden.
fields.body:
For Bookham Technology, the fibre optics group which joined the market a month ago, the official silence of the investment banking community is truly golden.

Since the company floated on both the London Stock Exchange and America's Nasdaq simultaneously, a 25 trading-day blackout has been imposed on the publication of analytical research.

So the rumour mill, and those doing their own personal research on Bookham, have done their work in a vacuum and come to the quick conclusion that this is one of those pure technological plays with global potential where the shares promise to go to the moon.

The stock's performance has been extraordinary. Despite an initial public offering which was unwittingly pitched in the middle of the recent "dot.com slump", when the Nasdaq composite and London's Techmark 100 indices fell by around a third from their highs, the issue was priced at the top of its 800p-£10 range.

And even that - it is now clear - grossly under-estimated investor perceptions of this company's value. For every week of trading since the flotation the price has gained £10, culminating in a spike to £46 at one stage yesterday morning. The shares finally settled at £39.25, up 212.5p - putting this 12-year-old firm's market capitalisation at close to £5bn.

Needless to say, it is on line to complete a techno-waltz into the FTSE 100 next month, following in the footsteps of techno-blue chips such as computer chip designer Arm Holdings, portable computer group Psion and software firm Sage.

So why the excitement? To be sure, a glance at the company's highly professional website (www.bookham.com) might give cynics the idea that investors are buying this stock simply because they can be damn sure few will understand what Bookham actually makes.

There's the BKM 3450 family of products, which takes in ASOC dual-wavelength single-fibre WDM transceiver modules (with laser diode driver, AGC TIA and limiting amplifier). Or you can trade up to the 52005 family, which takes in ASOC 4-channel Electronic Variable Optical Attenuator (EVOA). And so the list goes on.

The simple explanation for the market's fascination is that Bookham has developed and manufactures a wide range of integrated optical components used in the construction of fibre-optic cable networks - the communication lines at the heart of the new economy.

Its components are based on silicon chips that generate, detect, route and control light signals in fibre-optic telecoms networks. Crucially, it appears to be the first company to integrate light processing functions on a silicon chip using high volume semiconductor manufacturing methods.

And if it is difficult to focus on the science, look instead at what this has brought 40-year-old founder Andrew Rickman, who appears to have spent all his professional life in the telecoms business and who picked up an OBE for his efforts from the Queen last year. He and his family are now worth close to £2.5bn on paper.

Whether it is now too late for ordinary investors to join this optic show is difficult to say. But for brave investors ready to ride through bouts of exceptional volatility the answer is probably "no". Buy the shares ahead of what is expected to be a confident trading statement with next week's maiden first quarter figures.

fields.headline: 'Brainy building' for Silicon Fen
fields.standfirst:
EuroTelecom
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Silicon Fen, the area around Cambridge that is home to some of Britain's fastest growing hi-tech firms, is poised to have its first stock market- listed "intelligent building".
fields.body:
Silicon Fen, the area around Cambridge that is home to some of Britain's fastest growing hi-tech firms, is poised to have its first stock market- listed "intelligent building".

EuroTelecom, a recently floated supplier of broadband infrastructure to futuristic buildings that house internet incubators and software development houses, is close to buying 49% of QTon, a company which part-owns a state of the art £10m business support centre in Cambridge. EuroTelecom is also thought to be close to finalising a supply contract with serviced-offices group Regus worth around £50m over three years.

QTon is owned by 27-year-old entrepreneur Amanda Staveley and is developing the £10m QTon Forum on the Cambridge Science Park in conjunction with Trinity College.

The building - due to be complete in August - aims to provide fledgling hi-tech businesses with telecoms links, networking, video conferencing and meeting facilities under one roof.

The Cambridge area has thrown up several world class hi-tech firms in recent years, including the multi-billion pound duo of Arm Holdings and Autonomy Corporation.

Ms Staveley hopes the next generation of technology stars will use her purpose-built facilities rather than convert their own office space.

EuroTelecom, advised by broker Beeson Gregory, is understood to be paying about £2m for the 49% QTon stake.

EuroTelecom raised £17.25m from its recent flotation to fund joint ventures, acquisitions and provide working capital for new projects. Its shares closed last night at 150p.

fields.headline: Left on the shelf
fields.standfirst:
How hippies stole the socialists' thunder
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: How hippies stole the socialists' thunder
fields.body:
Not everyone was a winner last Thursday. A friend of mine had a £50 bet riding on a left resurgence. He shed a bitter tear when the London Socialist Alliance - a coalition of comedians and Trots - lost all but two of their deposits and failed to win a seat in the assembly. As for me, I couldn't help feeling certain that their one-point-something percentage, hailed as an "extraordinary" breakthrough by the Socialist Workers' spin-doctors, pretty much scotches the idea that the left will be the ultimate beneficiaries of the current disillusionment with Blair.

You can see why they might expect to be. People who think Blairism hasn't delivered on its key promises about health, education and poverty are hardly going to back the Tories. Nor are those upset by control freakery likely to vote for a party which rides roughshod over the wishes of its members. The more the two main parties are discredited, the more the way is opened for a vigorous, imaginative challenge to the status quo. LSA supporter Mike Marqusee is right to note a "palpably growing hunger among working people for an alternative to New Labour". The question is, how will this feeling express itself? Will people turn back to the traditional demand-led left agenda or will they want something more ambitious?

Classically, the left concentrates on the material wellbeing of voters. Presuming that their constituency is largely "working class", the LSA makes its appeals to that unsung majority's self-interest. Opposing the "sell-off" of council homes, securing a "fully-funded NHS" by opposing privatisation and cuts, creating "thousands of new jobs by building homes and hospitals", eliminating poverty - all these proposals urge reform of the current system by a simple reallocation of resources. There is no room for doubt that these are, indeed, "the issues", nor any sense that new hospitals might not contain the solutions to the whole range of modern maladies.

So if you feel alienated in your workplace, degraded by consumerism or spiritually diminished by your function as a profit generator, this bricks-and-mortar approach will help you get an NHS walking stick to smash against the wall in frustration, or lend you a policeman to spar with. What it won't do is help you get beyond the crass, economistic understanding of life promoted by those opponents of the system who can't see beyond its confines.

What would they say to the women, quite well-off most of them, protesting against Barclays' decision to close 171 rural branches? Or to those who resent Nintendo's refusal to put some of the millions purloined from small children during the Pokémon craze into making a half-decent movie (why should it, when the kids will go anyway)? Or to those who think it's "unfair" that car manufacturers should be able to set a different price in Britain from the one they set in Europe? Or to people who hold Nike responsible for the promotion of a global aesthetic?

Because these anti-capitalist views are the offspring of a cultural ennui, the left are understandably suspicious. They would rather wait for the proles to get the message than chat to the Cheshire housewives or the counter-cultural "hippies" who, in their terms, are premature anti-capitalists. Marx made it quite clear - didn't he? - that the job in the short to medium term is persuading the workers to "unite and fight" direct oppression. Only when they've done this will they be seen as ripe for the suggestion that their boss is one part of "the bosses" and as such is responsible for crimes beyond the gates of their workplace.

This softly-softly approach, beloved of Marxists everywhere, is one of the reasons why left propaganda is so bland and patronising. Unable to reveal the full story, they are forced into the white lie of social democracy, the idea that the system can be fixed. Theoretically sound though this may be, it prevents them from responding when people start revealing an ability to process things more quickly. This May Day, for example, trades unionists and socialists marched along a different route from the self-confessed anti-capitalists, which would be like dividing anti-nuclear campaigners into anti-war and pro-peace factions. This split has less to do with violence than it does with the left's inability to take the initiative.

Confronted with a groundswell of anti-capitalist opinion, they have fled to the hills in the hope that, when they come down, Utopianism will be out of fashion and all those dead-leg ravers will be moaning about tuition fees and the decline of manufacturing industry.

I sympathise, up to a point. It is painful to see a hippy masquerading as an enemy of the state. This wasn't their brief, one feels, nor was it within their remit to merge anti-capitalism with ecology. The desecration of the planet is just one of many consequences of the global economy. Another is the cost to humanity of living within a system which commodifies everything. It may well be some time before the seeds of the latter anxiety produces a more competent cadre than a bunch of mud-wrestling knobheads, but one thing, at least, is certain. The movement which emerges will be the result of a huge humanitarian outburst, not a spin-off from the fight for cheaper fares.

 I knew there was something wrong with Ken Livingstone's victory party the minute I walked in the door. The Blackfriars venue was predictable enough, as were the heaving masses trying to get a drink at the bar. I looked around for people I knew and drew a blank. Some of them looked vaguely familiar but where were all the men in suits? Where were all the women in discreet Nicole Farhi separates?

"There's something going on here", I said to the friend I arrived with. "These people - it looks like a..." "Party?" she suggested, and I realised that was it. I've never been to any political/media gathering that looked so much like a genuine event. There were young people, old people, activists, eccentrics, Camden babes, Islington queens and a representative from just about every class and social grouping in the Greater London area. If you don't think this indicates anything about the man who brought them together, try to picture Dobbo's party and estimate how long you'd have stayed.

webTitle: Clinton urged to revive trade talks

fields.headline: Clinton urged to revive trade talks
fields.standfirst: World Trade Organisation: special report
fields.trailText: Trade delegates are pressing President Clinton to launch a fresh round of global trade talks in the dying days of his presidency in a desperate attempt to get negotiations restarted before the end of the year.
fields.body:
Trade delegates are pressing President Clinton to launch a fresh round of global trade talks in the dying days of his presidency in a desperate attempt to get negotiations restarted before the end of the year.

The first attempt to launch a comprehensive round of trade talks for five years collapsed in Seattle last December, with protesters confronting riot police in the streets and the world's main trading blocs at loggerheads inside the conference rooms. Many analysts had written off the chances of a politically contentious new round getting back on track until the US presidential election in November.

The plan is for Mr Clinton to step in to revive the battered reputation of the World Trade Organisation in the window between the election and the inauguration of a new president in January. A source close to the Geneva-based body said that the Clinton plan hinged on a considerable amount of preparation between now and November to bridge the divides between the world's big trading blocs which sank the Seattle talks.

Hopes that some of the divisions may be narrowing were raised yesterday after the successful conclusion of talks over a confidence-building package for the least developed countries. Trade diplomats in Geneva agreed to give developing countries longer to implement some of the commitments they made in earlier trade rounds.

"This should certainly make the prospects of eventually getting agreement on a round brighter," said one European diplomat arriving for a session of the WTO's ruling general council at which the latest decisions were made.

webTitle: Challenge to ties that bind investment

fields.headline: Challenge to ties that bind investment
fields.standfirst:
News Analysis: Our entrepreneurs win more backing from abroad than at home. Gordon Brown is asking why

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Why is that the City invests so little in the grassroots of the British economy? The question has been around for donkey's years, taxing governments of left and right.
fields.body:
Why is that the City invests so little in the grassroots of the British economy? The question has been around for donkey's years, taxing governments of left and right.

In the mid 1970s, Harold Wilson chaired a committee which asked whether institutional investors had a responsibility which went wider than a servant/master relationship with their clients. In the 1980s Mrs Thatcher held a gun to the heads of the institutions when she needed private sector cash to build the channel tunnel, apparently threatening them with being struck off the invite list when the next chunk of family silver came up for sale.

Now it is Gordon Brown's turn.

In a speech at the London School of Economics last night, the chancellor outlined the parameters of the review of institutional investment announced in the Budget. The review, which is being launched next week by Paul Myners, head of fund manager Gartmore and chairman of the Guardian Media Group, will study whether there are systematic barriers to investing in small and growing companies.

Mr Myners will look at the decision-making chain which links pension fund trustees, who control assets worth £800bn, investment consultants who advise trustees on the best managers for their money, and fund managers.

He will examine how pension fund trustees are chosen, their level of expertise, their incentives, and the information life insurance policy holders have about how their money is invested. He will also ask why there are only four or five large consultancies.

"In our capital markets we must ensure that there are no closed circles, that there are no unnecessary constraints restricting investment decisions, and that investors have every opportunity and encouragement to back dynamic small and growing companies in manufacturing and services," the chancellor said.

The Treasury insists that Mr Myners is keeping an open mind on all these issues. But it has highlighted some facts which suggest it thinks there is at least a case for institutional investors to answer. For example, it points out that British institutions invest less than 0.5% of funds in venture capital, compared with 5% in the US.

It seems that overseas investors are far keener on Britain's venture capitalists than domestic ones, providing them with 37% of their funds compared with 13% from UK institutional investors. UK institutional investors, which control 45% of the quoted equity market, are also notably reluctant to invest in corporate bonds.

It is not clear to the Treasury why institutional investors behave in this way, or if their actions are based on sophisticated analysis or just the traditions of a close-knit industry in which there is insufficient competition.

"We are trying to look at whether this market is working," says a Treasury source. "And it may be that there are reasons to do with government regulation - the minimum funding requirement or rules for trustees - which we might have to change. One thing we are not doing is saying the government thinks there are better ways for the industry to spend its money, but it does seem that there are some oddities which will make any reasonable person ask whether there's anything which we or the industry can do something about."

The National Association of Pension Funds (NAPF) welcomes the inquiry but is reluctant to enter into a debate until it sees Mr Myners' remit next week. However, it points out that it has looked at the strategies of its members in the past and found that their reluctance to put money into venture capital is based on concerns about the riskiness of many such investments. As for the charge of short termism, the NAPF says research has shown the average horizon is seven or eight years.

When there is a genuine opportunity to earn a decent return for their clients, institutional investors are only to keen to stump up the cash, the industry argues. It points to the tide of money that has poured into hi-tech investment vehicles in recent years.

Alan Pickering, the NAPF chairman, says it is important to bear in mind that the City has many different types of clients with many different objectives. While rich individuals might be prepared to take a punt on small, high risk ventures, investors of more modest means prefer safer vehicles such as unit trusts.

Mr Pickering also expresses some reservations about politicians being seen to encourage investment in a particular asset class. While it might be alright for them to point out that venture capital is a much more modern sector than it used to be in the 1980s, they should be wary of en dorsing it wholeheartedly in case they encourage speculative dashes. He says this is especially important while the Financial Services and Markets Bill, which is designed to ensure investment advisers are properly qualified, is going through the Commons.

fields.bodyText: Why is that the City invests so little in the grassroots of the British economy? The question has been around for donkey's years, taxing governments of left and right. In the mid 1970s, Harold Wilson chaired a committee which asked whether institutional investors had a responsibility which went wider than a servant/master relationship with their clients. In the 1980s Mrs Thatcher held a gun to the heads of the institutions when she needed private sector cash to build the channel tunnel, apparently threatening them with being struck off the invite list when the next chunk of family silver came up for sale. Now it is Gordon Brown's turn. In a speech at the London School of Economics last night, the chancellor outlined the parameters of the review of institutional investment announced in the Budget. The review, which is being launched next week by Paul Myners, head of fund manager Gartmore and chairman of the Guardian Media Group, will study whether there are systematic barriers to investing in small and growing companies. Mr Myners will look at the decision-making chain which links pension fund trustees, who control assets worth £800bn, investment consultants who advise trustees on the best managers for their money, and fund managers. He will examine how pension fund trustees are chosen, their level of expertise, their incentives, and the information life insurance policy holders have about how their money is invested. He will also ask why there are only four or five large consultancies. "In our capital markets we must ensure that there are no closed circles, that there are no unnecessary constraints restricting investment decisions, and that investors have every opportunity and encouragement to back dynamic small and growing companies in manufacturing and services," the chancellor said. The Treasury insists that Mr Myners is keeping an open mind on all these issues. But it has highlighted some facts which suggest it thinks there is at least a case for institutional investors to answer. For example, it points out that British institutions invest less than 0.5% of funds in venture capital, compared with 5% in the US. It seems that overseas investors are far keener on Britain's venture capitalists than domestic ones, providing them with 37% of their funds compared with 13% from UK institutional investors. UK institutional investors, which control 45% of the quoted equity market, are also notably reluctant to invest in corporate bonds. "We are trying to look at whether this market is working," says a Treasury source. "And it may be that there are reasons to do with government regulation - the minimum funding requirement or rules for trustees - which we might have to change. One thing we are not doing is saying the government thinks there are better ways for the industry to spend its money, but it does seem that there are some oddities which will make any reasonable person ask whether there's anything which we or the industry can do something about."
