fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: There was an edgy feel to trading in London, with business said to be relatively thin.
fields.body:
There was an edgy feel to trading in London, with business said to be relatively thin.

A sizeable drop on the Nasdaq market in the US dented confidence over here, but although there was no sign of heavy selling of technology-related issues in London, the FTSE 100 index still closed 22.5 points lower on the day at 6,216.3 and the Techmark 100 shed 20 points to 3,733.91.

Vodafone AirTouch was a big discussion point. After a fall from 277p to 267p yesterday, the price has now fallen by a third from its early March high. Continued selling of Vodafone - which comes in the face of the recent recovery among many other big tech issues - has brought technical analysts out in droves, warning that this classic "momentum stock" (often bought by investors in the past simply because it kept going up) is breaking back down through some supposedly important chart levels.

Because of Vodafone's weight in the Footsie, this has reinforced thinking that the London market as a whole will remain under pressure over coming trading sessions.

News that European regulators have given the go-ahead to the merger between Glaxo Wellcome and Smith Kline Beecham , albeit with certain minor conditions, went down well. The shares rallied 75p to £19.49 and 34p to 868p, respectively. The regulators have asked the new combine to out-license a number of products in Europe, but sales of these across the continent amount to just £50m compared with pro forma group sales of £4bn. The merger still needs the nod from US regulators.

With the mood infecting others in the drugs sector, AstraZeneca rose from £26.15 to £27.15.

Freeserve was in demand all day, following weekend reports that parent Dixons (up 6p at 278p) is looking at selling down its 80% stake - which, in turn, has prompted speculation that the internet service provider will attract a bid. The shares ended the session at 437.5p, up 30.5p, before the after-hours announcement from Dixons that it was indeed looking at the options for its holding.

Pace Micro Technology , the set-top box specialist, jumped from 750p to 947p after news that it has reached a "far-reaching memorandum of understanding" with Microsoft to develop applications for digital television.

Regent Street department stores group Liberty jumped 55p to 255p following reports that a £68m bid is on the way from property group Marylebone Warwick Balfour (up 0.5p at 150.5p), which would value the shares at 300p if and when it arrives.

Abbey National also managed to buck the general market trend, with the shares adding 26.5p to 775.5p in the wake of weekend reports that Barclays is considering a £15bn bid.

Among the day's new issues, self-storage group Big Yellow made a strong start on the Alternative Invesment Market, trading at 127.5p against a 100p sale price. On the other hand, Motion Media , a specialist in video communication technology, slipped to 130p against a 140p flotation price.

webTitle: NHS on trial over secret baby tests

fields.headline: NHS on trial over secret baby tests
fields.standfirst: Doctors criticised for using children without proper safeguards
fields.trailText: The state of clinical trials in the UK, which allows researchers to treat adult volunteers and their children as human guinea pigs, was exposed yesterday in a damning report from an NHS panel investigating the work of consultant paediatrician David Southall and his colleagues in North Staffordshire.
fields.body:
The state of clinical trials in the UK, which allows researchers to treat adult volunteers and their children as human guinea pigs, was exposed yesterday in a damning report from an NHS panel investigating the work of consultant paediatrician David Southall and his colleagues in North Staffordshire.

Professor Rod Griffiths of the West Midlands regional NHS executive found that experiments had taken place in North Staffordshire without safeguards to ensure that the parents of babies who took part in random trials knew what was happening and agreed to it. At the centre of the inquiry were trials of an experimental ventilator, the CNEP (continuous negative extrathoracic pressure), which expanded babies' lungs to help them breathe without the need for a tube. But some parents believe the machine, which requires a tight seal around the baby's neck, caused long-term brain damage.

Professor Southall, the controversial paediatrician who has been attacked for his use of covert video surveillance of mothers alleged to have harmed their babies, is partly responsible for the inadequacies of the trial, says the report, which calls him "an enthusiastic and assertive lead researcher" who did not take enough care in the management of his trials.

Parliamentary under secretary of state, Lord Hunt, said last night: "There needs to be a culture change in the NHS - a shift in the balance of power towards the patient. It has to be wrong that patients can be the last to know what it going on with their treatment." A number of the recommendations, including producing guidelines for the conduct of clinical trials, had already been put into place, he added.

Professor Griffiths said people taking part must have confidence in the way clinical trials are carried out. "It is very important for the public to feel that they are not being used as guinea pigs."

Inadequate

But Professor Griffiths' fire is chiefly directed at the inadequate and variable guidelines meant to ensure that patients are safeguarded and treated with dignity and respect. He recommends that the Department of Health produces guidelines to clarify procedures for consent.

Professor Griffiths' brief - to look at issues of consent in the CNEP trials - was gradually widened to encompass other research activities of Professor Southall and his team. North Staffordshire hospital has been at the centre of a storm since the paediatrician was first revealed to be using covert video surveillance to try to catch mothers harming their babies.

Professor Southall believed that some children rushed to hospital in a critical condition were the victims of Munchausen's by Proxy - that they had mothers who half-smothered them, fed them salt or broke their limbs in order to get attention for themselves. Professor Southall felt that the ends justified the means to protect those children. To get evidence that would stand up in court, he called mothers in to hospital on spurious grounds, left them alone with their babies and filmed what happened. The evidence he garnered from the mid-1980s was enough to have children placed in care.

Mothers whose babies had been taken away began to fight back. The backlash led eventually to a series of inquiries by the North Staffordshire NHS Trust, as well as the inquiry by Professor Griffiths.

Professor Southall and his colleague Martin Samuels were suspended last De cember when the trust announced it was investigating personal allegations about their conduct and integrity. They have that inquiry and the General Medical Council, which has also received complaints, still to face.

Professor Griffiths' brief was to examine whether parents whose premature babies had been placed in an experimental ventilator by Professor Southall and his team had been properly told of what was going on and had given genuinely informed consent. Between 1989 and 1993, 122 babies were put in the CNEP machine. Of those, 43 died or were brain damaged, compared to 32 in a control group who were placed in the conventional ventilator. Statistically, the difference in outcome is not significant, but allegations have been made that parents were not told what was happening, were not asked for consent and that in some cases, their signatures on the forms giving permission were forged. The Griffiths report highlights a further problem - that the trial did not follow up the children to see whether brain damage showed up after they went home.

Professor Griffiths found that North Staffordshire complied with the rules governing clinical trials at the time, but that these were deficient and would not be acceptable today. There was nothing in the rules to safeguard parents and children taking part in trials. But that does not exonerate Professor Southall, who was "the senior academic in the responsible group. As far as we can tell he took relatively few steps to make sure that the project was in fact run in accordance with the research application".

Consent

There was no proper system of management for the trial, the report says. At the start of it, Professor Southall was in London, supervising from a distance. "Professor Southall seems to have assumed that the obtaining of consent was proceeding as intended but does not appear to have ensured that each member of staff who might be involved in the project was trained or supervised to ensure that they were doing what the research protocol said they should.

"Members of the research team were very ready to tell us that parents were often poor at remembering what happened and recalling what they were told. In effect, they were asking us to believe that these parents could not remember consenting to randomisation but did remember that CNEP was 'a kinder, gentler treatment',"the report says.

The report says the blame for poor management of the trial, if any, is a collective one. The ethics committee should have spotted the failings. "Professor Southall was also responsible to a significant extent. He should have recognised that he was not providing much supervision and that the design of the trial did not allow it to detect longer-term problems.

Machine based on 1950s iron lung

The baby ventilator pioneered by Professor Southall and his team works on the same principle as the "iron lung" used to save many lives during the polio epidemics of the 1950s.

Instead of forcing air into the baby's lungs, the CNEP machine provides a negative pressure around the infant's body to help breathing.

The iron lung operated in exactly the same way. The machine enclosed the patient in a box within which air pressure was lowered. Its use was discontinued because access to the patient was difficult, and complex manipulation of ventilation impossible.

CNEP stands for continuous negative extrathoracic pressure. The experimental system uses an incubator-like container in which the baby is placed with the head protruding through an airtight opening.

Pressure inside the box is reduced, causing the baby's chest to expand so that oxygen is drawn in through the mouth and nose.

Andy Petros, a paediatric intensive care consultant at Great Ormond Street hospital, said: "The general treatment is to put a tube into the trachea [windpipe] and attach it to a ventilator which pumps air into the lungs.

"But when you put air into tiny lungs, it can cause damage. The idea of using negative pressure is that instead of blowing, you suck."

CNEP is supposed to reduce the chances of lung damage, but its effectiveness has not been proved.
Press Association

"The review panel was told that to have designed and managed a better trial would have cost more money. If he was unable to raise the additional money, Professor Southall could have decided not to go ahead with the trial."

Responding to the publication of the inquiry, Dr Michael Wilks, chairman of the BMA's medical ethics committee, said: "The days when patients simply left it to doctors to try what they thought best are over. But obtaining informed consent is always complex and can be a very difficult matter, particularly in an emergency or when patients or parents are ill or distressed. The boundaries between experi mental research and pioneering but unconventional treatment are not always clear. There will often be an element of uncertainty about which treatment option is better. That makes it all the more important that doctors are clear about their ethical obligations and that hospitals have robust procedures for obtaining consent and for approving research."

The panel also looked at the hypoxia trial. This caused a furore because Professor Southall and his team, to test a hypothesis that flying in an aircraft with reduced oxygen could be a factor in subsequent cot death, exposed healthy babies - whose parents volunteered them to take part - to low oxygen levels. The report tells of confusion as to what the trial was about. Professor Southall told the review panel that it was to test the thesis that hypoxia was a trigger to an apneic attack (where the child stops breathing). "In fact the trial could not have investigated this because the type of hypoxia created was not that which is experienced in the reduced partial pressure found in aircraft cabins," the report states.

Dogged family that brought doctors to book

It was the persistence of Carl and Debbie Henshall that finally brought about the Griffiths report.

Two of their daughters, Stacey and Sofie, were entered into the randomised trial of the CNEP (continuous negative extrathoracic pressure) machine at North Staffordshire in the early 1990s. Stacey died and Sofie developed cerebral palsy. In neither case, they say, did they give informed consent.

"People are acknowledging now that we are not just two troublesome parents," said Mr Henshall yesterday. "I don't think I can blame any one person. They saw the loopholes in the system, but we had a system that allowed them to do that."

The only approach from the medical team for his permission to allow Stacey to enter the CNEP trial when she was born in 1992 - small, premature and suffering from breathing difficulties - was "a chat at the side of the cot" with someone he was later told was a trainee midwife.

"She told me how a tube could damage a windpipe, how lungs could be ruptured and how North Staffordshire used a safer, gentler form of treatment," he said. "That was about as far as it went with us. I did sign a form. I was led to believe it was the best treatment. At no stage was a trial mentioned."

The Henshalls make it clear that they do not believe they signed any papers when Sofie was born eight weeks prematurely in November 1992. "I think that forging a consent form is criminal and should be dealt with formally," Mr Henshall said.

"Debbie had a caesarean section and was extremely ill. Her temperature and blood pressure were extremely low. She was out of it for hours on high doses of morphine. I was not at the hospital in the two to four hours when the form had to be signed. I can only think the hospital took it upon themselves to put her [Sofie] in the clinical trial without our consent."

The form appears to be signed by Mrs Henshall. It has her daughter's name on it but the couple say it was signed on the day before they decided what to call their daughter.

The Henshalls are happy with the Griffiths report, which came about after their MP, Llin Golding MP, asked Lady Hayman to order an investigation.

"It is a good start," said Mrs Henshall. "It obviously points to things that could be done in the future in order to protect patients." Sarah Boseley

fields.headline: Imperial lifts profits despite smugglers
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Imperial Tobacco - the Embassy and Players group - battled increasing cigarette smuggling into Britain to push up profits by 15% in the six months to March 25, it reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Imperial Tobacco - the Embassy and Players group - battled increasing cigarette smuggling into Britain to push up profits by 15% in the six months to March 25, it reported yesterday.

Chief executive Gareth Davis estimated that 25% of all cigarettes consumed in Britain had - legally or illegally - managed to escape any domestic duty.

The company plans a big expansion in western Europe as the last state tobacco monopolies lose their special privileges. Mr Davis denied this was a backdoor route for increasing sales to British smokers, but admitted there was "bound to be some flow back" as tourists and others took advantage of the yawning gap between UK tobacco duties and those on the continent.

Earnings - at £210m before tax on turnover up 21% to £2.69bn - were better than had been expected in the City, and the shares rose 0.75p to 531p.

Investors were cheered also by the group's progress in ensuring more than 50% of earnings come from outside the UK - the total is currently about 46%.

Domestic profits fell £13m to £139m because of the timing by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, of the most recent rise in tobacco duties. In the past, slightly different timings have actually boosted profits.

Mr Davis said that, discounting this effect, UK profits were effectively unchanged.

The government's response to the roaring black market in cross-Channel tobacco has been to step up counter measures - including the deployment of more customs officers and X-ray machines at ports.

Despite this, one cigarette in four is now free of UK duty, said Mr Davis, either because the tobacco was brought in legally by people intending to consume it or because it had been smuggled.

Imperial predicted a further drift downmarket to cheaper cigarettes such as its own Lambert & Butler brand, and to hand-rolling tobacco, where the traditional thin "roll up", reflecting the relative poverty of the smoker, is giving way to the more robust hand-rolled smoke favoured in Germany and the Netherlands.

webTitle: Vodafone and Orange should pay up now

fields.headline: Vodafone and Orange should pay up now
fields.standfirst:
No licence for rule bending
E-finance: special report
Vodaphone
One2One
fields.trailText: British Telecom looked like the monopolistic clot it has so often been when, three months ago, it threatened to delay the entire auction of third generation mobile phone licences with legal action - in the process risking Britain's lead in a crucial area of technology.
fields.body:
British Telecom looked like the monopolistic clot it has so often been when, three months ago, it threatened to delay the entire auction of third generation mobile phone licences with legal action - in the process risking Britain's lead in a crucial area of technology.

It thought it unfair that Vodafone, in the wake of the takeover of Mannesmann, might own two licences at once, even though BT knew very well that Vodafone would have to sell Orange.

But after that unsightly tantrum, there is evidence now that, together with mobile rival One2One, the old monolith has something to shriek about.

The DTI sensibly bent the rules to allow Vodafone and Orange to bid for separate licences while both were owned - albeit temporarily - by the same company.

But there is no reason why they should be given extra time to pay the £10bn they bid for the two licences.

The official argument is that they can only pay for and receive their licences once Vodafone has fulfilled its promise to sell Orange. This will take time, so they must be given extra time to pay.

But this does not stand up. The rules have already been bent once in their favour. They should be made to pay now, and receive their licences when they have completed their divorce.

It is not as if the two operators are working closely together. They are, and will remain, bitter rivals.

If they cannot pay, they should lose their licences. If they can pay, they should do so at the same time as everyone else.

P&D bears all

Dogged determination or bloody mindedness - either way Phillips & Drew is sticking to with its four-year-old bearish stance on the stock market which has hurt its performance, damaged its customer base and cost its investment chief, Tony Dye, his job.

In the fund manager's much watched pension fund indicators report, published yesterday, the Swiss-owned fund management company admits that the "long bull run has been painful for our clients and we are indebted to them to their loyalty".

But the group remains adamant that its views and that loyalty from many of the country's biggest pension funds, will win the day. "We believe that this loyalty stems from our fundamental approach and our willingness to take a view. Neither of these aspects of our approach is changing and we believe that our clients' forbearance will be repaid as market exuberance fades," the report says.

In what it admits has been a "fallow period" P&D has been rejuvenating its research while speculators have been having more "fun and profit" by punting on technology favourites.

Yet, by P&D's arithmetic, all this dot.commery, now that it has infected the investment industry's professionals, is wiping at least £800m a year off the performance of pension funds in Britain. It reaches this conclusion on the basis that pension funds are spending heavy money rejigging their portfolios. This is not only to chase the new economy bandwagon, but also due to structural changes in the market, taking annual turnover levels to around 40% in UK equities - more than double the levels of the mid 1980s.

True to form, P&D hopes that this churning of portfolios will start to decline soon, or at least result in the worst offenders being penalised, with clients removing money from them and investing it - presumably in funds run by P&D which will not be subjected to the whims of the market, however attractive the short-term benefits.

Dot.better

When the Financial Times was relaunched into cyberspace in February and immediately ran into technical problems, there was much upset inside Europe's premier business newspaper when the venture was described in these columns as FT.Completelyuseless. In fact, this was said to be grossly unfair and inaccurate at the time.

So it is only fair to point out now -three months on - that the site has been revamped and is beginning to look halfway FT.Competent.

News is more accessible and the site layout is much clearer, while the determination to disseminate three-day-old information and computer error screens seems to have been largely overcome.

What is more - apparently at the personal instruction of Pearson chief executive Marjorie Scardino - the irritating "Navigation Bar," which in the past slowly imposed itself over a third of the screen, blocking items a user might be reading, has been relegated to an optional function.

Peter Martin, the editor of FT.com, clearly knows the importance of listening to customers, even if they also happen to work for competing publications.

webTitle: Factory prices up in face of falling oil costs

fields.headline: Factory prices up in face of falling oil costs
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's hard-pressed manufacturers gained a respite last month as falling oil prices reduced the costs they pay for raw materials and fuels, official figures revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's hard-pressed manufacturers gained a respite last month as falling oil prices reduced the costs they pay for raw materials and fuels, official figures revealed yesterday.

Manufacturers' input prices fell 3.2% in April according to the office for national statistics. But worryingly for the inflation watchers at the Bank of England, the prices firms charge for goods at the factory gate jumped by 0.5%.

Analysts said duty increases were behind the rise in factory gate prices. "Almost all of the April increases can be blamed on the chancellor's Budget measures, with core prices still fairly well behaved," said David Coleman, chief economist at CIBC World Markets.

The Bank has been monitoring the economy carefully for signs that strong demand is threatening its target for inflation of 2.5%. Its task is complicated by the fact that while manufacturing is in the dol drums, the consumer sector is buoyant.

Figures published today showed that shoppers went on an Easter spending spree, according to the British Retail Consortium. April sales jumped 7.4% on a like-for-like basis last month, but the BRC said that the three-month rate - a better trend guide - slowed.

Bridget Rosewell, the BRC's economic adviser, said: "The April figures have been distorted by the change in the tim ing of Easter and retailers continue to report difficulties pricing. The monetary policy committee should remain relaxed about the inflation outlook in the light of these figures."

The manufacturing inflation figures were also thought likely to reassure the Bank that further rises in borrowing costs would not be necessary.

"The inflationary impact of the rises in oil prices of the last year is beginning to fade," said Dharshini David, UK economist at HSBC markets.

webTitle: Wickes under pressure DIY predator hammers performance

fields.headline: Wickes under pressure DIY predator hammers performance
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Management at DIY warehouse chain Wickes yesterday was accused by predator Focus Do It All of "papering over the cracks" of a precarious situation by giving shareholders selective financial information.
fields.body:
Management at DIY warehouse chain Wickes yesterday was accused by predator Focus Do It All of "papering over the cracks" of a precarious situation by giving shareholders selective financial information.

The comments, made to Wickes shareholders as part of its £285m hostile bid, stung Wickes manage ment into an immediate rebuttal.

Chief executive Bill Grimsey, pictured above on his annual Easter "back to the shopfloor day", dismissed the arguments . "We have always been full and frank with our disclosures to shareholders who know and understand our strategy is working," he said.

FDIA Finance, a subsidiary of Focus Do It All, made a cash bid for Wickes on March 30. The circular yesterday said that Wickes' market position was under threat from Kingfisher's B&Q and Sainsbury's Homebase.

Bill Archer, chairman and chief executive of Focus Do It All and a director of FDIA Finance, said: "We are simply asking shareholders to focus on the real issues facing Wickes."

webTitle: The verdict: it's big, bold and beautiful

fields.headline: The verdict: it's big, bold and beautiful
fields.standfirst: It's big, bold and beautiful :  It's the largest modern art museum in the world and at last, it is opening. Over four pages, Guardian art critic  Adrian Searle salutes Tate Modern as a watershed in the cultural life of Britain
fields.trailText: It's big, bold and beautiful : It's the largest modern art museum in the world and at last, it is opening. Over four pages, Guardian art critic Adrian Searle salutes Tate Modern as a watershed in the cultural life of Britain
fields.body:
I have a fantasy of walking into Tate Modern, going up in a lift, then taking a left, a right, a left again, making a long walk to find one thing, one solitary artwork, looking at it, then leaving. Right now that is impossible. The Queen will open Tate Modern at Bankside on Thursday morning. She will hardly, perhaps, realise the importance of the building she is opening. Most of what Tate Modern contains will be a blank to her. There are many things here she would doubtless be alarmed at, dumbfounded, shocked and confused by. There is much here to unsettle us all.

The opening of Tate Modern is a watershed in the cultural life of this country. It signals the importance of the art of our times, and its centrality in our culture. Unlike most of the major cities and capitals of the western world, London has never had a museum dedicated to the permanent display of international modern art, and there has never been a museum anywhere on quite this scale. Tate Modern isn't just an extension of an existing museum; it is as important a venture as the Museum of Modern Art in New York or the Pompidou Centre in Paris. Tate Modern is bigger than either. Does that make it better?

It is huge. It is the largest modern art museum in the world. Half of it is a vast, echoing space. High up behind the tiers and clerestories are more than 50 galleries, half-galleries, double-height galleries, smaller rooms and ante-chambers comprising six suites of showing spaces on three levels. The galleries are practical, flexible and often extremely beautiful.

Nothing prepares you for this. One moment you are plunged into a blacked-out video installation, the next you find yourself in a river-lit pause between galleries, the Thames and the Millennium Bridge below, St Paul's rising across the river. You go from killer set-pieces - a room devoted to the severities of minimalism, say, to small and elegant chambers with few works. Turn again, and a view into the Turbine Hall plunges the eye into a space that feels all the bigger for its containment.

After this, Tate Britain at Millbank feels cramped, parsimonious and a bit shabby. Its inadequacies for the job it has had to do are suddenly all too apparent. Standing in Tate Modern, Millbank might as well be as far upstream as Berkshire. And what of the art, those parts of the Tate's collection that the Tate has decided, for reasons undoubtedly as political as they are aesthetic, are Modern rather than British?

In common with most modern art museums, the Tate has in the past grouped its collection in terms of movements, isms and historical determinism. You know where you are with an ism. Impressionism begat post-impressionism begat cubism, which sired futurism, expressionism and all manner of errant abstractions. This model, which was never altogether clear and was attended by all manner of bolt-on caveats and contradictions, has been under attack for at least three decades. Artists have always been suspicious of it, when they weren't using it to prove that they themselves were at the sharp end of an inevitable drive towards perfection. Art historians, who once plodded their way up and down the evolutionary slope of artistic development, unsure which way was forward, now view their subject in the light of social history, philosophy, psychoanalysis, linguistics, feminist theory and post-colonial politics.

Tate Modern's curators have taken on board the need to present art in a different way, even if paintings still hang on walls, and some sculptures insist on the quaintness of plinths. Taking the 17th-century genres of landscape, the figure (including portraiture and the nude), history painting and allegory, and still life as its categories, the Tate has made four different stabs at presenting its collection. Landscape becomes Landscape/Matter/Environment, the figure is now Nude/Action/Body, and still life is Still Life/Object/Real Life. History/Memory/Society stands, I guess, for everything else. Each of these sections realigns parts of the Tate's collection, as well as a significant number of loans, to tell the story of modern art in four distinct ways on two levels of Tate Modern.

We are left with differences, alliances, concordances and gaps. The different thematic groupings at Tate Modern are interchangeable, impermanent and contingent. I am quite happy with this as an idea, as it seems to be the only direction worth pursuing. But really it is a substitute for one's own map. It is also obvious, walking into a room filled with the Tate's surrealist collection, that calling this collection Inner Worlds and locating it in the landscape section is about as arbitrary as you can get.

The activity of looking at art demands that, as spectators, we make our own connections. Some of the conjunctions and alignments here - probably too many - are so awful that one hopes they are very temporary indeed. The most glaringly awful moment, perhaps, is the room containing the large, tremblingly beautiful Monet waterlily painting, which for many years hung in the National Gallery, opposite a wall-filling black and white splattery drawing by Richard Long. What do these two artists share, apart from an interest in nature? The perceptual field of the Monet and the all-over effect of the Long wall-drawing have nothing useful to say to or about one another. What does Long's red slate circle, down on the floor like a miniature mountain range, have to say for itself? Suddenly, it is a stone water lily. This is crass.

But you get used to the jolts. In a room called The Intelligent Object, Michael Craig-Martin's glass of water that thinks it is an oak tree finds itself with a Georges Braque painting of a glass on a table, a drawing of Duchamp's coffee grinder (the bachelor grinds his own coffee, ho ho), a computer designed by Richard Hamilton and a little Giorgio Morandi 1946 still life. Craig-Martin finds himself again, with one of his simplified line-drawn and coloured-in paintings, alongside Patrick Caulfield, Roy Lichtenstein and some furniture sculptures by Richard Artschwager. Standing here, I feel like I'm turning into Tintin. If I look down I'll find myself surrounded by an outline.

Putting the watercolour female figures of Marlene Dumas opposite Matisse's series of relief Backs is quite joyous: the lightness of Dumas's wash figures and the chocolatey heaviness of the Matisse relief bronzes play off one another to mutual advantage. The big, double-height gallery containing classic works of minimal art - Robert Morris's mirrored cubes, a lowering and dangerous Richard Serra, a beautiful

Eva Hesse, Don Judd and Carl Andre - is breathtaking. This work is in the Body suite, and it makes sense only in that these quasi-industrial and geometric forms make us aware what gawky, lumpy, strange, compound beings we are.

Returning to the History/ Memory/Society section, one moves from a room devoted to Picasso's Weeping Woman and the Spanish Civil War, to a smallish room called The Grid. There, Carl Andre's infamous bricks, a Sol LeWitt wall drawing, a quiet linear painting by Agnes Martin and a stunningly beautiful Jasper Johns white-on-white numbers painting from 1959 (a new loan from the Davros Foundation), are all roped off to one side, so one can't actually see the Johns or the Martin head-on. This is worse than frustrating. The Andre bricks lay half over one of the industrial-looking (but fake) grilles in the floor, part of the gallery's climate control system. This entire room is a replay of Rosalind Krauss's 1978 essay on the grid, recontextualised to highlight the grid's metaphoric relation to social order. Whether it is always what the artists had in mind is another matter.

On we go, walking through a room of Frank Auerbach paintings straight into Joseph Beuys. What do these two artists share? A belief in unseen forces, perhaps, which in Auerbach's paintings are evidenced by angular vectors in the sky. The Beuys room is one of the most beautiful galleries in Tate Modern. This tall space, illuminated by daylight streaming in through Giles Gilbert Scott's original bank of narrow windows, is gorgeous but much too crowded. Beuys's overwhelming Lightning with Stag in its Glare, with its huge suspended lump and smaller, delicate elements arranged on the floor about it, is somehow diminished and confused by the plugged stones of his equally monumental End of the Twentieth Century, and all the other bits of Beuysabilia, the vitrines and blackboards that share the room.

But you can see why the Tate might want to display as much as possible, and be suspicious of presenting art as spectacle. Especially - the uncharitable thought creeps into my head - when so many lenders of works and donators of collections are in town. The benefactors want to see what they've handed over.

I'm carping. I don't really mind all these problematic moments. This, surely, is all part of the unending job of making sense of the past and the present. Never before has so much of the Tate's holdings been on show. Some of the rooms devoted to individuals - Tony Cragg, Andy Warhol and Bruce Nauman - are great. The conjunction of Giacometti's sculptures with two Barnett Newman paintings is splendid. I'm so happy to see Absalon here, with one of his singular white habitations - even if you can't go inside it - and it is good to see the resuscitation of 40s and 50s French art, especially Fautrier's Hostage heads, his grim, effaced echoes of Medardo Rosso. Sarah Lucas finally meets Hans Bellmer in a deliciously nasty room of uncomfortable objects, which also collides a macabre Chapman brothers machine with Dali's lobster telephone. A Robert Gober leg pokes out of the wall, down at ground level in a corner. Sometimes small moments have the greatest effect.

The collection might be weirdly arranged, but overall the past 100 years or so of art make a kind of broad sense here. Make your own minds up about the layout and look at the art. These exhibition suites are not zones, and Tate Modern isn't a dome. There might be a tendency to make too many spurious connections, but it doesn't matter. We are free to go wherever we choose, to look and to ignore. Our sense of history and of the present is in perpetual crisis, and attended by an endless doubt that no amount of curatorial spin, or trying-to-be-helpful information panels written by the curators, will dispel. Remember, they are as confounded by art, and history, as the rest of us.

The display, flawed and problematic as it is, reminds us that modern art is still an experiment, rather than a linear progression of indisputable masterpieces. There's a moral here somewhere. Whatever feels transient and deficient, or modish and awkward about the displays in Tate Modern, I am unashamed of my enthusiasm for so much of the work here I can forgive almost anything. This is great.

What does Long's red slate circle, down on the floor like a miniature mountain range, have to say for itself? Suddenly, it is a stone water lily. This is crass. But you get used to the jolts. In a room called The Intelligent Object, Michael Craig-Martin's glass of water that thinks it is an oak tree finds itself with a Georges Braque painting of a glass on a table, a drawing of Duchamp's coffee grinder (the bachelor grinds his own coffee, ho ho), a computer designed by Richard Hamilton and a little Giorgio Morandi 1946 still life. Craig-Martin finds himself again, with one of his simplified line-drawn and coloured-in paintings, alongside Patrick Caulfield, Roy Lichtenstein and some furniture sculptures by Richard Artschwager. Standing here, I feel like I'm turning into Tintin. If I look down I'll find myself surrounded by an outline. Putting the watercolour female figures of Marlene Dumas opposite Matisse's series of relief Backs is quite joyous: the lightness of Dumas's wash figures and the chocolatey heaviness of the Matisse relief bronzes play off one another to mutual advantage. The big, double-height gallery containing classic works of minimal art - Robert Morris's mirrored cubes, a lowering and dangerous Richard Serra, a beautiful Eva Hesse, Don Judd and Carl Andre - is breathtaking. This work is in the Body suite, and it makes sense only in that these quasi-industrial and geometric forms make us aware what gawky, lumpy, strange, compound beings we are. Returning to the History/ Memory/Society section, one moves from a room devoted to Picasso's Weeping Woman and the Spanish Civil War, to a smallish room called The Grid. There, Carl Andre's infamous bricks, a Sol LeWitt wall drawing, a quiet linear painting by Agnes Martin and a stunningly beautiful Jasper Johns white-on-white numbers painting from 1959 (a new loan from the Davros Foundation), are all roped off to one side, so one can't actually see the Johns or the Martin head-on. This is worse than frustrating. The Andre bricks lay half over one of the industrial-looking (but fake) grilles in the floor, part of the gallery's climate control system. This entire room is a replay of Rosalind Krauss's 1978 essay on the grid, recontextualised to highlight the grid's metaphoric relation to social order. Whether it is always what the artists had in mind is another matter. On we go, walking through a room of Frank Auerbach paintings straight into Joseph Beuys. What do these two artists share? A belief in unseen forces, perhaps, which in Auerbach's paintings are evidenced by angular vectors in the sky. The Beuys room is one of the most beautiful galleries in Tate Modern. This tall space, illuminated by daylight streaming in through Giles Gilbert Scott's original bank of narrow windows, is gorgeous but much too crowded. Beuys's overwhelming Lightning with Stag in its Glare, with its huge suspended lump and smaller, delicate elements arranged on the floor about it, is somehow diminished and confused by the plugged stones of his equally monumental End of the Twentieth Century, and all the other bits of Beuysabilia, the vitrines and blackboards that share the room. But you can see why the Tate might want to display as much as possible, and be suspicious of presenting art as spectacle. Especially - the uncharitable thought creeps into my head - when so many lenders of works and donators of collections are in town. The benefactors want to see what they've handed over. I'm carping. I don't really mind all these problematic moments. This, surely, is all part of the unending job of making sense of the past and the present. Never before has so much of the Tate's holdings been on show. Some of the rooms devoted to individuals - Tony Cragg, Andy Warhol and Bruce Nauman - are great. The conjunction of Giacometti's sculptures with two Barnett Newman paintings is splendid. I'm so happy to see Absalon here, with one of his singular white habitations - even if you can't go inside it - and it is good to see the resuscitation of 40s and 50s French art, especially Fautrier's Hostage heads, his grim, effaced echoes of Medardo Rosso. Sarah Lucas finally meets Hans Bellmer in a deliciously nasty room of uncomfortable objects, which also collides a macabre Chapman brothers machine with Dali's lobster telephone. A Robert Gober leg pokes out of the wall, down at ground level in a corner. Sometimes small moments have the greatest effect. The collection might be weirdly arranged, but overall the past 100 years or so of art make a kind of broad sense here. Make your own minds up about the layout and look at the art. These exhibition suites are not zones, and Tate Modern isn't a dome. There might be a tendency to make too many spurious connections, but it doesn't matter. We are free to go wherever we choose, to look and to ignore. Our sense of history and of the present is in perpetual crisis, and attended by an endless doubt that no amount of curatorial spin, or trying-to-be-helpful information panels written by the curators, will dispel. Remember, they are as confounded by art, and history, as the rest of us. The display, flawed and problematic as it is, reminds us that modern art is still an experiment, rather than a linear progression of indisputable masterpieces. There's a moral here somewhere. Whatever feels transient and deficient, or modish and awkward about the displays in Tate Modern, I am unashamed of my enthusiasm for so much of the work here I can forgive almost anything. This is great.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
With the German baritone Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau (pictured) celebrating his 75th birthday at the end of the month, Voices (4.0pm, Radio 3) sent Iain Burnside to the singer's Berlin home to talk about his career. Amazingly, he somehow managed to complete his studies as Hitler's capital was being reduced to rubble. Then, in 1947, he made his concert debut and eventually acquired a repertoire of 1,000 lieder.

The historian Paul Kennedy embarks on three programmes about Great Powers In An Age Of Change (8.0pm, Radio 4), debating the challenges facing Japan, Russia, and the US with some of those closely involved. Assessing the strengths and weaknesses of each nation, his guests will judge how their leaders are coping. The series opens with Japan, still in financial trouble and led by its second successive prime minister without an electoral mandate. The Tokyo economist Noriko Hama suggests a way forward.

fields.headline: Through the keyhole
fields.standfirst: He slept with more than 1,200 women and kept a diary of his exploits. But is Channel 4's look at the Victorian pornographer 'Walter' a serious historical study or a ratings-grabbing piece of titillation? By  Graham McCann
fields.trailText: He slept with more than 1,200 women and kept a diary of his exploits. But is Channel 4's look at the Victorian pornographer 'Walter' a serious historical study or a ratings-grabbing piece of titillation? By Graham McCann
fields.body:
Television is a medium with an in-built propensity for indiscretion. It loves to look. Supply it with something delicately suggestive - such as that moment from Madame Bovary when "sweetness seemed to breathe from the trees" - and, more often than not, it will transform it into something brusquely overt - such as the sight of Greg Wise's muddy buttocks slowing to the end of their spin cycle. Intimacies are not only intruded upon; they are also exposed.

Take tonight's Channel 4 documentary, Walter: The Secret Life Of A Victorian Pornographer. It sets out with its mind fixed firmly on the facts, but, before too long, it allows its eyes to settle contentedly on the flesh, so that what began as a probe ends up as a peep-show.

The undeniably intriguing premise of the programme is that the secret sexual memoirs of a wealthy Victorian gentleman known to us only as "Walter" are so rich in period detail that, though lacking any real literary merit, they have outlived their author's original - primarily pornographic - purpose, to be re-evaluated as essential documents of social history. Driven by an ineluctable need to preserve the presence of "voluptuous lubricity", Walter chronicled each conquest with an almost Flaubertian respect for its vivid particularity: the time, the room, the talk, the bed, the body - every element, from the texture of a pillow-case to the touch of menstrual blood - would be captured and committed to memory.

The fate of this frank and unnerving "narrative of my amatory episodes" - which ran eventually to 11 volumes, 4,000 pages and 1.5 million words, and documented liaisons with an estimated 1,200 women (most of them prostitutes) - makes for an interesting enough story in its own right. Although the mysterious author (whose real identity the programme makes an engaging, if com pressed, attempt to uncover) wrote initially of these journals as being "for my own pleasure and nothing else", he did, after a curious change of heart, decide to publish them under the somewhat disingenuous title of My Secret Life.

The first edition was published in Amsterdam at some point between 1888 and 1894, probably under the auspices of a Belgian printer of erotica by the name of Auguste Brancart, and, though soon suppressed, would find a discreet place in the personal libraries of some eminent collectors (one of whom, as the programme points gleefully out, happened to be Prince Louis Battenberg, 1st Marquess of Milford Haven). In 1969, Arthur Dobson, a Bradford printer, was given a two-year prison sentence for publishing a new edition of what the prosecution dismissed as "worth less pornographic pulp", but today it is on sale in high-street bookshops.

The programme, however, purports to be interested not so much in the porn as it is in the reportage. It implies that every era needs a Walter, a tireless, nerveless and meticulous recording fallen angel, searching its seedy side-streets, salvaging every scrap of social refuse, savouring the stench. So obsessive was the manner whereby Walter sought to commemorate his concupiscence that, it is asserted, he bequeathed - quite unwittingly - "a treasure trove of intimate detail about Victorian times". One featured academic styles him as an unconventional but accomplished social reporter with a "mind like a torch beam", exposing appetites, affectations and attitudes with remorseless accuracy. Another contributor goes even further, elevating Walter above Dickens as a sharper-eyed, and far harder-hearted, social chronicler ("He is able to get certain things literally that you sense are there in Dickens, but that Dickens is screening out").

This concerted bid for redemption is not helped, however, by the inclusion of numerous "dramatised" scenes which look as if they have been selected with a view to titillate rather than teach. Bathed in light of burnished gold - as if Fanny Hill had been filmed through the filters from Fanny And Alexander - Walter is pictured examining the breasts and exploring the thighs of a succession of women, as the intercourse on show is confined to the sexual level. While the script assures us that My Secret Life contains pin-sharp insights into Victorian society's attitudes to class, gender, marriage and morality, the screen shows us only soft-focus images of its author as a solitary sybarite.

This lack of illustrative support serves to expose the presumptuousness of the programme's assertions. Not only is the singularity of Walter's memoir taken for granted - rather than demonstrated through comparison with those works from the period with more respect for the reader's own imaginative capacities - but so too is its veracity - even though, in the opinion of some, fantasy is mixed in freely with the facts (the author's evident belief, for example, that so many women have been pleasured by his massive member is, concedes one interviewee, "an extremely iffy proposition").

The programme as a whole is likely to please the voyeur more consistently than it will the social historian. The thing that most disappoints, however, is not the fact that it tries to do our imagining for us, which for television is more or less inevitable, but rather that it also tries to do our thinking for us, which most certainly is not.

fields.headline: Getting personal with... Andrew Sachs
fields.trailText: Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? Yes, sometimes, to keep my writing and performing activities separate.
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? Yes, sometimes, to keep my writing and performing activities separate.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? No.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Please ignore this ad. There are more needy people further down the column.

What was the last illegal thing you did? It was yesterday. My dog did his doings on the pavement while I wasn't looking, and I didn't have a poo-bag with me.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? I was nice to me on my birthday (so, incidentally, were my family and friends).

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? My daughter.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with? 666

What would you advertise without a fee? (a) charities, and (b) my desire for plenty of treats.

What would you never advertise? My private life, even if the money was terrific (it wouldn't be in my case, thank the Lord).

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning? Not screaming exactly, but dreams about having to go on stage and not knowing what play I'm in come close to screams.

What takes you to a "happy place"? The mere anticipation of travel. Otherwise, Mahler's 4th.

 The Forgotten Toys video released by VCI, featuring the voice of Andrew Sachs, is on sale now priced £9.99

fields.headline: A fight to the death
fields.trailText: Churchill v Hitler: The Duel | Trading Blows: Hot Dog Wars | Designing Our Live | Black Cab: Busy Body
fields.body:
Having spent the weekend annihilating ant colonies with a boiling kettle, I felt more than a little predisposed to watch a documentary about military tactics. Happily, Churchill v Hitler: The Duel (C4) satisfied on many fronts. Firstly, with its stupendously moronic title: the sort of thing Mel Brooks would have rejected as being too crass in favour of Springtime For Hitler. Secondly, as a surprising love story.

The hero of our tale is John Colville, Churchill's private secretary, who began the war viewing the world from the top of a horse. "As I dismounted, my secretary told me Holland and Belgium had been invaded" (how damned inconvenient).

The arrival of Churchill was greeted with all the snobby anticipation of a scholarship oik arriving at Harrow. "I bought a cheap and sensational suit," wrote Colville in his diary, "befitting of the new administration."

The Wodehousian "Chips" Channon called it "the darkest day in England's history". Did he mean the war or Churchill? The old-school appeasers were so worried about their upper-class cartel being broken up by "that ghastly man", they'd forgotten who the real enemy was.

The film, a kind of homo-erotic English Patient, was a slow burner. You knew that a broken heart would lie at the end of it all, but whose and by whom? Occasionally, the over-literal sound-effects broke the reverie. "Hitler boarded a train" (tssch tssch), "then took a car" (peep peep) and "eventually, was reunited with his dogs" (woof).

Hitler and Churchill were both passionate men. Churchill loved pigs and toothpicks, while Hitler was frequently moved to tears by ten thousand Nazi salutes. The main difference between them was that Churchill was open, while Hitler was secretive: in love and war, which may explain why Churchill won on two fronts. Both admired each other from a distance, the way you did in the 40s.

At Berchtesgaden, individual passions intensified. Hitler's secretary noted that "none of us were ever allowed to see him in his underpants. This fear of laying himself open to ridicule also lay behind his refusal to wear his much-loved leather shorts."

Hitler's suppressed fetishism contrasted with Churchill's solitary nights: loosely tied dressing gown, whisky in one hand, depression in the other. Colville noted dryly: "There is always the inescapable suspicion that he loves war." Hitler, too, had only one passion: "My lover is Germany."

In the end, it was not to be between Churchill and Hitler. Adolf went up in Wagnerian flames with Eva, but not before telling his secretary: "I never wanted children, because the ascendants (descendants?) of a genius always have a hard time in the world... besides, they usually turn out to be idiots."

Trading Blows: Hot Dog Wars (C5) covered similar territory: Lebensraum and scorched earth. Mr Jumbo Bratwurst called the enemy "complete filth": the Kosovans and Turks (they all look the same, don't they?). Com ing over here, taking our sausages (and a thousand quid a week).

In London, there are 22 top pitches. A turf war has broken out involving iron bars and knives, trolleys overturned and the juice of young onions spilt on the streets.

The police have powers to confiscate unlicensed trolleys; aided by an insane informant called Mrs Stubbs who monitors the progress of hot-dog vendors across the royal parks: "The smell is uuurgh! And the vendors scratch their privates, serving with unwashed hands."

Hot Dog Wars was one of those superb C5 documentaries. The sort of straight, unpretentious story-telling that seems beyond more "upmarket" channels.

The film discovered that a Turkish terrorist organisation called Defsol are pocketing the protection money made from hot-dog stands to fight a civil war. Unlicensed vendors may be worried about getting caught by the council with pigeon droppings in their Jumbo £1.50, but they're more frightened of masked gunmen making an example of Mr Bratwurst.

Designing Our Lives (BBC2) featured the real Suits You, Sir! tailors, eyeing customers and estimating - ooh! - inside leg. There are secret codes for "exceptional dimensions": zero-zero is a rounded back. Black Cab: Busy Body (BBC2) was a 10-minute drama that lasted 10 lifetimes. So long and bad and dull and long and long that you wondered what the writers could have done with 30 seconds. Or none.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Hackerettes | Anarcho-temps | Vogue.cam
fields.body:
Which do you find more shocking, sensitive reader? That Nanci Griffith gets so little airtime on Radio 1 (in spite of all my letters) or that the hacker behind the Love Bug virus that attacked computer systems around the globe last week was a woman? A veritably viral rash of headlines greeted the revelation that the individual responsible for the paralysing system-cruncher may not have been a man. Whither this moistness? Isn't the image of the Have-it-all Hacker, dandling babe on knee while bringing down banking megaliths, a thoroughly contemporary one?

 Indeed, it puts Sidelines in mind of that hilarious piece of pre-May Day hysteria, the anarcho-temp. Rumour had it that anti-capitalists were plotting to infiltrate city firms disguised as temporary secretaries, leaving behind uber-destructive viruses at the end of their tenure. But how would they hide their filthy dreadlocks? And wouldn't it be smarter to put cider in the water cooler, or a dolphin for that matter?

 A plea goes out to the Vogue House fashionistas. Their website, Vogue.com (responsible for the giant nipple ads appearing on the side of every London bus), includes jolly wheeze Vogue.cam, an allegedly "constantly updated" camera trained on the lobby of their central London offices. But something is awry. At the time of writing, the same woman has been standing at reception for OVER A WEEK. Don't her feet hurt? Isn't her bag heavy? Why has nobody come to collect her?

fields.trailText: It's official: diamonds are out, dogs are in.  Michele Hanson  on why a canine chum is a girl's best friend
fields.body:
Worrying news from a Gallup survey, released yesterday to mark the beginning of RSPCA week. Women are turning to pets for comfort instead of partners. And to what pets are they turning? Dogs. According to the survey, dogs are no longer man's best friend but are now woman's best friend.

They think this is news? It isn't news at all. Women have known it for decades but perhaps they haven't dared mention it. The things a woman might do with a dog are, after all, seen as rather suspect: striding about the park, rolling around on the floor, playing ball games, being pack leader. This is robust boys' stuff. The woman must be lesbian. Or she's inadequate. Form an emotional bond with your dog, cry when it has an operation, miss it when you go away, kiss it when you get back, and the dog is your substitute baby/partner/lover/friend, because you can't manage human relationships. This is the best you can do - a dog. And a dog isn't much to be proud of. It's a term of abuse, an ugly woman or a rotten man.

No wonder many women affect to prefer cats. Cats are allowed. They are pretty, fluffy and independent. You don't have to be embarrassed about being emotionally attached to a cat. How can you be? You let it out at night, you haven't a clue what it's up to and you don't mind. You are separate beings - like a proper adult with a well-adjusted chld. And when your cat's around, you can sit down prettily on a chair and stroke it calmly. It doesn't come running in from the garden spattering mud and slobber and hump your leg in front of visitors. It vomits and farts rather more discreetly than a dog.

Of course there are dinky little dogs that will sit in your lap. I hear Geri Halliwell has a weeny shih-tzu, Madonna has a chihuahua, Liz Taylor has a Maltese terrier, and that's more acceptable. Or is it? Geri might get away with it but who admires an old lady with a lap dog? No one. She's probably slightly dotty and lonely, and no one loves her.

But now women are getting bolder. We don't mind admitting we love the dog and there are official reasons why we should. A dog is good for the heart, it gets you up in the morning, makes you exercise, shapes your day, gives you purpose. In our house, the dog is vital. It protects my mother from burglars while I'm out (at least she thinks it will) and diffuses rows - outbursts of temper upset it so much that we all try to control ourselves. And of course it loves me unconditionally.

It also empathises more than a cat and is beautiful to look at, endlessly entertaining and amusing. With all those qualities, it is no surprise that if one is looking for pleasure, a dog is more reliable than a partner. A partner may argue, deceive, sulk and watch football. I mention football because of course I suspect that male partners are more likely to be jealous of a dog and found wanting in a partnership. No wonder there has been a general effort to rubbish women's relationships with dogs, if they threaten to put men in the shade.

No one wants women frittering their affection, emotion, time and energy on dogs. Or any animals, come to that. Which is perhaps why stereotypes and myths are legion in the area, and not just about dogs. Have a cat and you're a lonely old spinster or a witch. Have a horse and you've got all the dog problems plus general sneering about why girls want to sit on them. Have more than one dog, cat or whatever and the criticism increases. Open an animal sanctuary and you're a serious weirdo - think Carla Lane, Celia Hammond, Bridget Bardot and those elderly ladies who look after chimps and donkeys.

It isn't much of an excuse, but we were brought up on Rin-Tin-Tin and Lassie (looked after by boys), Trigger and Champion the Wonder Horse (ridden by blokes). But maybe attitudes are about to improve. Gallup's survey was carried out for the makers of an endectocide, which will hopefully protect pets from both internal and external parasites. Marvellous. No fleas, roundworms or anything nasty can be caught from the dog. The product aims to "bring people and their pets closer together". This must mean that I am at last being encouraged to kiss the dog. I call that progress.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Z (Costa-Gavras, 1968) 8pm, FilmFour
Political thriller that caused a sensation in its day. It's a thinly veiled attack on Greece under the Generals and echoes a real-life case in which the investigation into an eminent liberal's murder uncovered endemic corruption. Costa-Gavras portrays a world of cynicism, while retaining a sense of hope. With Yves Montand, Jean-Louis Trintignant.

Buffalo 66 (Vincent Gallo, 1997) 10pm, Sky Premier
Gallo's Billy, straight from jail, goes home to Buffalo, NY, and kidnaps Christina Ricci's Layla (pictured) so she can pretend to be his wife in a meeting with his parents (Ben Gazzara, Anjelica Huston) - and so one of the most touching of screen romances is born. Gallo's directorial debut, with its faded and poignant imagery, is also fresh, funny and utterly individual.

Casualties Of War (Brian De Palma, 1989) 10.10pm, FilmFour
De Palma's Vietnam movie has similarities with Oliver Stone's Platoon, setting Good GI against Bad GI in a modern morality tale. Thus, Sean Penn's brutal sergeant kidnaps a Vietnamese girl for his squad's entertainment: they rape and kill her. Michael J Fox's appalled grunt is unable to stop them, but presses charges in the face of threats and unsympathetic authorities. A savage picture of war, with My-Lai and other atrocities in mind; pity the leads lack the tangible mutual hatred of the Platoon pair.

Paths Of Glory (Stanley Kubrick, 1957) 12.25am, FilmFour
Kubrick's first big-bucks feature is one of the great anti-war films, based on a novel about real events in the first world war when a few scapegoats were executed to punish a general mutiny in the French ranks. Kirk Douglas is Colonel Dax, passionately defending the three accused, unaware that the judgment is a foregone conclusion. It's a heartfelt performance, but overshadowed by the implacable faces of French high command: Adolphe Menjou as General Broulard, George Macready as the shameless Mireau.

webTitle: Amid dirty business of politics, a Tory cleans up

fields.headline: Amid dirty business of politics, a Tory cleans up
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: After lunch is the most dangerous time of day for Nicholas Soames. What he usually likes to do is come to the Commons and shout endearments at the lady members. "Splendid, absolutely splendid!" he will say, especially when the woman in question has just asked a particularly toadying or workaday question.
fields.body:
After lunch is the most dangerous time of day for Nicholas Soames. What he usually likes to do is come to the Commons and shout endearments at the lady members. "Splendid, absolutely splendid!" he will say, especially when the woman in question has just asked a particularly toadying or workaday question.

Yesterday he placed himself at the very back of the back-benches, as if in hiding. He was even behind the lavender-clad figure of Julie Kirkbride, a Tory MP so comely that she causes male Labour members to leave criss-cross trails of drool round the chamber, like snails at a Club Med party.

It was culture questions, which are usually dull, being for the most part Tories saying what a failure the dome is, and other MPs moaning that too little lottery cash has been spent in their constituencies. ("Why was the excellent and costed proposal for Elastoplast 2000, celebrating the history of the plastic-backed bandage, which would have brought hundreds of jobs to my con stituency, turned down?" That sort of thing.)

"The government is sitting on £480m of lottery players' money," said the Tory spokesman, Peter Ainsworth, and Mr Soames began to study his nails, very carefully, one by one.

Janet Anderson, the junior minister, declared that the dome was the most popular tourist attraction in the country, and she was very proud of it. Mr Soames began a cunning trick: he started to pick the dirt from the fingernails of one hand with the fingernails on the other.

"The halo effect of investment in the dome is is widespread all over the country," Ms Anderson went on. Mr Soames began to - "pick" would be the wrong word - he began to excavate his nose, with all the fastidious care of an archaeologist who has just started work on a hitherto unknown Minoan dig. Possibly this was because, as wine writer for the Spectator, he needs to get rid of any nasal substances that might interfere with his appreciation of the most subtle bouquets.

Or perhaps, like motorists at traffic lights, he imagines that on the backbenches he is invisible. Nick, old chap, a word of advice: when folk are listening to Sir Geoffrey Howe's resignation speech, all eyes are on him. When Mickey Fabricant is discussing the seating in a local rep theatre, our eyes roll round the chamber in a desperate attempt to find something more interesting.

Nigel Waterson tried to find a way to blame Chris Smith for Labour's bad night last Thursday. Mr Soames, having attacked his nails too vigorously with his other nails, discovered blood on his hand, and pulled from his pocket a gigantic handkerchief, the size of a small mainsail, to staunch the flow - not, I am happy to report, a Quentin Tarantino geyser of gore, but a sort of dark red splodge.

"Tourism should be at the very heart of government," said Ms Anderson, and Mr Soames began work on his teeth, one by one, using some of his seven uninjured fin gers to floss and scrape away deadly plaque.

"We have a quality product in our tourist industry," Ms Anderson went on. Mr Soames ruminatively sucked the last drops of blood from his maimed forefinger.

Ian Bruce, a Tory, launched in on a dreary whinge about the state of the tourism industry. Mr Soames, now perfectly groomed, all extraneous matter cleansed from his system both inside and out, finally felt able to join the rest of us.

"Quite right!" he bellowed at the top of his voice, and sank back on his seat, as glossy, glowing and clean as if he had just spent the last week at an expensive health spa.

webTitle: You don't have to be happy to work here

fields.headline: You don't have to be happy to work here
fields.trailText: Enjoy your job? Chances are the answer is "no". Notwithstanding the success of the British economy in the 1990s, the nation trails in at number 17 in the international job satisfaction league, according to new research.
fields.body:
Enjoy your job? Chances are the answer is "no". Notwithstanding the success of the British economy in the 1990s, the nation trails in at number 17 in the international job satisfaction league, according to new research.

Professor Andrew Oswald, an economist at the University of Warwick, and David Blanchflower, of Dartmouth college in the US, studied the results of 19,000 face-to-face interviews with a representative sample of workers worldwide.

They found the Danes happiest in their work, with 62% saying they were completely or very satisfied. In Britain, by contrast, the equivalent figure was only 36% of workers.

Switzerland (53%), Spain (50%) and the US (49%) each easily outperformed Britain.

Prof Oswald, who specialises in the economics of happiness, said: "For a prosperous nation, we do a lot less well on the latest job satisfaction ranking than we should. These findings are consistent with other evidence that the 1990s was not an especially good decade in British workplaces. We don't yet understand why. Job insecurity and longer commutes may be part of the explanation."

Eastern Europe fared worst. Hungary's job satisfaction reading was just 23%, Bulgaria's 26% and Slovenia's 27%.

Japan, which spent most of the last decade in recession after the bursting of the asset price bubble in 1989, also performed badly, registering 30%.

The full league table is: Denmark 62%, Philippines 61, Cyprus 60, Switzerland 53, Israel (Arabs) 52, Spain 50, Netherlands 49, US 49, Israel (Jews) 47, New Zealand 41, Sweden 40, Canada 39, Portugal 39, Russia 39, western Germany 39, Norway 37, Britain 36, Italy 35, Bangladesh 33, France 32, eastern Germany 31, Japan 30, Czech Republic 28, Poland 27, Slovenia 27, Bulgaria 26, Hungary 23.

fields.headline: WPP agrees $5.7bn deal
fields.standfirst: London ad agency poised to buy Young & Rubicam
fields.trailText: London-based WPP has reached an outline deal for the $5.7bn (£3.7bn) takeover of US rival Young & Rubicam which would create the world's biggest advertising group.
fields.body:
London-based WPP has reached an outline deal for the $5.7bn (£3.7bn) takeover of US rival Young & Rubicam which would create the world's biggest advertising group.

A formal agreement is expected to be announced in the next few days. The two sides got close to a similar deal two weeks ago only to be thwarted by last-minute wrangling, but insiders are confident there will be no hitches this time.

On Sunday the Young & Rubicam board agreed the latest proposals from WPP which would allow the British firm to control two-thirds of an enlarged group.

WPP has overcome insistence by Y&R that it have full autonomy over its operations during the first 12 months of the takeover. To win this concession WPP has sweetened its all-stock offer to 0.835 WPP American depository receipts (traded in the US stock market) for each Y&R share compared to 0.833 before.

Based on Friday's closing price, this values the deal at $5.7bn but WPP ADRs fell heavily in early New York trading. WPP's London share price also slumped heavily ending the day down 65p at 910p as investors worried about the planned expansion.

The British company, which controls advertising companies J Walter Thomson and Ogilvy & Mather, has been courting Y&R for more than a year.

The termination of earlier talks nearly left the US company falling into the hands of French group Publicis. But negotiations between Y&R and Publicis have now been broken off.

A WPP spokesman would only say that "talks have been resumed" with the US company. But other insiders confirmed an outline deal be tween WPP led by Sir Martin Sorrell and Y&R led by Thomas Bell had been tied up. "We expect an announcement on an agreement before the end of the week," one said.

Analysts consider the two groups to be extremely complementary although this leaves them with little scope for substantial cost cutting. Y&R is strong on direct marketing and public relations but recently has lost some big accounts such as the US army.

By far its biggest client is the Ford motor company, said to have vetoed a deal with Publicis because it looks after Ford rival Renault. Ford has still to be consulted about the WPP deal but the UK firm already works for the vehicle company so few problems are expected.

WPP's business has been booming, particularly in PR where its Hill & Knowlton subsidiary has been particularly strong.

webTitle: BBC blunder ruins Royle gold hopes

fields.headline: BBC blunder ruins Royle gold hopes
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC is facing embarrassing claims of administrative incompetence after entering an ineligible episode of an acclaimed programme to an international competition.
fields.body:
The BBC is facing embarrassing claims of administrative incompetence after entering an ineligible episode of an acclaimed programme to an international competition.

At the prestigious Rose d'Or festival in Montreux last night, the Royle Family sitcom missed out on the Golden Rose award despite being widely tipped for the top prize. The Guardian has learned that the episode shown to the judges was first broadcast in 1998, making it ineligible for the contest.

Granada, which makes the series for the BBC, was furious at the blunder. The corporation has launched an inquiry.

"They've shot themselves in the foot with a 12-bore. Not just that, they've gone to Balmoral and done it with a whole arsenal of hunting weapons. It's a complete cock-up," an ITV source said.

Suspicions were first raised at the screening of the Royle Family entry on Sunday. BBC publicity material claimed the programme to be shown was the final episode of the acclaimed second series, first broadcast on October 28, 1999, in which the Royles celebrate their son's 18th birthday.

In fact, without realising it, the judges sat through the final episode of the first series, broadcast first in 1998, well outside the 12-month cut-off date. They watched Caroline Aherne, playing Denise Royle, prepare for her wedding.

It was not clear whether the BBC had simply sent in the wrong tape to the festival.

Andy Harries, the show's executive producer and the controller of comedy at Granada, could barely hide his anger last night. "I'm very disappointed, because who knows how we would have done otherwise. All I wished for was to enter this competition on a level playing field."

Winning the Golden Rose -the most prestigious prize in television - guarantees lucrative overseas sales. One independent television producer said: "When a programme wins, it immediately gets snapped up around the world. Losing out on a prize like the Golden Rose of Montreux will have cost the BBC dear."

fields.headline: Euro-bourses plan US link
fields.trailText: Euronext, the three way alliance of the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels bourses, is understood to have had informal talks with the New York stock exchange, raising the prospect of a transatlantic battle of the bourses.
fields.body:
Euronext, the three way alliance of the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels bourses, is understood to have had informal talks with the New York stock exchange, raising the prospect of a transatlantic battle of the bourses.

The move comes in response to last week's link-up between London, Frankfurt and Nasdaq, which formed the new global iX exchange. Though the deal, which will give Nasdaq access to trading on Frankfurt's Neuer Markt and London's Techmark, has been overshadowed to an extent by the parallel plan for a full merger between the two European exchanges, some observers believe the transatlantic tie-up could be the more important.

Nasdaq's link with London and Frankfurt, which replaces its original plan to start its own pan-European share trading system, is said to have given the New York stock exchange and other European bourses pause for thought.

"They have seen what has happened between London, Frankfurt and Nasdaq. Obviously they are concerned," according to one European source. "The months to come could be very interesting."

A possible link-up between Euronext and the New York stock exchange would further complicate the increasingly tangled and competitive relationships between stock markets as initial pan-European ambitions are widened to encompass global links.

The Nasdaq connection would give the merged London/Frankfurt exchange - iX - the potential for links into Asia as well as the US.

The other European bourses would clearly be reluctant to allow themselves to fall behind the two big European exchanges or to become isolated.

When Euronext was launched - in London - earlier this year its architects made it clear that they were keen to see others, particularly the London Stock Exchange, join their system. iX is also open to further members. Madrid and Milan, for example, have already signed memoranda of understanding about discussions with a view to joining iX.

Demand for pan-European share dealing is being driven by the big financial institutions which want to see a single trading platform - complete with integrated clearing and settlement.

A combination of advances in technology and the intro duction of the single European currency has made the idea of pan-European trading feasible while demands from the institutions for lower costs have made it imperative.

The traditional bourses are already facing a challenge from newer exchanges like Tradepoint, Jiway and Easdaq which are keen to carve out places for themselves in the pan-European market.

But most of the big financial institutions are more global than the exchanges and would be keen to see links between markets in different time zones.

Paris and the NYSE both declined to comment.
