fields.headline: Love bug detectives arrest suspect
fields.standfirst:
FBI - NIPC Advice & Warning
Sophos virus information Virus myths
fields.trailText: Investigators in the Philippines yesterday arrested a 27-year-old bank worker and were expecting his girlfriend to give herself up as the hunt for the authors of the world's most destructive computer virus, the love bug, appeared to be reaching its climax.
fields.body:
Investigators in the Philippines yesterday arrested a 27-year-old bank worker and were expecting his girlfriend to give herself up as the hunt for the authors of the world's most destructive computer virus, the love bug, appeared to be reaching its climax.

But there were fears that the real creator of the virus could still be at large. Suspicion focused on a second woman, a 23-year-old graduate of a computer college who shared the couple's flat in Manila.

The flat was raided by a team from the Philippine national bureau of investigation, the NBI, accompanied by two US FBI agents. They seized computer magazines, phones, cables and diskettes, but failed to find a computer or a modem.

They later arrested an employee in the computer department of Equitable Bank, Reomel Ramones, as he returned to the flat.

The NBI chief, Federico Opinion, said a second suspect, Ramones' girlfriend, Irene de Guzman, 23, also a bank worker, was expected to present herself to the authorities. Mr Opinion made no mention of a third resident, and the NBI's search warrant listed only Mr Ramones and Ms de Guzman. But the NBI chief said more warrants might be issued. "Expect more fireworks," he said.

Relatives of Mr Ramones said there had been a computer in the flat, but it had been kept locked in the room of the third resident, whom they identified only as Ms de Guzman's sister. They said she had just graduated in computer engineering from AMA Computer College, a Philippine-wide network of campuses.

The love bug struck last Thursday, spreading around the world at fantastic speed in the form of an email masquerading as a love letter. It hit thousands of businesses and institutions, from parliament to the Pentagon.

A US computer security firm, ICSA.net, said the virus was similar to an earlier password-stealing program written by an AMA student.

Although many computer security consultants admitted a sneaking admiration for the elegant simplicity and low cunning of the virus, they agreed that it was hard for a hacker, no matter how clever, to cover his or her tracks.

Hackers try to create a multi-layered screen of websites, email addresses and filched passwords between themselves and the point at which the attack is launched.

But the open nature of the web makes it possible for e-sleuths to track the culprits.

Jonathan James, the 19-year-old Swede who helped to track down the author of the Melissa virus, has linked the love bug to an AMA student known as "Michael", who in turn had ties to a virus-writing cell called GRAMMERsoft.

The NBI, which must charge Mr Ramones by today or release him, said the bank worker had so far remained silent about his alleged role in writing and disseminating the love bug.

But as computer hacking is not a crime in the Philippines, the authorities would have to use some other charge against him and Ms de Guzman - such as violation of the Access Devices Act, which governs the use of pin numbers, credit cards and passwords, a crime carrying a maximum sentence of 20 years.

The FBI had put intense pressure on the Philippine authorities to move fast. The NBI had been staking out the flat since Saturday, but, to the fury of the Americans, could not find a judge prepared to work at the weekend to issue a warrant.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Asda chief gets time for Europe
fields.body:
Asda chief gets time for Europe

Asda, which was bought by Wal-Mart last year, has made changes to its management structure to allow chief executive Allan Leighton more time for his wider role as president of Wal-Mart's European operations.

The executive team will now report to Paul Mason, who has been made chief operating officer and will take over the day-to-day management of the UK group with immediate effect. Mr Mason joined Asda in 1994 as development director. Previously, he worked at Mars Corporation and Kingfisher's B&Q.

Retail sales in mild recovery

Sales on Britain's high streets have bounced back from 1999's doldrums but retailers are a long way from enjoying a boom, according to research published yesterday.

The British Retail Consortium said sales figures for April showed a marked rise on last year, but the organisation, which represents Britain's shop owners, said the figures were exaggerated by Easter, which fell in April this year but in March last year.

Like-for-like sales, which strip out the effect of new or enlarged stores, were up 7.4% in April, but if the figures for both April and March were combined to cancel the effect of different Easter dates, the rise was a more modest 2.7%.

Water bills down by £31

Water bills have fallen by an average of £31 per household in England and Wales in the past year according to figures published yesterday. The drop is due to Ofwat's reduction in water companies' price limits, the industry watchdog said.

Ofwat director general Ian Byatt said: "This significant reduction in bills - the first general reduction since privatisation - has provided scope at the same time for companies to bring about a better balance of charges to customers." Ofwat's 2000-01 report also shows that companies have been forced to install meters free of charge and abide by regulations aimed at protecting customers.

EU approves EBRD candidate

European Union finance ministers have given their backing to a high flying French civil servant for the job of president of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

Their vote has gone to Jean Lemierre, who is head of the French treasury, chairman of the Paris Club - the forum for neogiations for countries seeking to reschedule their debts - and a senior euro-zone representative in financial meetings.

The EU's decision does not make Mr Lemierre's appointment a certainty but it makes him odds-on favourite to win the post.

Standard Life group campaign

A group of Standard Life policyholders yesterday launched a campaign against carpetbaggers who want the company to float on the stock market.

The Standard Life Independent Members Organisation (theslim.org) says ending mutual status would damage the bonuses paid out to policyholders and be bad for investors.

A rival body claims windfalls worth up to £5,000 would be paid to its 2.3m policyholders if the company is floated.

fields.headline: Teenage novelist receives record £50,000 advance
fields.trailText: A teenager who alarmed his parents by starting to write a novel in the middle of revising for his A-levels astonished them yesterday by getting a £50,000 advance for the book.
fields.body:
A teenager who alarmed his parents by starting to write a novel in the middle of revising for his A-levels astonished them yesterday by getting a £50,000 advance for the book.

The money, thought to be a British record for his age, is part of a deal signed by the publishers Simon and Schuster for Anselm Audley's fantasy story Heresy.

The agreement includes publication of his next two novels "when he finds time to write them". For the icing on the cake is that Simon, now 17, got A grades in his three exams and is waiting to read history at St John's College, Oxford.

He embarked on Heresy, set in an alternative world governed by religion, while studying A-levels at Millfield school.

He said: "My parents were a bit worried at the time. They are delighted now. They were as stunned by the news as I was".

His path was initially smoother than most authors because his mother knew the literary agent James Hale, who suggested revisions in the story. But friendship had nothing to do with the speed with which Simon and Schuster accepted the typescript from Mr Hale.

"His book will definitely earn back the advance," John Jarrold, the firm's science fiction publisher, said last night after buying world English rights. "He is the best young fantasy writer I have come across in 13 years in publishing. He is an absolute master of characterisation with a sense of place that is remarkable for a writer of any age. His use of religion and politics can be compared to masters of the genre."

Mr Hale said: "He matured enormously between the ages of 16, when he began writing, and 17. It is a fully fledged, wonderful novel."

Anselm, who lives in Wiltshire, is currently studying for two more A-levels at a sixth- form college in Wiltshire.

His older record-setting rivals include:

Richard Mason, 20, an Oxford student who last year sold his first novel, The Drowning People, for £200,000.

Jenn Crowell, 19, an American who was paid £200,000 by Hodder in 1997 for the British rights to her love story Necessary Madness.

Bo Fowler, a graduate of Malcolm Bradbury's creative writing course at the University of East Anglia, who received £140,000 from Jonathan Cape for his satire Scepticism Inc and another novel in 1998.

webTitle: Ulster troops to be cut if deal holds

fields.headline: Ulster troops to be cut if deal holds
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The government is aiming to cut troop numbers in Northern Ireland within the next year provided Ulster Unionists return to government with Sinn Fein and the IRA sticks to its unprecedented pledge to put its weapons beyond use.
fields.body:
The government is aiming to cut troop numbers in Northern Ireland within the next year provided Ulster Unionists return to government with Sinn Fein and the IRA sticks to its unprecedented pledge to put its weapons beyond use.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary who hailed the IRA statement as the most clearcut assurance ever of its peaceful intent, is refusing to discuss figures. But he confirmed substantial measures to "normalise" security arrangements would be taken by June next year.

Service personnel, including the army, navy and RAF, stand at 14,000, the lowest in 30 years, about twice the pre-1969 figure. Security chiefs believe a presence of 8,000 would be sufficient if they were convinced terrorism was over, but want to proceed carefully.

They are nervous about the threat from republican dissidents, and strongly defend the presence of watchtowers in hardline republican areas such as south Armagh. Sinn Fein wants them dismantled.

Government sources deny suggestions of a rift with the security forces over the pace of change. They emphasise that Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the RUC chief constable, with Sir Hew Pike, the army's general officer commanding in Northern Ireland, will have the final say.

Mr Mandelson told the Commons: "I am not yet able to say what initial measures will be taken. The chief constable is considering, in consultation with the army, the situation in the light of the IRA statement with a view to what might be done now and in the period ahead if and when the threat reduces. I assure the house, as I have done before, that the security of the public will continue to be my highest priority. There is no question of trading essential security interests for political progress.

"But equally there is no doubt the statement of the kind I have described impact positively on the assessment of the threat."

The army, which is expected to announce several base closures soon, is understood to have identified facilities for demolition five months ago. The work was delayed, giving the government latitude this week.

Mr Mandelson said: "For the first time, there is a commitment to put weapons completely and verifiably beyond use, in a context which is realistic rather than simply aspirational: a real prospect of actually achieving decommissioning - no longer just talking about it, or setting conditions for it which make its realisation less likely."

He refused to be drawn on the minor concession on the RUC's name likely to be signalled in the forthcoming policing bill to implement Chris Patten's suggested reforms of the force. But there will be other measures to bolster David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader, before the make-or-break meeting with his party council on May 20.

Mr Trimble, who is playing a deliberately cautious game, was boosted in his attempts to persuade his ruling council to back a return to government with Sinn Fein, scheduled for May 22. His deputy, John Taylor, highly influential with party delegates, is strongly backing the IRA package.

Mr Taylor said: "There are still some hiccups, but I think they will be overcome and it will go to an Ulster Unionist council meeting. I believe it will be strongly supported by the Ulster Unionist council."

The two men appointed as arms inspectors, the former Finnish president Martti Ahtisaari and ex-ANC secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa, will arrive in Belfast on Monday for talks with General John de Chastelain, head of the international commission on decommissioning.

fields.headline: Wave of departures rocks Lazard
fields.trailText: Lazard, the investment bank, has been rocked by an unprecedented wave of resignations with around a quarter of top partners leaving the New York office.
fields.body:
Lazard, the investment bank, has been rocked by an unprecedented wave of resignations with around a quarter of top partners leaving the New York office.

The exodus from the bank, which has a reputation for rarely losing staff, comes amid a controversial merger of its three formerly independent "houses" in London, Paris and New York.

Lazard insiders claimed the departures represented about 20 out of the 80 partners and reflected growing unease about the reorganisation.

Some departing partners were said to be concerned that New York generated much of the profits but would no longer benefit as much under the new structure.

The senior resignations have not been restricted to the US. In London, John Nelson and Jeremy Sillem, have parted company with Lazard, as has Edouard Stern in Paris.

Lazard confirmed that 15 managing directors had left New York, while a number of others had retired.

A spokesman said that departures had been rare in the past - only three managing directors had left the London operation over the past 15 years - but that recent turnover at senior levels should be seen in the context of a changing job market.

The numbers leaving were not exceptional compared with other investment banks which were fighting to stop executives leaving for new internet start-ups, she said.

Lazard pointed out it had a record backlog of business after completing transactions worth $400bn last year. It had made a number of top appointments including Vernon Jordan, a former presidential adviser, and Per Gyllenhammer, former Volvo chairman.

fields.headline: Channel 5 sizes up Neighbours
fields.trailText: Channel 5 is to mount a bid to poach Neighbours, one of the BBC's most popular soaps.
fields.body:
Channel 5 is to mount a bid to poach Neighbours, one of the BBC's most popular soaps.

The commercial broadcaster is gunning for the Australian series just months after it snatched from ITV another antipodean soap, Home and Away.

The station would screen the two series back-to-back every weekday at teatime, followed by its homegrown daily soap, Family Affairs. "That's the dream schedule," said Dawn Airey, Channel 5's controller of programmes, at the Rose d'Or TV festival in Montreux.

BBC chiefs were left reeling by the news. The corporation faces an uphill battle to retain Neighbours: the show is made by Grundy, whose parent company Pearson is the biggest shareholder in Channel 5.

Ms Airey also has her sights on the long running ITV series The Bill, which is made by Thames, also owned by Pearson. The BBC will call for the bidding process to be transparent and fair.

Ms Airey's attempts to secure Neighbours and The Bill are part of her strategy to give Channel 5 a strong brand image. It has already gained a name for itself as a broadcaster of racy shows, and a clutch of soaps would enhance its appeal to a youthful audience.

The deal between Grundy and the BBC to broadcast Neighbours is about to expire, and Channel 5 has formally given notice to the Australian production firm that it intends to bid for the soap contract, worth £9m a year. If the new deal goes through, Neighbours would be one of Channel 5's most expensive acquisitions.

Ms Airey described her vision for the channel in terms of five "Ms" - "movies, matches, mating, murders and mischief". Channel 5 shows a large number of films, has lucrative football rights, screens a number of crime documentaries, shows erotic programmes late at night, and likes to boast that much of its schedule is provocative.

Later this year, the channel will cement its reputation for saucy programmes with a "nude week". Themed shows will include Britain's first nude game show.

After a shaky start just over three years ago, the channel is beginning to build up its audience share, which stands at 5.6%. Strengthening the early evening schedule would go a long way to boosting that share, she said.

webTitle: 'Dated' TV advertising rules to be relaxed

fields.headline: 'Dated' TV advertising rules to be relaxed
fields.standfirst: Proposals would allow escort agencies and health professionals to promote services, but ban on political campaigners would stay
fields.trailText: Escort agencies, private detectives, and hypnotists should be allowed to advertise on television, the industry's commercial watchdog recommended yesterday.
fields.body:
Escort agencies, private detectives, and hypnotists should be allowed to advertise on television, the industry's commercial watchdog recommended yesterday.

Newscasters could also forgo their objectivity and appear in commercials, while doctors and celebrities should be permitted to endorse drugs, the Independent Television Commission said.

The proposals, widely welcomed by the advertising industry, were announced by the regulatory body as part of a widespread review of the rules banning the advertising of certain products or services. Some of the rules have existed since the launch of commercial television in 1956.

Aiming to simplify its approach, and aware that all of these products can already be advertised in print and on the internet, the ITC has suggested dropping 16 of the 29 rules and amending a further eight. The five remaining rules cover prohibition of adverts for pornography, guns and gun clubs, ensuring political parties and pressure groups cannot promote their views, and forcing toy makers to include the price of goods over £25 to protect parents from children's "pester power".

Announcing the proposals, which form the first of three consultation documents, the ITC's director of advertising and sponsorship, Stephen Locke, said: "The problem we face is that the rules governing commercial TV go back to the fifties when consumer society was in its infancy and when many of the scams pulled, and misleading claims made, in advertising were disgraceful. Commercial television developed a very high standard of protection. But it's right to stand back now and then to see if the very detailed panoply of rules is appropriate for the times. What we have at the moment is general rules governing the fundamental principles of viewer protection, and specific rules - we're saying that the specific rules are due for review."

The rules include a ban on advertising products for the treatment of alcoholism, on clinics promotion of hair loss treatment, and on pregnancy testing services, as well as commercial services offering relationship advice, psychology, psychoanalysis, hypnotherapy and psychiatry.

The ITC consultation paper, which will be sent to all agencies in the advertising industry, and should lead to new rules being announced next year, suggests newscasters be allowed to advertise products. It also calls for a shorter time-ban than the two hours either side of children's programmes when toys cannot be advertised. It will not recommend that adverts are allowed for campaigning bodies such as Greenpeace or Amnesty International, a subject that will be reviewed by the government.

The full consultation, which should finish by the end of the year, lines up with the Human Rights Act, guaranteeing freedom of speech, which becomes law in October. Commentators in the industry have suggested the ITC is being forced to lift bans on the more controversial services to comply with the law. But Mr Locke insisted the ITC already took into account freedom of speech, and balanced it with its principles - which say that adverts should not be misleading, encourage or condone harmful behaviour, or cause widespread or exceptional offence.

He defended the proposal to advertise escort agencies and private investigators. "We shouldn't presume such agencies are perpetrating illegal acts, and, if they're not doing so, it's not clear that leads to a case for banning them, although the rules governing scheduling might need to be extended to buttress it."

The proposals were greeted with disquiet by Jocelyn Hay, chair of The Voice of the Listener and Viewer, who said she was "very concerned" about the endorsement of medical products by celebrities. "There seem to be very good reasons for not allowing any of these types of adverts, and we need to look very much more closely at this before radically changing regulation."

But the Advertising Association, the industry's umbrella body, and the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising, which represents 200 advertising agencies, said they welcomed the consultation. "We don't want a total deregulation but we would like to see the ITC take a more generalist approach and allow anything that's legal, honest and truthful," said Simon Gallang, the IPA's legal affairs consultant. "To have a blanket ban on something as innocuous as a private investigations agency doesn't make good sense, while escort agencies could be advertised on a subscription channel with a pin number." He added that he thought every advertisement should be looked at on its own merits.


Products and services which could be advertised under the new proposals

 Commercial services offering advice on personal or consumer problems

 Private investigation agencies

 Escort agencies

 Schemes in which people are employed at home, such as addressing envelopes or making toys or garments

 Instructional courses

 Products to treat alcoholism

 Clinics for the treatment of hair loss

 Pregnancy testing services

 Hypnosis, psychology, psychoanalysis, psychiatry, and hypnotherapy

webTitle: US women prepare for street battle over guns

fields.headline: US women prepare for street battle over guns
fields.standfirst: Million Mom marchers and Second Amendment Sisters plan rival protests as election year focuses attention on child firearm deaths
fields.trailText: Next weekend Washington will be the scene of a gun battle: between women who want tighter firearms control and women who regard any changes to the law as an attack on their constitutional rights.
fields.body:
Next weekend Washington will be the scene of a gun battle: between women who want tighter firearms control and women who regard any changes to the law as an attack on their constitutional rights.

While the Million Mom marchers will be lining up in Washington and 60 other American cities to state their case on Mothers' Day, next Sunday, a rival group called the Second Amendment Sisters is organising counter-demonstrations.

The event that triggered the Million Mom March was a gun attack last August on children at a Jewish community centre in Los Angeles by a neo-Nazi gunman. Donna Dees-Thomases, a New Jersey woman who works as a publicist for CBS, watched the reports of the shooting on the television news and decided that it was time to take to the streets. She registered a date for the march and the news spread like wildfire by word of mouth and the internet.

While aiming for a million marchers, the organisers predict that hundreds of thousands of mothers at least will participate throughout the country.

The talk-show hostess Rosie O'Donnell will chair the rally, and three mothers of children killed in the Dunblane school shooting in Scotland in 1996 will also speak. Mothers of children killed in gang fights or cross-fire in the US will address the crowd.

"We're not opposed to gun ownership," said Kim McKay, one of the march organisers. But the march aims to urge politicians, and particularly those running for office this year, to pledge themselves to support tighter licensing and registration of firearms, the introduction of child-proof locks on guns and mandatory waiting periods before purchases are completed.

One of the organisers of a rally in Los Angeles, Victoria Ballesteros, stressed that the march was for "mothers and others". "This is election year so what we wanted to do was bring this to the forefront," she said. She said that there was a lot of interest in the march and "a level of motivation from women who have never left their comfort zone before".

But the march organisers are facing angry opposition from a group called the Second Amendment Sisters, which has been given permission to stage a simultaneous counter-rally in Washington and a number of other cites. (The second amendment of the US constitution states: "A well-regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep and bear arms should not be infringed.")

The Dallas-based Sisters have responded to the Million Mom March by organising their own Armed Informed Mothers (Aim) march.

"We need you to help us send a million moms of our own to let congress know that these women [the Million Mom marchers] do not speak for all mothers," was the message sent out by the Sisters. The goup, which was formed in February, stresses that it is not funded by the National Rifle Association and comprises women of different political beliefs. Its published material assures potential supporters that they do not have to be "a rightwing extremist" to join the march.

The Sisters' website shows a young woman pointing a handgun and saying: "So, you want to see me naked?" The picture is captioned: "As seen by a would-be rapist (for about 0.2 seconds)."

One of the group's supporters, Brenda Flowers of Colorado Springs, is the mother of a teenager who shot herself. She said: "My precious daughter's wrongful behaviour is not a reason to restrict the American people from exercising our right to self-defence."

Both sides quote statistics to back up their arguments. The Million Mom marchers point out that 12 children are killed in the US every day by a firearm, and that 68% of the 31,000 murders every year involve guns. The Sisters say "830,994 criminal attacks" were stopped by firearms last year, and that every 13 seconds someone uses a gun in self-defence against a criminal.

What may exercise the politicians more is the statistic that 73% of women want tighter control of handguns, compared with 56%of men. Last week, the Democratic and Republican presidential contenders Al Gore and George W Bush clashed again on the issue, with Mr Gore accusing his rival of being effectively a pawn of the NRA.

Despite the proximity of the two rallies, both sides say they are anxious that there should be no trouble. The Sisters warned their supporters: "Don't go armed. Any weapons found will be confiscated."

President Bill Clinton yesterday heartily endorsed the Million Mom March. "What they're doing is a very noble and good thing," he said after meeting organisers. He voiced frustration at the refusal of Congress to toughen gun controls, saying: "I am subdued. I'm frustrated. I'm very sad."

webTitle: Women MPs lobby speaker for lifting of breastfeeding ban

fields.headline: Women MPs lobby speaker for lifting of breastfeeding ban
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The ban on public breast feeding in the House of Commons will be challenged today when a cross-party group of women ministers and MPs meets the speaker, Betty Boothroyd, to call for reform. Julia Drown, Labour MP for Swindon South, who discovered the ban when she wanted to feed her six-month-old baby in a Commons committee room, will press for a relaxation of the rules, backed by a new pressure group of ministers and women's representatives from all three main parties.
fields.body:
The ban on public breast feeding in the House of Commons will be challenged today when a cross-party group of women ministers and MPs meets the speaker, Betty Boothroyd, to call for reform. Julia Drown, Labour MP for Swindon South, who discovered the ban when she wanted to feed her six-month-old baby in a Commons committee room, will press for a relaxation of the rules, backed by a new pressure group of ministers and women's representatives from all three main parties.

Ms Drown says she has received many expressions of support from fellow parliamentarians since a ruling from the Speaker's office last month that breastfeeding was forbidden in committee rooms and in the Commons public gallery.

Ms Boothroyd may consider launching some form of inquiry to establish the level of demand for change.

The pressure group, led by equal opportunities minister Margaret Hodge and also including women's minister Tessa Jowell, Tory women's spokesman Caroline Spelman, and her Liberal Democrat counterpart Jackie Ballard, is urging better facilities for parents, whether MPs, staff or members of the public.

At present, MPs can use the family room for breastfeeding, but some say the facility is inappropriate. Members of the public are forced to use public lavatories.

webTitle: Brown plays key role as Dewar has heart op

fields.headline: Brown plays key role as Dewar has heart op
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar, was in intensive care last night recovering from heart surgery to correct a leaking aortic valve.
fields.body:
The Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar, was in intensive care last night recovering from heart surgery to correct a leaking aortic valve.

A spokesman for the first minister said his condition was stable after a three-hour operation to repair the faulty valve with a mechanical device.

He will be in Glasgow Royal Infirmary for the next 10 days and is not expected to return to work for at least another two months. Jim Wallace, his Liberal Democrat deputy, will take control of the Scottish executive during Mr Dewar's recuperaton, and the enterprise minister, Henry McLeish, will stand in for Mr Dewar as Scottish Labour leader.

However it emerged yesterday that the chancellor, Gordon Brown, will have a key role in filling the political vacuum created by Mr Dewarís absence. It is now understood that Mr McLeish will liaise with Mr Brown on how best to manage the political landscape in Scotland.

Alex Salmond, the Scottish National party leader, said Mr Brown's intervention was extraordinary. "This development simply confirms that Labour are a London-led party," he said.

Mr Dewar is expected to make a full recovery from his operation, which has been prompted by a heart condition known as aortic regurgitation.

The condition was discovered during routine hospital tests last month. It results in the aortic valve failing to close properly, causing blood to leak back into the left ventricle which forces the heart to work much harder.

Although the operation is major, it also fairly routine. However, Mr Dewar's is a serious illness and there is mounting speculation that he will not stand for a second term and will quit the executive sooner rather than later. His replacement - most likely to be Mr McLeish - would need time to settle in to the job of first minister and win over voters.

The news of Mr Brown's intervention north of the border came as it was reported that the government is preparing to scrap the Scotland Office. However Downing Street insists no decision had been made on its future.

webTitle: Bill Clinton to move in with mother in law

fields.headline: Bill Clinton to move in with mother in law
fields.standfirst: If Hillary wins New York, he will see her at weekends
fields.trailText: Faced with the prospect of post-presidential homelessness, Bill Clinton has revealed plans to move in with his mother-in-law in Arkansas.
fields.body:
Faced with the prospect of post-presidential homelessness, Bill Clinton has revealed plans to move in with his mother-in-law in Arkansas.

Dorothy Rodham, a stern Methodist who is fiercely protective of her daughter, is known to have been deeply unimpressed with her son-in-law's philandering, but Mr Clinton clearly believes he has been forgiven and will find shelter under her roof.

"I really like her. We get along great," he told journalists travelling with him on Air Force One over the weekend. He said he would stay in Mrs Rodham's condominium in Little Rock for a "couple of years" until the completion of his presidential library nearby.

The Clintons were the only First Couple in modern US history not to own a home of their own, until they bought a house in Chappaqua, New York, from where Hillary has been pursuing her senatorial campaign.

Assuming she wins and remains a New York resident, Mr Clinton said he would fly up to visit her at weekends but would spend most of his time in Little Rock, working on the library, which will house mountains of presidential correspondence, documents and mementos.

He is currently trying to raise the estimated $125m (£81.6m) it will cost to build. Presidential libraries normally take more than four years to finish, Mr Clinton said, but he hoped to have his completed sooner.

Mr Clinton is clearly aware that he risks appearing a pitiful and lonely figure since Hillary packed her bags for New York, and power begins to seep away in the last months of his presidency. His parents are dead and the Clintons' only child, Chelsea, is away at university.

In a spoof documentary screened at a press dinner earlier this month, he was filmed idling away his time in the White House mowing the lawn, doing the laundry and preparing his high-powered wife's packed lunches.

However, not even that essay in self-deprecation quite envisaged the humiliation, at the age of 53, of asking to use his mother-in-law's spare room. He grinned bravely on Sunday when he reminded reporters of the words of one of his predecessors, John Quincy Adams, who said: "There is nothing in life so pathetic as a former president."

There has been much press speculation about Mr Clinton's choice of future career, with options ranging from political pundit to Hollywood film producer. He played down suggestions that he would mastermind either his wife's senate campaign or Al Gore's presidential bid. "If they ask my advice, I give it to them," he said. "But it's way over-rated."

For analysts of the embattled Clinton marriage, the surprise announcement offers mixed signals. If Mrs Clinton wins the New York senate seat, the couple will clearly live apart, but the president still feels sufficiently part of the Rodham family to live with Dorothy. Or perhaps it simply means the world's most famous unfaithful husband is now less frightened of his mother-in-law than of his wife.

Dorothy Rodham, a stern Methodist who is fiercely protective of her daughter, is known to have been deeply unimpressed with her son-in-law's philandering, but Mr Clinton clearly believes he has been forgiven and will find shelter under her roof. "I really like her. We get along great," he told journalists travelling with him on Air Force One over the weekend. He said he would stay in Mrs Rodham's condominium in Little Rock for a "couple of years" until the completion of his presidential library nearby. The Clintons were the only First Couple in modern US history not to own a home of their own, until they bought a house in Chappaqua, New York, from where Hillary has been pursuing her senatorial campaign. Assuming she wins and remains a New York resident, Mr Clinton said he would fly up to visit her at weekends but would spend most of his time in Little Rock, working on the library, which will house mountains of presidential correspondence, documents and mementos. He is currently trying to raise the estimated $125m (£81.6m) it will cost to build. Presidential libraries normally take more than four years to finish, Mr Clinton said, but he hoped to have his completed sooner. Mr Clinton is clearly aware that he risks appearing a pitiful and lonely figure since Hillary packed her bags for New York, and power begins to seep away in the last months of his presidency. His parents are dead and the Clintons' only child, Chelsea, is away at university. In a spoof documentary screened at a press dinner earlier this month, he was filmed idling away his time in the White House mowing the lawn, doing the laundry and preparing his high-powered wife's packed lunches. However, not even that essay in self-deprecation quite envisaged the humiliation, at the age of 53, of asking to use his mother-in-law's spare room. He grinned bravely on Sunday when he reminded reporters of the words of one of his predecessors, John Quincy Adams, who said: "There is nothing in life so pathetic as a former president." There has been much press speculation about Mr Clinton's choice of future career, with options ranging from political pundit to Hollywood film producer. He played down suggestions that he would mastermind either his wife's senate campaign or Al Gore's presidential bid. "If they ask my advice, I give it to them," he said. "But it's way over-rated." For analysts of the embattled Clinton marriage, the surprise announcement offers mixed signals. If Mrs Clinton wins the New York senate seat, the couple will clearly live apart, but the president still feels sufficiently part of the Rodham family to live with Dorothy. Or perhaps it simply means the world's most famous unfaithful husband is now less frightened of his mother-in-law than of his wife.

webTitle: US shoppers start to lose confidence in GM food

fields.headline: US shoppers start to lose confidence in GM food
fields.trailText: Although most Americans would buy genetically modified foods, confidence is falling, and almost 40% of the population still has no knowledge of the issue, according to an opinion poll yesterday.
fields.body:
Although most Americans would buy genetically modified foods, confidence is falling, and almost 40% of the population still has no knowledge of the issue, according to an opinion poll yesterday.

A poll shows that 63% of shoppers would be very or quite likely to buy a new product genetically engineered to resist insect damage, down 14 points in the last four years, the supermarket industry's annual convention in Chicago was told.

And 54% say they are very or quite likely to buy food modified to taste better or stay fresh longer, compared with 58% in 1996.

Nearly four in 10 people have not heard of genetically altered food, the poll shows.

More than half this year's soya bean crop and a fifth of the maize plantings will be biotech varieties that are resistant to herbicides or insect pests. Biotech animals, including leaner pigs and fast-growing salmon, are being developed.

But some food companies have stopped buying genetically engineered ingredients, citing fears about consumer resistance, and McDonald's and one leading grocery chain have rejected them.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Muslim rebels release hostage
Islamic rebels in the Philippines have released a bank teller who was kidnapped three months ago, but yesterday were still holding 21 mostly foreign hostages amid mounting concerns about the deteriorating health of the captives.
fields.body:
Muslim rebels release hostage
Islamic rebels in the Philippines have released a bank teller who was kidnapped three months ago, but yesterday were still holding 21 mostly foreign hostages amid mounting concerns about the deteriorating health of the captives.

Patrick Viray was released on a highway on Jolo island, 600 miles south of Manila, on Sunday by Abu Sayyaf rebels. However, one of the more recently taken hostages, said to be the German Renate Wallert, was in a serious condition after suff ering a series of strokes. [Reuters, Jolo island]

Two more plead guilty to spying
Two more of the 13 Iranian Jews being held for espionage in Iran's controversial spy trial acknowledged working for Israel yesterday.

The development is certain to further exacerbate a growing row between Iran and its critics, who fear the accused can not receive a fair trial in Iran. Five suspects in all have admitted the charges, with the other eight due to appear before the Revolutionary Court when the trial resumes tomorrow. Nine Muslims also stand accused of taking a part in the alleged spying ring. [Reuters, Shiraz]

Air conditioner recycles death
Six people died in New York when an air conditioner in recycle mode absorbed carbon monoxide from a nearby faulty furnace and pumped it throughout the house while they slept, police said.

Andrei Kranz, 46, found the bodies of his parents, his two-year-old daughter, two house guests and a baby sitter on Sunday morning. His wife and daughter, 17, were visiting relatives in Romania. The air conditioner and furnace were in the same room in the house. [AP, New York]

US restarts range training
US navy war planes resumed training yesterday on the controversial Atlantic fleet bombing range in Vieques, Puerto Rico, using non-explosive ordnance, according to a navy spokesman. The training - which was carried out by aircraft based at the nearby naval station Roosevelt Roads - came just days after 222 protesters were detained and removed from the range by American forces. Two more protesters were detained yesterday, the spokesman said. [ AP, San Juan, Puerto Rico]

Israelis pursue bombing raids
Israeli warplanes raided suspected Hizbullah guerrilla positions near Khirbit Selm village in south Lebanon for the second consecutive day yesterday, the Israeli army and a security source said. There were no immediate reports of casualties. [Reuters, Tyre]

webTitle: Stakes rise in Brazil's land battle

fields.headline: Stakes rise in Brazil's land battle
fields.trailText: Brazil faces increasingly violent clashes involving the rural landless after a week in which one person died and hundreds were injured during nationwide protests demanding faster land reform.
fields.body:
Brazil faces increasingly violent clashes involving the rural landless after a week in which one person died and hundreds were injured during nationwide protests demanding faster land reform.

The invasion last week of property in 22 of Brazil's 26 states by members of the Landless Workers Movement (MST) was one of the largest mobilisations in the group's history and showed that it was broadening its range of targets.

More than 30,000 MST protesters invaded land and federal buildings including offices belonging to the country's central bank, finance ministry and agrarian reform ministry. In some areas, heavily armed police used smoke grenades and rubber bullets to quell the demonstrations. One 30-year-old man died near the southern city of Curitiba after being shot in the stomach.

The scale of the MST protests - which spanned the country from the Amazon to Rio de Janeiro - stunned President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who issued a flurry of measures including the creation of a special police force charged with dispersing illegal settlers from land and public buildings. He also said that if peasants squat on land, their efforts to gain land titles will be delayed by at least two years.

The measures struck at the heart of the MST's long-held strategy of winning land disbursements by ordering squatters on to the vast swaths of arable, unused plots across Brazil. Through the success of this strategy the MST became one of South America's most important social movements, helping to redress the balance of land distribution in the continent's largest country, where half of the land is owned by a handful of wealthy families.

But political analysts fear that Mr Cardoso's tough new measures may force the MST to become illegitimate, fuelling the radicalisation of a group that relies increasingly on confrontation with the government.

"The government may have backed them into a blind alley," said David Fleischer, professor of politics at the University of Brasilia. "It's possible that the radicals will persuade them to become even more radical. If they do, Brazil is going to have a lot more problems."

Jaime Callegari, one of the MST's national coordinators, echoed the sentiments. "The Brazilian countryside is a powder keg right now. The conflict is going to be tougher than ever in the coming months and it is only a matter of time before there is more violence."

As the MST steps up its actions hardline farmers have said that their patience is running out with peasants invading their land, with some saying that they will use guns to deter the squatters.

In what may turn out to be the first of many clashes, eight landless peasants in the state of Sergipe were injured last week when armed men drive them off property.

Since Mr Cardoso took power in 1994, his administration has given land titles to more than 250,000 families, more than were granted by his predecessors in the previous 30 years. But the MST says he distributing too little, too slowly and then refusing to give financial help to make the land productive.

The activists who stormed into buildings and farms last week aimed to put pressure on the finance minister, Pedro Malan, to release more money for small farmers. Members of the movement said they would not leave the federal buildings without securing a meeting with Mr Cardoso or Mr Malan, but they climbed down and left the properties after the president threatened to send in troops to evict them.

The protests have come at a price. The broad support enjoyed by the MST has eroded recently as an increasing number of people - particularly former sympathisers among thr middle classes - perceive the movement as becoming more political, more radical and more violent.

The violence has also provoked opposition from traditional allies on the left who question the movement's drastic actions when land reform is moving at a faster pace than ever before.

fields.headline: Pan Am crash debris 'taken away'
fields.standfirst: Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: A police officer raised serious concerns about the way evidence was handled in the early stages of the investigation of the Lockerbie bombing, a court heard yesterday at the trial of two Libyans accused of murdering 270 people.
fields.body:
A police officer raised serious concerns about the way evidence was handled in the early stages of the investigation of the Lockerbie bombing, a court heard yesterday at the trial of two Libyans accused of murdering 270 people.

On day four of the trial retired police officer Douglas Roxburgh, 63, said he had told the chief inspector of Dumfries and Galloway police that he was anxious about the way certain agencies were removing evidence in the aftermath of the 1988 bombing without logging it first with police.

Under cross-examination by defence counsel, Richard Keen QC, Mr Roxburgh told the Scottish court, sitting in the Netherlands, he was concerned that air accident investigation branch officials or British military explosives experts had removed a piece of aircraft wreckage.

Mr Roxburgh's concerns emerged shortly after he told the court of the painstaking operation to record and store the large amounts of debris which rained down on Lockerbie after Pan Am flight 103 was blown from the night sky.

Aircraft debris was transferred to a Ministry of Defence base, where investigators attempted to piece back together the Boeing 747.

But suitcases and bags were sifted through by police officers, who would decide what was needed for the inquiry and what could be returned to relatives.

Abdelbaset Ali Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah face charges of murder, conspiracy to murder and breaches of the aviation security act at the hearing at Camp Zeist in the Netherlands.

The Libyans are alleged by the crown to have been working for the Libyan intelligence services when they planted a bomb concealed in a Toshiba radio cassette recorder and triggered by a Swiss-made timer inside a suitcase which was eventually loaded on to Pan Am flight 103.

The lord advocate, Colin Boyd QC, will try to prove that one of 20 bomb timers bought by Libyan secret services from the Swiss firm MEBO was used to blow up the jumbo jet.

The accused Libyans plead not guilty to all three charges. They have lodged a special defence of incrimination, blaming two Palestinian terrorist organisations and a crown witness - thought to be an Iranian - for the bombing.

The trial, before Lord Sutherland, continues today.

webTitle: Upward crime trend deals blow to Straw's crusade

fields.headline: Upward crime trend deals blow to Straw's crusade
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The rise in recorded crime is beginning to gather pace amid fears among ministers that the "crusade against crime" by the home secretary, Jack Straw, will not prevent the crime rate going up between now and the general election.
fields.body:
The rise in recorded crime is beginning to gather pace amid fears among ministers that the "crusade against crime" by the home secretary, Jack Straw, will not prevent the crime rate going up between now and the general election.

Home Office figures published yesterday show that police recorded crime rose by 3% to 5.25m offences in 1999, confirming that last year the crime figures rose for the first time in six years.

The figures are bound to provide ammunition for the Conservative leader, William Hague, when he tries to build on the momentum of last week's local elections by attacking the government's record on crime at the annual conference of the Police Federation next week.

At the same time, new official figures show that a tougher approach is being taken throughout the criminal justice system, with the police less frequently letting people off with a caution and the courts sending more people to prison and using community penalties such as probation less frequently.

Although the number of people the courts are sending to prison "remains high", the prison population at the end of 1999 was 2,000 down, at 62,100, from a year before. The total fell because of the introduction of the home detention curfew which saw short term prisoners released early with electronic tags.

The number of people prosecuted in the courts remained relatively stable at 1.47m but there has been a switch in offences from the crown court to the magistrates' court. This is the result of the introduction in October 1997 of the need for defendants to enter a plea before they are allowed to opt for a crown or magistrates' court hearing.

The publication of the quarterly headline crime figures for the first time was accompa nied by the results of new Home Office research on attitudes to crime which show that politicians may have less to worry about than they think when it comes to rising crime figures.

Although recorded crime fell by 10% between 1995 and 1997, and had been falling since 1993, the British Crime Survey found that 59% of the public believes it was going up over this period and half believe it had "increased a lot".

The survey also found that the public has an exaggerated view of how much crime is violent. It found that nearly 80% of people think that a third or more of all recorded crime is violent. But only 8% of crime is recorded as violent, including the more serious woundings and assaults.

The public also believes courts are far softer than they are - half the public, for example, thinks that more than 40% of adult rapists are not jailed when the actual figure is less than 1%.

Some 80% of people still think that judges are out of touch.

fields.headline: Blair confronts Labour rebels
fields.standfirst: PM renews pledge on air traffic privatisation
fields.trailText: The chancellor and prime minister yesterday joined forces to steady Labour after the local elections debacle by insisting they would continue to take unpopular decisions, including the privatisation of the air traffic services, if they are for Britain's long-term good.
fields.body:
The chancellor and prime minister yesterday joined forces to steady Labour after the local elections debacle by insisting they would continue to take unpopular decisions, including the privatisation of the air traffic services, if they are for Britain's long-term good.

As many as 40 Labour backbenchers are expected to add to Labour's worries by rebelling over the issue in the Commons tonight.

Before the vote Tony Blair will insist that the part-privatisation is exactly the "tough and unpopular decision" his government will continue to take.

The chancellor also moved yesterday for the first time to try to talk sterling down by saying the present "sterling-euro exchange rate cannot be justified by any view of the long-term fundamentals".

Mr Brown said he understood "the great difficulties that the current fall in the euro is causing for British industry, particularly in manufacturing."

Nevertheless, he ruled out any short fix move to bring sterling down. Some union leaders have been pressing him to use the £20bn revenue from the mobile phone auction to buy euros and so raise its level.

Mr Brown tried to woo elderly voters by reminding them he was planning for the next parliament a means-tested pensioners' tax credit targeted at thrifty pensioners with modest savings.

The chancellor defended his strategy, saying the first priority was to tackle penioner poverty.

The next stage was to ensure that pensioners were not penalised for their thrift, and therefore to do more for penioners with modest occupational pensions and small savings.

Details of the credit will be published in the autumn by the social security secretary, Alistair Darling. Labour canvassers have reported deep anger over the basic pension, but Mr Darling rejected restoring the earnings link.

Downing Street acknowledged a presentational problem over the basic pension, but said the government would continue to target its resources on the poorest.

Mr Brown's chief target yesterday was the institutional investors in the City who control 45% of quoted city equity investments. He has already asked Paul Myners, who is chairing a review group into investment by City institutions, to report back to him in time for the next budget on the "herd instinct" amongst City investors.

Mr Blair, speaking today at the Periodical Publishers Association, will try to project an unruffled government committed to the long-term by saying he will continue to govern from the radical centre.

In his first speech since Labour lost nearly 600 council seats, he will claim: "Britain is already a different and better country, but there's a huge amount to do..

He will acknowledge poverty in Britain, insisting that a steady economic policy is the best means of protecting those "without the breaks of birth and wealth, those that cannot survive the violent shifts of boom and bust, and those that rely on increases in living standards not for luxuries, but to make ends meet".

He will contrast the radical centre both with "the old left which will not face up to the tough decisions" and with the the Tories "who will always govern for the many not the few".

fields.headline: Yesterday day, bad day
fields.trailText: Download of day
fields.body:
Download of day

Police are investigating allegations that pornography was downloaded from computers at the Welsh assembly. Equipment belonging to journalists who work at the assembly building in Cardiff bay was tam pered with outside office hours.

Good day

Sharon Grant, widow of Labour MP Bernie Grant, who is putting herself forward as a candidate to succeed him in his Tottenham seat. She said she was "not jumping to any conclusions" about being selected but had found that many constituents would like to see her husband's work continued by someone who had worked closely with him. Labour's candidate is due to be chosen later this month.

Today

Commons: Environment, transport and the regions questions.Transport bill, report. Westminster Hall: Debates on law and order in rural areas, ancient woodlands, tourism in Southend, and conduct of privatised utilties in The Wrekin. Lords: Financial services and markets bill, report. Debate on clothing and textile industry.

fields.headline: Home work for mothers
fields.trailText: Ministers are considering giving women the option of continuing their jobs from home after having children, the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will reveal today as the government comes under renewed pressure to improve new rights to parental leave.
fields.body:
Ministers are considering giving women the option of continuing their jobs from home after having children, the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will reveal today as the government comes under renewed pressure to improve new rights to parental leave.

In a speech outlining a review of the maternity and parental leave announced in the Budget, Mr Byers will make clear that the government could legislate to force employers to allow mothers to work in new ways.

He will indicate that higher maternity pay and a longer leave entitlement are likely outcomes of the review, which will lead to a green paper in the autumn.

Mr Byers, addressing a conference organised by the pressure group New Ways to Work, is expected to say: "Poor maternity benefits contribute to women returning to lower-skill jobs and reduced pay levels - wasting skills and talent."

The review will also examine the case for paid paternity leave. Many companies allow new fathers a few days off, though the leave is not always paid or guaranteed, and many fathers use holiday entitlement.

It will consider whether a new right to 13 weeks' unpaid leave, restricted to parents of children from birth to age five, could be extended to cover children aged up to eight, as in other European countries.

Cherie Booth QC will represent the TUC in a high court action next week challenging the government for denying the new entitlement to parents of children born before December 15 1999. The government is expected to lose the case, since the European commission has just overturned a decision by the Irish government to restrict implementation of the European directive granting parental leave.

Ministers have signalled that Labour will include a pledge on paid parental leave in its general election manifesto.

Mr Byers will stress the need to remove barriers to women returning to work, and to examine the benefits of "returning part-time, working from home or on flexible hours".

fields.headline: The euro-motor idles
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: The Franco-German motor idles and the euro sinks - no sign yesterday of any new initiative from euro-zone finance ministers - leaving Europe's personification, commission president Romano Prodi, to twiddle his thumbs.
fields.body:
The Franco-German motor idles and the euro sinks - no sign yesterday of any new initiative from euro-zone finance ministers - leaving Europe's personification, commission president Romano Prodi, to twiddle his thumbs.

His predecessor but one, Jacques Delors, took his cue from the extraordinary (and temporary) meeting of minds between German chancellor and French president. Kohl and Mitterrand agreed on the speedy creation of a single currency as the complement to a single market and Mr Delors delivered, more or less. Mr Prodi's tenure has coincided with the public relations disaster of euro depreciation; its economic significance so far has been to bolster euro-zone growth without apparently pushing up inflation.

Meanwhile doubts about enlarging the EU grow and they have not been assuaged by Mr Prodi's tendency to talk loud and carry a small stick. Yet it is not the choirmaster's fault if the singers use different scores. There, this week, was the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, telling the Czechs their accession to the EU will be done and dusted by the end of next year. Cool heads think the reform of EU institutions and domestic acceptance of Euro-norms by the candidates could take a lot longer. A miasma of confused purposes rises above Brussels. But, wait, Emma Udwin is coming to the rescue.

The former BBC correspondent has been recruited by the commission to advise on getting its message across - as part of a shake-up in personnel which sees an Irishman become head of the commission secretariat, a Brit head of press, an Italian leading Mr Prodi's think-tank and a Frenchman head of his cabinet. With these changes Mr Prodi puts his stamp on top personnel. In the longer run, however, the changes being sought lower down the hierarchy by Neil Kinnock will matter more. The continuing transformation of Mr Kinnock into a hard-nosed manager is a sight to behold.

His relationship with Mr Prodi is a key one - and the former Labour leader's denials of the spring plot story have been entirely convincing. But Mr Prodi has also to master and massage the dangerous liaisons between the EU's big players. Rome is out for the count. (Mr Prodi must wonder in the small hours what he still might do for his country.) London is credited with a new alignment, via Madrid, Lisbon, the Netherlands and Scandinavia, receptive to the Blairite mantra about flexibility and other "Anglo-Saxon" virtues. The force of international capital seems to be with it - witness this week's stock exchange merger and the premium it places on the EU's capacity to move quickly and lightly to regulate. But London's capacity to lead is hurt by its hesitation over the euro. If -the noises from Germany get more ominous - the project were to collapse, it is not clear either that British reluctance would find its reward.

Conventional wisdom, elegantly articulated the other day by Lord Hurd, says intergovernmental relations trump supranational powers every time so (this bit sotto voce ) his Tory colleagues' fears are entirely misplaced. But in an inter-governmental world all roads lead eventually to Paris and Berlin. EU movement will rest on the minimum that can be agreed between a lethargic German chancellor and a rivalrous and confused French president and prime minister. Somewhere in there Mr Prodi has to seek his platform - a realistic timetable for enlargement, big reform of EU governance, flesh on the bones of defence and security cooperation and a solution for the Polish farmers that will not frighten the taxpayers.

webTitle: Defining moment Mr Blair must keep his nerve

fields.headline: Defining moment Mr Blair must keep his nerve
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The pressure on Tony Blair is piling up. From the right, William Hague is stirring up the Tory hard core with atavistic talk on asylum and vigilante justice. From the left, Ken Livingstone is proving that elections can be won even when a candidate strays off the Blairite script. From within Labour, there are voices pleading for a return to more of the old-time religion, starting with a spending spree aimed at the "heartlands".
fields.body:
The pressure on Tony Blair is piling up. From the right, William Hague is stirring up the Tory hard core with atavistic talk on asylum and vigilante justice. From the left, Ken Livingstone is proving that elections can be won even when a candidate strays off the Blairite script. From within Labour, there are voices pleading for a return to more of the old-time religion, starting with a spending spree aimed at the "heartlands". Even around his own cabinet table, as we reported yesterday, there are those who grow panicky at the prospect of facing the voters a year from now. They fear Labour would lose a May 2001 poll and so urge Mr Blair to serve out a full, five-year term. Only then, they argue, will the government's reforms have begun to bear visible fruit. From every direction, it seems, Mr Blair is bombarded with pleas to change course.

The prime minister's response has been to insist that he will hold his nerve. That must be right. Voters are not fond of governments which can be blown off course by a few gusts of bad news. Proof of that came last week, when Mr Blair's hand-written defence of his administration in the Sun prompted not plaudits but a one-word headline: Rattled. Besides, the Cassandras are exaggerating the depth of Labour's despair. The Tories may have won 600 council seats in England last week, but they did so with slogans which put off the very centrist votes the party needs to win a general election: hence the defeat in the higher-turnout contest in Romsey. Mr Hague's rightward surge may help to solidify the Conservative base, but it poses little threat to Mr Blair. Even the London result is not as bad as it looks: Labour did badly, but not because of a public appetite to go right. So Mr Blair is right to stick to his strategy: let Labour hog the golden centre of British politics and leave the margins, where elections are lost, for others.

But Mr Blair cannot afford to be smug; he should listen to the message that was sent last week. He can begin by killing off the control-freak image - allowing, for instance, Labour's Nicky Gavron to serve as Ken Livingstone's deputy mayor if the party in London wants her to. But it also means heeding the demand for a clear sense of purpose from this government. Delivery of improved public services will make a difference when it comes: in the meantime Mr Blair needs to define anew what he and his party believe in - and why they should have another term to make it happen.

fields.headline: Eco-warror sent to psychiatric hospital
fields.trailText: France's most colourful eco-warrior, Eric Pététin, also known as The Indian, has been taken to a psychiatric hospital by gendarmes after his 12-year struggle to stop a road tunnel being built through a Pyrenean national park.
fields.body:
France's most colourful eco-warrior, Eric Pététin, also known as The Indian, has been taken to a psychiatric hospital by gendarmes after his 12-year struggle to stop a road tunnel being built through a Pyrenean national park.

Before his arrest at the weekend, he told the press that the police were preparing to lock him up as a "nutcase" to pre-empt a final assault on a plan which threatens the habitat of the last colony of French bears.

As the leader of a group called The Drop of Water, Mr Pététin has been fined about 30 times since 1988 and jailed eight times for protests along the rural Aspe valley, where a highway is also being built.

A judge at Pau, Thierry Pons, opened the way to confinement a fortnight ago when he ordered the eco-warrior, who is famous for the vulture's feather he wears in his hair, to undergo hospital tests after he was fined for destroying equipment used to build the EU-financed Somport tunnel between France and Spain.

Mr Pététin, whose protest has attracted support from thousands of European ecologists, said his occasional "irrational behaviour" was due to "smoking too much pot, or a bad night's sleep", not insanity.

But police said his arrest was provoked by a revolt more dangerous than irrational behaviour, and that he had been confined to a psychiatric hospital because he was mentally unfit to follow normal judicial procedures.

According to a gendarmerie report from Pau, a woman motorist said she was forced to hand over her car to Mr Pététin in the village of Oloron-Sainte-Marie on Sunday. "Police cars pursued the stolen vehicle through the streets after Pététin had been seen jumping on the roof shouting there were too many vehicles in the world and they should be eliminated," the report said. "His escape attempt caused several collisions."

A central government official signed the confinement order, but Mr Pététin's lawyers are expected to claim that it is an attempt to silence the former scientific researcher, who has been at the centre of environmental protests since 1968.

Surrounded by a dozen mostly middle class "tribesmen", the eco-warrior set up his headquarters in a disused railway station near the planned tunnel in 1988. A decision to evict the protesters led to a hunger strike last month. Several pitched battles have been fought on the frontier with Spain, killing one protester and injuring dozens.

A permanent police presence has not prevented repeated sabotage but has enabled construction work to go ahead, despite pledges by the Socialist-led government to scale down the project.

webTitle: Killers could not bear to hear the truth

fields.headline: Killers could not bear to hear the truth
fields.standfirst: Bombs in Madrid: special report
fields.trailText: Jose Luis Lopez de la Calle popped out as usual to get the newspapers on Sunday morning. As usual, he took a coffee and a croissant at a local cafe in the town of Andoain, in the Basque country, before walking home.
fields.body:
Jose Luis Lopez de la Calle popped out as usual to get the newspapers on Sunday morning. As usual, he took a coffee and a croissant at a local cafe in the town of Andoain, in the Basque country, before walking home.

A few minutes later, Mr Lopez de la Calle was dead, shot four times in the head and throat by two gunmen and left lying in a pool of blood. This was no random act of violence, no mugging gone wrong. This, said Spain's prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, was a planned assassination. Mr Lopez de la Calle's "crime" was to be a newspaper columnist for El Mundo who was fiercely critical of Basque separatist violence. His cowardly executioners were the benighted, blinkered thugs of ETA.

This tiny gang of murderers is one of the last remaining groups in western Europe which still apparently believes that violence expedites political ends. Last December, it actually regressed, ending a 14-month ceasefire. Since then, three more victims have been added to its total of over 800 dead. Other journalists have been targeted in recent weeks. The only political effect of this mindless carnage has been to strengthen the Spanish people's determination to vanquish terrorism, as shown again yesterday by nationwide remembrances for Mr Lopez de la Calle. ETA's methods have almost zero support in the Basque country where, in any case, only a minority of the population favours independence. But still the ETA killers, like men lost in time, cling to their craven illusions and delusions.

Mr Lopez de la Calle, aged 62, was a man of brave conviction. A communist jailed by Franco's forces during the civil war, he later became an ardent pacifist. His writings brought several death threats but he was undeterred. ETA is the Basque problem, he argued. "It is the product of an accumulation of lies," he wrote in his last column on May 2. "It favours the most violent political confrontation possible." ETA could not bear the truth. Mr Lopez de la Calle died for it.

webTitle: Boy, 12, stabbed to death in London street

fields.headline: Boy, 12, stabbed to death in London street
fields.trailText: A 12-year-old boy has been stabbed to death and his half-brother seriously injured in a vicious knife attack in the heart of Covent Garden, central London.
fields.body:
A 12-year-old boy has been stabbed to death and his half-brother seriously injured in a vicious knife attack in the heart of Covent Garden, central London.

Diego Pineiro died from multiple stab wounds within an hour of the attack on Sunday evening in the the area known as Seven Dials.

His brother was taken to a south London hospital but his injuries were said yesterday not to be life threatening.

A 52-year-old man, described by police as an acquaintance of the boys, was arrested at the scene after being disarmed and restrained by two waiters from a local restaurant.

Local residents and eyewitnesses said the man, known as Alex, was often seen talking to Diego and hanging around a playground in the courtyard of St Giles's church near the scene of the murder.

The attack took place shortly after 8pm at the busy junction as thousands of people enjoyed a balmy evening. Sheikh Salim, 26, a waiter at the Sartaj balti house on Earlham Street, described how he intervened after hearing a scream outside the restaurant.

"I heard this shriek and looked out and saw two boys running and a man chasing them," he said. "One of the boys tripped, clutching his legs, and the man grabbed the other one and started giving him what looked like small rabbit punches - it was only later I realised he was stabbing the boy

"I tried to grab him from behind but he was so tense I couldn't - then I wrestled him to the ground and he elbowed me in the ribs and I fell. Then I noticed my sleeve was all bloodstained, and I could see this boy on the ground covered in blood.

"My colleague had managed to get the man in a headlock by now and I heard this metallic noise and saw a bloodstained knife drop. We wrestled him to the ground and I put my foot on his neck until the police arrived."

Diego and his brother lived with their mother nearby in Charing Cross Road and attended a local school. The boys' mother was said to returning from Spain last night.

Ruth Shaw, 40, who lives near the scene, said: "The man used to hang around with the kids even though we told them not to go near him.

"He was a spooky sort of bloke; the hairs stood up on the back of your neck when you saw him."

Another neighbour who declined to be named said: "I know that the mother is away in Spain. I don't know where the father is. They've only lived here for a couple of years. I used to see the father from time to time. It is a tragedy, it didn't have to happen."

A roundabout in St Giles's courtyard bears graffiti thought to have been written by the man as a message to Diego. It says: "Remember - always cheat others before others can cheat you - if they're clever enough. I wasn't, and I wouldn't want to be!"

The message, in neat white capital letters, is dated November 2 1999. Underneath is scrawled: "Welcome back."

Floral tributes left at the scene included one from the police community action unit.

Commander Michael Fuller, of the serious crime group which is leading the investigation, said: "The murder of a young boy in a London street is shocking.

"I would like to praise the members of the public for their bravery in intervening to try to save this young boy's life and in detaining this man.

"I would appeal to anyone who has not already contacted the police to come forward."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Four hurt in rail crossing crash

Four people were taken to hospital after a train hit a car transporter at a level crossing in Cornwall yesterday. The transporter was dragged 20 yards along the track and several cars were damaged in the crash at Tregoss near Roche. The train and lorry drivers and two train passengers suffered minor injuries.

fields.headline: North prepares for hot summers
fields.trailText: Manchester, a city notorious for the abundance of its rainfall, was warned yesterday to provide extra shade on its streets as global warming prepares to send temperatures in the north-west soaring towards 38C (100F).
fields.body:
Manchester, a city notorious for the abundance of its rainfall, was warned yesterday to provide extra shade on its streets as global warming prepares to send temperatures in the north-west soaring towards 38C (100F).

Tourism officials from the region, who gathered in sunshine for the country's first conference to consider the impact of climate change on the industry, were advised to plant banks of trees and build other shelters to counter the threat of savage sunburn.

"Hot, dry summers will be good for cafe society in Manchester and Liverpool, but we will need to take precautions against sunstroke and skin cancers," said Kenny Boyd, sustainable development manager for Marketing Manchester, which organised the conference in Salford in partnership with the region's tourist boards and the environmental group Sustainability North-west.

"People who sit out in the sun will need to be aware of the risks, and of the danger of increased traffic pollution."

But delegates were also urged to take advantage of the weather changes that will develop through to the middle of the century and beyond.

By 2050 "average temperatures will rise by up to 5C and sea levels will rise by between 12 and 67cm. Wind speeds will intensify too," said Steve Connor of Sustainability North-west.

"But we want to examine how tourism might benefit. If temperatures are rising here, imagine what conditions will be like in the Maldives or Canaries. Some tourist destinations will become unbearable. Northern Europe could become a serious new destination."
