fields.headline: Healing the wounds
fields.standfirst:
We're on the brink of success in Northern Ireland - and that is why punishment beatings must stop
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: We're on the brink of success in Northern Ireland - and that is why punishment beatings must stop
fields.body:
True democracy has been a long time coming to Northern Ireland. But now after false dawns, the frustration of suspension, we are finally moving into a better future.

Last Friday the two governments made a commitment to revive the assembly and the executive. On Saturday, in response to that commitment, the IRA stated that they would put their arms beyond use, completely and verifiably.

How the parties respond will shape Northern Ireland forever. A positive response means nothing less than this: a future which guarantees political inclusion - government by the people for the people. A future free from violence, free from the tyranny of guns.

It is an irony that Northern Ireland, once the object of in tense scrutiny and sharp criticism, is now transforming itself into a world leader in the protection and promotion of human rights. The outcast is becoming a model - one for others not to condemn, but to emulate.

In the two years since it was brokered the Good Friday agreement has given us a new human rights commission - potentially a radical and groundbreaking body, the depth and weight of whose work I hope will grow.

From the Good Friday agreement has flowed reform of the RUC, to help them to make the transition from a security force to a community-based policing service, with the protection of human rights as its guiding principle.

And the agreement goes further. Its constitutional structures have the potential entirely to redefine the relationship between the people of Northern Ireland and their government: it actively seeks to bring government and citizen's closer together. Because democracy and rights go hand in hand.

It is drawing a new political landscape in which lively, constructive debate on the bread and butter issues that really matter eclipses the old, sterile politics of blame and counter-blame.

But this is a long revolution. I would be naive if I did not recognise that this is only the start of the process of reconciliation.

There are still wounds that will not heal on the stroke of midnight when we are able to restore devolved government:

 The paramilitary attacks that inflict terrible injuries. They have nothing to do with justice and everything to do with keeping communities divided and in fear. They have to stop if the ceasefires are to live up to their name and protestations of peace are to have any meaning. And that is a message I deliver today to all the paramilitary organisations.

 The arson attacks that wreck homes and wreck lives.

 Contentious parades.

We cannot place a sticking- plaster over these sores and hope that they go away. Because the problems - and the answers - lie in the very bedrock of this country.

Northern Ireland has rich traditions across both communities. Too often these traditions have had their image sullied by the insolent demands of a few for rights that cut across the rights of the many. But I believe that at their best these traditions make Northern Ireland what it is - a vibrant, creative society capable of great tolerance and inclusivity.

I want to build on, not suppress these traditions. I want to see a society which celebrates its diversity. A society in which Orange and Green can live side by side in mutual respect, as keen to protect each other's rights as their own.

But I know that those of us whose duty it is to ensure that rights are upheld equally across the community will be judged on what we achieve, not what we aspire towards. On how we dispense rights and how we handle competing claims. And on our treatment of symbols.

We must have the sensitivity to understand that upholding the rights of one group - however well meaning our intervention - can cut across the rights of others. Part of my job is to weigh competing interests. To make fine judgments and meet the - often very personal - criticism head on.

There has to be a sensitive use of symbols on both sides. One that recognises the equally legitimate identities and aspirations of both communities. That underscores the principle of consent that lies at the heart of the Good Friday agreement, and the legitimacy of Northern Ireland's position in the United Kingdom while a majority wishes it.

Because this society is united by a shared language, shared values and shared land. And those bonds are strong enough to encompass diversity of religion, of politics and of custom.

And in return the message is clear: this is a two-way street. All citizens must shoulder the same responsibility for the health of that society.

Inequality has blighted community relations and marred individual lives. It has left people alienated, feeling that they owe nothing to the wider community.

And this is why we, the politicians, keep pressing on. The people of Northern Ireland have the right to live in a modern democracy.

Peter Mandelson is secretary of state for Northern Ireland. Extracted from a lecture yesterday to the British Council

webTitle: Brass band tops off Tate's modern mood

fields.headline: Brass band tops off Tate's modern mood
fields.trailText: It is billed as the party of the year, with tickets rumoured to be changing hands for hundreds of pounds. Mick Jagger, Paul McCartney and Madonna will rub shoulders with the world's greatest artists at the launch of the Tate Modern Gallery on Thursday night. The prime minister and half the Cabinet will be there too, and they will all be grooving on down to the sound of a brass band from Stockport.
fields.body:
It is billed as the party of the year, with tickets rumoured to be changing hands for hundreds of pounds. Mick Jagger, Paul McCartney and Madonna will rub shoulders with the world's greatest artists at the launch of the Tate Modern Gallery on Thursday night. The prime minister and half the Cabinet will be there too, and they will all be grooving on down to the sound of a brass band from Stockport.

The Williams Fairey Works Brass Band, which practises in a hut behind the heavy engineering plant on the outskirts of Greater Manchester where several of the band members work, have been rehearsing their repertoire of acid house anthems - such as Voodoo Ray - for the third biggest night of their history.

The first was winning Brass Band World magazine's band of the decade title; the second was their recent English Masters win.

"That was like winning the Olympics," said artist Jeremy Deller, who has worked with the band for the past three years. "All the bands are very serious about what they do and those competitions in particular. This will be a bit of a laugh for them, a day off work and a chance to mix with the kind of people you don't see much around Stockport."

The band will do three sets between some contemporary dance and a new piece from Harrison Birtwistle. Their version of 1980s dance tracks Can You Party? and A Day in the Life will provide the soundtrack for the grand finale fireworks display over the Thames.

Mr Deller said the band's appearance "sent all the right messages" that contemporary art was not just for the chattering classes.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: <B> •Even now, 18 months into our own precarious ceasefire, it pains me a little to say this - but hats off to Mandy Mandelson for the apparent triumph in Northern Ireland... and I know Mandy would be the first to join me in removing headgear to our beloved Mo Mowlam for laying so much of the groundwork. Meanwhile, word reaches us that friends of weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown seek to give the credit elsewhere. They are putting it around that the real hero was Mr Tony's chief of staff, Jonathan Powell. Silly old Gordon. When will he learn that fanning the fires of the old feud only serves to make Mr T look the only conceivable leader? As for Mr Powell, how big a part he really played is anyone's guess. But it's hard to believe that the man best known, you will recall, for handing his tiny baby in to the hat check girl at the Groucho Club did it entirely on his own.

Meanwhile, word reaches us that friends of weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown seek to give the credit elsewhere. They are putting it around that the real hero was Mr Tony's chief of staff, Jonathan Powell. Silly old Gordon. When will he learn that fanning the fires of the old feud only serves to make Mr T look the only conceivable leader? As for Mr Powell, how big a part he really played is anyone's guess. But it's hard to believe that the man best known, you will recall, for handing his tiny baby in to the hat check girl at the Groucho Club did it entirely on his own.

A most shocking thing has happened, and BMW is responsible. I am too upset to go into it today. Perhaps tomorrow.

While awaiting the official opening of the Stephen Glover Spring Festival, we dip into Paper Dreams, Steve's account of the Independent's early days. What quickly strikes the reader is the utter lack of pettiness. When Andreas Whittam Smith makes Sarah Hogg assistant editor, he writes: "Andreas looked rather guilty because this was officially my exclusive title. I laughed it off as a triviality, though I felt in my heart that he should not have done it." I should say not. At the launch party, meanwhile, "Andreas makes a short speech, thanking everyone for their hard work," but fails to name-check Stephen "as I thought he might." What a big man. What a titan.

The loyalist Times devotes its splash yesterday ("Blair: the fightback starts now") and two inside pages to bolstering Mr Tony, and I am intrigued by a pictorial edition change. In the first edition, a picture of Mr T bringing mugs of coffee (soooo natural) to interviewers Phil Webster and Peter Riddell includes the head of his mother-in-law Gail Booth - the one who's going to look after the Christ child - poking around a door. However, for reasons we can barely guess at, this photo was replaced with three shots of Mr Tony pulling various simian faces. Why anyone objected to the original is odd, but it can hardly be a privacy thing... unless, of course, the Blairs have decided against releasing a single snap of the new baby.

As any remaining regular readers will know (see below for the latest defection) this column is a stickler for good manners, so we are not pleased that Labour GLA member and possible deputy mayor Nicky Gavron (former wife of Lord Bobby Gavron, our own erstwhile chairman) was not on time for yesterday's swearing-in of Ken and his merry team. Poorest of shows. Quango queen Nicky may be known at Haringey council as "the late Councillor Gavron", but that won't do now. Buck up.

The following has arrived in the post, written in blue biro on computer paper. "Dear Mr Norman, you are obviously under the impression that you are the epitome of wit," writes Ex-Reader of Essex. "Take that Tony Blair! Have some of this Dobbo! Let me assure you, you are not witty in the slightest. You are a pompous wanker. Now f*** off." Another one gone to the Indy.

webTitle: MPs recall anguish of first day in class

fields.headline: MPs recall anguish of first day in class
fields.standfirst:
Hague bored, Blunkett abandoned in alien world

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: On his first day at Greaseborough primary school in Rotherham, William Hague, five, ran away at lunch time determined never to return, turned off by the tedium of jigsaw puzzles.
fields.body:
On his first day at Greaseborough primary school in Rotherham, William Hague, five, ran away at lunch time determined never to return, turned off by the tedium of jigsaw puzzles.

The confession by the Tory leader is included in a collection of pieces by MPs - in equal parts moving, amusing, revealing and bizarre - describing their first day in the classroom.

Mr Hague's opinion of the claim that schooldays are the best of your life - a "pearl of wisdom which is used by grown-ups to entice children to school" - is shared by many politicians who conjure up powerfully their dread of the unfamiliar and unknown.

He said his protest "didn't wash much" with his parents, and he was back the next day at the South Yorkshire school, which he was told to be proud of because his grandfather had helped to build it.

"Thereafter I soon learned to love jigsaws and Greaseborough and never ran away again.

"Eventually I learned that, while they might not necessarily be the best of your life, schooldays are certainly great, and we should all make the most of them."

If Charles Kennedy's recollection is perhaps the funniest - "Arrive chez Miss Melvin, who doesn't accord suitable respect for he who one day intends to lead Lib Dems" - none captures the sheer anxiety of the occasion more than that of the education secretary, David Blunkett, on parting from his parents in Sheffield: "I shivered as we entered the coolness of what then seemed to me an enormous building. A peck on the cheek. 'Goodbye son,' and then they were gone.

"For the first time I was alone in the alien surroundings, cast adrift, abandoned. The anguish I felt was heart-wrenching as I stood bewildered, fighting back the tears, in the assembly hall of Manchester Road school for the blind. It was a boarding school. I was four years old."

The experience of Julian Lewis (Tory, New Forest East) on the first day of his infants class at Sketty school in Swansea in September 1956 was frightening and profound. Led through a disused, out of bounds air raid shelter by a "little creep" who then said he would snitch on him, Mr Lewis recounted how the incident taught him "three useful lessons: do not subordinate your own judgment for the sake of politeness; do not assume that strangers are well-intentioned towards you; do not unnecessarily put yourself in the power or under the control of others.

"Some say that schoolchildren should be sheltered from experiencing deceit. I disagree. It is better to learn to protect oneself from the petty tricks of children than to discover human nature only when an adult, facing greater dangers."

In the collection, put together by the Preschool Alliance, a lobby group for nurseries and playgroups, there are some fonder memories. "It was an innocent time in an innocent age, and I loved it," said Ian Cawsey (Labour, Brigg and Goole) of days linking arms and chanting "Who wants a game of US Cavalry?" or "Cowboys and Indians?"

Nigel Beard (Labour, Bexleyheath and Crayford) remembers handing over a blue bear made of rubber, a required material, to help the war effort.

The former Welsh secretary John Redwood, familiar in alien surroundings, recalls his bemusement as other children cried, clinging to their mothers: "The teacher was less fierce and demanding than I had feared."

Ann Widdecombe recalls her first day at Bridge Mary school in Gosport, Hampshire, but she was there "only a little while before going to live in a faraway place called Singapore".

The Labour peer Lady Rendell yesterday nominated a shortlist of six contributors - Mr Blunkett, Mark Fisher, Theresa May, David Maclean, Peter Brand and Matthew Taylor - from which an overall winner will soon be chosen. She preferred the stories "that small children would appreciate and understand" but ad mitted that she could not remember her own school days.

Jamie Cann (Labour, Ipswich) is one of many who can still smell the unpalatable food. "People had their school dinners on the desks, and I can remember the dreadful smell of stale cabbage." Helen Jack son (Labour, Sheffield Hillsborough) recalls: "My stubborn refusal to eat prunes and rice or sago has remained."

And there's this from Helen Brinton (Labour, Peterborough). "My eyes leapt as I saw the pudding: chocolate cake with thick, gooey chocolate custard. I asked for a large helping, took one mouthful and was promptly sick all over the table, my frilly dress and my new shiny shoes. To Mum's horror, I was then carted out on a makeshift bed and spent the afternoon sleeping in a back room of the nursery."

Charles Kennedy

Can wait actually. Annie Macgregor (four and a half) coming along track. Am in love with Annie. Long to say "nice day for a hug" but decide not PC. However, stop to pass time of day. Trouble is, time of day passes. Sploshing late through mud. Fall. Smartness not enhanced. Arrive chez Miss Melvin, who doesn't accord suitable respect for he who one day intends to lead Lib Dems.

William Hague

By lunchtime on my first day I had decided Greaseborough primary was not for me, and I went home determined not to return I was, of course, eventually tackled by my mother and, after she had told me off for not liking school, she demanded an explanation. I just looked at my mum and said, quite simply: "I don't like jigsaws."

David Blunkett

All I had ever known before was my home and garden and a bit of the immediate neighbourhood. Now for the first time I was alone in the alien surroundings, cast adrift, abandoned. The anguish I felt was heart-wrenching as I stood bewildered, fighting back the tears, in the assembly hall of Manchester Road school for the blind. It was a boarding school. I was four years old.

John Redwood

I was rather surprised to see other children clinging to their mums, crying, not keen for them to go. I felt, well now we're here let's do something. What are we in for today?

Ann Widdecombe

A terrible thing happened. I left through the wrong gate and could not find my mother. She was very upset because she could not find me. Then another mummy with two children carrying blue balloons asked me why I was standing at the gate, and she took me back across the playground to where my mother and Anda Panda [Ann's cuddly toy] were waiting.

Peter Lilley

The one thing I remember about my first days at school was the assembly. We all stood in a circle and were told to close our eyes to say our prayers. Then one girl said: "Please, Miss, Robert hasn't got his eyes closed." That seemed to me a silly thing to say, since she could only tell Robert had his eyes open if she had her eyes open as well. But the teacher only told off Robert, which seemed a bit unfair.

Tim Loughton (C, Worthing East and Shoreham)

Bestest friend Billy lumbers

into view

Quickly form a gang, he'll

know what to do

We hunt down the playdough,

others take our cue

One hour later, carpet no

longer looks new.

Julian Lewis (C, New Forest East)

The playground still contained several air raid shelters. Against my better judgment, I allowed a new "friend" to lead me into one of these dark chambers. When we were far enough inside for me to have difficulty in finding my way out again, he said: "We're not supposed to come in here. I'm going to tell the teachers, and you'll get in trouble."

"Eventually I learned that, while they might not necessarily be the best of your life, schooldays are certainly great, and we should all make the most of them." If Charles Kennedy's recollection is perhaps the funniest - "Arrive chez Miss Melvin, who doesn't accord suitable respect for he who one day intends to lead Lib Dems" - none captures the sheer anxiety of the occasion more than that of the education secretary, David Blunkett, on parting from his parents in Sheffield: "I shivered as we entered the coolness of what then seemed to me an enormous building. A peck on the cheek. 'Goodbye son,' and then they were gone. "For the first time I was alone in the alien surroundings, cast adrift, abandoned. The anguish I felt was heart-wrenching as I stood bewildered, fighting back the tears, in the assembly hall of Manchester Road school for the blind. It was a boarding school. I was four years old." The experience of Julian Lewis (Tory, New Forest East) on the first day of his infants class at Sketty school in Swansea in September 1956 was frightening and profound. Led through a disused, out of bounds air raid shelter by a "little creep" who then said he would snitch on him, Mr Lewis recounted how the incident taught him "three useful lessons: do not subordinate your own judgment for the sake of politeness; do not assume that strangers are well-intentioned towards you; do not unnecessarily put yourself in the power or under the control of others. "Some say that schoolchildren should be sheltered from experiencing deceit. I disagree. It is better to learn to protect oneself from the petty tricks of children than to discover human nature only when an adult, facing greater dangers." In the collection, put together by the Preschool Alliance, a lobby group for nurseries and playgroups, there are some fonder memories. "It was an innocent time in an innocent age, and I loved it," said Ian Cawsey (Labour, Brigg and Goole) of days linking arms and chanting "Who wants a game of US Cavalry?" or "Cowboys and Indians?" Nigel Beard (Labour, Bexleyheath and Crayford) remembers handing over a blue bear made of rubber, a required material, to help the war effort. The former Welsh secretary John Redwood, familiar in alien surroundings, recalls his bemusement as other children cried, clinging to their mothers: "The teacher was less fierce and demanding than I had feared." She preferred the stories "that small children would appreciate and understand" but ad mitted that she could not remember her own school days. Annie Macgregor (four and a half) coming along track. Am in love with Annie. Long to say "nice day for a hug" but decide not PC. However, stop to pass time of day. Trouble is, time of day passes. Sploshing late through mud. Fall. Smartness not enhanced. Arrive chez Miss Melvin, who doesn't accord suitable respect for he who one day intends to lead Lib Dems. William Hague By lunchtime on my first day I had decided Greaseborough primary was not for me, and I went home determined not to return I was, of course, eventually tackled by my mother and, after she had told me off for not liking school, she demanded an explanation. Now for the first time I was alone in the alien surroundings, cast adrift, abandoned. The anguish I felt was heart-wrenching as I stood bewildered, fighting back the tears, in the assembly hall of Manchester Road school for the blind. It was a boarding school. I was four years old. John Redwood I was rather surprised to see other children clinging to their mums, crying, not keen for them to go. I felt, well now we're here let's do something. What are we in for today? Then one girl said: "Please, Miss, Robert hasn't got his eyes closed." That seemed to me a silly thing to say, since she could only tell Robert had his eyes open if she had her eyes open as well. But the teacher only told off Robert, which seemed a bit unfair. Tim Loughton (C, Worthing East and Shoreham) Bestest friend Billy lumbers into view Quickly form a gang, he'll know what to do We hunt down the playdough, others take our cue One hour later, carpet no longer looks new. Julian Lewis (C, New Forest East) The playground still contained several air raid shelters. Against my better judgment, I allowed a new "friend" to lead me into one of these dark chambers. When we were far enough inside for me to have difficulty in finding my way out again, he said: "We're not supposed to come in here. I'm going to tell the teachers, and you'll get in trouble."

fields.body:
The Ulster Unionist council, referred to yesterday in our page 3 report, Now it's over to the unionists, is due to meet on Saturday, May 20 (not Friday, May 20). Mr Trimble's assembly team was originally 28 strong, not 20.

In our review of the film, The Last September, page 5, Friday Review, May 5, we mistakenly credited the Polish composer Zbigniew Preisner as the cinematographer. In fact, he wrote the score for The Last September. Slawomir Idziak, who worked with Preisner on Kieslowski's films, was the cinematographer.

In a report headed Cost put at $1bn as love bug mutates, page 10, May 6, we said the program was written in Virtual Basic. The correct term is Visual Basic Scrip.

In a report, Computer scandal 'cover-up', page 14, May 5, we credited the source of the story as Computing Weekly. In fact, the publication is Computer Weekly. Apologies.

Sean Hughes became the author of The Silver Tassie, in our TV note on the opera based on the play, page 62, The Guide, May 6, depriving Sean O'Casey of a tiny portion of fame.

We said in a book review, page 9, Saturday Review, May 6, that "Darwin was particularly troubled by the peacock whose exuberant tail appeared to flaunt the logic of natural selection." We meant to say that in flaunting its tail it appeared to flout the rules.

fields.headline: Let's keep quiet
fields.standfirst:
Britain's record is murky. It is no wonder Mugabe is still angry

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The observers' verdict on the Zimbabwe election was tough. There was intimidation of voters and obstruction of candidates. The publicly owned media were biased. In parts of the country elements of the security forces operated as a "political army", and the government ought to have confined them to camps instead of allowing them to terrorise citizens.
fields.body:
The observers' verdict on the Zimbabwe election was tough. There was intimidation of voters and obstruction of candidates. The publicly owned media were biased. In parts of the country elements of the security forces operated as a "political army", and the government ought to have confined them to camps instead of allowing them to terrorise citizens.

Zimbabwe under Robert Mugabe? No, this was the view of the 11-nation Commonwealth team which observed how the British government and its proconsul Lord Soames ran the elections of 1980 which finally brought Southern Rhodesia, as it then was, to independence. In the thousand of words written about the current clash between Britain and the president of Zimbabwe, almost nothing has been said about Britain's murky performance in the country's historic transition from being a white-run colony to a one-person-one-vote democracy.

You did not have to be Mr Mugabe to suspect that Britain hoped he would lose that first majority-rule election. It was clear to every reporter who covered the campaign. More than that, the governor and his staff did as much as they legally could to turn their hopes into action. They tried every conceivable trick to prevent him winning.

There was talk of banning Mr Mugabe's party Zanu-PF from campaigning in parts of the country. Lord Soames announced he might not recognise the result in some constituencies if he felt there had been irregularities. His staff warned of possible coups by the white Rhodesian forces if the wrong people, ie Mugabe, seemed to be ahead. The governor toyed with all manner of potential coalitions in order to prevent Mr Mugabe taking power, even if he won the majority of parliamentary seats.

The biggest scandal was the way Lord Soames and his officials, in collusion with the Rhodesian army, turned a blind eye to gangs of black thugs, known as "auxiliaries", who were loyal to the puppet black prime minister, Bishop Abel Muzorewa, who had been rushed into office to replace the racist Ian Smith. The 35,000 "auxiliaries" mainly operated in the Shona villages where the bulk of Mr Mugabe's supporters lived. Because they were part of the official white-led security forces, who were laughably deemed to be "neutral", Lord Soames never reined them in.

Twenty years later Mr Mugabe is still making political capital by berating Britain. Many of his reasons are opportunistic and unjustified. But his bitterness with Britain for almost stealing his election victory in those majority-rule elections of 1980 undoubtedly still rankles. It must be a factor in his anger and suspicion today, and British politicians ought not to forget it. Aggressive hectoring about the values of democracy does not sit well when it is measured against Britain's own record in Rhodesia.

Fortunately, the vote total which Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF amassed in February 1980 was so overwhelming, in spite of Britain's efforts at manipulation, that his victory could not be tweaked away without precipitating a return to guerrilla war. Fortunately, too, the Soames team were so confident before the poll in thinking they had sidelined Mr Mugabe that they had no fall-back position. They were stunned and shocked when his votes piled up but at least they had the realism to accept the result.

Zanu-PF acted cleverly to escape the intimidation by the "auxiliaries" and deceive the Soames people. I remember covering a Zanu-PF rally two days before the poll in Chinai, a remote area of Mashonaland. Hundreds of people were about to set off on a 48-hour march to the nearest polling station (a shortage of polling stations was one of the government's many techniques). "If you meet any auxiliaries on the way, and they ask you how you're going to vote," a party organiser told the rally, "tell them 'Muzorewa' so they don't assault you. Your vote is secret so you can still vote for Zanu-PF." It worked and the Zanu-PF total was much higher than Lord Soames or the Thatcher government in London expected.

This is not to say that Mr Mugabe's people did not also use intimidation on occasion. A number of organisers for the rival guerrilla party, the Patriotic Front, were beaten up. Some were killed. But the final report of the Commonwealth observers concluded that "intimidation by the guerrillas was by no means as widespread or brutal as official spokesmen claimed". It said Lord Soames' failure to confine the auxiliaries to camps "was a major factor in the ensuing intimidation", since their activities "were very much worse than government spokesmen were ever prepared to admit". Its interim report had slammed Lord Soames and his team for "a lack of a sufficient degree of impartiality in dealing with the interests of the different parties".

It is no surprise if Mr Mugabe has not forgotten all this, though it is odd that Peter Hain, Britain's "minister for Africa" seems to have. He was a stern critic of British colonial policy and the Soames operation at the time, and Robin Cook also took a similar position in those days.

The past gives no one a blank cheque, and there is plenty of cause for concern over Mr Mugabe's activities now. He appears to be playing fast and loose with the democratic process, and allowing his activists to use intimidation on a broad scale. He only ratcheted up the latest crisis over the unequal distribution of land after he lost the referendum on the constitution earlier this year. But it is a technique he has used at every election before. This year it just happens to be worse because the opposition to Zanu-PF is stronger, more credible, and better organised than ever.

The right response for outsiders is to ensure enough observers go to Zimbabwe to scrutinise the process. Their presence may help to convince voters that the ballot is secret, just as - ironically - Mr Mugabe's organisers did at those village rallies in 1980.

But the first priority is to make sure that Mr Mugabe indeed calls the election. South Africa and other Commonwealth friends have been working quietly to press him into taking the plunge. Britain, however, is the last country which should seek to take the lead. It lost its credentials through 15 years of tolerating Ian Smith and then with its role in the 1980 election. The government would be better advised to keep quiet rather than look as though they are vindictively trying to reverse the results of a duel which Mrs Thatcher lost two decades ago.

webTitle: Fresh start school threatened with closure

fields.headline: Fresh start school threatened with closure
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government's fresh start rescue strategy for failing schools suffered a further blow yesterday when the first school to take part in the scheme was threatened with closure.
fields.body:
The government's fresh start rescue strategy for failing schools suffered a further blow yesterday when the first school to take part in the scheme was threatened with closure.

Local education chiefs said Firfield community college in Newcastle upon Tyne had failed to attract sufficient numbers of pupils since reopening with a new name and new staff less than two years ago, leading to a "substantial budget deficit".

The mixed comprehensive - previously known as Blakelaw school - hit the headlines as the first to be rescued under the so-called fresh start scheme, announced by the incoming Labour government as a drastic measure for turning around failing schools in inner-city areas. At the time Blakelaw had one of the worst examination performance rates in the country with high pupil truancy levels and demoralised staff.

The school reopened in September 1998 with £1.5m of government funds, promising pupils a new start under new management.

But the school hit problems last March when its head, Carole McAlpine, resigned to take up a post at an education action zone in Norfolk. She was one of three £70,000-a-year "superheads" running the 10 fresh start schools to quit within days of each other, in an apparent vote of no confidence in the scheme.

Yesterday parents received a letter from Newcastle city council outlining its plans to close the school, along with West Denton school in the same area, and inviting them to approve or reject the closure proposals.

Education chiefs from the city council will travel to London later this week to meet senior officials from the Department for Education to discuss the proposals.

The school, which has a capacity of 700, has only 433 pupils on its books. This lack of pupils has led to budget deficit in the region of £200,000. It persuaded only 43 primary pupils to make it their first choice of secondary school this year.

Yesterday, Newcastle city council's education chairman Keith Taylor said: "We are looking at new ideas which could have a positive impact on education in this area and creating a new and better school which has a wide appeal to residents throughout the city.

"Our consultation process has already begun. We will be considering carefully all possible options and discussing these fully with parents, staff and governors."

A spokesman for the Department for Education commented last night: "For the time being this is a local matter. There will be meetings but we don't have the final say."

He added: "Giving schools a fresh start is an important part of the government's drive to raise standards in inner city areas."

There were "some good early signs" in fresh start schools, he said. "We expect that investment in these schools will be worthwhile."

fields.headline: Deadly cost of opposing Mugabe
fields.standfirst:
A farmer who returned home to pay his workers is beaten to death in his carport
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: A hit squad murdered Alan Dunn here on Sunday. Six men dragged him from his home and bludgeoned him with concrete blocks. In less than 10 minutes the farmer was lying unconscious in a pool of blood with a fractured skull, broken arms and internal injuries. He died yesterday.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  at Maasplein Farm, Beatrice
fields.body:
A hit squad murdered Alan Dunn here on Sunday. Six men dragged him from his home and bludgeoned him with concrete blocks. In less than 10 minutes the farmer was lying unconscious in a pool of blood with a fractured skull, broken arms and internal injuries. He died yesterday.

The killing provides fresh evidence that Zimbabwe's president, Robert Mugabe, is continuing a campaign of violence against supporters of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

The murder brings to 19 the number of MDC backers killed by Mugabe supporters since April 1. The dead include white farmers, black farm labourers, city residents and peasants.

The MDC, which said a dozen serious assaults on members had been reported in 24 hours, accuses Mr Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party of trying to intimidate voters before parliamentary elections.

In the first reported revenge attacks, two black farm workers were beaten up by white men in incidents yesterday.

Charles Mlambo, 45, was walking to the post office in Beatrice, about 40 miles south of Harare, when four white men drove up in a car.

"They said do you know that Dunn is dead? I said I don't know anything and they said: 'You will tell us' and then started beating me," he said. Mr Mlambo was treated at a local hospital for bruised ribs, legs and arms.

Witnesses said that another man was beaten by a group of unidentified white men, but managed to escape. Police are investigating the incidents.

Dunn was a local MDC official, as well as a leading employer in Beatrice. After receiving death threats he left his farm two weeks ago. He returned at the weekend to pay his workers and to let his three teenage daughters pack for the start of a school term.

His wife and daughters were on the front veranda when he answered a knock on the back door. The men beat him to death in his carport.

Dunn's farm was not one of the 1,200 occupied by Mugabe supporters. "This is not about the land issue. Alan Dunn was an MDC supporter and maybe that has something to do with it," said Jerry Grant, deputy director of the Commercial Farmers' Union, which represents 4,500 farmers.

Many of Dunn's 180 workers have no doubt about the murderers. "He was killed by Zanu-PF supporters because they knew he backed the MDC," said Tendai Mahoso. "He was a very good man and a very good employer - if we had any problems, he helped us. He even helped people on the [government] resettlement scheme by giving them fertiliser and transporting their crops to the market."

Mr Mahoso said he had been worried for the farmer's safety. "There were some strangers who came and asked questions. They found out that Mr Dunn came back to the farm to pay us. I had fear in my heart so I went to Mr Dunn and I told him to leave. He told me not to worry and now he is dead. I loved Mr Dunn."

"It is part of a terror campaign that has been going on for the last three months," the MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, said yesterday. "White farmers who support the MDC are seen as a challenge to Zanu-PF and they are made to pay - some with their lives."

But Chenjerai Hunzvi, leader of the war veterans who spearheaded the invasion of white-owned farms, was unmoved. "There is nothing to say. He is dead," he said.

On Sunday Mr Hunzvi told British passport holders to leave Zimbabwe: "This is not Zimbabwe/Britain. This is Zimbabwe on its own. We are now going to search for those people with British passports [and tell them] to leave our country. They are not Zimbabweans and they are the ones who are causing lots of problems as far as we are concerned."

Tendai Mahoso does not share Mr Hunzvi's view. "Mr Dunn was one of those white people who helped us. Now who will give people free transport? The government? I don't think so."

Witnesses said that another man was beaten by a group of unidentified white men, but managed to escape. Police are investigating the incidents. Dunn was a local MDC official, as well as a leading employer in Beatrice. After receiving death threats he left his farm two weeks ago. He returned at the weekend to pay his workers and to let his three teenage daughters pack for the start of a school term. His wife and daughters were on the front veranda when he answered a knock on the back door. The men beat him to death in his carport. Dunn's farm was not one of the 1,200 occupied by Mugabe supporters. "This is not about the land issue. Alan Dunn was an MDC supporter and maybe that has something to do with it," said Jerry Grant, deputy director of the Commercial Farmers' Union, which represents 4,500 farmers. Many of Dunn's 180 workers have no doubt about the murderers. "He was killed by Zanu-PF supporters because they knew he backed the MDC," said Tendai Mahoso. "He was a very good man and a very good employer - if we had any problems, he helped us. He even helped people on the [government] resettlement scheme by giving them fertiliser and transporting their crops to the market." Mr Mahoso said he had been worried for the farmer's safety. "There were some strangers who came and asked questions. They found out that Mr Dunn came back to the farm to pay us. I had fear in my heart so I went to Mr Dunn and I told him to leave. He told me not to worry and now he is dead. I loved Mr Dunn." "It is part of a terror campaign that has been going on for the last three months," the MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, said yesterday. "White farmers who support the MDC are seen as a challenge to Zanu-PF and they are made to pay - some with their lives." But Chenjerai Hunzvi, leader of the war veterans who spearheaded the invasion of white-owned farms, was unmoved. "There is nothing to say. He is dead," he said. On Sunday Mr Hunzvi told British passport holders to leave Zimbabwe: "This is not Zimbabwe/Britain. This is Zimbabwe on its own. We are now going to search for those people with British passports [and tell them] to leave our country. They are not Zimbabweans and they are the ones who are causing lots of problems as far as we are concerned." Tendai Mahoso does not share Mr Hunzvi's view. "Mr Dunn was one of those white people who helped us. Now who will give people free transport? The government? I don't think so."

fields.headline: Oxfam replies to Clare
fields.trailText: Given we share the same aim of securing high-quality basic education for all the world's children, I am disappointed Clare Short misrepresented Oxfam's position (Letters, May 5). At the Dakar conference, we were calling for a global action plan aimed at mobilising political will and generating additional resources from governments, aid and debt relief in support of national education plans. To caricature this as a separate aid fund is inaccurate and unhelpful. The core objective is to ensure no government which is genuinely committed to achieving universal primary education should fail through lack of resources: wording along these lines was included in the Framework for Action agreed at the conference. But for this promise to become a reality, it must be backed up by a mechanism for achieving it.
fields.body:
Given we share the same aim of securing high-quality basic education for all the world's children, I am disappointed Clare Short misrepresented Oxfam's position (Letters, May 5). At the Dakar conference, we were calling for a global action plan aimed at mobilising political will and generating additional resources from governments, aid and debt relief in support of national education plans. To caricature this as a separate aid fund is inaccurate and unhelpful. The core objective is to ensure no government which is genuinely committed to achieving universal primary education should fail through lack of resources: wording along these lines was included in the Framework for Action agreed at the conference. But for this promise to become a reality, it must be backed up by a mechanism for achieving it.

That is why we proposed the plan, supported at Dakar by a coalition of 400 NGOs and teachers' unions from over 100 countries. It was reflected in the final document agreed at the conference which committed the international community to "develop a global initiative aimed at developing strategies and mobilising the resources needed to provide effective support to national efforts". The challenge is to turn these words into action, and we believe that the government is well-placed to play a leading international role. Given Clare Short's excellent record on education, we hope that she will seize this opportunity.
David Bryer
Director, Oxfam

fields.headline: No bias in my reporting
fields.trailText: I am the BBC correspondent whom Geneive Abdo (Comment, May 5) accuses of bias in my reporting of the Shiraz Jewish spy trial. To support a general assertion that "in most of these reports, there was an assumption the suspects were innocent", she cites a TV feature I did on the Jewish community in Shiraz and the anxieties aroused by the trial. She quotes "Iranian commentators" as pointing out that in my piece, not one Iranian was interviewed who "represented the judiciary's point of view". Ms Abdo overlooks the fact that in the first interview, the chief defence lawyer of the accused Jews, Ismail Nasseri, says: "This is not a trumped-up case. They've allowed qualified lawyers to study the files, to meet the accused, and defend them in court. All this outside pressure on Iran may be counterproductive ..."
fields.body:
I am the BBC correspondent whom Geneive Abdo (Comment, May 5) accuses of bias in my reporting of the Shiraz Jewish spy trial. To support a general assertion that "in most of these reports, there was an assumption the suspects were innocent", she cites a TV feature I did on the Jewish community in Shiraz and the anxieties aroused by the trial. She quotes "Iranian commentators" as pointing out that in my piece, not one Iranian was interviewed who "represented the judiciary's point of view". Ms Abdo overlooks the fact that in the first interview, the chief defence lawyer of the accused Jews, Ismail Nasseri, says: "This is not a trumped-up case. They've allowed qualified lawyers to study the files, to meet the accused, and defend them in court. All this outside pressure on Iran may be counterproductive ..."

The piece reflected the widespread belief I found among the Shiraz Jewish community - right or wrong - that the 13 Jews were not guilty of spying. If Ms Abdo has found Jews in Shiraz who say their coreligionists are spies, she has succeeded where I failed. I made no attempt to weigh the judicial evidence. It would have been impossible, since the evidence had not been made public. It still has not, apart from the confessions which I reported fully and without value judgments when they were made.

If the report was singled out as an example of a wider bias in my reporting, I challenge her to provide chapter and verse on that. She will not find it, because without seeing the evidence, I have not been able to form a judgment one way or the other.
Jim Muir
BBC Tehran correspondent

fields.headline: A people's mayor
fields.trailText: Local government has often been made the fall guy by central government, sometimes unfairly, but sometimes due to the failure of councillors and officers to match the civic virtues and municipal vision that ought to go with locally elected councils (Slow death of local government, May 8). It looks now as though there is no going back to the old committee system that variously gave councillors clout or left them brain dead through agenda overload. The choices are between cabinet/scrutiny systems - generally a recipe for secrecy and floundering - or directly elected mayors. There are a lot of potential disadvantages to elected mayors, not least Mr or Ms Big cosying up to business, fulfilling Roy Hattersley's worst nightmares.
fields.body:
Local government has often been made the fall guy by central government, sometimes unfairly, but sometimes due to the failure of councillors and officers to match the civic virtues and municipal vision that ought to go with locally elected councils (Slow death of local government, May 8). It looks now as though there is no going back to the old committee system that variously gave councillors clout or left them brain dead through agenda overload. The choices are between cabinet/scrutiny systems - generally a recipe for secrecy and floundering - or directly elected mayors. There are a lot of potential disadvantages to elected mayors, not least Mr or Ms Big cosying up to business, fulfilling Roy Hattersley's worst nightmares.

On the other hand, elected mayors could be used to forge a new, progressive set of ideals based upon local coalitions interested in advancing radical community involvement, neighbourhood management of services, environmental improvement and expanded education and leisure opportunities. This new agenda, encapsulating the benefits of living in a city, might be easier to focus in the context of an elected mayor, and certainly in Newcastle numbers of us are now planning a people's campaign for a people's mayor.
Cllr Nigel Todd
Newcastle upon Tyne
nigel.todd@newcastle.gov.uk

 A Millbank official says: "This is a disaster made in Downing Street. Blair made a fundamental political error of creating a job without first deciding who would fill it." (Frankly, he never stood a chance, May 5) New Labour: new democracy?
Iolo Davies
Ballygowan, Co Down

fields.headline: Missile scam
fields.trailText:
You continue to give the impression that the national missile defence (NMD) system is something more than a fraudulent attempt to win public subsidy for hi-tech business (Europe warned of Iranian missile threat, May 8). The Union of Concerned Scientists recently released a report showing that "any country capable of deploying a long-range missile would also be able to deploy countermeasures that would defeat the planned NMD system". Attackers could deploy warheads inside mylar balloons, releasing many empty balloons along with them. Or a nuclear warhead could be covered by a shroud cooled to very low temperatures, preventing the heat-seeking interceptor from detecting and homing in on the target.
David Edwards
Bournemouth
david@awed.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: Death and dentistry
fields.body:
While Derek Boothman and Silvia Bernadini (Letters, May 5) are asking Robin Cook for a justification for not granting a visa to Dr Alya Al-Rubai to attend the Manchester University conference on translation (Letters, May 5), could they, meanwhile, ask Saddam Hussein why he refuses to grant even "death visas" to the deceased from the Iraqi opposition, to be buried back home?
Lui Hashimi (Iraqi translator)
Maidenhead, Berks
 The worst indictment of capitalism I have come across all week is not from a May Day anarchist nor Ken Livingstone but from Larry Jegley, the county prosecutor in Arkansas. Commenting on the execution of Christina Riggs (Mother executed for killing her children, May 4), he said: "She claims she was horribly depressed, she was overweight and she was a single mom, and she didn't have enough money. My response to that is 'welcome to America'. Plenty of folks are in far worse situations than she was." Indeed!
Maggie Pearse
Shipley, W Yorks
maggiepearse@shipley112. freeserve.co.uk

 At least Eleanor Penfold (Letters , May 8) has the chance to trade Pokemon cards at playtime. At my school they are banned, but Pokemon is much more fun than playing Sharkey, Sharkey or boring skipping games.
Callum Reid (age 5)
London

 All that talk about expensive dentistry and still no picture of Martin flashing his toothie-pegs. (Martin Amis: the interview, G2, May 9). What a disappointment.
Delwyn Swingewood
London

 Re the love letter computer virus (Female hacker started love bug, May 8): I always knew saying "I Love you" causes trouble.
Collin Rossini
Harwich, Essex

fields.headline: Visions of Bloomsbury
fields.trailText: Joe Kerr's Big is Beautiful, (Space, May 4) was a near miss. As architect of the Brunswick Centre, Bloomsbury, my idea was to build to Georgian scale. Gower Street is over a mile long, while Russell Square's sides are each a quarter-mile, compared to the Brunswick's length of less than one of those sides.
fields.body:
Joe Kerr's Big is Beautiful, (Space, May 4) was a near miss. As architect of the Brunswick Centre, Bloomsbury, my idea was to build to Georgian scale. Gower Street is over a mile long, while Russell Square's sides are each a quarter-mile, compared to the Brunswick's length of less than one of those sides.

To make a recognisable bit of city (quartier in Paris) you needed to think at Georgian scale, which had grandness from horseback. Brunswick was meant to run through to Tavistock Place, giving it greater presence. Even so it was built to maximum residential density on top of a full ground coverage of commerce, a vast increase to the overcrowded slum conditions it replaced. Without recourse to tall building, it gave back three-quarters of the initial site area as public and private open space. All that was what mattered at the time, not the kitsch that came later.

Journalists write about the aesthetics of building, forgetting development and political pressures that often prevent positive dreams being realised. The Brunswick had plenty of those, which gave it its present tawdriness. So long as this unfinished work is not stopped by inappropriate listing, we have every hope of winning through a visionary conclusion that may still astound the public by its lovable audacity. But, as first intended, there will be no concrete visible and the public spaces will be as softly green as a baby's bottom is smooth. Great is beautiful.
Patrick Hodgkinson
Emeritus professor of architecture, Bath

fields.headline: Open verdict on the polls
fields.trailText: The inquest into Labour's local election results has presumed that the party's heartlands consist of the northern industrial working class and party activists (Heartland blues, May 8). Yet a major part of Labour's core vote comes from public sector employees who had high expectations of new Labour. These have not been met, and only partly because of underfunding. Rather, it is the continued denigration of the public sector, as parasitical, inflexible, wasteful and resistant to change which offends.
fields.body:
The inquest into Labour's local election results has presumed that the party's heartlands consist of the northern industrial working class and party activists (Heartland blues, May 8). Yet a major part of Labour's core vote comes from public sector employees who had high expectations of new Labour. These have not been met, and only partly because of underfunding. Rather, it is the continued denigration of the public sector, as parasitical, inflexible, wasteful and resistant to change which offends.

Even where extra funding has been forthcoming, it has been given with the tone of a concession to terrorists ("here's the cash, give us the modernisation") rather than of a government fulfilling the public service needs of its citizens. At the same time, the public sector continues to be bombarded with ill thought-out change programmes, target-setting, league tables and inspections - mostly of dubious value - Until Labour abandons its hostility to the public sector, it is unlikely to receive electoral support from its employees.
Dr Christopher Grey
Shepreth, Herts
 I too failed to hold what was considered a safe Labour seat. It is too easy to say, as Sir Jeremy Beecham does (Armchair rebellion alarms Labour, May 6) that Labour supporters stayed at home. In my ward the turnout was the same as last year - indeed marginally up. Last year's Labour majority of 503 was turned this year into a Tory victory of 181 so the stay-at-home theory presupposes that the Tories found nearly 700 new people to vote for them. No, I believe that our core voters (mainly the pensioners who always vote) switched straight across. I doubt that they wanted us to lose the seat; they were simply registering their dissatisfaction with their Labour government.
Margaret Gooch
Portsmouth

 I have rarely read such rubbish as that from your correspondents blaming the government for Labour losses in the local elections (Letters, May 6). In Exeter we did not lose a single seat. The reasons were simple: a good Labour council working with a popular government to deliver for the city, and a strong, united and extremely well-organised local Labour party that works hard to retain the people's trust.
Ben Bradshaw MP
Exeter

 I hope Labour asks one question: "Do we really have to be so boring?" Do we have to resist every attempt to make the Freedom of Information Act something like we've fought for for years? Couldn't Gordon Brown drop his scolding nanny attitude and say, for example: "Hey, we've got £22bn I didn't know we would have, let's celebrate and give every hospital in the country a hundred grand to buy a piece of equipment they really want." Please, some imagination, some fun. To this 68-year-old, this government looks like a collection of boring old farts. God knows what they look like to their contemporaries.
Brian Clark
Brighton, E Sussex

 The greatest crime of this government is not any specific act, but the way it has managed to turn almost the entire electorate off politics. They look exactly like the last lot and say all the same things. Where are the new ideas for a network age? We are all part of a vast and intricate web of relationships, and everything that makes our lives worthwhile comes from being connected to others. We depend on others and their work for our sustenance, our opportunities to contribute and be creative. Where is the understanding of that?

We are still trying to run our society with ideas developed in the 18th century. We don't live in a small scale, low-tech society. It is hardly surprising that it doesn't work.
Rosamund Stock
Dept of social psychology, LSE
rosamund@restock.u-net.com

fields.headline: Montenegro to receive EU lifeline
fields.trailText: The European Union agreed to a €20m (£11.7m) emergency-aid package to bolster pro-western Montenegro last night and protect the beleaguered republic from further destabilisation by Serbia.
fields.body:
The European Union agreed to a €20m (£11.7m) emergency-aid package to bolster pro-western Montenegro last night and protect the beleaguered republic from further destabilisation by Serbia.

EU finance ministers meeting in Brussels approved the aid after months of disagreement and heavy pressure from foreign ministers worried about the outbreak of a new Balkans crisis.

The money will be paid before next month's local elections, when candidates backed by the Serbian president, Slobodan Milosevic, are expected to challenge pro-independence Montenegrins.

"This is very good news," declared Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo, who had been issuing stark warnings that the government of President Milo Djukanovic could be toppled if new aid did not arrive soon.

Military pressure and trade sanctions imposed by Belgrade, furious at Podgorica's pro-Nato line during last year's Kosovo crisis, have brought the tiny country of 650,000 to the brink of ruin.

Speculation has been rife that the western alliance would have to intervene militarily to support Mr Djukanovic if Belgrade destabilised his government further.

After tough talk from Mr Solana and the external relations commissioner, Chris Patten, EU heads of government meeting at the Lisbon summit in March issued a call to support Montenegro. But their finance ministers refused to release extra funds on the grounds that the union can only aid independent states; Montenegro is still Serbia's partner in the federal republic of Yugoslavia.

Serious concerns have also been expressed about the country's culture of "crony capitalism", with widespread smuggling - especially of cigarettes and cars - and worries that sending aid would be throwing good money after bad.

Last year the Montenegrin foreign minister, Branko Perovic, was forced to resign after an Italian court summoned him and 26 others, including suspected members of the Mafia, to answer allegations of smuggling.

EU officials in Montenegro are now expected to be able to monitor how the cash is spent.

Having secured his first goal, Mr Solana announced that the EU was also pushing ahead with plans to secure loans worth a further £29.2m to support infrastructure projects in Montenegro.

The European Commission, meanwhile, is planning to set aside almost half its €5.5bn (£3.2bn) Balkans aid budget for Serbia, to be handed over if and when opposition forces topple Mr Milosevic.

However, Mr Patten and the EU's budget commissioner, Michaele Schreyer, have told colleagues they want formally to allocate the money to Serbia now instead of waiting until there is a political change in Belgrade. They hope to avoid a lengthy budget battle with EU member states when the money is needed urgently.

"We need to be able to move quickly," one commission source said last night. "If we cannot, then it will be like Kosovo all over again."

"This is very good news," declared Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo, who had been issuing stark warnings that the government of President Milo Djukanovic could be toppled if new aid did not arrive soon. Military pressure and trade sanctions imposed by Belgrade, furious at Podgorica's pro-Nato line during last year's Kosovo crisis, have brought the tiny country of 650,000 to the brink of ruin. Speculation has been rife that the western alliance would have to intervene militarily to support Mr Djukanovic if Belgrade destabilised his government further. After tough talk from Mr Solana and the external relations commissioner, Chris Patten, EU heads of government meeting at the Lisbon summit in March issued a call to support Montenegro. But their finance ministers refused to release extra funds on the grounds that the union can only aid independent states; Montenegro is still Serbia's partner in the federal republic of Yugoslavia. Serious concerns have also been expressed about the country's culture of "crony capitalism", with widespread smuggling - especially of cigarettes and cars - and worries that sending aid would be throwing good money after bad. Last year the Montenegrin foreign minister, Branko Perovic, was forced to resign after an Italian court summoned him and 26 others, including suspected members of the Mafia, to answer allegations of smuggling. EU officials in Montenegro are now expected to be able to monitor how the cash is spent. Having secured his first goal, Mr Solana announced that the EU was also pushing ahead with plans to secure loans worth a further £29.2m to support infrastructure projects in Montenegro. The European Commission, meanwhile, is planning to set aside almost half its €5.5bn (£3.2bn) Balkans aid budget for Serbia, to be handed over if and when opposition forces topple Mr Milosevic. However, Mr Patten and the EU's budget commissioner, Michaele Schreyer, have told colleagues they want formally to allocate the money to Serbia now instead of waiting until there is a political change in Belgrade. They hope to avoid a lengthy budget battle with EU member states when the money is needed urgently. "We need to be able to move quickly," one commission source said last night. "If we cannot, then it will be like Kosovo all over again."

fields.headline: Mollie Mackenzie
fields.trailText: Mollie Mackenzie, who has died aged 92, studied medicine at the Royal Free Hospital, London, from 1925-1930, at what was then the only teaching hospital in Britain training women to be doctors.
fields.body:
Mollie Mackenzie, who has died aged 92, studied medicine at the Royal Free Hospital, London, from 1925-1930, at what was then the only teaching hospital in Britain training women to be doctors. After the second world war, she joined that illustrious breed of practitioners at the Tavistock clinic who pushed forward the frontiers of the understanding of human development.

Mollie was the only child of Annie and George Townsend, who ran a chain of off- licences in north-west London. After qualifying, she was appointed house officer at Paddington Green children's hospital, where she was profoundly influenced by working with Dr Donald Winnicott, a founding father of British child psychiatry.

Mollie married in 1933, and set up practice in Hatch End, north London, working tirelessly during the war years as a general practitioner. Her only child, Malcolm, was born in 1942.

After the war, she trained as a psychoanalyst, in the process undergoing full analysis with Eva Rosenfeld, who had herself been psychoanalysed by Sigmund Freud in the 1920s. Through Rosenfeld, Mollie became friends with Freud's daughter, Anna.

At the Tavistock in 1950, she was appointed senior registrar to Dr John Bowlby, whose work on attachment and loss profoundly influenced the development of services for children and families from the 1950s onwards.

In 1957, Mollie became Bowlby's deputy, and nine years later was appointed as a consultant child psychiatrist at the Tavistock. From 1968 until her retirement in 1972, she was director of the clinic's department of children and parents. She was a founder member of the Royal College of Psychiatrists in 1971, and was made a fellow soon after. In 1987, Bowlby told guests at his 80th birthday banquet that without such a dedicated colleague as Mollie to undertake the clinical work, he would never have been able to achieve such ground-breaking research and write his many books.

Sponsored by the World Health Organisation in 1956, Mollie studied and promoted child health in Montenegro; in 1972, she performed a similar role in Cuba. She enjoyed teaching, and was an early exponent of family therapy and crisis intervention, which influenced a younger generation of child psychiatrists and social workers.

Her other passion was music, and she was a talented classical pianist. In retirement, she moved to Walberswick, Suffolk, became an enthusiastic supporter of the Aldeburgh festival, and devoted time to pursuing her other enthusiasms for birdwatching, bridge and the visual arts. She never lost her enthusiasm for life, her sense of humour, or her progressive political views.

Her son survives her.

Marion 'Mollie' Mackenzie, psychiatrist, born June 6, 1907; died April 24 2000

fields.headline: Henriette Gilles
fields.trailText: During the second world war, Henriette Gilles, who has died aged 79, worked for the French resistance as a radio operator in charge of allied parachute jumps, and survived imprisonment in Sachenhausen concentration camp.
fields.body:
During the second world war, Henriette Gilles, who has died aged 79, worked for the French resistance as a radio operator in charge of allied parachute jumps, and survived imprisonment in Sachenhausen concentration camp.

In 1939, Gilles, who came from a middle-class Protestant background, was working for the Red Cross in her native city of Lyons. Being in unoccupied France, having a strong republican tradition, and lying conveniently close to neutral Switzerland - and thus to information about the course of the war - Lyons became a resistance centre. Gilles was naturally influenced by this, but was particularly affected by her meeting with Raymond Fassin, a schoolteacher who had joined Free France in London, and been parachuted back to France in January 1942. He was with Jean Moulin and, under the orders of General de Gaulle, was in the mission to unite the forces of the resistance in southern France.

Gilles joined the team improving London-Lyons wireless communications. Fassin was known as SIF, and Gilles as SIF 5. She was in touch with the Gaullist intelliegence group, the Bureau Central de Renseignements et d'Action, and with the British Special Operations Executive. Her work also involved finding sites where RAF Lysanders and Hudsons could land. One famous contact that she made was with the Chateau of Villevieu, east of Lyons, the home of three elderly sisters, who allowed their spacious fields to be used for aircraft landing.

It was from Villevieu that Gilles organised the flight of Jean Moulin and General Delestraint to London in January 1943. Like many flights, it was delayed by bad weather, but it became one of the most successful missions. De Gaulle entertained the Frenchmen at his home in Hampstead, and Moulin was given the go-ahead for the formation of the National Council of the Resistance, whilst Delestraint was confirmed as commander of the secret army.

In March 1943, Gilles also organised the flight to London of Henri Queuille, a prominent radical politician. His presence strengthened the political position of de Gaulle, often accused of having dictatorial ambitions.

But, on June 21 1943, Moulin and other resistance leaders were arrested by the Gestapo in Caluire, a suburb of Lyons. The man appointed to be Moulin's chief assistant, Serreulles, arrived late and escaped capture, but was at a loss to know what had happened and what he should do. It was not until he made contact with Gilles that he was able to tell London.

Gilles's main preoccupation, after helping Serruelles, was to destroy documents that might be useful to the Germans, and to flee from Lyons. She went to Paris, and from there made contact with Fassin, who had become the regional resistance military delegate. Using the name "Carolle", she joined him in Lille. But Gilles and Fassin were given away by a French informer. Fassin was killed, but she survived in Sachsenhausen until liberated at the end of 1944 by the allied armies.

After the war, as an army lieutenant, Gilles worked in French intelligence, and, in 1948, she married a former resistance fighter, Jean- Dominique Christiani. She ended her career working in the decoding department of the French Ministry for Foreign Affairs and was awarded the Croix de guerre (with palms) and the Medaille de la Resistance (with rosette).

She leaves a husband and three sons.

fields.headline: Udham Singh
fields.trailText: Udham Singh, who symbolised the hockey ethos of India and was three times an Olympic gold medalist, has died aged 71.
fields.body:
Udham Singh, who symbolised the hockey ethos of India and was three times an Olympic gold medalist, has died aged 71. An inside-forward, he was known for his finesse and fluency of his play during the golden age of Indian hockey. He played in four Olympics - Helsinki in 1952, Melbourne in 1956, Rome 1960 and Tokyo in 1964 - and was unfortunate not to have been in five; only a finger injury stopped him playing at the 1948 games in London.

Born in Sansarpur, in the Punjab, considered to be the cradle of Indian hockey, Udham first played for his state at 17. He toured Poland with the Indian national team in 1953, played in the Warsaw International in 1955, and led his country's squad for the 1959 tour of East Africa.

Outside of competitive hockey, he became a coach for the Punjab police squads and played a leading role in shaping a host of star Indian players. A stickler for details and a strict disciplinarian, Udham always urged his wards to strive for more. Ignoring the advice of his doctor to recuperate after a heart attack, he was teaching children hockey in his home village when he died.

He married for a second time four years ago and leaves his wife and young child.

Udham Singh, hockey player, born August 4 1928; died March 23 2000

fields.headline: Fifth suicide at Edinburgh University
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Catriona MacAulay was 18. Bright and personable with a large circle of friends, she was close to finishing the first year of her psychology studies at Edinburgh University.
fields.body:
Catriona MacAulay was 18. Bright and personable with a large circle of friends, she was close to finishing the first year of her psychology studies at Edinburgh University.

But last week a neighbour found her dead in the common stairwell outside her Leith flat. She had hanged herself, the fifth Edinburgh University student to commit suicide in the past 18 months.

As her family from Penicuik in Midlothian struggled to come to terms with a personal tragedy, the university has found itself defending the support structure available to its undergraduates; and trying to make sense of deaths that defy national trends. Four of the five victims have been young women when most suicides in the 18-25 age bracket are men.

Edinburgh is one of Britain's biggest and most venerable academic institutions with a roll of some 22,000 students. Last year the society magazine Tatler declared it one of the most socially exclusive universities.

University officials are uncomfortable with suggestions that Edinburgh is elitist and at pains to point out the range of support services for all students, including a 24-hour helpline, an advice shop and health and counselling facilities. "There are a lot of support services at Edinburgh University," said Graeme McAulay, president of the university students' association. "The students here are actually quite lucky compared to a lot of other institutions.

"We have no idea why these students decided to do what they did. It has been suggested they committed suicide because they were worried about their exams, but that's bordering on the offensive to their families and friends.

"What these tragic events do is give an opportunity to sit down and have a think and to raise concerns about depression and stress students are under. The university needs to keep working to make sure students are aware of these services."

But a key problem at Edinburgh is that students appear unwilling to make use of the facilities. A recent study found that only 3% of the student body had used counselling service courses on coping with the pressures of university life. Researchers are trying to find out why.

"The problem is really trying to create an atmosphere where students will use these services," said the university's rector, Robin Harper, yesterday. "One in four people in society has stress-related mental problems. It would be reasonable that at a university far more students would have them."

Figures from the National Union of Students suggest 30% of undergraduates show debilitating signs of stress during exam time. Nationally, suicide rates in the 18-25 bracket have been put at 13 per 100,000 every year. Recently a study was launched to assess the rate for students.

"There is an awful lot of pressure," said a NUS Scotland representative, Ken Lloyd-Jones. "People are under pressure to be rounded, happy, successful, talented, bright young things - especially in a university. And people do want to fit in. They are under pressure not to appear under pressure."

Some within the student body, however, said the culture of Edinburgh itself might be exerting undue pressure on its undergraduates.

"Edinburgh has a very stuffy academic environment where everybody is meant to be, not public school, but stiff upper lip," said one students' representative. "It also has a fairly narrow class background and the middle class are not known for their touchy, feely side, are they?"

Graeme McAulay dismissed such notions. "Whether or not you are at Edinburgh or Glasgow Caledonian or Oxford University or Oxford Brookes there's always pressure on you to succeed, particularly now because it costs a lot of money to go to university. The pressure is there for everybody and people will respond to that pressure in different ways."

webTitle: Scientists race to beat DNA patents

fields.headline: Scientists race to beat DNA patents
fields.trailText: British and US scientists will today enter the final phase of their complete DNA blueprint for a human being. As they released 85% of the genetic recipe for humanity, colleagues in Japan and Germany last night also announced the completion of chromosome 21.
fields.body:
British and US scientists will today enter the final phase of their complete DNA blueprint for a human being. As they released 85% of the genetic recipe for humanity, colleagues in Japan and Germany last night also announced the completion of chromosome 21.

This is the fifth of the 23 human chromosomes to be decoded and published on the internet. The researchers - all working in an international, publicly funded partnership called the Human Genome Project, believe they have made their announcement days ahead of a claim by a private US company, Celera Genomics, that it too has completed a version of the human code.

"The progress in human DNA sequencing has been stunning," said Eric Lander, director of the Whitehead Institute centre for genomic research in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and one of the leaders of the Anglo-US partnership. "The early projections have been left in the dust. The result has been an information explosion that is fuelling a revolution in biomedical research."

Scientists believe that perhaps nine out of 10 causes of serious illness in the developed world have a genetic link. Chromosome 22 carries genes linked to at least 27 diseases, some of them cancers. Chromosomes 5, 16 and 19, completed by an American laboratory last month, contain genes which could be linked to kidney disease, leukaemia, hypertension, diabetes and atherosclerosis, as well as prostate and colorectal cancer. Chromosome 21, to be described by 62 scientists later this week in Nature, could ultimately help answer questions about Down's syndrome and other disorders.

Together, the publicly funded scientists have decoded and released overlapping sequences of data totalling 3.2bn DNA letters, or about 85% of the book of humanity.

The entire code for a single human is estimated at 3bn letters. But the data so far add up to a nearly complete "working draft", one quarter of which is considered as "finished".

Today 16 research centres around the world will begin the second phase of the cooperation: they will fill in the gaps in the sequence and increase overall accuracy to 99.99%.

"It's breathtaking to see the DNA sequences arrayed along the chromosomes, from one end to the other," said Robert Waterston of Washington University in St Louis, Missouri. "We can now turn to plugging the remaining holes."

John Sulston, of the Sanger centre, Cambridge, and chief of the British effort, said: "While the target for completion is officially 2003, the great majority of the work will be accomplished much sooner."

The human genome could contain 70,000 or more genes, written in four acids strung out on a sequence 3bn letters long. Decoding accelerated with advances in robotics and computing - and accelerated again when Celera Genomics said it was joining the race to decode the genome, and to seek patents on human genes.

Peter Dunnill, director of the advanced centre for biochemical engineering at University College London, last night warned that British biotech firms could lose their leading position if they did not get more effective support from the government.

"If we don't [exploit our leadership now], we will become just a research boutique for other countries," he said.
