fields.headline: Gino Bartali
fields.standfirst: Icon of Italian cycle racing and twice winner of the Tour de France
fields.trailText: Gino Bartali, who has died aged 85, was the oldest surviving victor of the Tour de France, a race he won in 1938 and 1948.
fields.body:
Gino Bartali, who has died aged 85, was the oldest surviving victor of the Tour de France, a race he won in 1938 and 1948. Until recently, he was a familiar visitor in VIP enclosures at major European cycle races, and he also took pleasure in attending small local events in his native Tuscany. His presence brought a touch of grandiose history to such occasions, for he was a link with the sport in the distant days of King Victor Emmanuel III, Pope Pius XI, and, of course, Mussolini, whose sports minister, General Antonelli, famously proclaimed that the Italian winner of the French tour was a god.

Bartali was born in Ponte a Enna, a suburb of Florence. He left school early, worked as a mechanic in a bicycle shop and, by 1931, was winning races in the junior allievo and dilettante divisions. In 1935, he turned professional, and the following year won the Giro d'Italia, the first of his three victories in this three-week-long tour.

His characteristics were then formed. He was a consummate climber who excelled in stage races, especially in poor conditions. He was also a man of powerful presence, who demanded respect from his team riders and was able to dictate the terms upon which any race might unfold.

Bartali was essentially an Italian cyclist, a champion who rode within sight of his own people, and was uneasy when the Tour de France travelled north of Paris. He never disputed the northern classics. This sense of being a supreme Italian, a feeling that he might exemplify his nation's virtues, lay behind the great confrontation of his life. Rightly or wrongly, he is mainly remembered for his rivalry with a younger cyclist, Fausto Coppi.

This mercurial beginner joined Bartali's team in 1940, and then won the Giro d'ltalia with a massive lead over his team leader. Bartali was astonished and affronted. Henceforward, the two riders were in personal combat - it often seemed that, as fierce rivals, they cared less about winning a race than beating each other.

Statistics tell one part of the story. Between 1940 and 1954, in events they started in each other's company, Coppi claimed 69 victories, Bartali 27. In races that neither won, Coppi finished ahead of Bartali 171 times, and Bartali finished ahead of Coppi 159 times. They were most evenly matched in the grand theatre of mountain passes; in all, they rode together over 158 cols. Coppi was in front 71 times, Bartali in front 70 times. Details of the other 17 passages are lost.

During these mountain struggles, lesser riders laboured far behind the two rivals. At the head of the race a national drama was being played out, both for fans and for those who did not normally follow cycling. No other sport has ever created such a prolonged and passionate duel. All Italians were divided - many still are - between those who cheered and wept for the operatic Fausto, and those who applauded and saluted the more dignified Gino.

By 1946, when Bartali won his third Giro d'Italia, he and Coppi had more than temperamental differences. They symbolised continuity and change in Italian society. webTitle: Sri Lanka spurns Tigers' truce offer

fields.headline: Sri Lanka spurns Tigers' truce offer
fields.standfirst: Tamil Eelam
fields.trailText: Sri Lanka's defiant president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, bluntly rejected a temporary ceasefire offer by Tamil Tiger rebels last night, which would have allowed government troops to withdraw from the Jaffna peninsula.
fields.body:
Sri Lanka's defiant president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, bluntly rejected a temporary ceasefire offer by Tamil Tiger rebels last night, which would have allowed government troops to withdraw from the Jaffna peninsula.

The president said she had no intention of evacuating the 40,000 soldiers marooned on the northern tip of the island, describing the offer as "ludicrous" and "propaganda". Government forces have halted the Tiger's advance, she insisted, following a series of spectacular rebel victories during the past three weeks.

In a statement issued yesterday, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) announced they were prepared to declare a temporary ceasefire to allow an "orderly evacuation of troops from Jaffna".

The offer was a "gesture of good will" to prevent further bloodshed and "to create a congenial environment" for the Sri Lankan army "to withdraw from the unfavourable theatre of war with dignity and honour", the statement added. The Tigers said a truce could "create cordial conditions for a permanent ceasefire [and] peace talks". But they warned that its rejection would have "disastrous consequences with heavy military casualties", for which the Sri Lankan government would bear total responsibility.

"We call upon the government of Sri Lanka to consider our proposal seriously and respond without delay," the LTTE said from its London headquarters.

The government wasted no time in rubbishing the proposal. Sri Lanka's military spokesman Brigadier Palitha Fernando said yesterday: "There is no prospect of evacuation. There is no point in talking about it because we are not doing it. We are not going to withdraw from Jaffna."

Most analysts believe the offer is a negotiating tactic, prior to a final massive offensive by the Tigers to recapture the town of Jaffna, which they lost in 1995. Although the rebels managed to seize a key military base at Elephant Pass on April 22, and sweep to within 23 miles of Jaffna 10 days ago, they have been unable to continue their advance to heavy resistance from Sri Lankan troops at a crucial naval base.

On Sunday, the Sri Lankan air force bombed Tiger positions at Elephant Pass, the gateway to the peninsula, and the army continues to pound rebel positions with heavy artillery, officials claimed.

Last night India's prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, ruled out the prospect of an Indian intervention in the conflict following a meeting with political leaders in New Delhi.

"We will continue to work for a peaceful negotiated settlement, within the framework of the Sri Lankan constitution," he said.

More than 10,000 refugees have so far fled to Jaffna, after being told by the advancing Tigers to vacate their villages. They are being accommodated by aid agencies which have provided them with plastic sheets and bedding. "The atmosphere is tense. We are worried how the situation will evolve," one aid worker said yesterday.

fields.headline: Paper chase
fields.standfirst: The link between how people vote and the newspaper they read shows the real power exercised by editors - and, in most cases, proprietors
fields.trailText: Politicians frequently worry about the effect on the voters of newspaper editorials endorsing rival political parties during a general election campaign. Harold Wilson, for example, was said to be obsessed by the press coverage of his government and the likely electoral consequences of it. Similarly, the current prominence of spin-doctors and the growth of media advisers in government demonstrate the importance of having favourable media coverage in the modern never-ending election campaign.
fields.body:
Politicians frequently worry about the effect on the voters of newspaper editorials endorsing rival political parties during a general election campaign. Harold Wilson, for example, was said to be obsessed by the press coverage of his government and the likely electoral consequences of it. Similarly, the current prominence of spin-doctors and the growth of media advisers in government demonstrate the importance of having favourable media coverage in the modern never-ending election campaign.

We know which newspapers endorsed which parties at the last election, although the extent to which they covered the campaign and the enthusiasm of these endorsements varied widely between them. To different degrees the Guardian, the Independent, the Financial Times, the Mirror, the Sun and the Daily Star endorsed New Labour in 1997. Equally and again with varying levels of enthusiasm the Daily Telegraph, the Express and the Daily Mail endorsed the Tories. The Times sat on the fence.

To what extent did readers follow these endorsements and vote for the parties in question? In terms of the strength of endorsement the two polar opposites were the Mirror and Telegraph. If editorials have an effect we would see pretty much all the Telegraph readers voting Tory and a similar proportion of Mirror readers voting Labour.

To be fair, if we do see an association between voting and editorial endorsements, we cannot be sure if it is because readers follow the advice of editors or because they choose newspapers which agree with their political preferences. Research suggests that at least some of the influence runs from editors to readers, so it is interesting to see how closely readers followed the endorsements of their papers.

The chart shows the relationship between voting behaviour and newspaper readership at the 1997 general election, using the British election study survey, which was conducted immediately after polling day. The newspapers are ranked in order of support for Labour. It can be seen from these rankings that, sure enough, the Mirror is at the top and the Telegraph at the bottom. But while the Mirror had the highest proportion of readers supporting Labour, it was not true that Mirror readers were the least likely to vote Conservative. This distinction went to Guardian readers. The election study, which consisted of about 2,500 randomly selected individuals, contained not a single Guardian-reading Tory. Guardian readers were more likely to turn out and vote than the readers of any other newspaper.

The highest levels of Labour support show among readers of the Mirror, the Guardian and the Daily Star. They were clustered together as a group with around 60% or more of their readers voting for Labour. A second cluster of readers included the Independent and the Sun with roughly 40% voting for Labour. Interestingly, the Independent's readers were more likely to vote Liberal Democrat than those of any other newspaper and the paper did run some enthusiastic editorials in favour of Paddy Ashdown, even if it did finally endorse Labour.

The third cluster of newspapers consists of those with a Labour vote of about 30%, including the Daily Mail and the Times. The Mail was clearly much more pro-Tory than the Times in 1997, although it is interesting that it was much less Conservative than its immediate rival, the Daily Express. Rather more than a fifth of Times readers voted Liberal Democrat - placing it just behind the Guardian in its support for Britain's third party. The most Tory of all newspapers, not surprisingly, was the Telegraph, although about a fifth of the Telegraph's readers voted Labour in 1997.

The most evenly balanced newspaper in relation to the voting behaviour of its readers was the Financial Times. The Financial Times is the polar opposite case to the Guardian in terms of the willingness of its readers to vote, with no less than 39% of them failing to turn out in that election. There is a well-known paradox in political science which states that if people are rational individuals who carefully calculate the costs and benefits of any type of action before they embark on it, then they will not vote. This might explain why the newspaper most closely identified with economic rationality and the market has a readership which is most willing to free-ride on its fellow citizens and not vote.

The final group in the chart are people who do not read a newspaper at all. In terms of Labour voting they were similar to the Sun and Daily Mail readers with roughly the same proportion of them opting for Labour as actually voted for the party in that election.

Overall there is a clear association between voting behaviour and newspaper readership. The top five newspapers in the chart all endorsed Labour and three of the bottom four endorsed the Conservatives. The Times, which sat on the fence, is in the middle. Thus the Financial Times is really the only paper which is out of order and this may be because its readers tend not to vote anyway. There are two possible explanations of these findings: either readers are following the endorsements of their favourite newspapers, or editors are carefully reflecting the views of their readers. If, as seems likely, both things are happening at the same time then clearly editors, or in some cases newspaper proprietors, are exercising real political power.

Paul Whiteley is professor of politics at Sheffield University paul.whiteley@sheff.ac.uk

fields.headline: Tony Van den Bergh
fields.standfirst: Writer with passion and energy for diverse causes
fields.trailText: Tony Van den Bergh, who has died aged 83, was a company director who became a trade union representative, a tobacco company executive who helped found the anti-smoking campaign ASH, and a boxer who spoke out passionately against the sport.
fields.body:
Tony Van den Bergh, who has died aged 83, was a company director who became a trade union representative, a tobacco company executive who helped found the anti-smoking campaign ASH, and a boxer - and official of the British Board of Boxing Control - who spoke out passionately against the sport. He was also, at various times, an actor, director, poet, playwright, broadcaster, author and investigative journalist.

Van den Bergh began his public career with an attempt to burn down his hated public school, Repton. His Dutch grandfather was one of the founders of Unilever. His mother was a Scottish Presbyterian, and he himself became a socialist in the 1930s, influenced by the Spanish civil war and the hunger marches. After a few months in his father's tea-broking business, he trained at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art and managed a short West End acting career before serving in the army and being invalided out with a perforated ulcer.

Postwar, he briefly headed the personnel department of the tobacco company Godfrey Phillips, while starting freelance work for the BBC in 1948. His output was enormous and varied. He was the author of more than 1,000 radio plays and documentaries; he acted, he wrote scripts and radio plays, he commentated, he made programmes.

He was one of the first voices of commercial television. After its first night in 1955, Bernard Levin noted (in the Guardian) that boxing commentator Van den Bergh had had the sense not to spoil the fight for the viewer by talking too much. Boxing also provided him with subjects for his earliest books, The Jack Johnson Story and The Padded Ring, and for one of his latest, Who Killed Freddie Mills? (1991).

Crime, and especially murder, held a particular fascination for Van den Bergh, and he had extensive underworld contacts. He was appalled by the fate of Ruth Ellis, the last woman to be hanged in Britain, and, with Lawrence Marks, he published Ruth Ellis: A Case Of Diminished Responsibility (1977).

Medicine, education, sex, psychiatry - and most other things - held his journalistic interest at one time or another, resulting in a lucid and occasionally quirky radio or television programme, or newspaper article. He had the real writer's respect for words, and was fanatically economical with them.

Radio plays he considered a great art, requiring the writer to be merciless with his own verbiage. The titles of some of his own efforts indicate the sort of stark dialogue he wrote: Shaka The Zulu, Strike!, Dead On Arrival, The Train Called Lenin. As often as not, he acted in them as well.

Age, illness and infirmity seemed to make Van den Bergh speed up. On his award-winning television documentary Treat Me Gently (1987), he gave a running commentary while his own hip replacement operation was in progress. For seven years, during the 1980s, he presented Central Television's programme for older people, Getting On, and last year he made a five-day London-Ostend run - in his wheelchair and through driving rain - to raise money for the Lifespan Trust, which provides for the needs of retired people.

It was supposed to attract attention, and it did. Van den Bergh set off from outside the House of Commons, making sure he was seen off by a few political luminaries, and was welcomed at the other end by the mayor of Ostend. When reporters were present, he said, as often as necessary: "We have the lowest pension in the whole of Europe. If you live on an old age pension in this country, you live in poverty."

I last saw him a couple of months ago, in the hospitality room before a television programme in which we were both to take part. He told me, ideas tumbling out of him, noisy and fast, as they always did, accompanied by an enormous and unpredictable laugh, that he had been drinking the previous night with his son-in-law, the broadcaster Tom Steel. He added the colourful but irrelevant detail that they had gone to the pub outside which Ruth Ellis shot her lover dead.

Van den Bergh's wife, Ursula, died in 1973; he leaves a daughter, Peta.

Edward Henry Coote 'Tony' Van den Bergh, writer and broadcaster, born July 4 1916; died May 3 2000

webTitle: Extortion and gore at art critic's trial

fields.headline: Extortion and gore at art critic's trial
fields.trailText: The controversial art critic Robert Hughes appeared in Broome magistrates' court, Western Australia, yesterday charged with dangerous driving in a case involving extortion and some painful prose.
fields.body:
The controversial art critic Robert Hughes appeared in Broome magistrates' court, Western Australia, yesterday charged with dangerous driving in a case involving extortion and some painful prose.

The 61-year-old author of the ground-breaking book Shock of the New was involved in a head-on collision on a quiet stretch of outback road in May last year. He says he has no recollection of the accident.

The trial went ahead even though police have charged their two key witnesses, who were in the other car, with conspiring to concoct false evidence. The police allege a plot by the two men to change their evidence in return for £20,000 from Mr Hughes.

Mr Hughes's lawyer, Mark Trowell QC, told the court of the extortion attempt late last week and revealed that the men had criminal records.

The New York-based Australian-born author was making a BBC documentary, at the time of the accident. He was trapped in the wreckage for hours, lay in a coma for five weeks and received multiple injuries.

The prosecution alleges that Mr Hughes, who was driving a rented car, was on the wrong side of the road and speeding, and made no attempt to slow down or swerve when he ploughed into the oncoming vehicle.

The speculation is that Mr Hughes, who could face 18 months in jail and a £1,200 fine if convicted, might have forgotten that Australians drive on the left hand side of the road.

"Bones may not just break, they can explode, like a cookie hit by a hammer, and that's what happened to several of mine," the Time magazine art critic wrote in the magazine last year. "Several ribs snapped, their sharp ends driven into the lungs. Collar bone and sternum busted." Mr Hughes said recently that he did not see the accident as bad luck because he was lucky to have survived. "If it had been a couple of inches to the left or right, I could have ended up as a blind, paraplegic eunuch. There was no damage to my spine or to my eyes or to my brain or to my balls, and these are the essential components of a critic's activity. I feel as though I've been handed something on a plate - namely the rest of my life."

The hearing continues.

The 61-year-old author of the ground-breaking book Shock of the New was involved in a head-on collision on a quiet stretch of outback road in May last year. He says he has no recollection of the accident. The trial went ahead even though police have charged their two key witnesses, who were in the other car, with conspiring to concoct false evidence. The police allege a plot by the two men to change their evidence in return for £20,000 from Mr Hughes. Mr Hughes's lawyer, Mark Trowell QC, told the court of the extortion attempt late last week and revealed that the men had criminal records. The New York-based Australian-born author was making a BBC documentary, at the time of the accident. He was trapped in the wreckage for hours, lay in a coma for five weeks and received multiple injuries. The prosecution alleges that Mr Hughes, who was driving a rented car, was on the wrong side of the road and speeding, and made no attempt to slow down or swerve when he ploughed into the oncoming vehicle. The speculation is that Mr Hughes, who could face 18 months in jail and a £1,200 fine if convicted, might have forgotten that Australians drive on the left hand side of the road. "Bones may not just break, they can explode, like a cookie hit by a hammer, and that's what happened to several of mine," the Time magazine art critic wrote in the magazine last year. "Several ribs snapped, their sharp ends driven into the lungs. Collar bone and sternum busted." Mr Hughes said recently that he did not see the accident as bad luck because he was lucky to have survived. "If it had been a couple of inches to the left or right, I could have ended up as a blind, paraplegic eunuch. There was no damage to my spine or to my eyes or to my brain or to my balls, and these are the essential components of a critic's activity. I feel as though I've been handed something on a plate - namely the rest of my life." The hearing continues.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: EU changes abattoir procedures
fields.body:
EU changes abattoir procedures

Britain is to change the way it slaughters many of its cattle because of fears that the method could spread BSE-infected tissue around their bodies.

Half the 375 abattoirs in the country will have to abandon a practice said to protect their workers from injury during animals' death throes if, as expected, officials from member states endorse an EU-wide package of measures aimed at cutting risks to humans from tainted beef.

The practice is called pithing and involves using a thin metal rod to clear brain tissue from animals skulls' after they have been stunned by the firing of a metal bolt into their heads and before they have their throats cut.

Ministers were last night still deciding which way their representatives should vote at the meeting of the European commission's standing veterinary committee on Thursday and of the EU's council of ministers next week.

However, they are unlikely to oppose the ban at a time when they are trying to boost the credentials of British beef abroad.

Some abattoirs have already begun abandoning pithing, for which the main justification is ensuring workers are not injured by reflex kicks from dying cattle. Germany, Ireland and the Netherlands do not pith cattle, and French authorities, alarmed by the spread of BSE there, have recently banned the practice.

The health and safety executive said it would have to conduct risk assessments of abattoirs that gave up the pithing system. James Meikle

Protesters `tore up GM decoy crop`

Protesters who destroyed crops at a test site missed genetically modified oil seed rape and tore up conventional plants placed there as a decoy, a court heard yesterday.

The protest left bald patches on around 100 square metres of the field but caused damage estimated at £1.50, Edinburgh sheriff court was told.

Catherine Johnson, 31, from Fife, and Stokely Webster, 29, from London, were charged with obstructing the police.

Mark Ballard, 28, and James MacKenzie, 27, both from Stockbridge, Edinburgh; Matthew Herbert, 29, from St Andrews and Alan Tolmie, 33, from Edinburgh, were charged with vandalism and obstructing the police. All six pleaded not guilty.

About 60 protesters invaded the site, tearing up or crushing plants, Duncan McNeil, the procurator fiscal told the court.

The damage happened during a demonstration at Boghall Farm near Dalkeith, Midlothian, last March at a test site for the Scottish Agricultural College.

David Cranstoun, the agronomist in charge of the site, told the court that it was possible for GM pollen from oilseed rape to cross-pollinate conventional crops of the same species, and eventually find its way into the human food chain.

The hearing continues. Press Association

Risky ploy by railway fare dodger

A fare dodger who clung to the windscreen wipers of a train for five miles was condemned yesterday for recklessly endangering his own and other passengers' lives.

The unidentified man survived speeds of up to 70mph after being ordered off the Nottingham to Skegness service when he refused to buy a ticket.

The guard found the man clinging to the back of the train when she returned to her cab after dealing with the incident.

He had jumped back on at Netherfield in the suburbs of Nottingham, grabbing the wipers and holding on until the next stop, Bingham, where he evaded waiting police as the train slowed.

A spokesman for British transport police said: "This is very dangerous and highly likely to result in death. If anyone knows who this man is, we would urge them to contact us, because he clearly needs help."

The two carriage Sprinter service was delayed for 19 minutes by a police search at Bingham, but the man is thought to have run off.

A spokesman for Central Trains, which runs the service, said: "I have heard of 'train surfing' in New York and London, but we have never had anything like that here." Martin Wainwright

Safety bill 'will put up rail fares'

Rail fares and subsidies will inevitably rise to pay for safety measures which have soared in cost from £250m to £400m since the Paddington crash, Railtrack warned yesterday.

Chris Leah, Railtrack's head of safety, confirmed that Railtrack's share of the cost of a new safety system was £330m, while train operating companies were contributing £50m, with the rest coming from what was agreed with the rail regulator.

Mr Leah suggested that even more investment might be required, preparing the way for a confrontation with the government and the strategic rail authority to sanction higher fares or increased subsidies from the taxpayer.

Mr Leah said the new train protection and warning system would "lessen the consequences of signals being passed at danger by 70%". Keith Harper

Shipman inquests to go ahead

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has given permission for inquests into the deaths of 23 former patients of serial killer Harold Shipman, it was announced yesterday. South Manchester coroner John Pollard needed permission because the suspected murder victims were cremated, leaving no bodies in his jurisdiction.

Shipman, 54, who ran a one-man medical practice in Hyde, Greater Manchester, was sentenced to life for murdering 15 female patients. The 23 inquests will be held on patients who formed a "B list" - the crown prosecution service says there is enough evidence to form a case but has decided against going ahead.

Jayne Gaskell, whose mother Bertha Moss is one of the 23, said: "It is really good that something is going to happen but what we really want is a full public inquiry." Press Association

Sylvan sounds Symphony orchestra plays for nature

An entire symphony orchestra will trek into a remote part of England on Sunday to further the cause of water voles and the wild lily of the valley, writes Martin Wainwright .

In day of activities run by English Nature to encourage visitors to explore 21 of Britain's most important national nature reserves, the Chesterfield orchestra will give two performances of "nature-related music" in Palmerston wood, in Derbyshire's Peak district.

"It's a remarkable place to give a concert," said Maureen Smith, organiser of the orchestra. "We haven't done anything quite so off the wall since we played at the Honda Accord launch."

The Peak site, at Lathkill Dale, reconnoitred yesterday by violinist Liz Redfern, and horn player Rachel Wilkes (above), is two miles from the nearest road, so double basses will be loaded on horse carts to reach the limestone valley, where English Nature staff normally use avalanche staves to avoid the uncapped lead-mining shafts.

"The idea is to try to give as many people as possible the chance of that special moment which opens your eyes to nature," said Ben Le Bas, English Nature's manager at Lathkill Dale. The dale, which has large stands of ash, and meadow flora, is home to voles and English crayfish, victims of environmental change.

fields.headline: Teach the children well
fields.standfirst: Gary Carpenter - composer in the July 18 Prom, and one of the judges in the young composers' competition - reflects on one of his musical influences
fields.trailText: Gary Carpenter - composer in the July 18 Prom, and one of the judges in the young composers' competition - reflects on one of his musical influences
fields.body:
Dennis Carney introduced me to the Proms when I was about nine. I was a pupil at Henry Maynard Junior School in Walthamstow, East London, and a trip to the Proms was the first prize in a little music competition Mr Carney - the school music teacher - had organised. Shura Cherkassky played Rachmaninov's 3rd Piano Concerto and Sir Malcolm Sargent conducted.

Mr Carney - Dennis - also taught the recorder. After the first lesson I had a repertoire of five notes (left hand only) and could play a German folk song called Little Bird and the opening bit of Robin Hood. Lying in bed practising, I got bored and started changing the order of the notes. Next lesson: more notes, more re-ordering. Within a month I wanted to spend the rest of my life re-ordering notes and, what's more, I have done!

I studied composition and piano with Dennis until I went to college at 18. Dennis had, and has, conservative musical instincts. He had little time for any music later than Elgar. Schönberg, his disciples and the post-war avant garde (not to mention anything popular - "that Cliff Richard, he won't last") were anathema to him. But he was rigorous in his teaching, avoided cant, loved music with a passion and taught me to endeavour to seek and destroy anything in my work that wasn't fresh, new or honest.

Dennis also generated enthusiasm for "serious" music throughout the whole school. The Music Club had 80% of the school as members. This was largely "music appreciation" but on a highly imaginative level. Quizzes, prizes, competitions and concert trips were interwoven with hard-core analysis of big pieces (no Classic FM relax-after-a-hard-day-at-the-office prissiness for us). Hardly a kid walked out of Henry Maynard without a working knowledge of sonata form.

The Prom Concert prize was hyped to the skies. Everyone wanted to go. The anticipation was huge; the journey from the East End, getting to hear some of the music in advance (on scratchy old mono LPs) and going into the cavernous Albert Hall space and hearing the orchestra tune up was magic. Then hearing nigh-on 90 musicians playing, in front of your very eyes... well, it beat the scratchy old mono LPs, and actually, beats bright, shiny new CDs also!

Incidentally, everyone will tell you that buildings you revisit when grown up that you knew from your childhood seem to shrink. The Albert Hall is exempt from this.

If you, the reader, are coming to the Prom on July 18, the second half contains music you may, and probably have, heard before: Leonard Bernstein's Symphonic Dances from West Side Story (one part of which, the Mambo, is the music for the current GAP advertisement) with its staggering percussion display and brain exploding trumpet solos, Copland's El Salón México - a sort of Tequila-fuelled knees-up (brain surgeon on standby for the trumpet player again) and Ravel's jazz-inflected Piano Concerto which, for those of you with a taste for these things, is about the only piece of music to begin with a whip solo.

The first half you will have not heard before. This is the world premiere of a piece called Scry involving three young people's ensembles, the virtuoso pianist Joanna MacGregor (who also plays the Ravel Concerto) and the dynamic percussion group, Ensemble Bash - around 200 performers in all.

Peter McGarr, Alec Roth and Nitin Sawhney have each been invited to write a piece for and work with The New Century Strings (Bolton), the Finchley Children's Music Group (London) and the Junior Guildhall School Of Music Ensemble (London) respectively. Joanna and Ensemble Bash will also play with each group.

My job is that of a kind of sonic DJ, writing the Prelude, the Interludes that in effect introduce each "item" and the Finale - so I'm the only one that gets to play with all the toys at the same time. The global idea behind the project is "the future": to scry is to gaze into a crystal ball.

The "theme" of this year's BBC Prom season is youth. This concert is one in the series that puts its money where its mouth is. Each of us four composers lives and works away from the ivory tower; winning South Bank Show awards for innovative CDs or arranging for Damon Albarn or teaching in primary schools or exploring the world of the Indonesian Gamelan orchestra and much more.

All of us endeavour to write music that communicates and excites; challenges and innovates; whether it be through, say, Nitin's sample-based political explorations or Peter's phantasmagorical aural dream worlds. All of us believe in the power of the young, their "sod it, let's go for it" approach as performers, and their openness and perception as auditors. The future, for us, is you.

A thought to take away with you - and one for Dennis, if he's reading this: 40 years ago at the age of nine, experiencing as I hope you all will be, the first Prom, I wanted more than anything else to be down there myself as either composer or conductor or, even better, both. And guess what...?

fields.headline: Youth 2000 at the Proms
fields.standfirst: Music remains an inspiration for young people, says Nicholas Kenyon, which is why the theme of youth is so important in this year's Proms
fields.trailText: Music remains an inspiration for young people, says Nicholas Kenyon, which is why the theme of youth is so important in this year's Proms
fields.body:
So do you put on a Simpsons video, play the new Nintendo game, go out with your friends, download some tracks from the internet, buy the latest fashions, follow your football team on Sky, or practise the piano? And don't forget to do your homework?

There has never been greater competition for young people's time than in the world of high-speed communication, where the efforts of countless commercial operations are focused with single-minded attention on the young, their energy and their spending. And there's no more serious issue confronting the musical world today than how, among this welter of activity, young audiences can be drawn to enjoy the huge riches of classical music.

I went to a Camden schools' concert at the Albert Hall a few weeks ago which packed that arena with committed children singing classical and pop music, playing in everything from orchestras to gamelan groups. It was a reassurance that in the best education authorities music still has a high priority, and that kids can enjoy it. But what next for them, out of school?

The BBC Proms have, for generations, provided a way into classical music, and that will continue, adapting methods and concert formats to new ways of listening.

The BBC Proms have a huge advantage in that everyone recognizes that the season provides a stress-free, informal, thrilling atmosphere in which to experience great music at whatever level you want.

We have to keep it that way. Hence the decision to make the year 2000, as we move into a new millennium, a year when we declare our faith in the future of music and present a season which features young people performing. On Proms Millennium Youth Day every national childrens' and youth music ensemble will gather in the Albert Hall as part of the nationwide Millennium Festival, for a sequence of concerts including a jazz commission, culminating in a massive Walton Belshazzar's Feast under Paul Daniel.

Mozart and Mendelssohn may not be the most obvious role models for today's kids, but to hear pieces they wrote when they were nine or 13 may be food for thought for today's young composers who, thanks to the creative aspects of the National Curriculum, are composing as part of music in schools more than ever before. Or to see the wonderful 20-year-old American violinist Hilary Hahn make her debut here in the famous Last Night of the Proms, or to see the Russian virtuoso pianist Evgeny Kissin - "a prodigy turned genius" - in the opening concert of the season.

One vital ingredient of the BBC Proms is the commitment to new music - what Henry Wood called his "novelties" - which we add to this year with a raft of special commissions.

A unique concert on July 18 brings together pianist Joanna MacGregor and the percussionists of Ensemble Bash in Scry, four new pieces for skilled young performers by Gary Carpenter, Alec Roth, Peter McGarr and Nitin Sawhney. With a popular second-half family programme of Copland, Ravel and Bernstein, this will be a Prom not to miss.

The experience of performing in the Albert Hall will be special for these young musicians. Similarly the commitment of young performers - whether in the collaboration of hundreds of Paris Conservatoire and Guildhall students in Berlioz's blazing Requiem, Pierre Boulez conducting the Mahler Youth Orchestra, the European Union Youth Orchestra, the National Youth Orchestra, jazz and choral groups - creates an electric charge for audiences.

Be there at the Proms this summer to share music with the musicians of the future.

 Nicholas Kenyon is director of the BBC Proms

webTitle: Radical revamp for German army report

fields.headline: Radical revamp for German army report
fields.trailText: Radical proposals to transform Germany's conscription-based armed forces into a British-style professional military were fiercely criticised by Berlin's mainstream parties yesterday, reopening a long-standing debate about the role of Europe's largest army in the post-communist era.
fields.body:
Radical proposals to transform Germany's conscription-based armed forces into a British-style professional military were fiercely criticised by Berlin's mainstream parties yesterday, reopening a long-standing debate about the role of Europe's largest army in the post-communist era.

The controversial proposals were drawn up by a special government-backed defence commission on the future of the army headed by the former German president Richard von Weizsäcker. They were leaked to the German media at the weekend, prompting an angry response from all parties except the Greens.

The measures, due to be published in full later this month, advocate draconian cuts in the German armed forces that would see the number of troops reduced to 240,000 from 330,000, with only 30,000 serving as conscripts compared to the 130,000 now obliged to complete a 10-month term of military service.

The proposals were put forward in response to demands by Germany's Nato partners, which have called on Berlin to slim down and professionalise its armed forces to enable them to contribute more effectively to a rapid-reaction force in external missions such as the Balkans. To fulfil this demand, the defence commission also envisages enlarging the German army's rapid-reaction force to 140,000 from 50,000.

However, the proposals appeared to have caught most German politicians and military experts unawares yesterday.

"With only 30,000 men, it would be impossible to continue with the idea of conscription," said Peter Zumkley, the Social Democratic party's parliamentary defence expert.

The German armed forces association also sharply attacked the plan: "This is a big step in the wrong direction," said the association's president, Berhard Gertz.

fields.headline: Compose yourself
fields.standfirst: Want to write music but worried that you don't have the right background? Don't be. As Peter Kingston discovers, classical, popular or avant-garde, there are many ways to be a composer
fields.trailText: Want to write music but worried that you don't have the right background? Don't be. As Peter Kingston discovers, classical, popular or avant-garde, there are many ways to be a composer
fields.body:
Howard Goodall

Composer and broadcaster. Age 41. TV and film theme scores include Blackadder; Mr Bean; The Vicar of Dibley; Red Dwarf. Compositions include The Hired Man (which won the Ivor Novello Award for best musical); Marlborough Canticles; We are the Burning Fire. Recently presented Howard Goodall's Big Bangs on Channel 4.

Like most other new students at university, Howard Goodall went along to Freshers' Fair, where the university clubs and societies try to sign up new members. His only clear notion was that he would like to write music for student revues. And there, in front of him, was a stall with a sign saying Revue.

"I said: 'I've done these musicals', and the bloke behind the stall said: 'OK, my friend will come and see you this evening'." Sure enough a young man did call on him. He was called Richard Curtis and he would later write and co-write a string of hit TV scripts, including Blackadder, and the film Four Weddings and a Funeral.

The bloke sitting behind the stall was Rowan Atkinson, later to gain fame as Mr Bean. Three weeks later they were putting on a revue called Tongue-Tied, with music by the 18-year-old Goodall.

"Not many people have meetings as fortuitous as that," he laughs. "The show was overshadowed by the obvious fact that Rowan was a comic genius of world order."

In Tongue-Tied, Goodall recalls doing something never seen in an Oxford revue before: using a synthesiser."Up till then, the revues had been accompanied by a jazz ensemble - clever people's music." One of the numbers was for a mime character which Atkinson did - the prototype for Mr Bean.

"I had this synthesiser which looked like a telephone exchange and could only play one note at a time."

Goodall enjoyed the classical English musical education which so many composers have had. At eight, he went to be a choirboy at New College, Oxford. "The total immersion in music technique at choir schools is a very good starting point." He was starting to write little bits and pieces, but nothing which was performed. "I just liked the look of it on the page and liked the idea of being a composer."

A stretch at Stowe, the well-known public school, followed. Then a switch to Lord Williams' School, Thame, a "big jolly comprehensive where the music was fantastic".

At 15, all he wanted to do, he says, was write songs at the piano for his band Halfbrother. It made an album, but you sense he doesn't want to dwell on that too long now.

By the sixth form at the comprehensive, he was writing musicals for the youngest children in the school to perform. One was based on John Masefield's The Midnight Folk, another on CS Lewis's The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe.

He read music at university. The Oxford music course was rigorously academic and on the dry side, with a heavy emphasis on "techniques of composition" - rewriting the great composers' works from the 15th to the 20th century, with just the top line or bass to give you clues. It did no harm - far from it.

He continued writing for student shows. One of the university drama societies took his musical The Loved One, based on the Evelyn Waugh novel, up to the Edinburgh Festival.

"By then I knew I wanted to write music for a living but I was pretty realistic that most people who want to do it can't." It was going to take another eight years after leaving university before he was making his living solely by composing.

"There's no composer in the world who didn"t have a lean period."

After Oxford he shared a flat in West London with Rowan Atkinson, who was taking part in a new TV comedy series: Not The Nine O'Clock News. "Does anybody know somebody who can help play instruments?" the cast was asked one day. Atkinson mentioned his flatmate. "I just went in and helped them a bit as a musical director."

Then it was suggested the show needed an original song in a different style each week, sometimes pastiching well-known singers. The pressure of doing this to order at the last minute was an invaluable experience.

"The big thing I learned was that I was working for other people and that their views mattered a great deal. "You may write what you think is a gorgeous tune but they say it's not funny or it's not right. The first thing I say to students now is: don't be passionate about the stuff you write. Accept that if you are writing for TV or film you are writing in a visual medium and you are number two. You can't be luvvyish about it."

His advice to any young composer is to write as much as possible and in as many voices as possible. "The great composers of the past had usually written a hell of a lot before producing their big stuff. Today people can be slightly lazy and get attached to their own music, hawking around the same piece again and again.

"The best thing to do is just write another piece. Write. Write. Write."

He has another pet theory, that all concert composers should be made to spend five years writing for film and TV. "They would learn how to edit their music. If somebody had told Wagner when to stop, he would have produced work you could sit through."

The collaboration with Atkinson and Curtis continued. He wrote the theme for the phenomenally successful Blackadder series and was paid £172, which now looks measly if you forget to include the fee he gets every time it's played.

Some more struggling composers might envy his luck in hitching up so early with such stars. He says: "Everybody will find people to work with of their generation. The chances are that you already know people who will be your equivalent in other fields. That's why universities and colleges are so vital."

Errolyn Wallen

Composer and performer in both classical music and jazz. Age 41. Her works include Horseplay, commissioned by the Royal Ballet, two operas, and Are You Worried About the Rising Cost of Funerals - Five Simple Songs. Her first orchestral work, a Percussion Concerto (1994), was commissioned for the BBC's Young Musician of the Year competition. She has written film, TV and radio scores, and worked with such artists as Courtney Pine, Eternal and Des'ree. With her band Ensemble X she is releasing her first album later this year: Meet Me At Harold Moores - a title which refers to the famous London music shop.

What finer sentiment from a bunch of musicans than this: "We don't break down barriers in music... we don't see any." They are Ensemble X, the band formed by Errolyn Wallen, and that, according to the blurb for her album Meet Me At Harold Moores, is their motto. If not barriers, there are of course boundaries, otherwise they would not be able to speak of barrier absence.

Part of the thrill of listening to the music is the clash and mesh of styles, and the knowledge that you are in the safe hands of someone who is familiar with them, who understands how music works and has grown up with a solid grounding. She can suddenly drop a tone mid track in The Lighthouse, a bewitching slow recitative over some Britten-like folksong progressions, into the theme from Bach's Goldberg Variations, and it is as shocking as the flick in a movie between, say, misty graveside and elegant drawing room.

Wallen was born in Belize in Central America and came to London when she was two. She grew up in Tottenham and came to classical music early because her real mbition as a little girl was to be a dancer. Her first compositions were songs for her younger sisters to sing on the way to school. One went: "It's quarter to nine, We've got plenty of time".

At nine, she started the piano. She was also learning the violin. "I was terrible at violin. But the piano - I can't remember not being able to read music or finding it hard to play."

She was always looking for new music. "I didn't have much guidance. I remember getting out Hansel and Gretel and playing it through." Opus 1 was perhaps Frogs and Toads, written when she was nine and which she and her class performed at school.

When Wallen was 13 the money became available to send her to boarding school on the Sussex coast. "There was a really good music teacher who straightened me out. I was introduced to Benjamin Britten and madrigals. My piano playing got better."

She went to Goldsmiths College, London to study dance and music, and then dropped the dance. "I was always composing and playing to friends but I didn't have a picture of myself as a composer." She set TS Eliot and Dylan Thomas, and her own poetry, to music.

She did an M Mus at King's College, London. "It was a very practical course. Everything we wrote got played." At King's she got into "weird and wonderful" systems, or minimalist music. She left with the sense of wanting to work with musicians "but no idea how to go about it".

Somehow she got into playing a lot on the comedy club circuit. She played keyboards with pop bands and with Courtney Pine and his band. All the time she was writing "other stuff": string quartets, a Psalm 150 setting. "Odd pieces would pop out."

Then, with another musician, she set up a studio and wrote music for film and corporate video. Some concerts mixing her classical stuff with her popular songs went down a wow. And then she founded Ensemble X, her band. "Don't be frightened to do your own thing. Stick to your guns," she advises fledgling composers. "And try to get as much silence as you can. In order to compose, you sometimes need to be with your own thoughts."

Nitin Sawhney

Composer, performer, comedian, actor, scriptwriter. Age 35. Writes TV and film soundtracks, and commercials. He's a much-in-demand songwriter, producer and remixer. His fourth album Beyond Skin is highly acclaimed.

It would be easier to jot down what this man can't do, than what he can. He co-created a comedy double act, The Secret Asians, for instance. It was taken by BBC radio and eventually grew into the award-winning TV sketch show Goodness Gracious Me.

For a short time in his mid 20s he was a promising financial controller with a certain hotel group. The crunch came when head office told him he had to sack an employee who had been working with the group for 14 years. "I thought: 'I don't really want to be this person' and walked out of the job next day."

He got work playing the piano for a Barry Keefe play Not Fade Away at the Theatre Royal, Stratford, East London and progressed to musical director. It's his four albums since then that he is most proud of, he says. Beyond Skin, for instance, mixes classical Indian qawwali singing, bols - the spoken form of the tablas - and Urdu verse. It also looks for the Indian origin of flamenco.

"I've always been writing music since I was five. I started playing the piano at that age and found myself, particularly with Bach two-part inventions, improvising quite a bit."

So why, then, was he drifting off text at an age when child pianists have to do their utmost to stay on it?

"Part of the reason was that I was listening to quite a lot of improvisation, mainly at home." Fortunately, his father had very wide and varied musical tastes which ranged from "from Ravi Shankar to flamenco" with a lot of jazz somewhere in between. At the age of eight, Sawhney bought his first Miles Davis album.

He progressed quickly on the piano, whipping through all the grades. "I was never really focused on the classical side of just playing what was in front of me.I was much more interested in oral forms, that is to say those that are not written down."

Music, he says, is about gradually exposing what's in the air around the musician. "That's why I'm very sensitive of what's around me when I'm writing and playing music."

He still retains vivid memories of his grammar school in Rochester, Kent, where he was the only Asian pupil out of 700 children. Every school day between the ages of 11 and 13 he would be attacked when he walked through the gates in the morning. At the time - the late 1970s - the National Front was active in Rochester, he says.

A music teacher would ban him from the piano practice room, where he liked to improvise, on the spurious grounds that he had "no sheet music" with him. If he heard the man's footsteps approaching, Sawhney would slip from what he was playing into some convincing-sounding music such as Mozart or Bach, and the steps would move away.

But his music was an escape from the daily racism. He would get home and play, three hours on the guitar and three on the piano. Playing as an end in itself, though, wasn't so important to him. "I guess that's what made me a composer in the end. For me music was much more about escapism. Music is an incredible catharsis if you are lonely."

fields.headline: Net nannies
fields.trailText: If you have the vocabulary, finding pornography, race hate sites and sundry other offensive material on the web is very easy.
fields.body:
If you have the vocabulary, finding pornography, race hate sites and sundry other offensive material on the web is very easy. Type any practice or persuasion into Google.com or Yahoo and a corresponding site is likely to appear.

Yet a child is very unlikely to stumble across such material by accident, just as they would not walk blindly into a sex shop. The difference is that a responsible shopkeeper would throw them out. The net will show them some titillating photos and promise them more if they can pay for it.

Consequently, for some parents and teachers, the sites that seek to persuade rather than entertain - such as neo-Nazi groups - will be of the greatest concern. Internet child pornography has probably caused more concern than any other issue because it can provide a conduit by which paedophiles can contact children.

Unless you always supervise children on the web, there is no fail-safe way of preventing them from finding undesirable material. Yet you can make the task more difficult. Certain search engines and directories, such as ukplus.co.uk or ajkids.com, only return reviewed and approved sites. Others, such as Altavista, provide a password-protected "family filter" which blocks sites containing particular words.

The "net nannying" software available to buy makes it possible to ban all sites containing such words. As anti-censorship campaigners point out, however, such software is a blunt tool and will exclude some harmless sites while overlooking others. Peacefire chronicles some of their failings.

Certain online services go further and will only allow access to pre-vetted sites. Others, such as CyberSentinel, will inform you when a child visits a non-approved site and provide a screen grab of the offending location. All of these can be found at pin.org.uk

"We'd certainly advocate the use of this software if parents find it helpful," says Ruth Dixon, deputy chief executive of the Internet Watch Foundation, which encourages anyone in loco parentis to report unsavoury sites. "Some sort of filtering is better than none at all. But they should never be used as a sort of electronic babysitter."

She adds that the IWF is developing a customisable piece of software that will be more sophisticated than those on offer. It should be in the shops early next year.

An important, basic rule is that children should never give away their email, home address or phone number without your permission. NCH Action for Children has published a list of tips and suggested rules for internet use. The department of education has a fuller guide called the Superhighway Safety Pack.

Ordnance Survey does not give away maps online, but does provide maps of Britain that enable you to zoom in to a particular place up to a scale of 1:35,000 - or a couple of square miles on screen at any time (explanation of scale provided). The service is only for personal or limited business use.

Volcano World
*****
Aimed at: everyone

From the Current Eruptions to the Ask a Volcanologist section, this site is invaluable for anyone excited by lava flow. For teachers, the guide to building models and the lesson ideas (found under Teaching) are useful, and one activity - constructing an erupting model from clay, a toilet paper tube, baking soda, vinegar and red food colouring - is particularly tempting for rainy days.

Disaster! Finder
***
Aimed at: everyone

The NASA Solid Earth and Natural Hazards Program - a contradiction in terms? - has extended the term "disaster" to include landslides, drought, epidemiology, avalanches, refugees and many hazards. Some sites recommended are too complex or specialised for pupils; others would make good case studies for older students.

GeoResources
****
Aimed at: everyone

Various case studies and a large collection of links make this a very helpful site, and its author, teacher David Rayner, has just launched a GeoQuiz for visitors. In terms of links relevant to key stage 3, GCSE and A-level. Probably the best geography site available.

IT and Geography
***
Aimed at: teachers

This section of the National Grid for Learning carries three case studies: a river study, locating a factory and internet population studies. The site co-ordinator is keen for teachers to provide more.

US Census Database
***
Aimed at: everyone

This dry but useful site allows vistors to generate population pyramids (present and predicted), and demographic and socio-economic data for most countries. The CIA World Factbook is also worth a look, though it does offer a rather US-centric version of the world.

Essential Guide to Rocks
*****
Aimed at: everyone

An engaging exploration of all things geological, the guide includes an interactive timeline where you can watch continental drift, experiments to try at home, and 10 virtual walks around Britain which trace the origins of the stone used to build towns and cities.

NFU Farm Studies
***
Aimed at: everyone

The NFU has assembled nine case studies, in English and Welsh, of different types of farm. A tour of a dairy farm for primary pupils and a Filipino farm study are also online. At secondary level, these tackle the economic decisions made by farmers and would make good case studies at key stage 4.

fields.headline: Carnegie shortlist
fields.trailText: Once again the shortlist for the Carnegie Medal closely follows books picked out in the Guardian's Young Fiction Award.
fields.body:
Once again the shortlist for the Carnegie Medal closely follows books picked out in the Guardian's Young Fiction Award, including our winner Jacqueline Wilson. A feature of the Carnegie is the "shadowing" of the national judging by thousands of children. If your school would like to take part, see the Library Association's website for more details.

Kit's Wilderness
David Almond
(11+, Hodder Children's Books, £4.99).

Almond draws the reader into a dark, multi-layered novel through the character of Kit, who becomes involved with the troubled John Askew and a strange game down a deserted coal pit. Set in the north-east's mining country in winter, the book explores the darkest corners of the mind, and deals with big themes - death, exclusion, the supernatural. A very moving tale.

Little Soldier
Bernard Ashley
(12+, Orchard Books, £4.99)

Kaninda is a refugee from an African war in which he joined the rebel army. Brought by aid workers to England, he finds a different kind of warfare on London's streets. Through wonderful, subtle characterisation, Ashley shows aspects of British culture through the eyes of an outsider, and it's not a pretty sight.

Postcards from No Man's Land
Aidan Chambers
(14+, Bodley Head, £10.99, offer price £8.99 + 99p p+p)

Rich and complex, this novel weaves together the story of a second world war soldier with that of his grandson and namesake, Jacob, who is visiting Amsterdam for the commemoration of the Battle of Arnhem 50 years later. Every word is well chosen with perfect timing and pace in a sophisticated book for older teenagers.

King of Shadows
Susan Cooper
(10+, Bodley Head, £10.99, offer price £8.99 + 99p p+p)

A powerful, time slip story which cleverly parallels the lives of two young actors in the 20th and 16th centuries. Nat comes to terms with his father's death only when he is transported to the past and befriended by William Shakespeare himself.

Tightrope
Gillian Cross
(12+, OUP, £5.99)

A thriller about an inner-city ganglord and a quiet, independent girl who dares to challenge him. A tense read with excellent characterisation and intriguing commentary by different characters at the end of each chapter.

The Rinaldi Ring
Jenny Nimmo
(11+, Mammoth, £4.99).

A beautiful story about a boy coming to terms with his mother's death and how the past impinges on the present. Nimmo creates a subtle mix of family relationships and fantasy as Eliot encounters a ghost in his room whose fiancee dies as a result of the first world war.

Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
J K Rowling
(8+, Bloomsbury, £5.99)

A potent, magical mix of adventures, strong characters, sparkling dialogue and witty one-liners. Universal themes and social issues are set in a make-believe world firmly rooted in reality, and we follow Harry as he continues his journey of self-discovery.

The Illustrated Mum
Jacqueline Wilson
(10+, Doubleday, £3.99).

An emotional and compassionate novel about two sisters coping with a manic depressive mother. Wilson strikes a remarkable balance between darkness and humour; characterisation is strong, dialogue sharp and structure masterful. Written, often very movingly, from the child's point of viewpoint.

fields.headline: Window dressing
fields.trailText: Window dressing
fields.body:
How much is that doggie in the window? Do you mind! That's my Shih-Tzu, and it's not for sale.

Sorry. But why's it in the window? It keeps me company while I work.

Oh, so you must be a window dresser. Visual merchandiser, if you don't mind, duckie.

Sounds fascinating. It is, if you're allowed to get on with it.

That ladder looks nice. What do you mean?

Well, you've made me actually want to buy it. Pulleeze! It's not part of the display. I need it to hang these drapes.

Ah. Anyway, what do window dressers - sorry, visual merchandiserS need? A bit more up top than some people have got, duckie, not naming names.

You mean me. Please yourself.

Anything else? You need to be physically A1 in this job. It gets strenuous. And if you're a shrinking violet, forget it. You've got to accept that the public will gawp at you.

But it's not that difficult, surely. How dare you! We are in the vanguard of retailing. The store's shock troops.

How do you mean? We pull the punters in. If they like my manifestation, they come in. If the window looks an utter fright they walk on past.

Gosh! Important work. You've said it. But it's not just getting the public through the swing doors.

Really. No, no. We are deployed to promote particular lines and to inform potential customers what new products are available.

Must be quite an art. Oh, you're so right. And ideally it demands an artistic disposition. Creativity. A sense of design and colour. A good eye is de rigueur.

Two eyes even. If there's (sniff) nothing else, I must be getting on.

Just a couple of things. Do all shops have visual thingies? You jest. The bigger operations, for instance, department stores and national chains, have their own people. Smaller outfits often hire freelancers.

How does one get started in visual merchandising? You can start as a store assistant and then scream loudly that you are interested in display work.

Are there qualifications to be had? Certainly. The British Display Society (BDS) has a General Certificate Grade I and II; it also offers a National Diploma Advanced Level in Retail Display or Exhibition Design. And there's a BTEC National Diploma in Design (Display). Students on BDS courses get the chance to enter a national window display competition.

Can you get a job straight from college or is work experience needed? Some firms hire straight from college. Others prefer to train on the job, with college day release included.

 British Display Society Ltd, 146 Welling Way, Welling,Kent, DA16 2RS Telephone 020 8856 2030

 Distributive National Training Organisation, Business Development Division, The Coda Centre, 189 Munster Road, London, SW6 6AW

 learndirect 0800 100900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: We've given in to our children's badgering and bought a computer, can you offer any useful guidelines?
fields.body:
We've given in to our children's badgering and bought a computer, but worry that they won't get the most out of the internet. We know there are lots of educational websites, but don't know where to look for them. We don't want our kids to use the internet as a shortcut to complete homework and so on. Can you offer any useful guidelines?

Amanda Roper is an ex-teacher and now writes for the Guardian's Education supplement.

The internet can be scary. With stories of teenagers duped into undesirable online relationships, the dangers of websites that contain offensive material, and the fear of a soaring telephone bill, it is a wonder that anyone risks a ride on the information superhighway.

But it can also be an excellent resource. There are many ways to ensure that children get the most out of the internet, without placing themselves at risk or bankrupting you. Have the computer in a family room - you can then supervise its use and emphasis that the computer is a resource for all the family. You can ensure that computer use is with your knowledge by assigning your own password.

There are several ways of filtering out unwanted material. You can buy a piece of software with a "not" list, which checks the text of a website to see if it contains any of the words in the list. If it does, then that text will not be displayed. You can update and modify the list yourself.

You can spend literally hours trying to find websites on a certain subject, so the best way to get started is to visit a site that will advise you on other good sites.

For example, Education Unlmited's Netclass has useful sites for every national curriculum subject.

Once you find a helpful website, "bookmark" it - add it to your list of favourites - allowing you to return to it easily. As well as the internet, you can also buy from a huge range of software, "Encarta" being a popular example.

Remember both the internet and software packages are tools - they're only as good at finding information as the person using them. Channel 4's Homework High website allows children to type in queries that they have about a particular subject to a qualified teacher, like myself, who then replies with their pearls of wisdom.

Not as straightforward as it may sound. A question from last week - "Easter uprising 1916 GCSE coursework" - got this response from me: "What about it?!"

You need to think carefully about exactly what it is you want to know before you even turn the computer on. Encourage children to write or type up the information they get from the web in their own words and then explain it to you - that normally sorts the men from the just-hit-the-print-button boys. Point out that it's blatantly obvious if a piece of homework has been taken verbatim from the internet, especially if it has the name of the software/website at the bottom of the page!

Discourage your children from visiting online encyclopedias too often, unless you're with them. These can end up confusing more than illuminating, as they are not generally written with children in mind and contain a lot of hyperlinks (a way of moving to another, related section). Whilst hyperlinks can be extremely useful, they can also take you on a journey that goes further and further away from your original line of enquiry. Finally, be aware that American sites may sometimes be of only limited use for the British/Irish curriculum in terms of helping with homework.

Some useful starting points

Details on filtering software packages.
www.pin.org.uk offers excellent advice and guidance by the Parents Information Network.
The DfEE provides a general introduction to the subject.

Next week's query: My daughter has just started her "study leave" prior to GCSE exams this summer. Having failed to do as much as she could have done since starting year 10, she is now beginning to panic. How can I help her to make the most of this time? Has she left it too late, as I've been telling her since our last disastrous parents' meeting?

fields.headline: Student photography competition
fields.trailText: Aim! Click! Oops! Take lens cap off... Drat! "Um, excuse me, your majesty, but would you mind doing that thing with the sword on that bloke's shoulder again..." Never mind. As every photograhper knows, you can't snap 'em all. But here's something much more exciting. The Guardian, with the Further Education Development Agency (FEDA) and The Photographers' Gallery in London, is today launching a competition for budding photographers.
fields.body:
Aim! Click! Oops! Take lens cap off... Drat! "Um, excuse me, your majesty, but would you mind doing that thing with the sword on that bloke's shoulder again..." Never mind. As every photograhper knows, you can't snap 'em all. But here's something much more exciting. The Guardian, with the Further Education Development Agency (FEDA) and The Photographers' Gallery in London, is today launching a competition for budding photographers.

The theme is: student life - the reality. We want your pictures to show us what it is like to be a student today. Perhaps you think students have never had it so cushy. Or you reckon they face a much tougher time at college than recent generations. Whatever your view, the judges will be looking for creative and stimulating photographs. Any format will be accepted as long as they are good quality, but no snap shots please.

The pictures will be judged by an eminent panel including Eamonn McCabe, the Guardian's picture editor, Paul Wombell, director of the Photographers' Gallery and FEDA's chief executive, Chris Hughes.

The first prize winner will get three days on work experience at the Guardian in London, a book worth up to £50 from a selection at The Photographers' Gallery and a £200 voucher to spend on photographic equipment. The Guardian will publish a selection of the winning photographs and they will be included in an exhibition at The Photographers' Gallery in London's West End. Twelve runners-up will each receive a £100 voucher to spend on photographic equipment. Their entries will also be on FEDA's calendar.

And here are the rules:

1. The competition is open to students from further education, art, sixth- form and technical colleges, and school sixth forms throughout England and Wales.

2. Entrants must be on full-time or part-time courses

3. Entrants must be aged 16 or over on 1st September 2000.

4. Three prints of each photograph must be submitted and should be no bigger than 10x8.

5. Up to five photographs can be submitted by one person.

6. If entrants want their work returned they must provide a stamped addressed envelope.

7. No responsibility will be taken by the competition organisers for lost or damaged work.

8. Photographs that have been previously published are not eligible.

9. The deadline for entries is 1st October 2000. Winners will be announced in Guardian Further on October 17, 2000.

10. A parent or guardian must accompany any winner under the age of 18 while in London. FEDA will arrange and pay for accommodation and travel, and subsistence costs.

11. The judges' decisions are final and no correspondence will be entered into.

12. Entrants must be willing for their photographs to be reproduced in FEDA publications and the Guardian without payment. Any photographs that are reproduced will be credited to the photographer.

Entries should be addressed to FEDA Photographic Competition, FEDA, Citadel Place, Tinworth Street, London SE11 5EH.

fields.headline: Leave us alone
fields.standfirst: James Tooley  tells the government to keep its nose out of post-16 education
fields.trailText: James Tooley tells the government to keep its nose out of post-16 education
fields.body:
Many in further education are frustrated by the stultifying intrusion of government. Their dissatisfaction raises the question: why is government involved in further education at all? What business does it have interfering in the activities of young adults who seek qualifications which will bring themselves economic and personal benefits?

Three reasons are offered. The first is that there is a "skills gap" which only government can fill. David Blunkett was pushing this line in the New Year: "The UK performs badly in comparison with the rest of Europe. Our vocational skills system has been historically poor." This national disease, comparing ourselves unfavourably to the Europeans, has been going on for years, and has been misguided most of the time, except when we really were suffering from the sclerosis of over-government in the 1970s.

In the late 19th century we believed that the German's state-supported education system was the cause of its prosperity - but the much admired success of Germany's steel industry was made possible by the work of an amateur Englishman, Sidney Gilchrist Thomas, and his back-yard scientific discoveries, and had nothing to do with German further education.

There is a gap, it is true, of about 35 percentage points between the number qualified to NVQ level 3 or its equivalent, in the UK and in Germany, a gap which has stubbornly persisted since the early 1980s. But our success vis-à-vis that of Germany has nothing to do with the number of young people waving paper qualifications, but owes much to government de-regulation.

The second reason is equity: only government can ensure that disadvantaged young people have access to further eduction. But the only intervention this requires is targeted funding (or better still, loans) for those currently too poor to take part.

Finally, we are told that, without government intervention, there will be a confusion of qualifications. Not wanting a thousand flowers to bloom, a pruning government created the neat and tidy solution of the NVQ. It's really odd that anyone can think that benevolent government can detect market failures and correct them, without regard to the self-interest of its members or more general political considerations. Not surprisingly, NVQs have solved none of the faults of the previous system, but have added some extra ones, just for good measure.

This isn't just my opinion - not along ago, a veritable Who's Who of experts in vocational education wrote to the Financial Times, worrying about the state of NVQs. Employers who have adopted NVQs are those large ones which have always heavily invested in training - and would continue to do so whether or not there was an NVQ system.

In countries as diverse as China, India or Ghana there is considerable demand for vocational qualifications. What they look for are familiar brand names, such as City & Guilds, Pitman, and RSA.

fields.headline: Bluffer's guide to partnership liason
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock on international accord
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock on international accord
fields.body:
I regret taking on the responsibility for liaison with our partner college in Big Bluff, South Dakota. To be honest, I thought I might get a free trip to the USA out of it. A fact-finding mission in term time on expenses. But my American dream turned out to be just a dream.

After the bad publicity we received when the bursar was caught fiddling expenses on a trip to a conference in Harrogate, the chance of a foreign junket was right out of the question. The closest I got to Big Bluff Community College was visiting its website. Dreamily, I stayed logged on to a webcam of the student car park, mindlessly watching pick-up trucks judder in and out of the frame.

Arranging the visit of a group of American students became just another tedious chore. The amount of paperwork that oozed from the fax machine became a joke.

"Guess what?" Dorothy in reception would chirp down the phone. "This time it's 200 pages about medical details. Shall I get a lorry organised to deliver it to your office?"

Finding host families was hard enough, but the paperwork drove me mad. Take the medical questionnaire, for example, that had to be filled in by all members of the host family. When the forms were returned incomplete because no one could work out how to answer some of the sections, I had to e-mail Big Bluff for clarification.

Instead of trying to track down veterinary records for all family pets, Dorothy and I became creative. According to us, all gerbils had never come into contact with rabies, all cats had practised safe sex and no dogs were in any way connected with the Communist Party.

When the students arrived it got even more difficult. Despite the kind of detailed transatlantic communication that only Nato can match, we had made mistakes. I had assumed that Robin was male and that Tracey was female, but when they arrived it was clear that an error type OSHIT-99 had occurred.

Rapid room mate gender re-alignments had to be made. The first couple of days (a weekend) were fraught with difficulties. I was introduced to the fascinating world of American teenage allergies. Sidney (female) had hysterics when she discovered a cat hair on her pillow, while down the street Ricky (male) took a dislike to a wooden toilet seat. Apparently he was prone to dangerous reactions to splinters. I had to persuade the host family to replace it with a plastic one for the duration.

By Sunday night, or actually very early on Monday morning, I had dealt with probably all allergies known to personkind. And I'm not counting the problems with food. Jude (male for the first week, then discovered to be female on the second Tuesday) wouldn't eat anything except the peanut butter she had brought with her.

I was driven crazy for a frantic fortnight. But everyone agreed - everyone who wasn't directly involved in sorting out language barriers, missed classes and coach trips to castles - that it had been a great success.

And I have been asked to do it all over again next year.
