fields.headline: A fair deal
fields.standfirst: Sonja D Lewis explores the continuing appeal of America's 118 black universities and colleges
fields.trailText: Sonja D Lewis explores the continuing appeal of America's 118 black universities and colleges
fields.body:
Imagine a college or university in a predominantly white society where students read black history as a part of the overall curriculum, compete for honours in a non-racist environment and celebrate black culture as standard practice.

In 1904 Mary McLeod Bethune did, and consequently started Bethune Cookman College, one of 118 recognised Historically Black Colleges and Universities in the US.

Though Bethune's efforts were laudable, they were not revolutionary. Richard Humphreys, a Quaker philanthropist, had opened the first black college in 1837 - 26 years before the end of slavery - to train free black teachers.

It was this effort that inspired her, other individuals, both black and white, and state governors to start establishing such schools in the mid-1860s, shortly after emancipation.

By 1902, there were 85 black colleges and universities, and until 1954, when the US supreme court ended "separate and equal" schools, they were the most likely option for black college hopefuls.

Among the graduates are Martin Luther King, the civil rights leader, Toni Morrison, winner of the 1993 Nobel Prize for literature, 50% of all black lawyers, 50% of black engineers and 85% of black physicians.

Unlike their ancestors, today's black students can attend any US university if they meet the entry requirements. So why, then, are black colleges and universities still around, attracting almost 20% of African American university students? Haven't they served their purpose?

Dr Claude Perkins, dean of the school of education at Albany State University in Georgia, a black college with about 3,400 students, says it is because "there are false barriers that still limit access for black people and other minorities to a quality education". This is especially prevalent in the more prestigious schools such as Harvard and Yale.

So black colleges need to prepare for a long haul. The face of America might have changed, but underneath there are race-related problems in education that have yet to be tackled. Even successful black colleges are still having to make their case for separate state funding - a few years ago, state of Georgia officials considered eliminating some of its black colleges by merging them with integrated schools.

This would have meant the end for Albany State, but the black community, anxious to avoid job losses and demotions - the fate of many black educators when integration in schools was rolled out in the 1960s - successfully protested against the merger.

The colleges argue that, if they did not exist, many black students would be denied a place in school due to their standardised test scores. Research done by FairTest, the National Centre for Fair and Open Testing, shows that the scholastic aptitude test used for entry into most US institutions is racially and culturally biased. The results often suggest that minority students are inferior learners.

Monty Neill, director of FairTest, challenges this notion. He advocates dropping standardised tests because they draw on knowledge of cultural activities, which is rare in urban, rural and ethnic communities. Rural and inner-city students are unfamiliar with many of the terms. For example, when asked to define the term "regatta" for the SAT, only 22% of the black students answered correctly against 53% of their white peers.

While most black colleges require the SAT, they sometimes accept lower marks if students excel in internal exams. Also, excellent high-school grades weigh heavily. The schools have been criticised for this, with some people suggesting the colleges are nursing poor students and issuing fraudulent degrees.

Perkins disagrees. "It is impossible to adequately determine the abilities of a person through a standardised test," he says. "You must look at their potential and willingness to accomplish objectives."

Another reason black colleges are critical is that they continue to reiterate black pride. Not only do they promote the achievements of black authors, historians, and leaders through their core curriculum, but they also celebrate black culture through sports, the arts and humanities.

More significantly, black colleges provide a non-threatening learning environment for students, offering opportunities that some might have missed, such as the chance to be editor of the newspaper, captain of the debate team or president of the student body.

Many black college graduates who attended predominantly white high schools attribute their first opportunity to compete in a non-racist environment to their university experience.

Even so, not everyone thinks black colleges should continue. Some believe they have run their course, and that they perpetuate black extremism. Perkins, however, believes these schools are still a major force in educating black students. Although they constitute only 3% of the country's institutions of higher learning, 28% of all blacks who receive bachelors degrees get them there. "If you look at the record of higher education in this country, you will see that an extremely high percentage of students going on to integrated graduate school are from black colleges and universities too."

As for black extremism, Perkins dismisses this. He says these schools neither practise discrimination nor have they ever barred the entrance of non-black students or taught hate. Consequently, more and more whites are attending black schools. Albany State's enrolment is 14.6% white. "Students who attend black colleges are doing more than getting a degree," said Perkins. "Through nurturing relationships, they are preparing to deal with life and become great citizens."

Although some of these black colleges have funding and other problems, they should be accepted as part of US society and judged as individual entities like other US universities. Some, such as Spelman and Morehouse Colleges and Howard University, remain as much a force as the well-known schools, at least in the black community.

Such institutions might not be the answer to race-related problems in higher education in England, but Perkins warns that any nation wanting to excel "must have goals to improve people's life chances. And the best way is through access to quality education."

The facts

Black colleges and universities exist in 14 southern states, six northern states, three midwestern states, one western state, the District of Columbia and the Virgin Islands. They are two- and four-year institutions, including graduate and professional schools. Over 50 are private and the rest are state schools. They enrol more than 370,000 students - more than 13% of them are white, 1.5% are Hispanic, 3.5% are non-resident aliens, and a small percentage are Asian, American Indian and Alaskan.

National Institution for Equal Opportunity in Higher Education
United Negro College Fund

fields.headline: Go no further
fields.standfirst: While the government invests heavily to bring more students into colleges,  schools are doing all they can to keep them out
fields.trailText: While the government invests heavily to bring more students into colleges, schools are doing all they can to keep them out
fields.body:
If David Blunkett really wants value for money from his escalating investment in further education he should talk to schools. Because the message from schools to their able and industrious students is loud, clear and unambiguous: "if you've got what it takes to stay on at school, take the prestigious subjects post 16 and aim for a prestigious university. Do not even think of further education."

The message is confirmed in detail by a recently completed Leverhulme-funded study at Warwick University. The overriding response of the teachers surveyed was that extended education is valuable, and that staying on at school is the best way to get more of it. It was seen as enhancing life chances, keeping options open and improving career prospects. And if students were not yet quite ready to appreciate this, staying on at school offered just the environment to bring them to their senses.

But underlying this enthusiasm was another factor - school self-interest. Motivated, able students were courted for their tonic effect on numbers and results. They and their parents formed a classic captive market and a sitting target for a hard sell.

Neither were schools in any doubt about the students they did not want. The list turned out to be a long one. Pregnancy topped it as an almost total eliminator, followed by more directly school-related factors, such as truancy, non-compliance, disinterest, non-motivation and other unwanted behaviours, some of which had already led to exclusion or expulsion.

British African-Caribbean boys were more frequently perceived as occupying some of these categories, although teachers were quick to emphasise that "they were not the only ones". But they made obvious links to social class if not ethnicity, obliquely expressed as "what can you expect from a family like that?"

Students had certainly received loud and clear the schools' message implicit in comments such as: "Don't be stupid enough to leave at 16, don't let anybody persuade you to change your mind." As they themselves said: "They would like me to stay on because I am a very hard worker," or simply, "they think I am clever."

The students were well aware of the economic motives of their schools and talked about what their staying on would bring in resources, staffing and salaries, not to mention prestige and reputation. Many felt they were being manipulated - "teachers talked about nothing else" than that they should "stay on" and "stay here". There was little guidance on further education, still less any preparation for it. For most schools, with or without a sixth form, further education was another world. Even if the teachers did know about it, they did not see it as part of their job to tell students. In their eyes, further education was hostile competition.

The Association of Colleges revealed last year that many colleges no longer ask schools for references because the heads then interview the students and browbeat them into staying at school. They also reported that many schools refuse to supply colleges with names of school leavers, and even misinform students that college courses are full. When the government is spending £3.3 billion annually on further education to rescue the talent being lost through leaving at 16, schools remain unwilling to prepare or support students to move into it.

The fault line at 16+ is so fundamental that students who enter further education have to be recruited to education all over again - at formidable cost, and often with modest success. We were amazed to find that students discovered further education by non-school means, mostly through glossy college brochures - augmented by local radio, posters, mail-shot advertising and open days.

As alarming as the waste, is the growing polarisation in education. Gillborn and Youdell in their recent book, Rationing Education, have shown how the examination-based league tables relentlessly lead schools to conserve their energies and focus only on students with a chance of achieving A-C GCSE grades in the more prestigious subjects - and, at best, to contain the "hopeless cases" and not waste scarce teaching resources on them. Further education, for many teachers, is just a second chance for those regarded by the school as no-hopers.

What hope is there, then, for Blunkett's new vision - that substantial parts of the further education system become an alternative location for higher education? Almost unspoken, and certainly not attributable, is the thought in the minds of some teachers: what if the students the schools do not want could transfer to full-time further education at 15, or even 14? Such a move would satisfy major government aspirations at a stroke. Schools would immediately deliver higher proportions of good GCSEs. There would be a dramatic drop in school exclusions, expulsions and suspensions and a gratifying rise in full-time further education students.

The outcome would, of course, only be the realisation of the current binary policies of the government. But this would finally fragment half a century of equal opportunities endeavour in education and one must hope that it remains politically unacceptable.

Time will tell.

 John Eggleston is Emeritus Professor of Education, University of Warwick. A fuller version of the report, Staying on at School - the hidden curriculum of selection, is available, price £5.95, from Trentham Books, London Road, Stoke-on-Trent, ST4 4NP.

fields.headline: It's free for all!
fields.standfirst: Nick Tester reports on plans to lure more teenagers into college
fields.trailText: Nick Tester reports on plans to lure more teenagers into college
fields.body:
The government plans to extend free tuition to part-time 16- to 19-year-old students, to boost its war on low achievement. And ministers are to get the power to cap tuition fees charged by colleges and private training providers, if they are deemed excessive.

A quarter of a million part-time further education students in the 16 to 19 band are expected to benefit from the removal of fees, as will unemployed people in receipt of jobseekers' allowances and mean-tested benefits. A further, as yet unknown, number of students will be charged no more than 25% of course costs, the lifelong learning minister, Malcolm Wicks, has announced.

The capping powers, contained in the Learning and Skills bill, are intended to prevent private providers making excessive profits from the lucrative training market.

College managers have fretted that the bill gives government unprecedented powers to set fees that all training providers receiving public funds must charge students and companies. Managers have warned that any attempt to force their prices up could deter potential students. Although roughly 8% of total college income is derived from fees (£220m), 90% of fees charged are less than £200.

Colleges also detected interference with their powers to exempt certain courses and categories of students from fees in order to meet local social and economic needs.

Conversely, being forced to cut fees could damage the finances of colleges in more affluent areas, they've argued. Last week's National Audit Office report revealed that about 60 colleges are still in poor financial health.

The government hopes such fears were reduced by assurances in the Commons last week by Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, and by a promised consultation paper on funding expected this Friday.

John Brennan of the Association of Colleges described the fee exemptions as a "great victory for further education colleges and young learners". He said: "We have campaigned long and hard for the free entitlement to encompass more youngsters than merely those studying full-time. It's a very considerable step forwards."

During the bill's committee stage Wicks declared: "We are proposing no new change to colleges' current powers to waive or reduce those fees for individual learners. I want to emphasise that."

Nevertheless, he insisted the controversial new power must stay in the bill to enable a future Secretary of State, via the forthcoming Learning and Skills Council, to establish fee levels. Precise details of how this might work will not be spelt out in legislative language so that future ministers can respond quickly to changing circumstances. "The Council will want to consider fee policy carefully, and it will be poorly served if it has its work on the matter circumscribed by primary legislation," Wicks said.

He's adamant no fees will be charged for adults studying basic education in literacy and numeracy or for those speaking other languages taking English courses. "One set of categories will be applied uniformly to all LSC funded provision, whether it leads to a qualification or not," he said. However, this may change in due course, he admitted. "It is difficult for any government or any committee exactly to foresee educational need for lifelong learning in five or 10 years' time and to predict what categories might be regarded as a priority. So it would be wrong to put that on the face of the bill - it could lead to inflexibility."

fields.headline: Hard luck, old chap
fields.standfirst: Failed to get that academic job? Simple, suggests  Val San Luis. You're wearing the wrong school tie
fields.trailText: Failed to get that academic job? Simple, suggests Val San Luis. You're wearing the wrong school tie
fields.body:
The barriers to working-class students breaking into higher education are well known. But surely once someone has gained a first-class degree and a doctorate, there can be no quibbles about their social background when it comes to a career in academe?

That's what I thought until a chat with a former student who, in 1992, gained entry into a prestigious university. I was not surprised: despite a poor and problematic background he got four As at A level and was given my college's Chamber of Commerce student of the year award. He didn't apply to Oxbridge because didn't want to go. He did receive unconditional offers from four "premier league" universities.

So he was something of a rarity in my establishment. Not because he was bright, but because he had the determination to excel in the face of obstacles that defeat so many students attending FE colleges in areas of high social need - trying to study and subsist on benefit, with the attendant demands that claimants must show that they are available for work. But he did attend all the government restart sessions and the interviews for jobs.

He went to his first-choice university and continued to collect honours. He also began setting records - he got first-class honours, notably gaining a first in all his nine subjects. He won the faculty Chamber of Commerce prize. He has now gone on to complete his doctorate and has published research.

He could have been forgiven therefore, for assuming that his wish to become a university lecturer would be achievable. It is hardly asking for the moon, given that he has been in the system for eight years and has experience in lecturing and as a researcher. Nor is he a nerdy swot who cannot communicate - he has been an interesting and interested tutor. And yet he is about to return to the dole queue from which he came, having failed to get permanent posts as a researcher or a lecturer.

His belief is that for the first time his background is now a major barrier - specifically, the lack of school tie and the lack of an old boys' network. As a result, he says, he has had no access to the informal networks that are part of the public school system and which still seem vital for those who want an academic career.

"There's an intense snobbery about being in the right institution," he says. He is in one of the leading institutions. He suspects that the residual and most intractable problem is that he can do nothing about the fact that he went to the local comp and FE college and not a public school.

Even though a person may acquit themselves admirably within these venerable alma maters, reality suggests that most backgrounds just won't cut the mustard when it comes to getting an academic job: "I've not had the right opportunities to meet the right individuals," he says.

He showed me an application form for one institution. The A4 sheet was divided into two, with the upper half given over entirely to secondary education; the bottom was subdivided into columns encompassing college, university and PhD. Even though an applicant would be expected to attach additional sheets to the form, he felt that giving so much space to school background was telling.

If his suspicions are correct, what on earth is the point if bright but poor individuals end up back on the dole - wiser but deeper in debt? I don't believe that this is permanent for him, and neither does he; but proclamations by higher education establishments and indeed governments encouraging working-class students to go to university take on a jaundiced hue in this context.

Could it, in fact, be the old bums-on-seats economics that makes the great unwashed currently hot property? Is it to do with the elite establishments wanting their own quota of rough so they can make it into New Labour's post-cool pseudo meritocracy?

Tony Blair's commitment to maintaining selective education, despite the manifesto pledge, would perhaps support this seemingly ideological and most cynical exercise in political correctness.

In my naivety I thought that he was now set to fly. I still think he will succeed, because he is determined; but why should he have to fight against apparent prejudice when he has a track record of excellence?

He told me: "I hate people who went to public school... because they're getting the jobs that I should get... I find myself hating people I've never even met."

He never used to be bitter.

fields.headline: Happy ending
fields.standfirst: Eddie may have lost his farm, but, says  John Crace, at least he's transferable
fields.trailText: Eddie may have lost his farm, but, says John Crace, at least he's transferable
fields.body:
Forget the shower scene. The big storyline from the Archers was to be heard last week. Here's an edited transcript.

Eddie: I got to the Job Centre and I looked at the board and I found a couple of good jobs almost straight away. One of them was 15 grand a year.

Clarrie: (IMPRESSED) That's good.

Eddie: Trouble was, when I sat down with the adviser, she asked had I got all these qualifications. I just looked at her and said "I'm a farmer. That's it."

Clarrie: Don't suppose that counts for much these days.

Eddie: That's the impression she gave me. Then she asked what "transferable skills" I had.

Clarrie: What are those?

Eddie: Things I can do that might be useful for something other than farming. So I told her I could handle most types of machinery including a digger. So she told me about this job on a building site.

Clarrie: Yeah.

Eddie: Next thing you know, I've gone round there and I've got the job.

And no, it's not Eddie Grundy quitting farming that's the big story, it's the fact that the phrase "transferable skills" has penetrated the Ambridge psyche.

"All Archers storylines are thoroughly researched," said Vanessa Whitburn, editor of the Archers. "In this case we contacted a Job Centre in a Midlands rural area so we could accurately reflect the advice given to people in Eddie's position." Quite so. But if Ur-yokel Eddie has grasped the concept of transferable skills, then Malcolm Wicks can hang up his briefcase and ask for a promotion, as lifelong learning is a done deal.

You might argue that Eddie is unfortunate to end up losing his farm. But the reality is very different. Eddie is, in fact, extremely lucky to walk straight out of the Job Centre and onto the building site. Agricultural jobs are increasingly in short supply. A mixture of the strong pound, the BSE crisis, the Common Agricultural Policy and government intransigence has led to a mass exodus from farming in the past two years. The National Farmers Union (NFU) reports that roughly 20,000 people left farming between June 1998 and June 1999, the same number as the previous five years combined and the predictions are that this year's figures will be just as bad.

While some of the larger farms continue to get by, many of the medium-sized and smaller holdings are going to the wall. According to the NFU, some beef and sheep farmers are earning as little as £4-6,000 per year. So what solutions are on offer?

"We're encouraging farmers to diversify," says Bob Fiddaman, chairman of the NFU's employment and education committee. "Tourism is a huge growth industry in the west country and many farmers are converting cottages for self-catering homes and taking in B&B guests in their farmhouses. Others are turning outbuildings into livery stables and converting crop fields to horticulture. Farmers' wives are also turning their hands to businesses, such as making and selling baby clothes and agenting adventure playground materials, to pull in extra income." Even so, many farmers are just giving up the unequal struggle.

Unfortunately, even though the NFU recognises the importance of retraining, especially in areas like IT, it has few funds available to organise anything itself. Up till 10 years ago, the government, through its quango the Agriculture Training Board (since renamed Lantra), used to fund reskilling for farm workers but now the industry has to find the funds itself. And as money has got tighter across the board, training has been one of the first areas to feel the squeeze.

"We now try to steer people in to the existing retraining networks," continues Fiddaman. "In disadvantaged areas which qualify for money from the European Social Fund this has worked quite well, in others it has been more difficult." But for farmworkers, especially the older ones, with no buildings or other agricultural assets to fall back on, the picture is far from rosy. "Many just end up out of work," says Fiddaman bleakly. Which, as you can see, makes Eddie Grundy something of a success story.

fields.headline: Short but sweet
fields.standfirst: John Beckett reports on summer schools for university entrants from inner cities
fields.trailText: John Beckett reports on summer schools for university entrants from inner cities
fields.body:
For those who experience them, summer schools have plenty of benefits - and not always the expected ones. Eighteen-year-old Belinda Washington from Wimbledon, for instance, felt liberated from her usual family responsibilities. "I was surrounded by lots of like-minded, intelligent young people," she says. "And I had superb tuition."

Aisha Phoenix, 18, from Haringey, who joined her on the Oxford Access Scheme, enjoyed "working hard in a stimulating environment with great teaching and the social activities".

David Johnston, 18, from Leytonstone, found working in the university atmosphere gave him a "sense of what Oxford would be like - and the fact that the facilities were all open to us made us feel like we were university students".

For Natalya Vince, 18, from Hackney, a crucial benefit was gaining the confidence to apply to Oxford - and the subsequent mutual support students gave each other "when we returned in December for interviews".

From this autumn onwards, the phrase "I attended a summer school" will become increasingly commonplace on the personal statement section of the Ucas form. No bad thing, either. While summer schools have existed for years, a large cohort of students who may never have had the opportunity of attending one will now have the chance to do so.

The government, via the Department for Education and the Higher Education Funding Council for England, is providing large sums of money to enable inner-city pupils who are from disadvantaged backgrounds to attend summer schools free. The scheme aims to offer up to 5,000 places a year at 70 HE institutions.

The scheme is part of the Excellence in Cities initiative, whose aim is to help gifted and talented students in inner-city areas achieve their full potential. It focuses on those expected to achieve good A-levels, but whose family and educational background are such that they consider only a limited range of universities and colleges - if they consider higher education at all.

All this dovetails neatly into the Widening Participation agenda that is near the top of the priority list in most higher-education institutions.

The summer schools are to be at least one week in length and to be available in three streams: science, arts/humanities and social sciences. The content will include teaching in the generic subject area, study techniques, the reinforcement of skills in team working, problem-solving, communication, presentation and project planning and a day devoted to issues connected with graduate employment and employability.

There are 24 Excellence in Cities local education authorities. They cover inner London, Manchester/Salford, Liverpool/Knowsley, Birmingham, Leeds/Bradford and Sheffield/Rotherham.

Within each of these authorities, Gifted and Talented Students co-ordinators have been appointed. Their task is to nominate 16- and 17-year-olds from any or all of the maintained secondary schools, City Technology Colleges and further education colleges in their LEA's area. Each LEA has been allocated a certain number of places at certain institutions. Four million pounds has been allocated to the scheme, at a unit cost of £800 per student for a residential place and £550 per non-residential place.

Schools, which will already have identified 10% of their students in each year group who could benefit from the summer schools, will be contacted by the authority's coordinator. The scheme is complicated by the fact that some universities want GCSE-year students and others take lower-sixth (Year 12) participants.

Perhaps inevitably, in the first year, things are happening quickly and in a last-minute fashion. There is no overall brochure for students and parents to browse through, and the allocation of particular higher education institutions to some LEAs has raised questions.

But judging by the amount of detail and thought going into the design of some of the specific programmes, students have much to look forward to and gain from a week in the summer school environment.

Course outlines and lectures on the following subjects give some idea of the variety likely to be on offer - Risk! Finance and our Future; Asia and Africa in the 21st Century; Bollywood; Looking at Europe; the Universe and Everything; We Live To Shop; New Technologies and Media.

Staff involved in the planning and delivery of the summer schools are all positive about the benefits. The London School of Economics will be offering 200 places for students from two London Boroughs on five different social-science themes. "One of our principal aims," says Rosemary Gosling, director of LSE External Study, "is always to encourage students to think critically and positively about their studies, to inspire them to go on to higher education, and to sample the intellectual excitement of being a university student.

"One student on the last week-long course we ran described the whole experience as 'wicked'. That is the kind of enthusiastic response you want."

There are similar vibes from the LEA perspective. Rob Stoker, from the Education Department at Hammersmith and Fulham, sees the summer schools as "a fantastic opportunity for pupils to gain experiences they otherwise would not have. It will widen their horizons and get them thinking about larger opportunities than they had previously considered - [which is] important especially for those where family expectations and aspirations would not normally be towards higher education. It is an opportunity to be grabbed!"

Local Education Authorities covered by the Excellence in Cities Initiative are Birmingham, Bradford, Camden, City of London, Greenwich, Hackney, Hammersmith and Fulham, Haringey, Islington, Kensington and Chelsea, Knowsley, Lambeth, Leeds, Lewisham, Liverpool, Manchester, Newham, Rotherham, Salford, Sheffield, Southwark, Tower Hamlets, Waltham Forest, Wandsworth and Westminster.

The 70 higher education institutions cross the spectrum. They include universities and colleges that are old and new, based on campus or in cities, and others that are specialists in their field.

fields.headline: Judgment days
fields.standfirst: The Institute of Learning and Teaching is facing a boycott
fields.trailText: The Institute of Learning and Teaching is facing a boycott
fields.body:
A grassroots revolt by lecturers is threatening to derail government attempts to improve and regulate university teaching.

Members of the largest university lecturers' union are being urged to boycott the Institute of Learning and Teaching, which was set up as a professional body with strong support from vice-chancellors and the leadership of the lecturers' unions as well as ministers. Rejection by the Association of University Teachers, which represents staff at the old pre-1992 universities, including the prestigious Russell group institutions, would seriously undermine the credibility of the institute.

At the union's annual conference in Bournemouth this week the executive is under attack for supporting the institute, and its tactic of trying to fend off criticism by blaming the York-based body for failing to promote itself effectively amounts to an admission of how unpopular it is, especially among academics in the old universities.

A motion to the conference urges the union to withdraw and campaign against the institute "as currently constituted", to hold a ballot of members on the principle of the institute and the methods of accrediting lecturers. It goes on to censure the executive for cooperating with the new body, which it accuses of sending out sexist literature: "Women members have special reason to be wary of these proposals."

Gillian Howie, a philosophy lecturer at Liverpool University, who will move the motion, said the institute was trying to assess current teachers and provide training as well as being a professional body. "It is a very small organisation attempting to do three very big jobs on the cheap."

While the institute was popular with deans and vice-chancellors, lecturers were concerned about the bureaucratic procedures for joining and the cost (£100 in the first year), she said. They were also worried that membership of the institute would be linked to pay and promotion, and even become compulsory. "This could make us post-A level teachers. What makes us good teachers is that we are good at our subjects," said Howie. "We could do with some training in teaching, but it is the connection between teaching and research that needs to be made."

Paul Cottrell, the union's assistant general secretary, said the institute would be controlled by its members and not government quangos: "I don't get the impression that there is widespread opposition among lecturers - widespread ignorance is the problem."

If the motion was passed, the union would sever links with the institute. Cottrell added: "I don't think it would be very helpful in trying to convey to the government that we are concerned about professional standards and the quality of teaching."

Professor Sally Brown, the institute's director of membership services, said they had liased closely with both lecturers' unions and listened closely to comments from academics. Since its launch last summer the institute had received 1000 applications for membership and 12,000 online forms had been downloaded from its website. "There is very substantial interest."

Scientists working on some of the country's most crucial health questions are seriously discontented about their pay and lack of job security, a survey by the union suggests. About 600 staff are employed by the Medical Research Council on fixed-term contracts. Their health projects include childhood leukaemia around Sellafield, how air pollution affects young children and replacements for asbestos in buildings.

"Two out of three researchers don't believe they have a career in research, yet the projects they are working on are vital," said David Triesman, the union's general secretary. "The best research results from teamwork where each person feels valued and is fully committed to their work."

fields.headline: As if by magic
fields.standfirst: The secretive, superfast language-learning techniques of Michel Thomas are now available on CD.  Helen Davies meets him and tests the theory
fields.trailText: The secretive, superfast language-learning techniques of Michel Thomas are now available on CD. Helen Davies meets him and tests the theory
fields.body:
For a nation of linguistic no-hopers like we Brits, Michel Thomas is a precious find indeed. A man who claims to be able to give any student a working knowledge of a foreign language in just a few days is someone we need to get to know.

Now in his eighties, Thomas has been teaching languages for 50 years, but for the most part only to those with up to £10,000 to spend at one of his two exclusive language schools in the US. His client list includes the rich and famous - Doris Day, Woody Allen, Warren Beatty, Bob Dylan and Eddie Izzard, many of whom have paid tribute to his teaching.

In fact, he himself has always been less interested in languages than in the process of learning itself. Thomas recalls his days as a psychology student at the Sorbonne (as a Jew, he had fled from Poland to Germany, and then to France) when he was deeply struck by a lecturer's comment: "No one knows anything about the learning process of the human mind." Settling in America after the war, he decided to investigate how people learn, and to use learning a foreign language as the medium for that investigation because students start by knowing nothing, and so progress is easy to measure.

His techniques, he says, took 25 years to develop and he had been secretive about what they were. So Sue Hart, commissioning editor at Hodder and Stoughton, was "pretty pleased" when, in the months that followed a BBC2 broadcast about Thomas, she managed to persuade him to distil his magic on to a series of cassettes and CDs.

The students who took part in the recordings were enthusiastic. "It was an amazingly positive experience," says Christine Dymkowski, who was taught Italian for two days. She had "paper knowledge" of French, but had never been able to speak it and her only experience of Italian was from holiday phrase books.

"He removes all the anxiety and self-consciousness from the process. He puts the language into your head without any struggle. You do not get a big vocabulary, but the basic structure of the language. He leaves you feeling in control."

The experience of being taught by Thomas on the CD is unexpectedly relaxing. He starts by explaining his ground rules, which are that the student should be sitting comfortably - not at a desk - and, crucially, should not make any effort to remember what is being taught. Thomas believes that the striving creates a tension that inhibits learning. The student needs no pen or paper, nothing is to be written down or learnt by rote and there will be no homework. The responsibility for learning, he assures his student, lies with the teacher. So just sit back and let it happen.

And what does happen? As Thomas gets under way, his tone is conversational. His starting point seems random, but he very quickly has the student building simple phrases and then sentences. He explains the structure of these sentences, relating back all the time to the English constructions we already know. He then has the student slotting different words into the structure. Although he never says so, what he is teaching is grammar. What Thomas seems to have done is strip away all the inessentials, so that at the start the student learns only the structures they will use regularly; for example, in the first two hours, only the "I" and "you" forms of the verb are mentioned.

"He seems somehow to have condensed the way you learn as a child," says Christine Dymkowski.

Thomas nearly always links new words to things the student already knows, using mnemonics and other tricks for remembering spelling rules, pronunciation and so on. The student is speaking constantly, gradually building up more complicated sentences phrase by phrase under his close attention. He almost never corrects or tells a student something they have forgotten. He simply goes back to the point where he introduced that phrase, or where the student was getting it right, and gets them to rebuild the phrase from there.

Thomas describes his technique as "making an imprint on the mind and then going back and deepening that imprint". But this is not done by simple repetition, so although you may be relaxed, you are engaged all the time and there is little opportunity for the mind to wander.

Thomas does not claim to give an exhaustive knowledge of the language in eight hours of CD, just a knowledge and understanding of the structure, a practical ability to speak and a small vocabulary. "I am the architect who builds the house, it's up to you to decorate it," he says.

Hodder & Stoughton Educational,

338 Euston Road,

London NW1 3BH.

First 25 postcards will be the lucky ones.

fields.headline: Aliens ate my MBA
fields.standfirst: John Crace gets down-to-earth management tips from the pages of science fiction
fields.trailText: John Crace gets down-to-earth management tips from the pages of science fiction
fields.body:
Brown is the new black, grey is the new brown and science fiction is the new media studies. Well, not quite. Universities may be desperate to get bums on seats, but no one has yet stooped to making Star Wars a degree subject. But all is not lost for those with an unhealthy interest in flying saucers, as there is a growing band of academics who are using science-fiction as a semi-serious paradigm for re-examining traditional subjects from a different angle.

The fun started lasted year when Warren Smith and Matthew Higgins of Leicester University and Martin Parker and Geoff Lightfoot of Keele University published a joint paper in the journal, Organization, entitled Amazing Tales: Organization Studies as Science Fiction. None of them expected much feedback, but out of the woodwork came a host of other sci-fi academics, keen to link their parallel lives and universes into the mainstream of their working lives.

So last September the worlds of secretaries and X-Filing clerks, management and chaos theories, enterprise and the Starship Enterprise merged at a conference organised by Leicester University's management centre. More than 50 international delegates from disciplines including astronomy, physics, history, literature, cultural, film and media studies and management knuckled down to the nitty-gritty of utopias, corporate powers and cyberpunk. And that's not the end of it, as the best of the papers are being published by Routledge in book format sometime next year.

For someone who spends so much of his time with his head in the asteroids, Smith, a lecturer in organisational studies, is resolutely downbeat about the place of sci-fi in academia. He and his co-authors make no great claims for sci-fi as a means of improving organisation studies, but rather see it as another window through which the subject may be viewed. "Organisation science is just as fictional as science fiction, voodoo or Chinese medicine," they say. "Or just as true, which amounts to saying the same thing. It is not so much a question of legislating that 'anything goes' but recognising it, and then allowing that recognition to license the exploration of some rather empty spaces."

This may sound a wilfully Dadaist approach, but even die-hard sceptics have to concede that sci-fi has offered illuminating insights into the way we view the world. Plato got the ball rolling with his Republic, and the genre was continued by Thomas More with Utopia, Samuel Butler with Erewhon and William Morris with News from Nowhere. The tradition may owe its existence in part to a desire to escape the confines of political censorship, but today's management gurus, such as Alvin Toffler and Charles Handy, have known no such constraints as they dabble in their generally well-received crystal-ball gazing.

The 20th century was perhaps more noted for its dystopias than its utopias, with George Orwell's 1984, and Aldous Huxley's Brave New World well to the fore - and the theme has been picked up by contemporary sci-fi writers, such as William Gibson, and film-makers. "Within academia there's a slight tendency to regard literature as the upmarket end of sci-fi, and to see film as decidedly lowbrow mainstream, because books allow themes to become more fully developed," says Smith. "But even the blockbusters tell us something. Take Star Wars - The Phantom Menace. The Federation clearly resembles the Japanese, suggesting a stereotypically uniform management system."

Hollywood's contribution to the debate is worth a PhD or two with films like Bladerunner, Alien, Robocop, Brazil and Total Recall. But TV, too, with Dr Who and Star Trek, has also helped define human relationships with new technologies and ideas. But sci-fi doesn't just have a reflective role, it is also predictive. Science is sometimes as much about creative leaps of the imagination as tough deductive reasoning, and science fantasists have had their fair share of successes.

Arthur C Clarke predicted the geostationary satellite and Isaac Asimov developed the three laws of robotics that are frequently cited as fact within cybernetics. However, as Smith, Higgins, Parker and Lightfoot point out, Asimov would be horrified as he spent his last 40 years exposing the contradictions and dangers inherent in even such apparently universal and applicable laws.

On a lighter note, they also observe that management change consultants have plundered sci-fi as a resource for thinking about alternative scenarios for strategic planning, and that Wess Roberts has used the "secrets" of Captain Picard from Star Trek: The Next Generation to sell his particular brand of charismatic leadership.

But as any sci-fi fan knows, every utopia has its obverse, and sci-fi has also come perilously close to doing for us all. "It has been suggested that the 1940s film, Murder In the Air, was the basis for the proposed US Star Wars defence programme in the 1980s," says Smith.

"Ronald Reagan would have known the film well and might have given his backing for the lasers in space programme on this basis."

And with this terrifying vision of Armageddon, Smith pulls out his light sabre, morphs into a Jedi knight and teleports himself into a fifth dimension.

fields.headline: Ave, Maria
fields.standfirst: Matthew Leigh swots up on classics summer courses
fields.trailText: Matthew Leigh swots up on classics summer courses
fields.body:
July and August are busy months for classicists. A range of summer courses offers intensive study of Greek and Latin at all levels, and supplements this with lectures on most aspects of ancient civilisation.

The Joint Association of Classical Teachers organises four predominantly residential courses. One, at Kingswood School in Bath, specialises in Latin. Another, at Bryanston School in Dorset, teaches Greek. A third, at Durham School, offers both languages, and a fourth, at Repton in Derbyshire, devotes itself to classical civilisation.

Teachers and lecturers are drawn from schools, universities and museums. Most students are between 15 and 25. Many are studying one or both of the ancient languages and relish the opportunity to meet other classicists and immerse themselves in unfamiliar authors and texts. Many are preparing for intensive programmes at university, and gain their first experience of often complex languages under the guidance of expert tutors.

A highlight of the Latin course is a lecture on the city's complex of Roman baths, followed by an evening tour of the site. Students at Bryanston rehearse a tragedy, learn their parts in the original language and put on a performance in the school's own Greek theatre.

A residential course at Lampeter teaches Latin and Greek to a rather different group of people. The influx of mature students into the university system has had a particularly marked impact on classics departments. The Lampeter summer school is not just for older students, but it might just be the place for anyone who wants to concentrate on the subject in hand rather than being sidetracked into campus social life.

For those living in London or Birmingham, non-residential study is a possibility. The Rowley Regis Summer School is a special programme for students in the Sandwell area. Local state schools send along their most enthusiastic linguists to gain a first taste of Latin and Greek, and those who are hooked receive tuition in before- and after-school classes throughout the following year.

Without the dedication of one tireless classics teacher, Myles Walker, and the loyalty of a team of former pupils who come back to teach, it would be impossible.

The London Summer School in classics, which this year celebrates its 25th anniversary, offers four hours of language classes and a lecture every day. Students are drawn from schools across London, and the course is hosted by University College's department of classics. A special festive programme is promised this year.

So are you frustrated by the lack of classics in your area? Or just desperate for more? Come to summer school!

 JACT Latin Summer School, Kingswood School, Bath, July 31-August 10. Cost: resident £295, non-resident £110. Contact Tim Wheeler.

 JACT Classical Civilisation and Ancient History Summer School, Repton School, Derbyshire, July 15-July 20. Cost: accommodation £140, tuition £50. Contact Jo Howling, 42 Carrington Lane, Sale, Cheshire, M33 5ND.

 JACT and Newcastle University classical summer school in Latin and ancient Greek. Durham School, July 22-29. Cost: £300 single room, £265 double room, £230 dormitory, £220 non-residential. Contact: The Secretary, The Lifelong Centre for Learning, Newcastle University, NE1 7RU.

 JACT Summer School in Ancient Greek. Bryanston Sch, Blandford, Dorset, July 30- August 12. Cost: £300 for residence, £100 tuition. Contact: E Merrylees, Dale House, 187 Mottram Rd, Stalybridge, Cheshire, SK15 2QX.

 Lampeter Summer Workshop in Greek and Latin: July 23-August 5. six nights' accommodation, full-board: £165, tuition per week £55. Contact: Prof MR Wright.

 London Summer School in Classics, July 11-19. Cost: £70, non-residential. Contact: Amanda Cater, Department of Greek and Latin, University College, London, Gower Street, London, WC1E 6BT; July 11-19; £70 non-residential; travel grants available.

 Rowley Regis College Summer School, July 5-12 and 13-20. Cost: £12-£14 non-residential. Contact: Myles Walker, Rowley Regis College, Hawes Lane, Rowley Regis, Warley, West Midlands, B65 9AH.

fields.headline: Safely installed
fields.standfirst: The box project has united pupils in Greater Manchester in an exploration of contemporary art
fields.trailText: The box project has united pupils in Greater Manchester in an exploration of contemporary art
fields.body:
The words "contemporary art" can produce either quizzical looks or dark mutterings about Damien Hirst and pickled sheep. But "encompass 2000" aims to show young people that, far from an esoteric or "difficult" subject, contemporary art can be engaging and exciting, as well as a valuable resource for learning. Throughout May, 10 projects across England will connect schools and art galleries, targeting two audiences - primary school children and their families, and 16- to 18-year-olds.

At the Turnpike Gallery in Leigh, Greater Manchester, three year 5 groups from a cross-section of local schools will work with the artist Leo Fitzmaurice on the "box project".

The box project was first launched by the Museum of Installation in 1997. The idea is a simple one: artists were invited to use or customise a lidded, A5 sized, cardboard box as "exhibition sites". Some filled their boxes with concrete, some water, some £5 notes; others presented their boxes as mini-gallery spaces, or filled them with personal memorabilia and thought-provoking objects.

For the pupils, following brainstorming sessions with Fitzmaurice in school, the action moves to the Turnpike. Here they can contribute their own examples of "installation art" alongside the work of more than 200 artists from the UK and overseas.

In addition to producing their own works, pupils from St Phillips CE, Leigh Central and Higher Folds schools will be introduced to the notion of what constitutes an art gallery and who goes there.

Martyn Lucas, visual arts outreach officer at the Turnpike, hopes that the young people will appreciate the gallery as a "space of the imagination - a place to explore, question, experience, learn and contribute to".

The project also seeks to involve teachers and the wider community in the work of the gallery. Lucas argues that teachers don't always fully realise the role of contemporary art as a resource in the classroom and how it relates to the core curriculum.

Families are encouraged to attend special events, where the pupils can act as expert guides. This will also help pupils to develop an understanding of the concepts and language of art.

Maybe, then, the words "contemporary art" will elicit something more in future than the age-old retort of "I don't know much about art, but I know what I like"!

 The Turnpike Gallery, Civic Square, Leigh, Greater Manchester WN7 1EB, tel: 01942 404469. For further information about "encompass 2000", contact Cameron Duncan or Jo Harte on 0207-636 3750.

fields.headline: Client services
fields.trailText: Many complaints that governing bodies are asked to deal with arise from sheer frustration and/or simple misunderstanding.
fields.body:
Many complaints that governing bodies are asked to deal with arise from sheer frustration and/or simple misunderstanding. Dissatisfaction can lead to further dissatisfaction unless it is dealt with quickly and effectively, so a procedure for making complaints, not covered by statutory regulations (ie exclusions) must be clear and fair.

The school prospectus and other literature sent to parents/guardians should stress that complaining is a positive thing - strange as that may sound! It provides an opportunity for the school to keep striving for the highest possible standards.

A minor concern about a lost jumper that someone believes was not investigated properly can escalate as the result of not knowing where to turn for help. This is especially true of secondary schools, where it can be very confusing to someone not familiar with how things work. A transparent system for dealing with such issues is therefore a must.

Parents/guardians should feel comfortable about making an informal complaint to the school. Good communication can prevent matters going further, but if this doesn't work, a formal complaint can be made via the clerk to the governors. This doesn't need to be in writing, and the parent or guardian is entitled to have an "advocate" to help them put their case across if they so choose.

The clerk must ensure the complaint is properly investigated through an impartial panel of governors. An open relationship between school and parents or guardians is invaluable. It's in everyone's best interest for a complaint to be treated with professionalism, as the school is at the centre of a partnership between parents/guardians, staff, governors and pupils. The clerk must keep the complainant informed of what's happening before, during and as a result of the investigation.

If this fails to rectify the situation, the next stage would be to refer to the local education authority, which can mediate and inform all parties of further action that could be taken. A last resort is to go to the Department for Education, but they will not become involved unless all other options have been fully exhausted.

Schools could learn from the business world. They must listen to the concerns of their "clients" and communicate effectively. Where there are problems, these need to be looked into thoroughly, and something must not only be done, but be seen to be done. A mechanism for making complaints in which there is real confidence is an absolute priority and will lead to a more productive and successful relationship between the school and the community it serves.

 Amanda Roper interviewed Macia Grebot, schools support officer with London Borough of Richmond local education department.

fields.headline: Tests, tests, tests
fields.standfirst: The government is determined to raise learning targets amongst schoolchildren.  Rebecca Smithers  offers a guide to the tests and advice on how to survive them
fields.trailText: The government is determined to raise learning targets amongst schoolchildren. Rebecca Smithers offers a guide to the tests and advice on how to survive them
fields.body:
David Blunkett joked at the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers' annual conference in Llandudno recently that he was considering emailing all 11-year-olds in the run-up to this month's tests, saying "please help me, my head's on the block", but decided that a message saying "relax, be happy, don't worry about me" was probably more appropriate.

The Education Secretary and the government have staked their reputations on hitting a series of ambitious national learning targets. Blunkett has threatened to resign if 80% of 11-year-olds fail to reach the expected standard in literacy for their age by 2002, and 75% achieve the same level in numeracy.

The tests, originally devised and introduced under the Tories by the then education secretary Kenneth Baker, have been embraced and continued with unbridled enthusiasm by the Labour government. This month marks the sixth consecutive year that all 7-, 11- and 14-year-olds will take the national curriculum tests. In the massive exercise overseen by the government's Qualifications and Curriculum Authority, around 600,000 pupils will take the tests at each key stage. In total, around 1.8m pupils are involved, with around 7.2m scripts marked across key stages 2 and 3.

Age 4 and 5: Baseline Assessment

What is it?

The government's view is that baseline assessment is not a test, but rather an essential evaluation to test a child's basic skills when he or she first sets foot in the classroom, to help teachers plan effectively for individual learning needs. The assessment also helps schools to measure and monitor children's progress from the time they start school. This lets them check whether children are achieving as well as they should as they move through school.

What does it cover?

Schools can choose from different schemes approved by the QCA. But all include language and literacy, mathematics and personal and social development.

When does it take place?

Usually when children join reception class at the age of four or five, and within seven weeks of starting school.

How are children assessed?

Schools will normally make the assessment seem like part of an everyday classroom activity (such as looking at a book with a child). So children may not even be aware that they are being assessed.

What will school tell parents?

Schools will arrange to discuss children's progress with parents during their first term. The assessment helps teachers decide if your child has a particular learning need and, if so, more detailed discussion will take place.

How can parents help?

Don't be tempted to "coach" your children as this will only provide a snapshot of what has been learned most recently. The following steps should help to ensure your child has a good start at school:

Talk with them and discuss their questions; encourage them to concentrate on activities for more than a few moments; read and talk about books, and encourage them to look at books by themselves; introduce them to as many new words as possible; help them count and use numbers in everyday situations.

Age 7, 11 and 14: National curriculum tests

These tests are designed to provide a snapshot of attainment at the end of each key stage (ie, 7-year-olds at key stage 1, 11-year-olds at key stage 2 and 14-year-olds at key stage 3). Each child's results will be reported to parents alongside on-going assessment made by teachers as a measure of their progress. The tests are related directly to the content of the national curriculum, so no "trick questions" are included. Tests are designed to show how well your child is doing in different areas of a subject on a particular day. Teacher assessment, by contrast, judges your child's performance in the whole subject over time.

When do they take place?

Key stage 1 tests can take place any time in May, while key stage 2 tests must be taken between this Friday (14 May) and next Thursday (18 May). Key stage 3 tests take place from yesterday (8 May) to 15 May.

What is included in the tests?

For 7-year-olds: children are tested in English (reading, spelling and writing including handwriting) and maths. In reading, most children are tested both on their ability to read aloud and on their understanding of what they have read. The tests are short. Children will probably spend less than three hours on them, spread over several days to fit in with other schoolwork.

For 11-year-olds: children are tested on English (reading, writing, spelling and handwiring), maths (with and without a calculator and mental arithmetic) and science. The tests are more like short exams, sat on a certain day, lasting about five hours over one week.

For 14-year-olds: children are tested on English (reading, writing including spelling and handwriting and a scene from a Shakespeare play), maths (with and without a calculator and mental arithmetic) and science. Most 14-year-olds will spend between seven and eight hours on the tests.

Who marks the tests?

Class teachers mark the key stage 1 tests, but the other two stages are marked by externally-recruited examiners approved by the QCA.

How do parents get children's results?

The results of the tests and teacher assessment are in the form of a level on the national curriculum scale. They are reported to parents by the end of the summer term. But the timing of key stage 2 tests makes it impossible for them to be used for secondary school selection, which is largely complete before the tests are taken. Some of the tests for 7- and 11-year-olds will also give scores related to age, which schools may pass on to parents. These tell you how your child is doing compared with other children born in the same month.

Can the results be challenged?

If a school is unhappy with the external marking and believes it has been done incorrectly, it can request a review which may lead to changes. If as a parent you are unhappy about the level awarded to your child, you can also request a review. This could lead to the mark and the level being changed.

How can I help my child prepare for the tests?

Assuming you have made sure your child has kept up with his or her homework and any school preparation for the tests, you can help your child by ensuring he or she gets a good night's sleep beforehand, has a good breakfast and is not up at the crack of dawn doing a paper round!

In the pipeline Age 9 and 13

The government is to introduce so-called "world-class tests" late next year, after being piloted in around 50 selected schools. The tests are designed to select gifted and talented children and will be strictly optional. Pupils aged nine and 13 will tackle questions in maths and problems-solving which are pitched at the level of the brightest 15% of children in the world. Teachers and parents will be encouraged to put suitably bright youngsters forward for the tests, which will be taken on computers.

Age 12 and 13:

Ministers have recently underlined their concern about the "dip" between years seven and eight when pupils are adjusting to the transition between primary and secondary school and often have a tendency to go "backwards". Schools will be given the chance to offer optional tests to 12- and 13-year-olds as a useful staging post on the way to key stage 3. The tests are likely to be introduced for year seven pupils in the summer term next year and the following year for pupils in year eight.

Further information

Department of Education and Employment
National curriculum
QCA

fields.headline: No: 1631  Nicky Gavron
fields.trailText: Description: "Extremely ambitious and a skilled political operator," according to friends.
fields.body:
Description: "Extremely ambitious and a skilled political operator," according to friends.

Also known as: The Quango Queen.

Why? I'm guessing, but I'd say it's probably because of the mellifluous alliteration achieved thereby.

No, I mean, why quangos? That's a reference to the jaw-dropping number of public bodies on which Gavron sits.

Such as? The Independent Commission for Integrated Transport, the Strategic Planning Committee, London Arts Board...

Enough! I'm not done yet: London Planning Advisory Committee, now subsumed by the Greater London Authority (not, technically, a quango) on which she sits as Labour member for Enfield and Haringey; the Better Chicken-Sexing Task Force, the...

Really? No, but there are at least 10 more.

What an extraordinarily busy woman. I don't think I mentioned her job as councillor for the London Borough of Haringey, or the job she's likely to accept as deputy mayor of the capital, where, as a loyal Blairite, she will play the role of mediator between Tony and Ken.

She must need a powerful car to drive between all those meetings. One hopes not. Gavron loves congestion charges and other policies the motoring lobby detests. And she has influence: "Two Jags" employs "16 Jobs" as a key adviser on transport in the capital.

She must spend a lot on public transport. No problem either - she's a millionaire.

Surely there's not much cash in committees? Much of the moolah may come from her ex-husband, the publishing tycoon Bob Gavron.

Who we won't be mocking in this column. It's OK - the generous Labour donor (now a Labour peer) has left his job as chairman of the Guardian Media Group.

Do say: "With her membership of so many important bodies, Nicky Gavron sets an example of public-spiritedness to us all."

Don't say: "Hello, Ms Gavron? It's about this leaky drainpipe in my Haringey council flat..."
